HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

Players Ready to Return
After Court Issues Order
Baseball players said they were ready to return to work after a Federal judge issued an injunction ordering baseball owners to restore salary arbitration, competitive bidding for free agents and the anti-collusion provision of the free-agency rules.
 It was still not clear whether the owners would let the players return. A hearing was set for Tuesday on the owners' request for a stay and an expedited appeal. Page 1.
 
A Swap Plan for Educational TV
The F.C.C. wants TV stations to broadcast up to five hours of educational programming a week, but will propose that they be allowed to pay other stations to do the job for them. 38.
 
Health Systems Wins Contract
Health Systems International won a $2.5 billion contract to provide health coverage to 720,000 Government workers and is studying whether to renegotiate its $1.78 billion stock-swap deal with Wellpoint Health Networks. 36.
 
Horizon to Buy Continental Medical
Horizon Healthcare will buy Continental Medical in a $502 million stock swap. 36.
 
Medical Claims Hit Alden Stock
The stock of John Alden Financial, a health insurer, fell 38 percent after the company said that unexpected medical claims would reduce last year's profit by nearly $10 million and cut first-quarter profits. 36.
 
Strike Settled at Chrysler
Striking workers at Chrysler's only automatic transmission factory reached a tentative agreement. The walkout had threatened to close the auto maker's car and truck assembly plants. In Michigan, workers struck a G.M. truck plant. 7.
 
Revised G.D.P. Up Surprising 5.1%
The Government said fourth-quarter G.D.P. rose 5.1 percent, an upward revision that took economists by surprise and indicated that the economy grew even faster in late 1994 than previously thought. 34.
 
No Bankruptcy for London Fog
London Fog averted bankruptcy after agreeing to convert $317.4 million of debt into a note and a loan totaling $211 million and preferred stock valued at $106.4 million. 36.
 
Christopher Urges Iran Trade Ban
Administration officials said Secretary of State Warren Christopher has recommended that the United States ban most trade with Iran, prohibiting American companies from buying Iranian oil and from investing in projects there. 5.
 
Higher Rates Worried Fed
Top Federal Reserve officials were unanimous in deciding to raise short-term interest rates at their meeting on Feb. 1, but some of them were concerned that the central bank was moving too quickly. 39.
 
Bank Derivatives Holdings Level Off
The Comptroller of the Currency reported that the derivatives holdings of banks have abruptly leveled off to $15.6 trillion after years of rapid growth, but that the holdings remain large in comparison with bank capital. 36.
 
Airlines Cut Summer Fares
American and United airlines are offering discounts of up to 50 percent on all domestic flights booked by April 14. The offer came a day after Northwest Airlines announced a summer fare sale. Tickets must be bought 30 days in advance and require a Saturday night stay. 38.
 
Japan to Relax Economic Rules
Japan disclosed a five-year plan to abolish or relax hundreds of economic regulations, including some that would ease the way for imports. But Japanese, American and other foreign businessmen and officials criticized the plan as inadequate. 38.
 
Fewer Delays at New Denver Airport
The F.A.A. said Denver's new airport in its first 30 days handled 42,000 landings and takeoffs with only 245 delays. 7.
 
Use of Temporary Workers Soars
The number of temporary workers supplied to American companies soared to nearly 2 million last year, or 1.5 percent of the work force. 37.

HEADLINE: Gas, Food, Laundry;
Entrepreneurs Seeking Heavy Traffic in Light Starch on the Parkway

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
This is Paul McDonald's vision of the future of laundry: A car rolls to a stop in the southbound Hutchinson River Parkway service area in the Bronx. A uniformed attendant scrambles. Ten seconds later, the driver accelerates back into traffic and a dozen dirty shirts head for the wash, to be picked up that night across the parkway on the commuter's trip home.
 If there is a business niche between the Daytona 500 and Botany 500, Mr. McDonald has staked a claim to it with a proposal to open what cleaning industry experts say would be the first business of its kind: a laundry and dry-cleaning service at two vacant service areas on the parkway just south of the Westchester County line. 
Commuters want speed, Mr. McDonald believes, but they also want clean suits, and he has promised, in a bid being considered by New York City parkway administrators, to deliver both.
 According to Mr. McDonald's calculations, 10 seconds is plenty of time to drop off dry cleaning, if he uses laser bar-code readers and old-fashioned hustle. He cautions, however, that the pickup portion of his laundry-a-go-go business, called Commuter Cleaners, could be slower than the drop-off portion, in which a receipt would be quickly dispensed.
 It could take up to 25 seconds for money to change hands, and even that pace is contingent on drivers being able to pop the trunk from inside the car in order for their clean clothes to be deposited.
 "There's a premium on time," said Mr. McDonald, 34, a former commuter from Stamford, Conn., who already operates six Commuter Cleaners sites at Metro-North Commuter Railroad stations in Westchester and Connecticut, where he has honed the transaction times to an average of about 40 seconds, he said. "Anything to save time," he said.
 As is often the case with projects involving the New York parkway system, Mr. McDonald's business idea has inspired debate about esthetics. The parkways, built in the 1920's and 1930's during the reign of Robert Moses, New York's legendary Parks Commissioner, were envisioned as pleasure-cruising greenswards where motorists could flee the urban thrum.
 And that mentality lingers, despite the reality of modern traffic volume, which in the case of the Hutch, as it is known, exceeds 50,000 vehicles a day. Parks officials in Westchester County turned Mr. McDonald down cold last year when he proposed a Commuter Cleaners on the Bronx River Parkway near Scarsdale. County officials said that a cleaner was not an "appropriate" use for parkland, Mr. McDonald said.
 Across the border in New York City, on the other hand, Mr. McDonald and his partner, Wayne T. Jeffers, a gas station operator, say they have heard nothing but encouragement, and they expect their plan to be approved shortly and to begin operations this summer.
 Henry J. Stern, the city's Parks Commissioner, who said he has the sole authority to sign off on the deal, asserted that with commuters increasingly pressed for time, new uses for the parkway service areas must be encouraged. Under its contract system, the city also has an economic incentive to encourage parkway businesses, with provisions that guarantee the city a minimum rent from a tenant, or a percentage of sales revenue, whichever is greater.
 Mr. Jeffers, who operates 75 gas stations around the New York City region, said that if the Hutchinson proposal proved successful, it could mean the launching of a new laundry and gasoline empire. He and Mr. McDonald are already planning their next project, at two long-closed service areas on the Saw Mill River Parkway in Hastings. Because one of the service areas is considered architecturally significant, that plan hinges on approval from New York State historic preservation officials.
 Mr. Jeffers said that at the Hutchinson business, he plans to sell gas and snacks, groceries and newspapers. But it is the dry cleaning and laundry service, he said, that will be the real hook.
 "Selling gas is not that brilliant an operation, but if we tie the necessity of gas to saving some time, then we think we've got a synergy," he said. "Conceptually, once the commuter is stopped at the cleaners, he's stopped, and he might as well stop for gas."
 Mr. McDonald said he plans to take advantage of bar codes on New York State vehicle registration stickers, which are placed on windshields. He would use a hand-held laser device to read the bar codes and spit out an instant receipt with the car owner's name and address. The laundry would be trucked 13 miles to Port Chester, where the Commuter Cleaners plant already handles the wash from its Metro-North Railroad stations in Rye, Chappaqua, Bronxville, Croton-Harmon and Port Chester, in New York, and its Connecticut station site, Greenwich.
 Then it will all go back to the parkway. But since dropoffs will be taken from both directions, each bundle will have to land on the opposite side of the parkway from where it started.
 "There's still some logistics to be worked out," Mr. McDonald said. "But they told me it wouldn't work at the train stations either."

HEADLINE: A Wild Day for the Markets as Dollar Resumes Its Plunge

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The dollar plunged to new post-World-War-II lows against the German mark and the Japanese yen yesterday, as stocks closed mixed after a tumultuous day that began with a fall of more than 60 points in the Dow Jones industrial average. After sharp swings of their own, long-term interest rates rose slightly.
 Although stock and bond prices rallied from their lows, analysts say the three-month-long decline in the dollar may finally be dragging down the stock and bond markets in the United States, as a weak dollar discourages foreign investors from buying American assets. 
"The dollar was in free fall and clearly starting to have an effect on the bond market," said Terrence Crowe, vice president for bond arbitrage at the Nikko Securities Company International.
 But the dollar was not the sole reason for the market volatility. In fact there seemed to be so many factors that it was hard to pinpoint what was most important. These included the lack of a decision by the Bank of Japan on the yen, a Wall Street analyst's downward reassessment of four technology stocks, a spike in the price of gold and silver, end-of-the-quarter "window dressing" by money managers, a rumor about a special Federal Reserve meeting and a general uneasiness that stock and bond prices might have simply risen too high.
 A revision of the estimate of fourth-quarter economic growth to 5.1 percent from 4.6 percent may have also helped send stock prices lower, while a decline in factory orders in February may have helped the rebound.
 The variety of factors that buffeted the markets, coming at the end of the quarter, exaggerated the price swings in the markets. Without the quarterly reckoning and especially the speculation about the Bank of Japan, analysts say, prices might still have dropped, but not as far and as fast.
 "Everything has been grossly, grossly exaggerated today," said Kevin Lawrie, manager of foreign exchange at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
 After dropping more than 60 points, the Dow Jones industrial average rallied to 4,157.69, finishing down just 14.87 points. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 1.51 points, to 500.71.
 After a steep drop in the morning, the Nasdaq composite index, rich in fast-rising technology stocks, rallied and finished at 817.21, up 0.35 point for the day.
 Bond prices rebounded some in the afternoon after falling sharply in the morning. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.43 percent from 7.41 percent.
 The angst started early. On Thursday, the German central bank, the Bundesbank, had surprised currency traders by cutting interest rates. Because some traders decided that this was a ploy to prop up the weak dollar, they concluded that it followed that the Japanese central bank, the Bank of Japan, would also cut rates.
 When the Japanese did nothing yesterday, currency traders around the world dumped dollars, sending the American currency to as low as 86.34 yen and 1.3649 German marks. In New York, the dollar settled at 86.55 yen, down 3.4 percent from 89.55 yen the day before, and settled at 1.3715 marks, down 2.6 percent from 1.4083 marks.
 The dollar has already lost 12 percent of its value against the mark this year and almost 14 percent against the yen. Since mid-1985, the dollar has fallen 65 percent against the yen and 55 percent against the mark.
 Moreover, markets in both Japan and the United States were unsettled by the end of the Japanese fiscal year.
 Japanese needed to settle their accounts after a sour three months, when the Nikkei 225 stock index dropped more than 18 percent. Because of the losses, Americans feared Japanese would liquidate some of their American assets in bonds and stocks and sell dollars for yen.
 The backdrop, therefore, was not good when the American markets opened yesterday. The Dow drop of more than 60 points set off the New York Stock Exchange's "circuit breaker" rules just 15 minutes into the trading day.
 The price of gold, a widely followed indicator of market nervousness that had crept up all month, jumped on Thursday and leaped $5.70 yesterday to $392.20 an ounce, approaching the $400 level that gold investors had long been looking for. In two days, gold has vaulted $9.30.
 The Commerce Department revision of the fourth quarter's economic growth came out an hour before the stock market opened. Moreover, just before 10 A.M. yesterday, an analyst at CS First Boston, lowered to "hold" from "buy" his assessments of four stocks favored by institutions -- Intel, Motorola, Advanced Micro Devices and LSI Logic, all of which ended lower for the day.
 "So a lot of portfolio managers were upset that he had to come out with this assessment on the last day of the quarter when everyone is rushing around," said Todd Clark, managing director of equity trading at Rodman & Renshaw.
 "Window dressing" also was a factor in yesterday's trading. Window dressing refers to the practice of institutional investors' buying and selling to maximize their portfolio's performance for the quarter. Yesterday, that buying helped stocks rebound in the afternoon.
 Capping the morning was a rumor that the Federal Reserve was to hold an emergency meeting at 11 A.M., when it supposedly planned to rescue the dollar by raising short-term interest rates by a full percentage point. Such a move would be a sharp departure from the Fed's usual practice of raising rates by a quarter or half a percentage point. The Fed denied the rumor.
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above average, with 353.1 million shares changing hands, about 7 percent more than this year's daily average of 330 million shares.
 One indication of the window-dressing effect was the high volume of trading in the last hour of the session, some 80 million shares, or almost a quarter of the day's volume.
 Among the biggest gainers of the day was Electronics for Imaging, a computer software company, which rose 5 1/2, to 53 1/2, after it signed a large contract with Canon, the maker of copiers. Wackenhut Corrections, a manager of private prisons, rose 2 1/2, to 28 3/8, after it won a $35 million contract to continue managing a Louisiana prison.
 Among the biggest decliners was John Alden Financial, an insurance holding company, which fell 11 3/8, to 18 1/2, after announcing a $10 million charge against last year's fourth- quarter earnings of $18.9 million. Interdigital Communications, a telecommunications company, dropped 5 7/8, to 6 1/8. It has lost a patent infringement case against Motorola.
 The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.79 point, to 271.04, with advancing stocks lagging declining stocks by 994 to 1,232. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.60 point, to 464.41.
 In Tokyo, stocks ended lower yesterday on disappointment that interest rates were left unchanged. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 372.27 points, or 2.25 percent, at 16,139.95.

HEADLINE: Christopher Proposes Tighter Curbs on Trade With Iran

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher has concluded that the American strategy for isolating Iran is not working and has recommended that the United States ban most trade with the country, senior Administration officials said today.
The recommendation, presented in a recent meeting at the White House by Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, would prohibit American companies from buying Iranian oil on the open market and from investing in projects in Iran, the officials added. 
 American oil companies are allowed to buy Iran's oil as long as they sell it outside the United States. Last year American oil companies were the largest purchasers of Iranian oil, buying about one-fourth of its supplies, worth upward of $4 billion worth on the open market.
 Mr. Christopher's recommendation has met with fierce opposition from senior officials at the Defense, Commerce, Treasury and Energy departments. Representatives of those departments argued at the recent White House meeting that curbing American trade would have little effect on Iran and could hurt American companies instead.
The Commerce Department, which has aggressively promoted American business interests abroad, is urging only those actions that the allies can reasonably be persuaded to join, and Iran's European and Japanese trading partners have no interest in a trade ban.
The President's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, is expected to preside over a higher-level meeting next week in which the issue will be debated at the White House. The State Department's recommendation has a strong chance of succeeding, in part because Mr. Lake is also said to believe the current strategy needs to be strengthened.
Mr. Christopher's move reflects his belief that the Administration's international campaign to thwart Iran's ability to rebuild its military economy has been undercut by the oil companies, and that if the Administration does not impose a trade ban, Congress will do so.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican, has introduced legislation to prohibit American companies or their foreign subsidiaries from doing business with Iran, arguing that the United States is "subsidizing Iranian terrorism by purchasing their oil."
The issue of the Iran trade ban poses a particularly difficult dilemma for the Administration because it represents a clash between two pillars of its foreign policy: its desire to promote American business around the world and its determination to punish countries it considers "rogue states."
The United States bans imports from Iran, but Iran is allowed to buy a wide range of nonlethal American goods, including consumer items, oil drilling and engineering equipment, chemicals and gas turbines. The United States is the eighth-largest exporter to Iran, far behind countries like Germany, Japan, France and Britain.
Nearly two years after it unveiled a policy of "dual containment" to isolate both Iran and Iraq, the Administration still considers Iran an "international outlaw" that sponsors terrorism worldwide, opposes Middle East peace efforts and is involved in a crash program to develop nuclear weapons.
Mr. Christopher has opened an international campaign to deprive Iran of equipment useful to its military and to oppose international lending and the rescheduling of Iran's debt. The Administration has also tried unsuccessfully to block a Russian deal to sell Iran two nuclear power reactors.
As for Iraq, the United States has successfully headed off efforts by France and Russia to ease economic sanctions imposed after the country's forces invaded Kuwait more than four years ago.
But acute economic deprivation has not eased President Saddam Hussein's firm grip on power in Iraq. And Mr. Hussein has challenged the international community once again by imprisoning two Americans who crossed into Iraqi territory this month.
The State Department recommendation comes after President Clinton's executive order this month to block a $1 billion project by Conoco Inc. to develop two offshore oil and gas fields with Iran. Mr. Christopher is asking for a broader executive order that could perhaps be followed by legislation, a senior official said.
The current rift in the Administration reflects the positions taken by various agencies last year over whether to sell Boeing 747's to Iran. The Commerce and Treasury departments and some senior officials in the Pentagon strongly favored the deal, but Mr. Christopher opposed it and ultimately prevailed. Iran bought European Airbus planes instead.
When Administration officials are asked why, if Iran is truly an outlaw state, the United States does business with it at all, the answer is a practical one: If we don't trade, someone else will.
The State Department has not decided whether to recommend a ban on exports to Iran, which totaled $328 million last year, down from $750 million in 1992. Nor has the department decided whether the trade ban should cover trade by foreign subsidiaries of American firms.
Over the last several months, Mr. Christopher and Martin S. Indyk, the new Ambassador to Israel and until recently the senior Middle East specialist at the White House, have become increasingly uncomfortable with the inconsistency in the current policy. They argue that it has complicated Washington's efforts to persuade its allies to weaken their ties to Iran.
Every time Mr. Christopher has raised the issue of Iran with Germany and Japan, they have cited the American oil purchases, officials said. Chancellor Helmut Kohl made that point publicly during his recent meeting at the White House with President Clinton, saying it was "American companies, not German oil companies" that were buying Iranian crude oil.
Japan is Iran's largest customer for crude oil, and Japanese officials have told their American counterparts that they would not take part in efforts to isolate Iran economically.
On the other hand, after intense American pressure, the Japanese have agreed to delay a loan for a dam project over the Karun River in Iran, and will send a senior emissary to Washington this weekend to inform Mr. Christopher of their decision, officials said.

HEADLINE: Clinton, in Haiti, Marks the Withdrawal of G.I.'s

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 31

 BODY:
Luxuriating in the cheers of thousands of Haitians, the praise of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide and the crisp salutes of soldiers from a score of nations, President Clinton today handed over the responsibility for the security of Haiti from American troops to a United Nations peacekeeping force.
Saying the restoration of Mr. Aristide to power after an American military intervention last fall represented "the triumph of freedom over fear," Mr. Clinton promised the United States would continue to support efforts to establish democracy here. But he also made it clear that Haitians must bear the primary burden of building a just and prosperous society. 
 "The tasks ahead will not be easy," he told a crowd that had begun gathering at dawn in the main square in front of the National Palace. They had amused themselves during a long wait under a blazing tropical sun by singing, dancing and donning free T-shirts emblazoned with images of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Aristide.
"You must work hard; you must have patience; you must move forward together with tolerance, openness and cooperation."
Mr. Clinton's arrival in Haiti came barely six months after more than 20,000 American troops landed here and brought an end to three years of military dictatorship. Beginning Saturday, Haiti's security will be guaranteed by 6,900 soldiers and police officers from more than 30 countries, including the United States, Bangladesh, Canada, Nepal, the Netherlands and Pakistan.
The warm, festive atmosphere stood in sharp contrast to the violence and political tension that dominated the days preceding Mr. Clinton's arrival. On Tuesday, a prominent opponent of Mr. Aristide, Mireille Durocher Bertin, was killed by three gunmen as she drove her car down a busy main street here.
Shortly afterward, American officials disclosed that they had warned Mr. Aristide last week both of a plot to kill Ms. Durocher Bertin and of the possible involvement of his Interior Minister, Gen. Mondesir Beaubrun. The issue threatened to derail the visit and make a mockery of Mr. Clinton's assertion that American troops have established a "safe and stable environment" here.
During a ceremony at the National Palace this morning, however, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Aristide were full of compliments for each other. Mr. Clinton, who towered over the slight Haitian leader when they stood side by side behind a bulletproof screen, called Mr. Aristide a man of "tremendous courage" whose "strength in the face of great challenge reflects the unbreakable will of the Haitian people."
"We respect him as the President you elected freely and fairly, and for his leadership of all Haitians since his return," Mr. Clinton said.
In his remarks, Mr. Aristide, turning to the preaching style he used as a Roman Catholic priest, led the crowd in a call-and-response chant that thanked the American President for sending troops here and ending three years of repression. "Has President Clinton been good to us?" he asked in Creole, to which the cheering multitude responded with a fervent "Oui!"
It was "thanks to the nonviolent resistance of the Haitian people and to you," he told Mr. Clinton, that "on Sept. 19 Haiti moved from death to life." The American presence here, he said, "has forged a tunnel of hope through the mountains of suffering" and made Haitians eager to offer the American President "the warmth of the light of a welcome never before seen."
Mr. Clinton's trip was the first to Haiti by an American President since Franklin D. Roosevelt visited Cap-Haitien, a northern port, on July 5, 1934, to take part in ceremonies mark the end of an American occupation that lasted of 19 years. No major agreements were reached during the 11-hour visit, but Mr. Clinton announced plans to help rebuild Haiti. He said the Peace Corps would come here later this year "to help to organize the planting of millions of trees" in the badly deforested country, and he also pledged assistance in paving 700 miles of Haiti's primitive roads.
During the ceremonies, no direct mention was made of Ms. Durocher Bertin's killing or the allegations against General Beaubrun. But at the start of a private meeting between the two leaders at the National Palace after the morning festivities, both men referred to the case in responding to reporters.
"They're doing an investigation," Mr. Clinton said, alluding to Mr. Aristide's request this week for an F.B.I. team to lead an inquiry into the killing. "I think we should applaud his quick and decisive action and let the investigation proceed and not presume its results."
"This is a day of celebration, and nothing can cast a cloud on it," he continued. "It's a day of mission accomplished for the United States, a day of celebration for Haitians."
After denying that General Beaubrun was in any way involved in the killing, Mr. Aristide took a similar cooperative tone. "We welcome help from the international community and from the United States, who is helping us find truth about violence," he said in English.
After the meeting, the American delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, said the two Presidents had "discussed the problem of having an event of this type take place" and the "necessity of investigating it." But she said that economic and political issues made up the "major part of what they talked about."
Haitian officials would not say if General Beaubrun had been ordered to stay away from the transition ceremonies to avoid embarrassing Mr. Clinton, though foreign officials said there was no sign of him in the section of the dais reserved for members of the Haitian Cabinet. In any case, American officials said, protocol required Mr. Clinton to shake hands only with Mr. Aristide, Prime Minister Smarck Michel, Foreign Minister Claudette Werleigh and the presidential chief of staff, Leslie Voltaire.
Early in the day, a large banner proclaiming, "President Clinton: Haitian people believe in you for a New Haiti," was strung on the main square. But by the time Mr. Clinton's helicopter landed on the lawn of the National Palace shortly after 11:00 A.M., the poster was removed.
The formal transfer of authority from American troops to the United Nations took place in the afternoon, after a lunch-hour meeting between Mr. Clinton and members of the Provision Electoral Council that will supervise elections here this year. Mr. Clinton strongly endorsed the multinational presence in Haiti, saying it "demonstrated the effectiveness and the benefits of international peacekeeping."
In his speech accepting the peacekeeping mission, the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, struck much the same tone that Mr. Clinton had earlier in the day. "The people of Haiti must maintain their commitment to rebuild their nation," he said, adding that "continued cooperation will bring later achievements."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Drop for 2d Consecutive Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the second straight day in reaction to news of higher-than-expected economic growth late last year, soaring precious metals prices and a slide in the dollar.
 The 30-year bond fell 7/32 , to a price of 10211/32 for a yield of 7.43 percent, up from 7.41 percent on Thursday, and 7.36 percent a week ago. 
 The rate of growth in the gross domestic product in the final quarter of last year was revised upward yesterday to 5.1 percent, exceeding expectations of a 4.7 percent gain. Also, the report's implicit price deflator was up 1.3 percent, showing a slow but steady inflation.
 Elliott Platt, director of economic research at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, said the quarterly G.D.P. growth rate was the third highest since the recession ended in March 1991, while the growth of final sales was the second highest of any quarter in this expansion.
 Analysts noted that bond traders and dealers were particularly concerned about the dollar's slide because it was affecting precious metals and other markets, where it was seen as an inflationary signal.
 Yesterday's economic reports sent the same mixed signals that have kept yields on the 30-year bond between 7.35 percent and 7.50 percent in recent weeks. For example, the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago said its March index of industrial activity fell to 55.0 from 62.7 in February; the forecast had been for a reading of 59.8.
 Another sign that manufacturing could soon cool came from the Government's monthly estimate of factory orders, which fell two-tenths of a percent in February after rising seven-tenths of a percent in January. Forecasts had called for a February decline of four-tenths of a percent.
 There were also signs that consumer optimism was fading a bit, as the University of Michigan's March consumer sentiment index dropped to 90.3, from 95.1 in February.
 Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said that of the many influences on the market yesterday, the most important were profit taking and positioning as the calendar quarter ended, and the renewed weakness in the dollar.
 "The unexpected upward revision to fourth-quarter G.D.P. produced a brief flutter of activity," he said, "but upon reflection the market realized it was interesting only to history buffs."
 About the only new information that came out of the report, he said, was that gross domestic product continued to be larger than gross national product in the fourth quarter. "This, of course, is a relatively new phenomenon, and results from the fact that foreign repatriation from America is now greater than American repatriation from abroad," he said, adding that it was "one of the major reasons why the dollar remains so weak."
 Many market analysts saw the Chicago purchasing management report and the University of Michigan sentiment index as favorable for the bond market, but these reports still took a back seat to the dollar and the end-of-quarter activity.
 "The market will now focus its attention toward the much more important national purchasing management report on Monday, motor vehicles sales and the labor market statistics due on Friday," Mr. Fine said.
 He considers the vehicle sales reports, expected on Monday and Tuesday, to be the most important because they will provide the first hard data from March on consumer demand, which, he says, is the ultimate driving force of the economy.
 Elsewhere, municipal bond market prices finished with losses of 3/8 to 1/2 point in spotty trading. The Bond Buyer's index of 40 municipal issues put the average yield to maturity at 6.37 percent, up 3 basis points from the previous day.

HEADLINE: A Fretful Atlanta Awaits a Deluge

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 31

 BODY:
Like viewing azalea blossoms, agonizing over the annual April onslaught of thousands of black college students is becoming a rite of spring here.
The Atlanta Black College Spring Break, popularly known as Freaknik since it was first celebrated by local students in 1985, has attracted increasing numbers of black students from around the nation in the last few years. The event is a raucous three-day party in which the two central activities are lounging in Piedmont Park to the party rhythms and sexually explicit lyrics of rap music and cruising bumper to bumper, horns blaring, in a car caravan that renders streets around the park, just north of downtown, impassable. 
 Last year Freaknik drew a record 200,000 students, who spent $20 million, according to the Atlanta Convention and Visitors Bureau. But it also cost the city $250,000 for litter cleanup and Police Department overtime and resulted in a chorus of complaints from the largely white neighborhoods around the park about public drinking and rowdy behavior among the sometimes menacing crowds.
This year the event is scheduled for April 21-23. As the date approaches, City Hall is sending mixed signals to the students about whether they will be welcome, and neighborhood residents are pressing city officials to exercise strict control over a weekend that is characterized by spontaneity.
Perhaps inevitably, the debate has taken on racial overtones in this black-majority city that prides itself on being the cradle of the civil rights movement and is home to a progressive black middle class. But the debate is also emerging as a generational battle in which defiant young adults say they will assert their right to party regardless of what city elders say.
The Rev. Edward Branch, who heads the Catholic Center for the Atlanta University Center, said, "It is young adults acting accordingly and city fathers and city mothers acting like mothers and fathers period."
Adding to the concern this year is that the last day of Freaknik coincides with the first day of Atlanta's annual Comdex Spring show. One of the nation's largest annual gatherings of computer and software vendors, Comdex is a prized weeklong event that is expected to pump $40 million into the local economy. The specter of both events converging on Atlanta has Comdex officials worried.
Beginning last fall, Mayor Bill Campbell indicated that the city would discourage Freaknik, and he reiterated the position at meetings in January with Vincent Polito, the managing director of Comdex. But lately, Mr. Polito said, as local opposition to the Mayor's stand surfaced, Comdex officials detected some subtle shifts at City Hall.
"I was pretty confident about things in January and less confident now," he said. "If our event goes poorly as a result of the Freaknik crowd, it would seriously jeopardize my ability to come back. So Atlanta does have a lot riding on the success of this."
Last year, just days after Freaknik, Mr. Campbell said things had gone well, apart from midtown traffic gridlock, and he admonished Atlanta residents that they could not build a fence around their city.
But in October, a spokesman for the Mayor said Atlanta was not the right place for Freaknik. And in later meetings with community groups, the Mayor talked of "zero tolerance" for law breaking.
Then in January the Mayor persuaded the presidents of the six historically black colleges of the Atlanta University Center -- Morehouse, Spelman and Morris Brown colleges, Clark-Atlanta University, Morehouse Medical School and the Interdenominational Theological Center -- to sign a letter to the presidents of other historically black campuses urging them to discourage their students' participation. Atlanta, the letter said, "is not the proper site for an event of this scope and magnitude."
Finally, in a meeting last week requested by students at the local black colleges, the Mayor softened his tone, saying the students would be welcome but would be expected to obey the law.
Dr. Samuel DuBois Cook, the president of Dillard University, a historically black institution in New Orleans, said he was disturbed by the letter and added, "I wonder what would happen if they were white college students."
In some ways Atlanta is grappling with the same issues faced by other traditional spring break destinations, including Fort Lauderdale and Daytona Beach in Florida. In the 1980's, when the numbers of vacationing college students, mostly white, began to overwhelm these communities, officials responded by tightening traffic control and enforcing standards of public conduct. Such tactics cooled the party fervor of students and shrank their numbers over the years until they returned to more manageable levels.
For many people who live near Piedmont Park, Freaknik is less a racial issue than one of noise, gridlock and inconvenience. Steve Brinkley, president of Midtown Neighbors, a group of residents who live near the park, said that the Mayor might have "tempered his words" in recent days, but that his strategy remains the same and that is to try to deflate the event over time.
"The word is out," Mr. Brinkley said. "Freaknik will happen but it will not be of the same magnitude as in the past. The laws will be enforced."
The threats and the letter could backfire. Dr. Cook, for example, said he had suggested to some of his fellow college presidents that the letter "was the best way to insure that their students would come to Atlanta."
"It was like waving a red flag in front of a bull," he said in an interview.
Jamal Coleman, president of the Student Government Association at Clark-Atlanta University, said calls to his school from around the country indicated that "people are coming." He said he hoped that those who came understood the city's intention to strictly enforce the laws and were aware of the possibility that some police officers might feel "hostility" toward them.
"If they can't react properly," Mr. Coleman said, "hopefully they will stay home."
In the last week some local elected officials and ministers have tried to ease anxiety about Freaknik.
C. T. Martin, a member of the City Council from one of the more affluent sections of the city's largely black south side, noted on Wednesday that there were just 20 days remaining to turn the event into something positive. He said that he and residents of his district were pressing the Mayor to promote acceptable behavior by visiting students but also to come up with traffic plans to channel the car caravan rather than ban it from certain areas.
"I understand the Mayor's predicament," Mr. Martin said. "But this is the home of Martin Luther King and six black institutions of higher learning, and we owe it to the parents of these young people to cradle their children while they are here."

HEADLINE: For Half Century, Tradition Has Foiled Attempts to Clean Up Fulton Fish Market

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
Fifty years ago, the Government arrested and won the conviction of a ruthless gangster, Joseph (Socks) Lanza and confidently proclaimed victory in eradicating the Mafia's influence at the Fulton Fish Market.
 The proclamation was premature. 
 While prosecutors tried a variety of methods to attack the mob -- from criminal cases to court-appointed administrators -- they say organized crime still retains a stranglehold there, mainly because of the Genovese family's tight grip and the entrenched culture of suspicion that intimidates honest merchants and workers from testifying.
 Experts say that the fire that devastated one-third of the market on Wednesday was the most dramatic symbol yet of the crime and corruption problems that have plagued the market since the days of Mr. Lanza.
 Michael G. Cherkasky, a former prosecutor, said that the Government's most recent efforts to crack down on the mob's control of the market failed because the authorities were unable to gather significant evidence through traditional investigative methods: planting undercover agents, establishing phony businesses as sting operations and gaining testimony from victims.
 "It was impossible to do deep undercover work there," said Mr. Cherkasky who was the chief of the investigation division in the Manhattan District Attorney's office from 1988 to 1993. "Newcomers are viewed immediately with suspicion. And merchants would tell you everything about what is going on, but they were too terrified to testify or to allow anyone to wear a hidden mike in their business places."
 For half a century, Federal, state and city prosecutors tried to clean up the market by seeking convictions of mobsters on charges of extortion and labor racketeering. Some prosecutors relied on civil court remedies that exiled suspected mob figures from doing business at the market. Others hoped that a court-appointed administrator would prevent abuses.
 On Monday, the Giuliani administration and City Council leaders unveiled the latest plan, giving the city the right to investigate, fingerprint and conduct background checks of merchants and workers.
 Although investigators disagreed as to whether the mob was behind Wednesday's blaze, Mr. Giuliani said the fire would not delay quick approval of his plan and would not weaken his resolve to rid the market of the mob's influence.
 Located mainly on city property in lower Manhattan, the Fulton complex is the nation's largest wholesale fish market. About 50 wholesalers employ about 1,000 workers and generate gross sales of $800 million to $1 billion a year.
 Investigators say the mob is able to extract payoffs because of its threats to interfere with the transportation in and out of the market of quickly perishable seafood. They say the wholesalers, retailers and restaurants often must pay kickbacks to get their seafood loaded and unloaded quickly and that deliveries are not done on first come, first served.
 The market's history of violence and racketeering dates to the mid-1920's when Mr. Lanza organized a Sea Food Workers local. Ralph F. Salerno, who was the head of the organized-crime squad in the New York City Police Department from 1946 to 1967, said that Mr. Lanza acquired the nickname Socks for punching wholesalers and deliverers who refused to pay him for permission to do business.
 Mr. Lanza, who was called the czar of the Fulton market, was convicted in 1943 on Federal extortion charges. Even from prison, the authorities said, he continued to run the market's rackets.
 Investigators say that Carmine Romano succeeded Mr. Lanza as the head of Sea Food Workers Local 359 and as the Genovese family controller in the market.
 In 1981, Mr. Romano was convicted of extortion and racketeering at the market with his twin brother, Peter. After Mr. Romano's conviction, Federal prosecutors acknowledged that convictions of mob figures simply led to the Genovese family replacing them with new overseers.
 In 1987, Mr. Guiliani, who was the United States Attorney in the Southern District of the state and a vocal opponent of organized crime, tried a new approach. He brought a civil racketeering suit to seize administrative control of the market and Local 359.
 The suit led to the banning from the market of Vincent Romano, another brother of Carmine Romano, who prosecutors said was then the Genovese family's controller. Ten other men who were said to be linked to organized crime also were barred from doing business at the market.
 Frank H. Wohl, a former prosecutor, was appointed in 1988 as a Federal monitor with the authority to bring civil charges against companies in the market that committed business abuses. His main crackdown was fining six unlicensed unloading companies a total of $200,000 on charges that they dictated prices and determined how fast seafood could be delivered. The companies have appealed the fines and none have so far been paid.
 In 1989, the Federal campaign was dealt a setback when a judge ruled that prosecutors had failed to prove that Sea Food Workers Local 359 was run by the Genovese family and rejected a proposed government takeover of the local.
 Mr. Wohl's supervision of the market essentially ended in 1992 when Otto G. Obermaier, who was then the United States Attorney in Manhattan, said that the Government would no longer monitor conditions. He noted that the Government had spent $3.5 million and that it was the city's responsibility to manage the place.
 Mr. Wohl said that until recently the city had abdicated its responsibility for regulating and supervising businesses in the market.
 "The result is a frontier atmosphere," he asserted, "in which the prevailing attitude is that the market is a sovereign entitty where the laws of economic power and physical coercion, not the laws of New York, prevail."
 Investigators say that the Genovese rackets in the market are now controlled by two capos or captains, Ross Gangi and Alfonso Malangone. Both capos, officials said, were appointed by Vincent Gigante, the boss of the family and much of the loot from the market is funneled to Mr. Gigante.
 The sons of Mr. Gangi and Mr. Malangone are listed in business records as the owners of two of the wholesale companies in the market. Carmine Romano's son also is the owner of a wholesale firm.
 "The market is the most intractable organized crime problem in the Northeast," said Mr. Cherkasky, the former prosecutor. "Prosecutions alone will not work. You remove one guy and a whole set of two-bit hoods are lined up to replace him."
 Gerald J. McMahon, the lawyer for the loading and unloading companies, and leaders of Local 359 and two wholesale dealers' associations, said there was no evidence that mobsters controlled the market. They described the charges by city officials as exaggerated and promised court action to block the city's bill to regulate companies and workers.
 "My men don't want to be fingerprinted," said Anthony Cirillo, president of Local 359. "They don't want to wear photo identifications and they don't want to go through background checks."

HEADLINE: 11 Years, 11 Late Budgets: Divided Albany Misses the Deadline Again

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 31

 BODY:
As the midnight deadline for passing the New York State budget loomed, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders conceded tonight that negotiations had collapsed and that the state would have a late budget for the 11th consecutive year.
 Clearly frustrated, Mr. Pataki blamed Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Democrat from Manhattan, for the deadlock. The Governor had made an on-time budget a major Republican campaign pledge. He said Mr. Silver, after weeks of negotiations, had not even released a plan showing how much the Democrats wanted to spend or how they would pay for it.
 Mr. Pataki said he would follow through with his threat to withhold paychecks on Wednesday for himself, the 211 legislators and their 4,462 aides unless the budget is passed by then. However, aides to State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a Democrat, raised questions about whether the Governor had the legal authority to carry that out.
 That is because the April 5 paychecks will be for work performed in early March. And under one interpretation of state law favored by the Democrats, the Governor is required to honor all the state's financial obligations from the previous fiscal year, which ends tonight.
 "The Assembly has failed," Mr. Pataki said in a news conference after a brief negotiating session with Mr. Silver and the Republican Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, ended bitterly. "They haven't passed my budget bills, they haven't passed the Senate's budget bills, they haven't passed their own budget bills and they continue to refuse to allow the people to see where they stand."
 In equally testy tones, Mr. Silver said the stalemate was a result of the Governor's refusal to consider any Democratic ideas for raising more revenue. The Assembly Democrats want to restore cuts to education, health care and mental health programs, among others, in the Governor's $32.4 billion proposed budget.
 As the talks between Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders stalled this evening, each house of the Legislature was trying to pass its own version of a budget bill. Because neither bill stands much chance of passing the other house, the votes were largely political exercises intended to inoculate the two sides against criticism for delaying the budget.
 The Republican-controlled Senate today finished passing most of a budget supported by Mr. Pataki. The Senate's version would increase spending by $335 million above Mr. Pataki's original plan, and the additional spending would be used to lighten the cuts to hospitals, nursing homes, higher education and local school districts.
 But illustrating the great division between the two sides, Mr. Silver called the Senate-Pataki budget "a sham" because it will not be the final version. "The people of this state want to know what kind of health care the senior citizens are going to have," Mr. Silver said. "What's the tuition of the state and city universities going to be?" The Senate bills, he said, "will be telling the public nothing in that regard."
 Nevertheless, Mr. Silver said the Assembly would begin amending the Republican budget, probably by adding spending opposed by Mr. Pataki. That process will probably continue throughout the weekend.
 Mr. Pataki has said that legislative aides will receive their checks only after a budget is passed. But Steven Greenberg, a spokesman for Mr. McCall, who issues state paychecks, said it was unclear what would happen on Wednesday.
 Mr. Greenberg said Mr. McCall has the legal authority to issue checks on Wednesday because he is required to pay the state's outstanding obligations from the 1994-95 fiscal year. Those paychecks would cover work done in early March, which was part of that fiscal year.
 On the other hand, Mr. Greenberg said Mr. Pataki could ask the Legislature to pass emergency appropriations bills that would forbid the Comptroller to pay the legislative employees. It is unlikely that Mr. Silver would support such a bill.
 There is a twist, however. Mr. Greenberg said that if Mr. Silver were to block Mr. Pataki's emergency appropriations bills, there would not be enough money available to pay thousands of other state workers. If legislative employees were paid while other state workers were not, it would place Mr. Silver in a politically awkward position.
 Throughout the day, legislative employees braced for the worst. Some said they planned to take emergency $500 loans at 12 percent interest from their credit union. Others plan to seek help from relatives.
 Late budgets have not always been the rule. . Former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, a Republican, had Republican-controlled legislatures for most of his 14-year tenure, and most of his budgets passed on time.
 That all changed in 1974, when a Democrat, Hugh L. Carey, was elected governor and the Democrats took control of the Assembly. Democrats have held the Assembly ever since, while the Senate has remained controlled by Republicans.
 That history of divided Legislatures has made timely passage of the budget virtually impossible. Since 1975, Mr. Carey's first year in office, the budget has been late 17 times: 6 times under Mr. Carey, 10 times under Mario M. Cuomo and now once under Mr. Pataki.
 Though Mr. Bruno tried to show solidarity with Mr. Pataki by passing a budget the Governor supports, he also demonstrated some independence from the Governor by vowing to pass what he called an "economic development" plan that includes spending Mr. Pataki opposes.
 The Senate's budget bill, which is expected to pass on Monday, includes $77 million for stadiums and other athletic projects in mainly Republican districts, including a $24 million swimming center in Nassau County. "I think some of them are sound economic development projects," Mr. Pataki said. "Others of them are at best questionable."

HEADLINE: BACKED BY COURT, BASEBALL PLAYERS CALL STRIKE OVER

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
A Federal judge issued an injunction against major league baseball owners yesterday, setting the stage for their players to return to work after a nearly eight-month-old strike.
The players, who walked out last Aug. 12, have offered to end the longest work stoppage in professional sports history and revitalize a game that last year lost its signature, the World Series, for the first time in 90 years. 
 After the decision by Judge Sonia Sotomayor in United States District Court in Manhattan, the players were prepared to race to spring training camps in Florida and Arizona. But the 28 club owners did not immediately decide to accept their offer.
The owners scheduled a meeting tomorrow in Chicago and planned to vote on whether to welcome the players back or to lock them out while beginning the season with replacement teams. The season is scheduled to start tomorrow night with the Mets playing the Marlins in Florida.
A meeting scheduled for today could be an indication of how the owners are thinking. Lawyers for the clubs and the union planned to meet to discuss back-to-work issues, adding to the growing belief that there will be no lockout.
Reports from owners opposed to a lockout and conversations with people familiar with the owners' position and with lawyers advising them indicate they do not have the 21 votes required for a lockout. If that view holds true tomorrow, the players could begin preparing early next week for a delayed start to the 1995 season.
In a stern and swift ruling issued from the bench, Judge Sotomayor created that scenario by issuing the injunction and preventing the owners from establishing new work rules in the absence of a new collective bargaining agreement. After conducting a 98-minute hearing, she took an 18-minute recess, then read her opinion for 47 minutes. It was obvious that she had prepared most of her opinion before the hearing, having studied the lawyers' briefs on the National Labor Relation Board's request for an injunction.
The board contended that the owners had unlawfully made unilateral changes in the working terms and conditions they had told the board's general counsel eight weeks ago they would restore. The judge ordered them to reinstate salary arbitration, competitive bidding for free agents and the anti-collusion provision of the free-agency rules.
"This strike has placed the entire concept of collective bargaining on trial," Judge Sotomayor said. "It is critical, therefore, that the board assure and that I protect its assurance that the spirit and the letter of Federal labor law be scrupulously followed."
Her injunction did not rule on the merits of the unfair labor practice charges the players filed against the owners; nor did it order the players back to work. She was well aware, however, of the players' offer to go back.
The owners' lawyers immediately asked both Judge Sotomayor and Judge Roger Miner of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for immediate stays of the injunction, but both rejected their request. A hearing was set for next Tuesday before a three-judge panel of the circuit court on the requests for a stay and an expedited appeal.
Asked what the players would do if they reported to training camp and then had the injunction stayed, Donald Fehr, the union chief, said, "The only way they would leave camp would be if the clubs forced them out."
The owners, of course, have to let them back first. At last count, six owners were said to be firmly in the no-lockout camp: the two New York teams, Baltimore, Toronto, Los Angeles and San Diego. They would need only two more votes to block a lockout, and some were confident they had them.
The dynamics could change when the owners meet tomorrow, but some of them simply have had enough of the strike and others fear the possible legal and economic consequences if they locked out the players and the lockout were found to be illegal because they hadn't bargained in good faith.
"Representatives of the 28 clubs will meet to discuss legal and practical options now available," Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, said in a statement, "and will certainly give the players' union a timely answer to their offer to return to the field."
Fred Wilpon, the Mets' owner, said in Port St. Lucie, Fla., where the Mets' replacements have been working toward the scheduled start of the season tomorrow night, that he had a good idea how the vote would go, but he declined to say what it was.
But Mr. Wilpon, who wouldn't say but is known to oppose a lockout, said he would lobby for his position. "I would do anything necessary in a businesslike manner to explain my point of view to whomever would be willing to listen," he said after participating in a conference call of the executive council, the eight-owner group that rules Major League Baseball in the absence of a commissioner.
Mr. Selig clearly did not like the judge's ruling, saying the injunction "may represent a step backward in our negotiations for a meaningful agreement with the players' union." But Mr. Fehr emphasized the union's desire to negotiate an agreement.
"If both sides want it to be," he said at a news conference at a midtown Manhattan hotel, "this could be an opportunity to bargain this out. We ought to do our level best on both sides to seize that opportunity. We are and I hope the clubs will be, too."
While issuing Mr. Selig's statement publicly, the commissioner's office privately sent a list of nine talking points to the clubs.
"The two sides have to settle this between themselves," one point said. "We can't depend on some third party to pinch-hit for us."
"The clubs want to make a deal, but this injunction enables the union to keep dodging serious negotiations," said another.
And: "It means the regular season will be played under the threat of another player strike, possibly wiping out the playoffs and World Series for a second year in a row."
But Mr. Fehr noted that it was the owners who had been cited for unfair labor practices. "We believed for a long time," he said, "the owners were not complying with their obligation to bargain in good faith and that's the primary reason we weren't able to reach agreement."
When the hearing began, Judge Sotomayor, based on her comments and questions, appeared to be prepared to drop the salary arbitration element from the injunction. Early in her ruling, she even said it would be "more limited" than the board requested. But that was a phrase she evidently did not edit out once she changed her mind.
It was the arguments of George Cohen, the union's lawyer, that apparently won the judge over to the inclusion of salary arbitration. After Judge Sotomayor asked why players eligible for salary arbitration couldn't have their salaries remedied once the board found the owners to have violated the labor law, Mr. Cohen suggested it would be like "trying to unscramble the egg."
"We tried this kind of situation in the context of a settlement agreement in the so-called collusion cases," Mr. Cohen said. "We are five years into that process and we are still not even halfway done trying to reconstruct a system."
Not only did Judge Sotomayor rule for the labor board, but she also said the owners would have to come back to her before declaring an impasse in negotiations, if they do at some point in the future. The owners declared an impasse last Dec. 23, but the board found there was no legal basis for it and induced the owners to rescind their action.
That was when they also agreed to restore the status quo, but they omitted the elements the judge dealt with yesterday.
An administrative law judge will hold a hearing beginning May 22 on the merits of the board's complaint against the owners.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Judge Sonia Sotomayor chided baseball's owners in her ruling. Woman in the News, page 33. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bank Business In Derivatives Leveling Off, Study Shows

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
The derivatives holdings of American banks have abruptly leveled off after years of rapid growth, but the holdings remain large in comparison with banks' capital, a Federal agency said today.
 The study by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which is part of the Treasury, provided the latest indication of a slowdown in one of the fastest-growing and most profitable businesses for big banks in the early 1990's. 
 Derivatives are synthetic securities that are based on other assets like bonds, stocks or oil; their prices vary with the underlying assets but tend to be far more volatile. Their popularity has faded over the last year as rising interest rates have produced heavy derivatives losses at industrial companies, local governments and mutual funds, and led to numerous lawsuits.
 The underlying assets of bank-held derivatives leveled off at $15.6 trillion during the third and fourth quarters of last year after soaring from $6.2 trillion in early 1990, the comptroller's office said.
 Such figures tend to overstate the actual credit risk to banks, which the comptroller's office estimated to be no more than 1 or 2 percent of the value of the underlying assets. But the derivatives-related credit risk at the nation's biggest banks, nonetheless, averaged 170 percent of their capital, the comptroller's office found.
 Douglas E. Harris, the senior deputy comptroller who handles derivatives issues, said that the percentage was "not a cause for concern" at the comptroller's office. But he added that the agency still wanted the banking industry to improve its risk management procedures for derivatives.
 "It is adequate but certainly we see now, based on examinations over the last year and a half, that there is some work to be done," he said.
 The national average is for banks to issue commercial and industrial loans equal to 158 percent of their capital. Today's figures showed that a half-dozen large banks have larger derivatives exposures.
 James D. McLaughlin, the director of Federal agency relations at the American Bankers Association, said that the large derivatives exposures were not surprising because the demand for commercial and industrial loans had faded as more and more companies raised money directly from financial markets by issuing notes and bonds. The shift toward large derivatives exposures "is really a reflection of the way some banks are serving their customers' needs," he said.
 Carolyn H. Jackson, the executive director of the International Swaps and Derivatives Association, a New York-based trade group, said the comptroller's office might have overstated the risk percentages, possibly doubling them, inasmuch as banks often hedge by buying multiple contracts with opposite financial effects.
 Mr. Harris said that the comptroller's office was still trying to determine the net effect of each bank's derivatives deals, and that the credit-risk exposures represented a "worst case scenario."
 Bert Ely, a financial consultant in Alexandria, Va., said that derivatives contracts tended to be safer than commercial and industrial loans because banks' partners in the derivatives deals were often big, stable corporations, while the banks' main loan clients were mainly small and medium-sized companies now. But some holders of money-losing derivatives have sued financial institutions, questioning whether the risks of their investments were fully disclosed.
 Bankers Trust had the largest exposure to derivatives, equal to nearly seven times its capital.
 The number of banks doing business in derivatives also dropped during the fourth quarter of last year, to 633 from 648 in the third quarter, according to today's review. "Some of it may have been as a result of mergers, and some of it may be because banks were scared away from derivatives because of the negative publicity," Mr. Harris said.
 The comptroller's office plans to issue detailed information on derivatives holdings every quarter, beginning with today's report on the fourth quarter of last year. Today's compilation covers off-balance-sheet derivatives like futures and options contracts, but not on-balance-sheet derivatives like certain mortgage-backed securities. Beginning with the first quarter of this year, the comptroller's office plans to begin counting the on-balance-sheet derivatives as well, Mr. Harris said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Douglas E. Harris, Senior Deputy Comptroller of the Currency, said his agency wanted banks to improve risk management of derivatives. (David Scull/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fed Minutes Indicate Some Voiced Doubt on Rate Rise

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
Federal Reserve officials were unanimous in deciding to raise short-term interest rates on Feb. 1, but some of them initially expressed concern that the central bank was moving too quickly, according to minutes of the meeting released today.
While the Fed's rate-setting group, the Federal Open Market Committee, remained united then, the minutes suggest that sentiment may be building that 7 rate increases over the last 14 months may have been enough to prevent rapid economic growth from leading to inflation. 
 While a majority of the committee wanted to raise rates immediately on Feb. 1 and prevailed in doing so, "a few preferred to delay such an action pending the receipt within the next few weeks of significant new information that could help the committee to evaluate whether and to what extent the economic expansion might be slowing," the minutes said. The Fed raised short-term rates by half a percentage point that day.
Paul L. Kasriel, a vice president and monetary economist at the Northern Trust Company, a Chicago bank, said that it remained possible that the Fed would raise rates again at the committee's next meeting on May 23. But based on the minutes released today, he said, "my suspicion is they won't be unanimous if they do."
The Federal Open Market Committee met Tuesday and left rates unchanged.
The committee's members are the 7 governors of the Federal Reserve Board, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and, taking turns, 4 of the presidents of the 11 other Federal Reserve regional banks.
Committee members who expressed reluctance to raise rates immediately on Feb. 1 wanted to wait for other Government agencies to finish tabulating various indicators of whether the economy was slowing, like January retail sales. Minutes show they also expressed concern that a tighter monetary policy might make Mexico's financial problems worse. The minutes did not identify the members.
But the members' concerns did not run deep enough to prompt votes against the rate increase. The minutes indicate that these members thought there was a less than even chance that any additional information would persuade them not to raise rates.
Two committee members did vote on Feb. 1 against portions of the Federal Reserve's contribution to the international bailout of Mexico, while the other 10 members voted in favor and approved the bailout, according to the minutes.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, and Thomas C. Melzer, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, both voted against increasing the Fed's line of credit for Mexico and against allowing certain foreign exchange transactions to help with Treasury Department loans to Mexico. "They did not believe that the committee had been provided sufficient information to assess whether developments in Mexico threatened U.S. financial stability, a possible justification for increased central bank lending on a short-term basis," the minutes said.
Mr. Lindsey and Mr. Melzer also worried that Fed action might compromise the central bank's independence, while Mr. Lindsey expressed concern that the risks of this were greater than usual because of the lack of Congressional authorization or general public support for the bailout, the minutes added.

HEADLINE: G.D.P. Growth in Late '94 Is Revised Sharply Higher

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
The Government issued revised figures today indicating that the economy grew even faster in late 1994 than previously thought, with output expanding at an annual rate of 5.1 percent, a pace that raised concern on Wall Street.
 The surprisingly large upward revision in gross domestic product, which a month ago had been calculated to have grown at a 4.6 percent pace, weighed on the bond and stock markets as investors and analysts re-evaluated the prospects that the Federal Reserve would once again raise short-term interest rates to restrain the economy. 
 The Fed has already raised rates seven times since February 1994.
 "It clearly is a source of concern to the Fed," Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities in New York, said of today's report. He noted that most of the strength in the fourth quarter was attributable to final sales rather than a buildup of inventories.
 Most analysts say the central bank seeks to hold growth to a pace of about 2.5 percent, and it has appeared from nearly all statistics published in recent weeks that the economy has been rapidly cooling.
 Indeed, shortly after today's G.D.P. figures were issued the pattern resumed as the Government reported that orders for goods from factories declined in February and as corporate purchasing managers in Chicago and Milwaukee said that industrial growth had slackened in March.
 In addition, the University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment eased to 90.3 from its mid-March reading of 91.8, subscribers to its survey said.
 Still other figures today showed that corporate profits from current production climbed less than half as fast in the fourth quarter as in the third -- $4.3 billion compared with $9.6 billion. Much of the slowdown reflected lower profits at banks and other financial companies.
 Taken together, today's figures seemed to both confirm the economic slowdown and suggest that policy makers may need extra time to achieve their goal, which now involves cutting growth to a pace half that of the final months of 1994. In the four quarters that ended in December, gross domestic product -- the total output of goods and services within the United States -- rose 4.1 percent, down only modestly from the 4.4 percent for the four quarters through September.
 "I have no doubt that the economy is returning to a more normal rate of growth," said Alan M. Gayle, senior vice president of Crestar Bank, based in Richmond. "But the question is getting it to slow far enough, fast enough to relieve the pressures that have built up" on capacity and in prices for various raw materials.
 James W. Coons, chief economist for the Huntington National Bank in Columbus, Ohio, said that he still expected "sharp deceleration" in the economy this year but that interest rates "will be under greater upward pressure" in coming months than during February and March.
 In raising fourth-quarter G.D.P. to a rate of 5.1 percent, the Commerce Department said the largest upward revisions were in business investments and in international trade. Revised figures on aircraft shipments and on prices helped raise the equipment category by $2.3 billion while the introduction of newly available source data cut imports by $2.4 billion, according to Carol S. Carson, director of the Bureau of Economic Analysis.
 The first G.D.P. estimate came Jan. 27, when the annual rate was put at 4.5 percent, with a buildup of inventories cited as a significant factor. A revision on March 1 raised the pace a notch, to 4.6 percent, and most analysts had expected little further change today.
 As for factory orders, also compiled by the Commerce Department, the February decline was the first since October and was dominated by the skid of eight-tenths of 1 percent in durable goods that was initially reported last week. Orders for nondurable factory goods climbed six-tenths of 1 percent as increases for oil, coal and paper products more than offset declines for leather goods and food.
 Shipments of manufactured goods rose five-tenths of 1 percent in February, the fourth consecutive increase, while unfilled orders rose four-tenths of 1 percent.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Real Economic Growth" shows annual rate of change in the gross domestic product, based on 1987 dollars, by quarter, seasonally adjusted. (Source: Commerce Department)
