HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bigger Roles for Suppliers of Temporary Workers

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 31

 BODY:
As they have in every economic expansion, the ranks of temporary workers are swelling, but something is different this time. Now the giants of corporate America -- companies like AT&T, the Bank of America, Johnson & Johnson and Hewlett-Packard -- are getting serious about managing them.
 The number of temps supplied by agencies to American companies soared from 500,000 in 1983 to nearly 2 million, or 1.5 percent of the work force, last year. Large temp firms have hundreds of job categories from traditional secretaries and assembly workers to computer programmers, robotics specialists and chemists. Temporary professionals, from lawyers to accountants to surgeons, are also available. 
 More revealing than the sharp increase, though, is the trend among big companies to form close, sometimes exclusive, relationships with the giants of the temp industry like Manpower, Kelly Services, the Olsten Corporation and Adia Services.
 "The consolidation is taking place at every big company we know," said Mitchell S. Fromstein, chief executive of Manpower, of Glendale, Wis., the world's largest temp company.
 Once viewed as an incidental aspect of business to be handled by local managers, the hiring of temps is increasingly seen as a piece of the human resources pie big enough to command senior management attention.
 "We keep a close eye on it, and we don't want temps to be a second-class work force," said Margaret Johnson, who oversees Hewlett-Packard's worldwide use of temps. Hewlett decided in 1993 that temp compensation and performance had become impossible to monitor, with more than 60 agencies providing as many as 5,000 temps. After nearly a year of research and bid reviews, Hewlett designated Manpower and Volt Services Group, a subsidiary of Volt Information Sciences, based in New York, as its preferred suppliers throughout the United States.
 Since last fall, Manpower's and Volt's share of Hewlett's temporary worker business has jumped from less than 40 percent to more than 50 percent; it is expected to reach 80 percent in two years. Hewlett is considering the expansion of its Manpower contract to cover overseas operations, as well.
 National partnerships can allow manufacturers, banks and other heavy users of temps to bargain for better prices and extra services, like electronic billing and training programs tailored specifically to their needs. A national contract can be worth as much as $100 million annually -- a dazzling opportunity for temp agencies that until recently regarded even a $5 million deal as a plum.
 Temp agencies began promoting the partnership concept in the 1980's, a movement spearheaded by midsize companies like the Norrell Corporation of Atlanta and Talent Tree, a subsidiary of BET P.L.C., a British conglomerate, based in Houston. It did not catch on until a few years ago, when it became faddish to have corporate staff functions like security, information management and human resources handled by outside personnel.
 "Now it's the customers who are pushing this," said Peter Yessne, publisher of Staffing Industry Report, an industry newsletter.
 The trend could be good news for some temporary workers. The closer the relationships between big companies and agencies, the better the chances that the agencies can provide the kinds of training and placements that will lead to permanent jobs.
 Some companies have essentially turned over many of their recruiting and training functions to their biggest temp suppliers, either through the national contracts or exclusive local ones that put a temp agency employee in charge of the site's needs for temporary workers. Manpower controlled 330 client sites at the end of 1994, up from 15 in 1992.
 "Big customers now assume that whoever we send out is skilled," Mr. Fromstein of Manpower said. "They are now looking for better methods of inserting people, for how to make them more soluble."
 But labor economists say there is a dark side to the trend. Most of the nation's 8,000 or so temp companies are small concerns based in a single community, or they supply only one type of worker. With more companies demanding that local office and factory managers justify any departures from the national deal, doors once open to the small entrepreneurs are now all but shut.
 "Small vendors can compete effectively with the Manpowers locally for recruits, but not for national bids," Mr. Yessne said.
 The national contracts are also likely to increase the number of temps. Perhaps 30 to 40 percent of temps are not looking for permanent work, like retirees, students and homemakers with children. But most temps would prefer a permanent job. Turning millions of Americans into "economic shock absorbers" with no long-term ties to their employers is not sound policy, said Harley Shaiken, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley.
 The consensus is that the temporary work force will grow faster than the permanent one for years to come. Manpower, which earns about half of its revenues overseas, may have a slight advantage with companies looking toward global relationships. But the biggest contracts so far have been national in scope, and those that have become public are spread among the industry leaders. Manpower's longtime rival, Kelly, which is based in Troy, Mich., has big contracts with both Kraft General Foods and Johnson & Johnson.
 Olsten, which is based in Westbury, L.I., was chosen by AT&T to run its temporary staffing operation. Four Olsten managers were moved to AT&T's Morristown, N.J., offices, where their mandate was to fill job openings first with AT&T's internal temp staff, then with employees from Olsten or Unique Support Services, a minority-owned company based in New York. Revenues from that deal and national contracts with Bristol-Myers Squibb and the computer services unit of General Electric total about $200 million, said Gordon Bingham, Olsten's senior vice president for marketing.
 Bank of America chose Adia Services, which is controlled by Klaus Jacobs, a Swiss investor, to handle $45 million in temp assignments that were formerly scattered among more than 200 companies in California and other Western states. The bank specified that Adia, based in Redwood City, Calif., could keep half of the business and parcel out the rest among an approved list of backup suppliers, including several companies owned by women and members of minority groups.
 For temp agencies, profit margins are still higher in the small and midsize accounts -- long the industry's bread and butter. But the competition is fiercest for the big customers.
 "I wouldn't be surprised to see the relationships with the big clients become semipermanent over the next few years," John Rowberry, senior vice president at Adia, said, "like those they have with their accountants."

HEADLINE: Second Man Is Under Arrest In a Doctor's Killing in 1981

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
More than 13 years after a popular young resident in pediatric surgery at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center was shot and killed in a struggle with muggers, a second suspect has been arrested by the Manhattan detective whose tenacity broke the long-dormant case with a first arrest last summer.
 The new suspect, Daryl Whitley, 32, has been in prison for 6 of the last 13 years on robbery and drug convictions and was to be released from an upstate prison in May after serving a term in a parole violation case. He was brought to New York from his cell on Thursday and charged with the murder of Dr. John Chase Wood Jr. 
 The detective, Jerry Giorgio of the 34th Precinct, who accumulated a 20-pound carton of evidence in the case over the years, said in an interview yesterday that he had found several new witnesses who linked Mr. Whitley to Dr. Wood's killing on Riverside Drive at 165th Street on the night of Nov. 2, 1981.
 "I keep thinking about the children he would have saved or helped," the detective said of Dr. Wood when asked about his determined pursuit in the case. And he told of "a special place in my heart" for Columbia-Presbyterian, where his own son, facing death as an infant with hydrocephaly 30 years ago, underwent three successful operations.
 Two muggers -- some witnesses said three -- accosted Dr. Wood as he returned to work after dinner with his wife, Diana, a nurse who was pregnant. There was a scuffle, and he was shot in the heart in a moment of madness that yielded the killers $5, destroyed a promising life, shattered a family, stunned friends and colleagues and stirred outrage across the city.
 The victim's widow gave birth to a boy, later became an anesthesiologist in Boston and recently remarried, said Detective Giorgio, who continued his investigation after the headlines faded, interviewing hundreds of potential witnesses and tracking countless leads.
 The detective finally broke the case last July 30 with the arrest of Patrick McDowell, 30, an unemployed janitor from Washington Heights who had spent 10 of the previous 13 years in prison for another slaying. He was accused of firing the 22-caliber bullet that killed Dr. Wood, but has not yet been brought to trial.
 Wayne Brison, a spokesman for District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau, confirmed yesterday that Mr. Whitley had been indicted by a grand jury in Dr. Wood's death and that he would be arraigned on Monday. He said it was unclear whether Mr. McDowell and Mr. Whitley would be tried together.
 Both men had been suspects in the Wood case since early 1982, when they were arrested in the unrelated robbery and murder of a Manhattan woman. In that case, Mr. McDowell served 10 years for manslaughter and Mr. Whitley 2 years for robbery. Mr. Whitley also served four years, from 1986 to 1990, on a drug charge, was jailed for a minor offense in Raleigh, N.C., last year and was returned to the Franklin Correctional Facility in Malone, N.Y., last December for violating parole.
 The two arrests do not mean the Wood case is over, Detective Giorgio said.
 "There may be a third person," he said. "It's a suspicion I've always had. Two people approached the doctor, but there may have been a third, a lookout. I'm not giving up. I have to get rid of that doubt in my mind."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Reports Plan on Economic Rules, and Criticism Is Swift

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 31

 BODY:
The Government disclosed a five-year plan today to abolish or relax hundreds of economic regulations, but both businessmen here and American officials immediately criticized the package as inadequate.
"There are some things that are hopeful," Walter F. Mondale, the American Ambassador to Japan, said in an interview today. "The rest of it is so general and delayed and vague that we just can't give it any weight." 
 The package, approved by the Cabinet this morning, affects a wide range of industries. Some of the rule changes should make it less expensive to import goods and transport them in Japan, while other rules might ease the use of American wood products in Japanese homes.
But the plan is vague in places, calling in some cases only for certain regulations to be reviewed, not necessarily to be revised or abolished. Many of the 1,100 items are steps that had already been announced. And the plan leaves out deregulatory steps proposed by both Japanese industry and foreign businesses.
The package does not relax a law that makes it difficult to open large stores, saying only that the law will be reviewed by the end of the plan's five-year period. Washington has complained that the law makes it difficult for American mass merchandisers to open outlets here in the world's second-largest economy.
The package also does not deal with deregulation of Japan's automobile inspection system because that is the subject of trade talks with the United States aimed at increasing sales of foreign automobile repair parts.
Deregulation has become a battle cry in Japan in the last two years. Economists say it would bring down high prices and help revitalize the economy by easing new business formation. The United States and Europe have been pressing for deregulation to ease the entry of foreign companies into Japan's markets.
Some businessmen here had hoped that a strong deregulation package, which would eventually help reduce Japan's trade surplus, would help stem the rapid rise of the yen against the dollar. Instead the yen soared to a new high today, threatening to choke off Japan's nascent economic recovery by making exports less competitive.
Shoichiro Toyoda, the chairman of Keidanren, Japan's most powerful business organization, said, "There is much room for improvement" in the plan, which includes only 211 of the 456 deregulatory measures the organization proposed.
Japan has introduced numerous deregulation and import-promotion packages over the years, often with great fanfare. But when put into effect the plans usually fall short. The new plan was ordered by Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama, but his administration left decisions on what rules to eliminate to the very bureaucrats who have a vested interest in maintaining the rules.
Officials here say that this new five-year plan sets more specific timetables than past ones, calling for annual reviews that will be open to foreign suggestions.
One of the rule changes will enable air cargo to clear customs more quickly. Another change will allow standard-sized containers used on ships to be carried by trucks. Under current regulations, cargo shipped into Japan must be transferred to smaller containers for road travel, adding to costs.
Other measures would relax restrictions on sales promotions and would strengthen the agency that enforces antitrust laws.

HEADLINE: Italian Left Could Play Kingmaker Role

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Tell These Italians Communism Doesn't Work" (Reggio Emilia Journal, March 24), on the "consistency and even efficiency" a Communist administration has brought to the town of Reggio Emilia, highlights the increasingly prominent role the left is playing in the Italian social, political and economic arena. 
 For the Communists, "respectability" with the Italian electorate began roughly in the late 1980's and early 90's, when they renounced Marxism and adopted a less threatening name, the Party of the Democratic Left.
While they were kept out of the power structure (the executive branch) since the formation of the Italian Republic following World War II, the Communists directed their energies principally into hundreds of local administrations and the labor movement.
In both areas they were generally respected for their efficiency, sense of innovation and probity (the Party of the Democratic Left was the only major party not affected by the recent corruption scandals).
The amalgamation in the 80's of the three major labor unions was largely spearheaded by the Communist labor union. In its expanded, coordinated form the labor movement has gained considerable support from its membership and increased its impact on management.
The Party of the Democratic Left, after canvassing its membership, supported Prime Minister Lamberto Dini's interim "government of technocrats" in the March 16 vote of confidence. This in a sense ratified the austerity programs Mr. Dini has proposed to restore financial stability to Italy. By casting more than 50 percent of the "yes" vote, the party became the decisive political factor in extending and expanding the tenure of the Dini Government.
The Party of the Democratic Left bids fair to become a kingmaker in the general elections later this year.
 
VINCENT R. TORTORA
Port Washington, L.I., March 27, 1995

HEADLINE: S.I. Port Sludge to Be Sent Out of State

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
Bowing to concerns of residents on both sides of New York Harbor, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have agreed on a plan to dump 150,000 tons of contaminated sediment in an out-of-state landfill rather than into underwater pits off Coney Island and Staten Island, despite the new plan's higher costs.
 The sediment would come from dredging the waters of the Howland Hook Marine Terminal, a cargo port that is to be deepened to about 40 feet from 31 feet so deep-hulled ships can start docking there. 
 The terminal, on the northwest shore of Staten Island, has been closed for almost a decade because it cannot accommodate the freighters now used in most major shipping. Two previous plans for disposing of the sludge -- involving an underwater pit a mile off Coney Island and another three miles from Staten Island -- met with vociferous opposition from residents, environmentalists and fishermen.
 Officials of New York City and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said a main reason for disposing of the contaminated material out of state was to avoid lawsuits over environmental permits that might delay reopening the terminal. City officials have long put pressure on the Port Authority to hasten the terminal's revitalization.
 "The plan offers a solution to an impasse over disposal of material that must be dredged from berths at Howland Hook before the 187-acre site, virtually unused since 1986, can again handle cargo," a statement by the Port Authority said.
 Two landfill sites are under consideration, one in New Milford, Conn., the other in East Carbon, Utah.
 The director of the Port Authority's port department, Lillian Liburdi, said the companies that operate the two landfills -- Waste Management Inc., which runs the one in New Milford, and the E.C.D.C. Laidlaw Corporation, which operates the landfill in Utah -- have already submitted bids for transporting and disposing of the dredged material. One bid is $15.7 million and the other is $29 million, Ms. Liburdi said, but she would not disclose which company had made which proposal. The higher bid is about four times the cost of using the harbor pits.
 Officials said the higher cost is justified because opening the harbor to deep-hulled vessels is essential to restoring economic vitality to what was once one of the world's premier cargo ports. The agreement, Mayor Giuliani said in a written statement, "shows our desire to bring jobs and activity back to our once-thriving waterfront."
 The dredging of Howland Hook, which could begin in June if all the government permits are obtained, is expected to create 300 jobs almost immediately, the Mayor said, "with a potential for up to 1,700 for the coming years." Eventually, he said, the terminal is expected to generate $230 million in economic activity.
 Initially, the sediment from the dredging was to be deposited in what is called the Mud Dump, a federally regulated site off Sandy Hook, N.J. But the Federal Environmental Protection Agency barred the use of the site after tests determined that the Howland Hook sediments fell into the highest category of toxins.
 The Port Authority then proposed dumping the material into the excavation pits left by sand-mining operations in the harbor and capping the pits with sand and clay.
 Among the contaminants found in the Howland Hook sediments are pesticides, trace metals and polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's. There has been some debate whether there are also dioxin compounds in the sludge, with one biologist, Dr. Angela Cristini, saying that at least six studies have established their presence and New York City officials saying tests there have found only minute amounts that pose no hazard.
 "We took on the Port Authority, a $4.5 billion Goliath, and stopped them from cutting their costs at the expense of our health," Assemblyman Daniel L. Feldman, a Democrat from Brooklyn and a leader of the opposition to dumping the material in the harbor, said yesterday. "At the beginning of the struggle, I think they perceived us as a toothpick trying to topple the Washington Monument."
 More than 15,000 people eventually signed petitions opposing the harbor dumping plans.
 Ms. Liburdi said that if new dredging permits are approved by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation and the Army Corps of Engineers, the first berth area at Howland Hook could be ready by June. She said a tenant, Howland Hook Marine Terminal Inc., owned by Carmine Ragucci, a former manager of the terminal, is waiting to begin operations there.
 Dr. Cristini, a member of the Dredged Materials Management Team formed by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, said she thought "it's a very good idea that they are planning to use upland disposal" in a landfill for the material.
 "I think it can be done environmentally soundly if the landfills where they are supposed to go are capable of receiving toxic sediments," she continued, "meaning that they have the appropriate lining, the proper containment so that the stuff doesn't get into the groundwater."
 When asked about the possibility that the landfill in New Milford might be used, Michele Sullivan, a spokeswoman for the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection, said: "This is premature to us. The state will not accept any waste material that does not fit the criteria for the environment and public health.
 "To date, we have no permit application in front of us, and we have received no data on the dredge material."

GRAPHIC: Map: A New Milford landfill is being considered for disposal of 150,000 tons of sediment from the Howland Hook Terminal. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
Body Bags at 11

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
SIRENS BLEAT, BODIES float, suspects cringe, victims weep. Celebrities preen and promote. Anchors chat and emote. It's local news time: normally 30 minutes of hell and blather, ads and promos, weather and sports, starting at 9, 10 or 11 -- local television's most profitable time of night and its most disheartening use of the air.
There are exceptions, of course, here and there, one night or another. But in most of America, whatever channel you watch, the late news is obsessed with crime and disaster, encouraging fear or smug comfort, or both. It assails the mind but offers nothing much to think about -- not even about crime, war and disaster. No helpful assessments of the police or local hospital. Almost nothing about education except some school shooting. Nothing about housing except some landlord's venality. Nothing about traffic except some flaming collision. Much less anything reflective about politics, economics, foreign affairs. 
 We all know it's so, but local news being local, it's hard to document the dreary sameness from city to city, set to set, anchor to anchor. It's also been too easily excused: after all, didn't the nightly local news replace the local evening paper that thrived on crime and scandal, astrology and sports? Yes, but even the yellowest of the yellow sheets had a distinctive personality and point of view, style of writing and roster of stars. Most of the papers' TV descendants lack the confidence and talent to stray from the pitiful norm, and now I've got the proof.
The evidence is called "A Day in the Life of Local TV News in America." It's a pamphlet assessing the content of one night's local news on 50 stations in 29 cities, large and small. Volunteers in selected cities were recruited by the Rocky Mountain Media Watch of Denver to tape the Jan. 11 news shows (fussily called "programs" by The Times); Paul Klite, Robert A. Bardwell and Jason Salzman then ran the tapes past their stopwatches. It takes less than the time of one newscast to absorb their findings.
They began by defining an American television newscast: The average commercial station devoted 43 percent of its air time -- less than 13 minutes out of the typical 30 -- to what can be generously called general news. None offered more than 17 minutes of news in a half hour, and none less than 10. Sports and weather averaged a little more than 6 minutes. Commercials on average claimed nearly 8 1/2 minutes -- and more than 10 minutes at 10 of the stations.
The news segments, predictably, were dominated by "Mayhem" stories involving either crime or disaster. The stations' search for distress that January evening was helped along by vivid scenes of the devastation caused by California's rains and floods. But half the time devoted to purely local news (not counting the floods or O. J.) was also given over to mayhem. And the majority of the crime stories, mostly about murder, were plainly local:
Son shoots mother five times with bow and arrow. (Pittsburgh)
Boyfriend sets girlfriend on fire. (Chicago)
Body mutilated and put on display. (Austin)
City's first female drive-by gang shooting. (Tucson)
On to the "Fluff Index." This category encompasses trivial features, anchor chatter, celebrity items and teasers about the news to come after the commercial. Somewhat arbitrarily, the analysts had to decide how much O. J. was celebrity gossip and how much crime. (The next morning, which was two weeks before the start of the Simpson trial, The New York Times's O. J. article appeared on page 14: "Prosecution Says Simpson Abused Wife for 17 Years.")
The average newscast served up 1 minute of fluff for every 3 minutes of news:
Girl reunited with dog.
How to tango.
Ex-Mayor's portrait on beer bottle.
Today's daily trivia question.
Baby tamarins at the zoo.
Fluff seems to be a sensitive area for some stations. The Rocky Mountain monitors observed that WRC-TV in Washington, with an average fluff-to-news ratio of 1 to 3, was running a promo advertising "No fluff, no chit-chat, no nonsense." And KMGH-TV in Denver, promising "No filler, no fluff, no contests," was judged to be offering fluff to news in a ratio of nearly 1 to 2.
A station that stood out favorably with low scores on both the fluff and mayhem charts was WBBM-TV, the CBS property in Chicago. Surprise, surprise: it runs a distant third in the ratings behind ABC's WLS-TV (not covered in the survey) and NBC's WMAQ-TV (double the fluff and more than double the mayhem). Understandably, results like that frighten the managers of commercial stations.
But at least in some cities, viewers seem to be commendably restive. WCCO-TV, the CBS station in Minneapolis that scored high on the mayhem index but low on fluff, discovered last year that 4 out of 5 viewers clicked the Remote to switch channels during the 10 o'clock news -- and on average they clicked five times during the half hour! Thus was born an idea that may, in time, offer the local news everywhere a measure of redemption.
John Culliton, WCCO's general manager, decided to give the switchers a place to land. He began in January to produce a second, simultaneous newscast on an independent station that offers the same headline appetizer but a different main dish -- generally more local and life-style news in place of the sports and weather. By using the same commercials, the two programs qualify for a combined viewership rating.
Real distinction, however, would transcend such modest choice. It would offer journalistic expertise and showmanship to compete with the vivid pictures of maimed victims, burning buildings and distraught relatives. It would require reporters who know their subjects as well as the sports and weather people know theirs. It would put a premium on covering the cost of Medicare and the trickery in City Hall's budget. It would require hiring animators to turn out colorful, instructive graphics that explain the stories that don't photograph well.
The customary excuse for the low quality of local television news is that the viewers won't stay around for anything better. But hardly any stations employ enough talent to test that proposition. Hardly any are even willing to try analyzing urban violence instead of merely filming it and to make celebrities of worthy citizens instead of celebrating models of fluff. Yes, the attention span of the local news audience is scandalously short. But to find the juiciest scandal, local television news need only look at itself.

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
Step Right Up to Broadway's Revivals Museum

BYLINE: By MARGO JEFFERSON 

 BODY:
RIGHT NOW MUCH OF broadway is a Museum of the American Musical staffed by busy curator-directors eager to put their stamp on every show they mount.
Their handiwork includes the "revisal," as in the brand-new "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying"; treatments of pre-existing musical texts, as in "Tommy" and "Smokey Joe's Cafe"; arduous restorations, like "Show Boat," and meticulous concert versions like "Call Me Madam." 
 Museums today are afraid of losing their audiences. And so these musical exhibits must be crowd pleasers as well as genuine attempts to do justice to a great American form -- one that has dwindled and diminished in recent years.
Harold Prince's "Show Boat" is a closely supervised, lavish restoration, involving research, scholarship and all the resources of present-day stagecraft. Actually, it is a curious amalgam of several versions -- the first one, in 1927, the 1936 film and the 1946 Broadway revival, among them -- made to look like a dream vision of the original. The aim is to seal up all the cracks in this gorgeous, awkward, daring, sickly sweet, eager-to-challenge yet eager-to-please musical: to buff and polish it till it looks like new. But to my mind, antiques that look too new lose some of their character.
The "Encores! Great American Musicals in Concert" series takes a very different approach. They almost completely discard the frippery of sets and costumes and pare the work down to its basic structure of words and music. "Encores!" did a terrific job with Irving Berlin's 1950 "Call Me Madam" last month. They will have done Cole Porter's "Out of This World" by the time you read this, and next month they will be doing Rodgers and Hart's "Pal Joey." The shows run for just three days at City Center and wouldn't look amiss in a small, pretty Broadway house. If they are all as good as "Call Me Madam," I'd like them to play for months.
The orchestra replaced the scenery in this cheerfully lightweight sendup of President Truman's appointment of Perle Mesta, Washington's most flamboyant hostess, as his Ambassador to Luxembourg. The cast, led by Tyne Daly as the hostess-with-the-mostest, dressed simply, sang winningly and performed while carrying their scores. Not that they weren't impeccably rehearsed by Charles Repole, the director -- of course they were. The scores were like certificates of authenticity, meant to remind us that these performers were getting down to the business of putting on a show. You saw the work and you saw the result of that work, the sparkle and the hard-won spontaneity, at the same time. It was as if you could view the land of Oz in all its illusory glamour while watching the Wizard work away backstage to produce those illusions.
The revue takes a simpler, more improvised approach to its material. It's a survey, a glance backward at music and manners that usually flourished outside Broadway's boundaries, in the neighborhoods of jazz, blues or, as in "Smokey Joe's Cafe: The Songs of Leiber and Stoller," currently playing at the Virginia Theater, 1950's and early 60's rock-and-roll. No plot is required. All the story we need is in the songs and the styles they recall: ways of walking, talking, dressing, flirting, yearning and showing off. The fact that these styles are being framed and mounted on Broadway now is proof of their staying power. They've lasted in our imaginations, so they can go legit.
The songs in "Smokey Joe's Cafe," songs like "There Goes My Baby," "Stand by Me," "Young Blood," "Kansas City," "Yakety Yak," "Hound Dog" and, yes, "On Broadway" (hail to the Drifters, Ben E. King, the Coasters, Wilbert Harrison, Big Mama Thornton and Elvis Presley), come across as good clean fun. But after all, this is still supposed to be rock-and-roll. A little less goodness and a little less ingratiating cleanliness would be a lot more fun.
The most ambitious approach to classic musical theater texts can be seen in the plush, showy revisal of "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying" that opened 10 days ago at the Richard Rodgers Theater. A revisal is part revision, part revival and part reappraisal. A revisal's director (in this case Des McAnuff, who also directed the plush, showy "Tommy") acts as a kind of anthropologist and social psychologist. Our dear ancestors, he seems to say of those who wrote the work he is staging: how vital and gifted you were, how much you gave us. But you were backward in certain ways too, a prisoner of your times. It is up to me to free you now, to enhance your virtues and to minimize, chastise or eradicate your faults.
"How to Succeed," which opened in 1961, was Frank Loesser's last musical. (It succeeded "Where's Charley?" "Guys and Dolls," "The Most Happy Fella" and "Greenwillow" in his canon.) Following one J. Pierrepont Finch from his job as a window washer to his position as chairman of the board of the World Wide Wicket Company in New York City, it manages to be both a satire and a fairy tale. It is satiric because it mocks American how-to-better-yourself instruction manuals stretching from Benjamin Franklin to Dale Carnegie and because it mocks the chicanery, nepotism and mediocrity that keep big business humming. It is a fairy tale because all those how-to-better-yourself dreams come true and because chicanery, nepotism and mediocrity are put to the service of a happy ending for all.
The score and the story are a perfect fit: in fact, the lyrics are so smart and so well served by the music that together they nearly carry the story and render the book (by Abe Burrows, Jack Weinstock and Willie Gilbert) superfluous. Loesser could submerge himself in a song the way certain actors can submerge themselves in their character. He had so many musical tricks and manners; he could write arias, anthems, ballads, hymns, swing songs and patter songs, and he could write them straight or as parodies.
The characters in "How to Succeed" are meant to be played straight and for parody. They get to have it both ways, and so do we. J. Pierrepont Finch (played by Matthew Broderick) is a boy ingenue and a shameless schemer. Rosemary Pilkington (Megan Mullally) is the secretary who loves him: a girl ingenue with a heart of brass. He has his eye on a company presidency; she has her eye on him and on a home in New Rochelle. For now, the company president is J. B. Biggley, an officious executive with a trifling nephew he keeps promoting and a big, gold-digging blond girlfriend he keeps finding jobs for. There is a male chorus of greedy executives and a female chorus of cynically vivacious secretaries.
"How to Succeed" is that rare thing in the annals of musical comedy, a man's show, for the perfectly good reason that the business world of 1961 was a man's world. The men's roles are bigger, better and easier to play well. Rudy Vallee played Biggley in the original, and he was both pompous and unctuous. (He had already given us a younger version of this figure in Preston Sturges's film comedy "The Palm Beach Story.") This time around, Ronn Carroll is louder, coarser, more unsure of himself and more bullying, which is fine. Charles Nelson Reilly turned Biggley's nephew Bud Frump into a smug, portly dweeb. To equally good effect, Jeff Blumenkrantz makes him a skinny, nervous and slightly foppish nerd, beset as much by ambition as by incompetence.
Robert Morse's inimitable Finch was a merry prankster, a kind of amoral Robin Hood, who robbed from the rich to make himself rich. Matthew Broderick is a shyer, slyer actor: his Finch manipulates with a clear conscience and a pure heart. I can't help it, it's my inner child, he seems to be saying every time he pulls a new trick on someone. The choreographer Wayne Cilento plays this up cleverly. Whenever Ponty is about to launch a new scheme, he breaks into eccentric dance movements, as if he were entering his own personal dream ballet. And when he actually dances, he looks like an infantilized Jerry Lewis who longs to be Fred Astaire.
MR. CILENTO TRIES TO DO the same thing for Megan Mullally's Rosemary. This 1990's revisal wants us to believe that Rosemary is mistress of her fate and future. She may sing like a doe-eyed ingenue, but that's just to soften us up; when she dances, she dances like a svelte Cyd Charisse. But this is a concept, not a characterization. The concept dictates that Rosemary and all of the secretaries at the World Wide Wicket Company be in command: though they may appear vulnerable, superficial or merely coquettish, they are really superb sexual tacticians with a feminist agenda.
But the year is 1961, and however smart they may be, secretaries are still babes in corporate toyland. "How to Succeed" depends on sexual hierarchies along with the social and economic ones. These working girls can no more triumph as feminists than the men they work for can turn into enlightened public servants.
Nothing makes the situation clearer than a song that the director of "How to Succeed" chose to drop. The song is "Cinderella, Darling," and the secretaries sing it to Rosemary at the moment she is about to resign from her position as Ponty's fiancee. "How often does it happen/ That a secretary's boss/ Wants to marry 'er?/ How often does the dream come true/ Without a sign of conflict/ Or barrier?" Smitty, the sharp-tongued leader of the typing pack intones. "How often can you fly/ From this land of carbon paper/ To the land of flower'd chintz?/ How often does a Cinderella/ Get a crack at the prince?"
And then the girls chime in: "Don't, don't, don't,/ Cinderella, darling/ Don't turn down the prince!" and unfurl a vision of Bergdorf Goodman, Elizabeth Arden and the New Rochelle P.T.A. "Why spoil our enjoyment;/ You're the fable,/ The symbol/Of glorified unemployment!" they chant. With Victoria Clark's Smitty in charge, this song would have worked. It is a shrewd capsule portrait of pink-collar femininity circa 1961, more accurate and therefore more biting than what Mr. McAnuff substitutes: a girl-group reprise of Ponty's "How to Succeed" anthem, in which they plot to marry tycoons and take over companies.
Trust the tale, not the teller, said D. H. Lawrence. Trust the audience too, one might add. Des McAnuff's revisal is a good-looking, fast-moving show. But if he had trusted the tale he would not have had to patronize the audience. "How to Succeed" could have been tough-minded then, instead of mealy-mouthed.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Air Pacts, Partnerships Bridging the Atlantic

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
MORE flights between Europe and North America should at least theoretically -- be the result of a spate of agreements between the United States and nine European Governments to open their skies to each other's airlines. Despite a warning in February by the European Union, which wants to negotiate a global accord on air service with Washington, several member countries, including Belgium, Luxembourg and Austria, and some nonmembers, like Switzerland and Iceland, have reached preliminary agreement to phase out restrictive treaties that have governed air travel. The others -- Denmark, Sweden, Finland and Norway -- are expected to do so this month.
"This will open up big business centers in Europe to direct traffic," predicts Tony Molinari, a United Airlines spokesman. But United, like other carriers canvassed, said it had no immediate plans to expand flights to Europe as a result of the new accords. 
 After signing a similar agreement with Canada in February, the United States has been seeking to achieve open skies over the major European countries, including France and Germany. So by reaching accords with the smaller countries, the hope is to gain access to the bigger markets as well.
Unlike the United States accord with Canada, which sparked a flurry of announcements by airlines in both countries, and some lower fares, the European agreements have not yet prompted any of the European national carriers to propose specific new flights. Partly, this is because most of them are grappling with cost-cutting measures needed to restore financial health after the recession of the last few years. It is also because many of the airlines involved already had plans to increase connections with North America through cooperative agreements with carriers there.
For example, Austrian Airlines, eager to serve American cities other than New York, began a three-way code sharing arrangement last month with Swissair and Delta to fly Vienna-to-Geneva-to-Washington and Vienna-to-Zurich-to-Chicago. Johann Jurceka, a spokesman for Austrian, said no reduction in existing fares was planned.
Code-sharing arrangements enable airlines to coordinate connecting flights and list them jointly in reservation systems as if the partners were one airline. For passengers, code-sharing can open up previously unavailable destinations. The result is to put more passengers on planes, making them more profitable for the airlines to run.
Last fall, for example, Sabena expanded its relationship with Delta, offering shared flights to and from Brussels and four American cities, Chicago, Boston, Atlanta and New York. Moreover, Delta travelers on Sabena aircraft can now connect through Brussels to German cities including Dusseldorf, Hanover, Hamburg, Munich and Stuttgart.
A Sabena spokesman, Ives Panneels, said the airline had no plans to increase flights to the United States because of Belgium's agreement with Washington.. A Swissair spokesman said any additional flights to the United States would be added through its code-sharing partner, Delta.
"We have always lobbied and spoken out in favor of open skies," said Todd Clay, manager of corporate communications at Delta. "And an integral part of that is code-sharing, where we now have 10 different arrangements."
Today, Atlanta-based Delta is scheduled to begin operating shared routes with Virgin Atlantic Airlines of Britain, affording Delta travelers access for the first time to Heathrow Airport outside London. Delta now flies into Gatwick, London's second airport, from several American cities, including Boston, Orlando, Miami, Cincinnati and Atlanta. Delta will also share Virgin flights to Heathrow from seven American points, including San Francisco, Los Angeles and New York.

HEADLINE: A Foreclosed Co-op in Brooklyn Becoming a Rental

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
IT is every co-op owner's worst nightmare: The building falls into default on its underlying mortgage. Then the bank moves to foreclose. Then the co-op files for bankruptcy. Then the judge sells the building, effectively liquidating the shareholders' equity and turning every apartment owner into a renter.
Such a scenario is unfolding in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, where a 106-unit co-op, Hamilton House, which was built as a co-op in 1986, was foreclosed on by Citibank last year after falling behind in payments on its $7.2 million underlying mortgage and filing for bankruptcy. 
 The six-story building, at 100-31 Fourth Avenue and 419 101st Street, was sold at an auction last month for $5 million. If the closing goes through as scheduled on Friday, the buyer would own it as a rental.
Among those who stand to lose their investment are nine apartment buyers who purchased their units for occupancy; the remaining buyers were investors who held the apartments as rentals.
Despite the well-publicized troubles of many co-ops that converted from rentals in recent years, only a few have failed to the point that they reverted to rentals. The precise number is not known, according to the New York State Attorney General's office, which oversees co-ops, because there may be some unpublicized cases.
Large banks like Citibank have usually not been involved in these deconversions. The mortgage holder has been either a small private lender or Freddie Mac, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
In one case, Freddie Mac foreclosed in 1993 on 101 Lincoln Road, an 86-unit apartment building in Brooklyn in which 20 of the 86 apartments had been sold. The rest continued to be occupied by rent-stabilized tenants. The 20 shareholders, however, lost ownership of their apartments.
"It is very unusual, in general, when a co-op is successfully foreclosed on and even rarer when a building is foreclosed on and does not automatically fall under rent-stabilization," said Arthur I. Weinstein, vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives.
He added that the Hamilton House situation did not appear to portend similar problems elsewhere in the city. "Most people have negotiated solutions to their problems or are in the process of solving their problem," he said.
Hamilton House, which has an underground garage, was built by James C. Gherardi, who also built the nearby Water's View at Verrazano development. He owns several units in the co-op. Originally, apartments at Hamilton House sold at $80,000 to $103,000 for studios, $101,000 to $153,000 for one-bedrooms and $185,000 to $198,000 for two-bedrooms. Most of the units sold within the first two years, mainly to investors.
By 1993, though, it became apparent, said Thomas W. Smith, an attorney in Yonkers who represents the co-op corporation, that the underlying mortgage on the property was more than the co-op could afford and would grow even larger because of needed repairs. The co-op defaulted on the mortgage after failing to reach a workout agreement with Citibank. Because of the problems, one-bedroom units had been offered recently for as little as $5,000.
In a co-op, an underlying mortgage is the loan used to buy, renovate or maintain the building. It is obtained by the co-op corporation, which may be controlled by occupying shareholders, or by the builder or conversion sponsor in cases where they still control the board. This mortgage differs from a share or end loan, which is obtained to finance the purchase of an individual unit. The shareholder also has a lease from the corporation to occupy the apartment.
To pay off the underlying mortgage, the shareholders make maintenance payments, which are also used for taxes, repairs, cash reserves and operating expenses. If a co-op falls behind in mortgage payments, the holder of the underlying mortgage can move to foreclose on the building.
Generally, though, co-ops are not foreclosed on, even if they have been in default for months, because they would revert to rent-stabilized status, and few buyers would want to own them, not even the holders of the underlying mortgage.
WHAT made Hamilton House an appealing buy -- there were three bidders and more than 30 parties that expressed interest in bidding -- is that it was never a rental before it became a co-op; it was built as a co-op.
The prospective new owner, Lennard A. Katz of Manhattan, who runs a family real estate business, the Katz Realty Group, believes that the building will fall under the city's rent-stabilization laws for only one or two years -- and only because the developer accepted a Section 421a tax abatement. After that, he believes he can charge market rents.
Even if the building were to remain rent-stabilized, though, he believes that the rents would be high enough to make the building profitable. He believes that at the worst rents would be rolled back to the level of the shareholders' last maintenance payments. Maintenance payments in the building currently run from $650 to $1,100 a month.
"I'm in for the long haul," Mr. Katz said.
The 421a program was authorized by the State Legislature at New York City's behest in 1972 in an effort to stimulate residential construction at a time of recession. It has been used in the construction of more than 67,000 apartments in the city -- the total includes condominiums, co-ops and rental buildings.
Harry G. Ryttenberg, a spokesman for the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal in Albany, which oversees rent stabilization in the city, said he was unsure how long or even if the building would qualify as rent-stabilized.
"We would have to examine all the circumstances carefully, and our legal department would render an option," he said.
AS it now stands, Mr. Katz is expected to take over the building this week and negotiate rents with the shareholders, many of whom have not only lost their equity in their apartments but also have share loans outstanding. Several lenders, according to Mr. Smith, are also calling in their share loans for immediate payment, citing the lack of equity backing them.
"A lot of people don't know what they are going to do," said Steven Schiesel, a lawyer, resident-shareholder and president of the Hamilton House five-member co-op board; he is also the only resident-shareholder on the board.
"I don't know what to do," he added, noting that he still owes $70,000 on his unit and plans to continue making payments of about $600 a month to the Dime Savings Bank just to preserve his credit.
"I do know, though, that I'll never buy another co-op again."
Even if the building becomes rent-stabilized, it is not clear what the rents would be. Some co-ops have argued that the rents should be the maintenance payments before the dissolution of the co-op. Some lenders, however, note that co-ops, as a pre-emptive way of dealing with this possibility, often reduce their maintenance payments to a bare minimum when a foreclosure is pending. The matter is pending in the courts.
If the building is made rent-stabilized, though, the shareholders would not be able to rent their units out for much more than the rent-stabilized level. The landlord would also not be obliged extend the leases if the units were occupied by subtenants, rather than former shareholders.
Mr. Schiesel speculated that the judge in the bankruptcy proceedings did not seek a workout of the defaulted mortgage because so many of the shareholders were investors rather than owner-occupants.
Mr. Smith also said that Mr. Katz has rebuffed his attempt to seek some sort of arrangement that would allow shareholders to keep ownership of their units.
"They are just not interested," he said.

HEADLINE: Hartford Mulls Stadium for All Seasons

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
STATE legislators, who agreed to build a $251 million stadium in an effort to lure the New England Patriots football team to Hartford -- only to have the Patriots decide to stay in Foxboro, Mass. -- may now be asked to help back a scaled-down complex with tenants that might include UConn football and basketball teams.
Though considerably smaller than the previously proposed stadium, the complex would have at least one additional feature: a dome that would enable it to house hockey and basketball games, concerts, circuses and other indoor events, in addition to football. 
 As envisioned by its main proponent, Lewis B. Rome, a Hartford lawyer and chairman of the University of Connecticut board of trustees, the stadium would become the home of the UConn football team -- which is expected to be elevated to Division I-A status -- and the home away from home of the Huskies men's basketball team. It also would replace the Hartford Civic Center as the home of the Hartford Whalers of the National Hockey League and would be host to other events now held at the Civic Center. Mr. Rome, the leading force behind the campaign to upgrade UConn's football program to Division I-A status, the top echelon of college football, is convinced that the stadium would lead to a renaissance for downtown Hartford, where it would be situated.
"The main question is whether such a stadium would produce sufficient revenue to justify it being built, and I'm convinced that the answer is yes," said Mr. Rome, a former State Senate majority leader.
Mr. Rome said some of the money would come from the private sector, but that, "the bulk would have to come from the state." Mr. Rome said he has had discussions with prospective investors but was not at liberty to discuss them. He did say he has received a commitment from William R. Berkley, a Greenwich businessman, to place a Canadian Football League team in Hartford if the stadium is built. Mr. Berkley, who has made a nonrefundable deposit of $100,000 for such a franchise, said in an interview he hoped to have the C.F.L. team play at the Yale Bowl in New Haven starting in the summer of 1996 if he receives assurances that the stadium will be built. The new stadium, he and Mr. Rome believe, could be ready for C.F.L. use by 1998.
As proposed by Mr. Rome, the stadium would have a capacity of about 42,000 for football, compared with the 65,000-seat stadium that had been promised the Patriots. Capacity would be about 30,000 for basketball, hockey, concerts and other events. He estimated that it would cost between $80 million and $120 million to build the complex on the same downtown site where the previously projected stadium was to have been built. (Some analysts say the stadium, as projected, could cost as much as $150 million).
As part of the overall project, Mr. Rome has suggested converting the Hartford Civic Center -- which would be within walking distance of the proposed stadium -- into a convention center at a cost of about $15 million. In the process, the coliseum, where hockey and basketball games and many other events are held, would probably be converted into an exhibition hall.
Such a plan would be far less costly than a new convention center, which has been proposed for a different site, and, Mr. Rome said, could cost as much as $250 million. Last December, UConn trustees approved a committee report calling for the upgrading of the Huskies' football program from Division I-AA to I-A. The report has been sent to the university's president, Harry Hartley, and to the UConn athletic director, Lew Perkins, who both favor the upgrading and are expected to move on it by November.
Far and away the biggest obstacle to upgrading the football program is the absence of a suitable stadium, one that seats at least 30,000 spectators, as required by the National Collegiate Athletic Association (Memorial Stadium, where the Huskies play their home football games on the Storrs campus, has a capacity of 16,200). The stadium proposed by Mr. Rome -- which some are already referring to as the "Rome Dome" -- would serve that purpose. Dr. Hartley said in an interview that the university is not in a position to build a larger stadium on its own, particularly in view of needed improvements on the Storrs campus.
But both the UConn president and Mr. Rome concede that another tenant, such as a C.F.L. team, could make a proposed stadium a more attractive and viable proposition to whoever might finance construction.
"There's no way it's going to be a UConn stadium," Dr. Hartley said. "We're adamant that it will not be a UConn budget decision. If it's built, it will have to be through private and public funding. But I think they'll be able to do it."
If UConn does move up to Division I-A in football -- a proposal that has met with strong resistance by many, if indeed not most, faculty members -- it would find itself playing such Big East football powers as Syracuse, Boston College, Pittsburgh and Miami, along with Notre Dame, West Virginia and Rutgers, which will join the conference as basketball members next year.
As for the new stadium, certainly not everyone favors the idea. Referring to what he called "the creative imagination that has gone into the Rome Dome concept," Denis Horgan, a columnist for The Hartford Courant, wrote, "If a small fraction of this imagination had gone into helping the university itself, maybe the place wouldn't have deteriorated the way it woefully has."
Gov. John G. Rowland has not expressed a view on the proposed stadium. But his spokesman, John Chapin, called it an "intriguing project."
"UConn 2000 has gotten our attention right now," Mr. Chapin said, referring to a comprehensive financial proposal now before the legislature to improve the university's infrastructure over a 10-year period. As the stadium proposal "becomes less hypothetical, we might have some thoughts on it."
But some legislative leaders are dubious about the stadium's chances. "Given the current fiscal condition of the state, it would be a tough sell," said William DiBella of Hartford, the State Senate minority leader.
"We have to take a look at anything that might create more revenue," he said. "However, I'd like to see private investment encouraged toward any stadium project.
Another Democratic legislator from Hartford, State Representative Thomas Ritter, the House Speaker, said, "It would be great to have a stadium in downtown Hartford, but I can't see that happening. First we have to take care of educational needs."
Both Mr. DiBella and Mr. Ritter expressed surprise when told that Mr. Rome's plan called for primarily state funding. "The bulk of the money can't come from the state," Mr. Ritter said. "That's just not going to happen."
State Senator James Fleming, a Republican from Simsbury who is the Senate majority leader, said legislators would be wary of such a proposal after having authorized bond money for the failed stadium plan for the New England Patriots. "The legislature is not about to move forward on a proposal like this unless we have real assurances that it makes sense economically," he said. "I personally would want to see a concrete, hard-core analysis."
Mr. Rome conceded that proponents of the stadium would have to be extremely persuasive in their arguments. "I realize it would be a tough sell unless a lot of things fall into place," said Mr. Rome. "But if it's built, the stadium would support itself easily."
Even if UConn decides against elevating its football program to Division I-A status, Mr. Rome said, the stadium could succeed. "We can do it without UConn football," he said. "but UConn football would be the frosting on the cake."
But some believe that is a bit disingenuous. Mr. Rome, an avid UConn sports booster, has been a major figure in pushing for the football upgrade.
Mr. Berkley, the head of W. R. Berkley Inc. in Greenwich, an insurance holding company, said he would place his Canadian Football League team elsewhere if the state declines to build a stadium in Hartford. "If no stadium is built, we'd have to look at other cities," he said.
Whether a C.F.L. team would draw sufficient spectators in Hartford is open to conjecture. For one thing, football has never had a strong hold on the Hartford area. And for another, the C.F.L. game differs in several ways from American football.
Furthermore, the only major league team that Hartford has had in modern times, the Whalers, have not drawn well, averaging fewer than 10,000 spectators in the 16,000-seat Hartford Civic Center Coliseum.
Another professional team, the Hartford Hellcats of the Continental Basketball Association, folded in January after not-quite-two losing seasons at the Civic Center Coliseum and after having received almost $1 million in loans from the Connecticut Development Authority.
Still, after including only Canadian cities for many years, the Canadian Football League has taken on an increasingly American look. When the season begins in July, six of the 14 teams will be in United States cities -- Baltimore, San Antonio, Memphis, Birmingham, Shreveport, La. and Jackson, Miss. Mr. Berkley's team would become one of two more expansion clubs that the league plans to add in the next few years.
Whether the league is able to place a team in Connecticut will depend largely on Governor Rowland and the State Legislature, along with any private investors who might think a new stadium in Hartford is a good investment.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Trinity Church as a Landlord;
Turning Hudson Square Area Into an Office Hub

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
GIVEN his druthers, the Rev. James G. Callaway Jr., the deputy for grants at Trinity Church, would probably rather talk about Trinity's good works. There are the interest-free loans for housing in the South Bronx. There are the new parishes it has helped set up. There are the community-based programs it supports.
But Father Jamie, as everyone calls him, does not flinch when the talk turns to Trinity Church as a tough commercial landlord. Over the years, the church has been as quick to evict deadbeats, as steadfast in keeping rents up and concessions down, as adamant about getting personal guarantees to back up leases, as any developer around. 
 Indeed, Father Jamie and the real estate folks sound a lot alike. "We find it difficult to evict tenants but we do it all the time," said Joseph T. Palombi, Trinity's executive vice president of real estate. Now hear Father Jamie: "In the grimmer days of the 90's, we cut grants in half and laid off 38 people, but we still put millions into the buildings. We have to preserve our patrimony."
And quite a patrimony it is. Trinity Church owns close to 6 million square feet, most of it in 27 buildings around Hudson Square, an area bounded roughly by Canal and West Houston Streets, Avenue of the Americas and the Hudson River. Over the last few years the church has pumped more than $100 million into its properties, all in hopes of converting the area, which Trinity got from Queen Anne of England in 1705, from a printing and manufacturing bastion to an office hub.
Now Trinity is looking at its retailing, too. It has asked New Spectrum Realty, a store leasing company, to study whether the old printing buildings should house fancy stores. "We need to know whether this area can develop the same cachet as the rest of SoHo," Mr. Palombi said.
That's pretty aggressive talk for a landlord that got into the active real estate business by default, in the literal sense of the word. By this century's turn, Trinity had given away or sold about 97 percent of Queen Anne's bequest. St. Luke's Hospital, Columbia College, numerous parishes, all sprang up on Trinity land.
Trinity rented most of the remaining land to developers, who built printing plants and other manufacturing buildings on it. The developers, with Trinity's permission, used the land to secure their mortgages. In the Great Depression, many of them defaulted. Trinity had a choice: Assume the mortgage payments, or lose its land.
It took Trinity until the mid-1950's to pay off its debts. And it was not until 1970 that Trinity formed a coherent strategy for the church itself, and for the part its patrimony would play. It decided to stop subsidizing affiliated chapels, and instead strengthen its own congregation and works program.
Slowly, Trinity redirected its real estate profits toward such church-owned programs as Trinity Institute, which trains clergy, and "Trinity Playhouse," a series of television dramas with religious underpinnings that run on cable channels. And it set up a grant program to help build housing and the like.
Off and on, Trinity thought about selling its buildings, "but we just never got a fair offer," recalled Walter F. Spardel, Trinity Real Estate's managing director. By the 1980's, Trinity had decided that real estate was a good long-term investment, provided the buildings generated more cash.
"The net profit from light industrial property is maybe $3 a square foot, and we knew offices would pay better than that," Mr. Palombi said.
In fact, Trinity began converting empty printing floors to office use in 1980. But since the printing plants still provided a fine cash flow for the buildings, Trinity felt little pressure to rush the process. And then the stock market collapsed in 1987, dragging the city's printing industry -- which, along with publishing, still made up about 80 percent of Trinity's tenancy -- down with it. In 1987, Trinity's buildings were almost full; by 1992 occupancy was down to 72 percent.
Increasingly, printing seemed a precarious basket to hold Trinity's financial nest egg. So the church decided to accelerate the conversion to offices.
"WE walked through Midtown South, looked at what they'd done with the old buildings, and said, 'Gosh, we can do this here,' " Mr. Spardel said.
Fortunately for Trinity, it had a small but elite tenant base to build on. In 1985, Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Worldwide, a huge London advertising agency, agreed to locate its New York office at 375 Hudson Street, a building at Houston Street that Tishman Speyer was erecting on Trinity land. In the ensuing three years, Della Femina, Travisano & Partners; Ephron, Raboy, Tsao & Kurnit; Cadwell Davis Partners, and several other ad agencies left midtown for Trinity-owned buildings like 345 and 350 Hudson and 100 Avenue of the Americas, all within a block or so of Saatchi's new home.
Today, Trinity has converted nearly two-thirds of its portfolio to offices. It has inspired other local landlords to do so as well.
"We converted to offices only after Trinity pioneered it," said Barry Gosin, a co-owner of 200 Varick Street, near West Houston, who says his building is fully rented. "They could take the chance first, because they don't borrow money. They can live with a 30-year or 40-year payback."
The payback will probably be quicker than that. Occupancy is back up to 80 percent, and Mr. Palombi expects it will be 85 percent by year end. He expects rents, which now still hover in the low teens, to go as high as $20 a square foot soon.
For now, Trinity is focusing on attracting advertising, entertainment and publishing companies, "that whole group of companies that really doesn't need stainless steel buildings and a Park Avenue address," Mr. Palombi said. And it is focusing on renting space it owns.
But those strategies are not set in stone. Five years ago Trinity happily let the developer Edward J. Minskoff build 101 Avenue of the Americas, on a parcel of Trinity land near Grand Street, as the headquarters of Local 32B-32J, the union of building-service employees. It came close to marketing 225 Varick Street, near West Houston, as a biotechnology center, then scuttled its plans when it realized that biotech companies need to be closer to research hospitals.
Nor is Trinity slamming the door on new construction. Mr. Spardel talks about building on the lot behind 345 Hudson Street, breaking through the walls, and creating 75,000-square-foot floors that could accommodate television studios. He even talks about building Trinity's first from-scratch project, on a parcel of land bounded by Varick, Canal, Grand and Sullivan Streets.
"We've already gotten the permits, we have lots of pretty pictures, we even have an offshore tenant in mind," said Mr. Spardel, who noted that the project was conceived before the recession made new construction unthinkable. "When the economy is finally right for this, we're ready to go for it."
IF word of mouth can help, Trinity may get some nice aid from past and former tenants, and even from some brokers. Some complain that negotiating with Trinity can be an excruciatingly slow process, because the real estate people do have to get approval for many things from the church leaders. But most also say that the church strikes fair deals, and that it sticks to the spirit as well as the letter of its contracts.
"They delivered a new lobby and everything else they said they would do to upgrade this building," said Ronald Fierman, chief financial officer of Warwick, Baker & Fiore, an advertising agency that signed on at 100 Avenue of the Americas when it was still being converted for office use.
"They are like any institutional landlord, you bring them a credit-worthy tenant and they'll respond to its needs," said James P. Quinn, an associate director at Cushman & Wakefield.
Even tenants Trinity has dislocated in its office-conversion process harbor little bitterness against the church. RPM Graphics had been at 100 Avenue of the Americas for several decades, and certainly intended to keep renewing its lease. The last time, about five years ago, Trinity refused.
"It cost us at least $1.5 million in renovations and such to move," said Robert Mastelone, RPM's owner. Mr. Mastelone remained loyal nonetheless. He has moved to 75 Varick Street, another Trinity building near Watts Street.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Agents Say That in Prime Areas, It's Like Early 1989;
For Large Co-ops, Prices Are Soaring

 BODY:
Bidding wars? Soaring prices? In Manhattan real estate?
No, this is not the mid- to late 1980's, but the city's top brokers all say it feels like it is, at least for apartments with more than eight rooms in blue-chip locations. 
 "People are paying top dollar -- to me, it feels like early 1989," said Will Hunt, co-owner of Hunt-Kennedy Real Estate. "Some poor guy just got outbid for the second time, and his agent is scrambling over the Upper East Side to find him another apartment."
According to statistics released last week by the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan real estate agency, there were 21 four-bedroom apartments for sale on Central Park West in December 1994; by mid-March, there were four left. On Park Avenue, there were 76 four-bedroom apartments available in December; now there are 34.
"Bidding wars are going on all the time," said Diane Ramirez, sales director of the Halstead Property Company. "We've had a couple of dozen already this year that sold over the asking price."
As an example, one broker told of a 12-room prewar apartment at Park Avenue and 77th Street that sold in May 1991 for $1.75 million. After $500,000 was spent to fix it up, the same apartment sold this year for $4.2 million.
It was on the market for less than 30 days. Other apartments sell even more quickly.
To find these scarce apartments, agents mail brochures to residents of posh buildings and call every friend-of-a-friend who might be selling. According to Ms. Ramirez, the apartments are bought by families that are planning to grow and by people with money who want to move to their "final" apartment before the interest rates, and the prices, go so high the big apartments are no longer a good investment.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
With Dreams of Croissants and Nova, South Orange Takes On the Malls

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

DATELINE: SOUTH ORANGE

 BODY:
Like other small towns across the nation, South Orange has been fighting a losing battle against shopping malls. Since the 1970's, when two malls were built nearby, business failures have turned the village's central business district into a checkerboard of shuttered storefronts.
But South Orange is fighting back with an offbeat approach to redevelopment. Anticipating a new commuter rail link that will open in 1996, and taking advantage of a 1992 state law giving greater clout to municipalities that want to finance their own urban renewal, it has begun what village officials hope will be a complete makeover. 
 "We understand that we will never compete with the malls for large stores," said Barbara Sacks, the South Orange village administrator. "What we can attract is the kind of small service businesses that you don't find in the malls."
That is the strategy behind the first phase of the village's plan. South Orange has raised $500,000 in low-interest financing for a developer to renovate its biggest commercial eyesore, a row of six blighted and mostly vacant stores on South Orange Avenue, directly under an elevated New Jersey Transit railroad station.
"The thing that makes this work, and could make things happen elsewhere in New Jersey, is that the village is using its own good credit to support redevelopment," said Cary Heller, the developer.
To be sure, the partnership between Mr. Heller and South Orange has not been without strife. The project was delayed for more than a month early this year, and nearly abandoned, when the village's Planning Board insisted that the developer seek several small tenants to provide a variety of services, and he refused to rule out the possibility of having only one tenant.
But that was resolved in late February, when Mr. Heller agreed to seek at least three tenants. Now, he says he is trying to lure a gourmet food store, a printing shop, a diner, a bakery and other small stores, and expects the first, the bakery, to move in by the end of June.
South Orange, meanwhile, has bigger plans. In January, the village trustees approved a blueprint for the blocks surrounding the train station, including a hotel, 220 new town house-style homes, a garage and a movie theater.
The cost, according to village officials, is projected at $57 million, all of it dependent on private investment at a time when the New Jersey economy remains weak.
But there are reasons the plan could work.
"This is a village with unusual advantages," said Patrick Henry, a partner in the Atlantic Group, an urban development consulting firm that has been advising South Orange. "There is reason to be enthusiastic that this will come together."
Although there is no single culprit in the decline of South Orange's business district, shopping mall culture has taken a huge toll. The Livingston Mall and the Short Hills Mall, both less than 20 miles from the village, have been luring shoppers for two decades, gradually pushing a furniture store, a shoe store, an art supply store and other retailers out of business.
But the village, with 16,000 residents, remains affluent. The median household income is over $65,000, according to the State Labor Department. Seton Hall University provides a tantalizing market for retailers, and many residents commute to high-paying jobs in Manhattan.
The village's link to Manhattan is about to become more convenient. New Jersey Transit is expected to begin operating the Kearny Connection, a rail line from Penn Station that will make its first westward stop in South Orange, next March. The new line will eliminate the need to make a connection in Hoboken, and could bring hundreds of additional commuters through town.
That prospect was what attracted Mr. Heller to the stores under the South Orange train station. Late last year, he formed a development concern called Lokko Motive Inc., and bought out the lease. To finance the deal, he persuaded South Orange to take advantage of the New Jersey Redevelopment Act, which lets villages underwrite development in a way used more commonly by states, by selling tax-free municipal bonds to extend low-interest loans.
With a $500,000 loan from the village, and with the new train service being readied over his stores, "my project makes sense even if none of the rest of the plan happens," Mr. Heller said. But Mrs. Sacks said the village was aggresively promoting its larger redevelopment scheme, with the new train link as its cornerstone. She said village officials had begun talks with New Jersey Transit to construct a parking garage near the station.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A developer plans to renovate stores under the South Orange train station. (Lenore Victoria Davis for The New York Times)
