LENGTH: 2607 words

HEADLINE: New Jersey, Dateline America

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
OLD-TIMERS in New Jersey like to tell the story of the former Newark mayor who used to say that wherever American cities were going, Newark would surely get there first. These days, though, as the millennium looms, that principle may apply best to New Jersey's place in the nation. Wherever America is heading, New Jersey appears to be on the cutting edge.
People in New Jersey may have known all along that the jokes missed the point (that the mosquito was not, in fact, the state bird). But the truth is getting harder for everyone else to deny: New Jersey has become the nation's laboratory -- the field station where political and social solutions are tested, a barometer for our psychic weather, a prototype-in-progress for what America may become. 
 The anti-tax movement took the Democrats hostage here in the early 1990's. Welfare reform sailed through. Now New Jersey is the stage on which the national Republican Party intends to prove that its program works. Governor Whitman is a national celebrity, patron saint of moderate Republicans. The Mayor of Jersey City, Bret Schundler, is a G.O.P. poster boy, dreaming about devolution and school vouchers just off Manhattan's western shore.
From health care to telecommunications, New Jersey is busy sloughing regulatory skin, unleashing its hospitals to duke it out in a Darwinian free market, its phone companies to blast into the fiber-optic future.
Out of the embers of its industrial past, New Jersey has risen to become something of a Southern California of the Right Coast -- the prototypical post-industrial, service-oriented state, its work force among the highest-earning and most highly educated in the nation.
The Garden State is now truly the Suburb State, redefining the country's future on its exurban frontier, where deer haunt the corporate campuses and urban escapees find peace on three-acre lots. New Jersey may be the most densely populated state in the nation, but only 10 percent of its people now live in its largest cities, decaying urban dinosaurs punished for their obsolescence.
And out beyond the pockmarked stretches of Route 22, the aging strip malls, lube shops and suburban blight, planners are plotting a new life not in villages or hamlets but in gleaming "activity centers" and "smoke-free shopping environments."
These days, Michael Aaron Rockland, a Rutgers University professor who teaches a course in Jerseyana, finds himself called upon to ponder the once unimaginable question: What ever happened to the Jersey joke?
"Rather than being, as we used to say around here, the armpit of the universe, New Jersey is, well, you pick the body part," Professor Rockland observed, not without a trace of regret.
If the jokes ever bothered people in New Jersey, all is forgotten. Or at least almost all.
"Nobody's laughing at New Jersey anymore," Governor Whitman crowed earlier this year (suggesting, perhaps inadvertently, that at least a smidgen of the state's civic inferiority complex had survived the boom). And, that smidgen notwithstanding, a new poll by The New York Times finds New Jerseyans strikingly content.
Nearly three out of four say they believe that their state and town are excellent or good places to live. And 60 percent predict that their community will be as good or better in 10 or 15 years. Traveling out of state, they declare their home turf proudly. Six in 10 say crime is not a problem where they live.
In interviews, many praised the state for its humble virtues: cleanliness, friendliness, safety, a temperate climate. The highways are well maintained, they said, and New Jersey is always close to somewhere else.
"Kearny has just about everything -- a decent shopping center, movies, nice parks," said Joan Rodrigues, 44, who teaches fifth grade in the Hudson County town. "We're near the entrance to just about every major road."
Most were less enamored of the condition of their public schools (52 percent rated them fair or poor) and of local property taxes (53 percent considered them too high). In their political affiliations, 31 percent considered themselves independents, roughly echoing a national Times poll taken last month.
Many New Jerseyans seemed tickled by their Governor's rising star. "New Jersey's image has got to be real positive with what our new Governor is doing," said John F. Zelesnik, a retired gas station owner and registered Democrat from Woodbridge.
As for New York City, few New Jerseyans seem to feel that they live in its shadow. The fact is they simply don't think about it much. New York is at best a convenience -- a place to visit, but not a place to work or live. (Indeed only 8 percent of those who were employed said they worked outside New Jersey.)
Dr. Joel R. L. Ehrenkranz, a 43-year-old endocrinologist and scientific director of a burgeoning biotech company in Morristown, is convinced that he and his company are about as well situated as they could possibly be.
Dr. Ehrenkranz was a physician in private practice who happened to find a way of measuring body temperature through urine. Suddenly, in the late 1980's, his gizmo was in demand -- and he knew nothing about engineering or business. But he was in New Jersey. So he found researchers at Rutgers to help him set up a manufacturing line, and innumerable veterans of New Jersey's vast pharmaceutical industry to help him build a business and expand.
Now, his company, Franklin Diagnostics Inc., cranks out millions of dollars' worth of ovulation-predictor kits, pregnancy tests and more, and, according to Dr. Ehrenkranz, regularly turns down invitations to move out of state.
"All the resources that we need -- patent, financing, regulatory, manufacturing, quality control -- are in area code 201 or 908," he said.
What's more, Dr. Ehrenkranz gets to ride his bicycle 10 miles to work. Bluebirds nest in his yard. He lives within walking distance of two national parks -- and 22 minutes from Newark International Airport when he needs to fly around the world.
The Rush to Suburbanize
In many ways, of course, New Jersey has always been ahead of the curve. Its cities industrialized early and deteriorated first. Manufacturing jobs evaporated early, but a high-tech, information-based service economy took root.
Because of its population density, the state tackled many problems first. It is now a leader in environmental regulation and planning. Its turnpike antedated the Interstate system. It had to: traffic was choking the state.
But what it also did first, and furiously, was suburbanize. For more than a century, it has been chopping countryside into towns, laying communities like industrial carpet from the Delaware River to the George Washington Bridge.
Deep into the 1980's, New Jersey boomed. Fifty-six thousand new housing units went up in 1986 alone. In places like Somerset County, the state's "edge cities" have proved precursors of others now sprouting nationwide.
New Jersey's older cities, meanwhile, were left to waste away. One of the richest states, it houses some of the country's poorest cities.
In Newark, Msgr. William J. Linder has watched the population dwindle from 440,000 to 275,000 since he was assigned to his first parish in 1960. As jobs fled, people were left behind with no way to follow. Now the community-development corporation that he runs, New Community Corporation, operates 3,000 units of housing, a nursing home, seven day-care centers and the first new shopping center in the Central Ward in 30 years.
"We train people for jobs that don't exist," he said sadly. "It's the most pitiful situation in the world." He described Newark as "probably one of the worst cases of abandonment of a city."
Some argue that the reasons were as much racial as economic.
"White folks walked away from the cities," said Mark Fury, the 37-year-old Mayor of Plainfield. His city, he said, was 80 percent white and Republican when he was growing up; now it is 65 percent black and 10 percent Hispanic, and is controlled by the Democrats.
"What happened in Plainfield happened in Newark, Trenton, Camden," Mayor Fury said. "While we like to cast it politely in terms of what happened to the cities, the reality is white people walked away from black people because they were afraid."
In the end, power and money shifted firmly to the suburbs -- just as they are doing, more gradually, nationwide. And that shift underlies the anti-tax and anti-government mood that carried in a Republican Legislature and Ms. Whitman.
Why it happened first in New Jersey is partly a quirk of the electoral calendar: New Jersey holds off-year elections. So Republicans wrested control of New Jersey in 1993. A year later, much of the country followed.
But New Jersey's voters are also in many ways the quintessential suburban voters, according to political analysts. They are fiscally, but not socially, conservative; many are baby boomers, feeling economically pinched.
Their party loyalty is weak. And polling shows they tend to know less about their candidates than voters elsewhere, in part because most of their television news comes from out-of-state stations that neglect New Jersey news.
"We're not a bad barometer," said Cliff Zukin, who did polling in New Jersey for many years. "We've got a larger floating middle which can react more quickly to any passions of the moment."
Take Jeanette Kohler, an account manager from Montclair. She had always voted Democratic. But she found herself shifting her allegiance and voting for Mrs. Whitman, for reasons she admits she cannot fully explain.
Now Ms. Kohler, who says she was "never political," is president of a newly formed citizens' group in Montclair dedicated to stopping the town's property taxes from rising any further.
"Whitman seemed to be more in touch with the present and the future," Ms. Kohler said. "I can't even think what it was. I felt New Jersey needed some new blood in that position. I felt she was a forward-thinking politician."
Mrs. Whitman emerged from that election and her tax-cutting first year in office as a model for Republican gubernatorial candidates throughout the Northeast (though in recent days predictions of a large revenue shortfall has given the Democrats new ammunition). And the state has emerged as a kind of laboratory for Republican ideas.
In Jersey City, Mr. Schundler is ensconced as the first Republican elected Mayor since 1917, elected by 69 percent of the vote in a city where a tiny fraction of the voters are registered Republicans.
At age 36, he has become a darling of Speaker Newt Gingrich. Party leaders hold him up as a harbinger of a new generation of Republican politicians with inner-city appeal. In his wood-paneled office in City Hall, he sits in suspenders and shirt sleeves, a computer purring at his side, as he beats the drum for devolving power to municipalities and for regulatory revolution.
"My own proposal would be to take a machete to the regulations," he said, sketching schemes to use welfare money for "neighborhood improvement districts" and school vouchers.
The Republican-controlled Legislature, meanwhile, has begun dismantling one of the country's more elaborate systems of hospital regulation in an attempt to subject the state's hospitals to what it hopes will be healthy competition. As a result, hospitals across the state are engaged in a frenzy of affiliating and "networking," scrambling to survive by lowering costs and being able to compete for contracts with insurers.
Inner-city hospitals, however, are feeling left out. Cathedral Health Care Systems, which runs hospitals in Newark and Orange, says it is facing a loss of $33 million in uncompensated care for the poor as a result of deregulation.
"How are we going to insure that those safety-net institutions that take care of the poor and underserved are still going to be there?" wondered Frank Fumai, the president and chief executive officer of Cathedral.
Worries on the Edge
 Other questions loom in the new cutting-edge state.
Suburban living, as it turns out, comes at a high social cost. New Jersey residents spend more time than ever in their cars. Traffic is frequently jammed, even though the state tops all others in road miles per square mile.
Farmland is dwindling. The air is polluted. People fear that the state's water supply will be the next to go if suburbia continues its relentless march outward, leapfrogging its way toward the New Jersey Highlands.
"We're like early pastoral people," said Richard C. Leone of Princeton, the former New Jersey Treasurer and former chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "We slash and burn and move on."
Others worry that the state's new centers lack a sense of community, that it is impossible to go on foot from office park to mall, that edge cities will never be places to, say, hold a parade on the Fourth of July.
Meanwhile, property taxes climb relentlessly upward in support of services that people have grown to expect, and towns find themselves lured into the game of "ratable chase" -- the competition for big property-tax generators -- just to pay their bills.
At the same time, city living strikes many as no option.
Barbara L. Lawrence made a conscious decision to leave the suburbs for a city, moving from Plainsboro in search of "a real community." She found it on a narrow Hoboken street where butcher shops bookend row-house blocks.
But she and her husband pay for it. Their property taxes come to nearly $8,000 for an 1,800-square-foot house on a 14-by-100-foot lot. And they avoid the public schools by sending their son to private school, 25 minutes away.
"We've allowed our cities to deteriorate to such a point where they are no longer an alternative," said Ms. Lawrence, in the kitchen of her 100-year-old house. "I don't think people are wrong. They are making absolutely rational choices."
As a result, Ms. Lawrence now works as executive director of New Jersey Future, a group that works to implement New Jersey's land-use plan, which was intended to avoid further sprawl by concentrating growth in certain areas.
But even state officials admit the plan has "gums, not teeth." And there are many who prefer it that way, convinced planners are trying to dictate a life style that people reject.
"You cannot straitjacket society," said Patrick J. O'Keefe, chief executive officer of the New Jersey Builders Association. "Planning should be steeped in the reality of contemporary life."
For the time being, that reality in New Jersey includes the impulse to go ever West, to build a house on a three-acre lot, to glimpse wild turkey at the bird feeder and a coyote crossing the next field.
Ned Ward tells a story about building his first house. He chose a steep, rock-strewn site in New Vernon. He bought brick from Bayonne. When the truck pulled up, the driver got out and said, "Christ, who'd want to live here?"
"And I thought, 'My God, isn't this wonderful?' " recalled Mr. Ward, a real-estate agent in New Vernon. "We all think we have a little piece of paradise where we live. And I think it's wonderful that we all don't like vanilla."
Now Mr. Ward sells his version of paradise to bank presidents pursuing privacy. And Morris County is no longer what it was when Mr. Ward was growing up there, trapping mink and muskrat and shooting pheasant with a BB gun.
Does it worry him, what is happening to his slice of New Jersey?
"Compared to the way it was in 1945? Yup," he said. "But I suspect it's quite rural compared to what it will be in 2025."
Cheerfully, he concluded: "The only thing that's constant is change."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Megastores are Making Over the Highway Retailing Landscape

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Until last summer, shoppers looking for pet supplies along Route 10 in East Hanover had one choice: NJ Pets. It was a modest 1,500-square-foot store for all seasons, stocked with a limited selection of pet food, dog and cat toys, and a nail-clipping and bathing service.
But suddenly, there are five pet stores in a two-mile stretch. Hanover Pet Center opened last July about a quarter-mile from NJ Pets. Petland Discounts arrived in February in the shopping center next to Hanover. And Petco, an 18,000-square-foot megastore, opened a half-mile away in December. For shoppers who can wait until July, Pet Food Giant will unveil an 18,000-square-foot store half a mile down the road in Livingston. 
 Even NJ Pets has undergone a change, expanding into an 11,000-square-foot space last August.
The growth in size and numbers of those stores is a window into recent changes in retailing in New Jersey.
Along six major highways in the northern half of the state, retailers are moving in and getting bigger. "For Lease" signs in front of vacant stores have been replaced by signs that say "Opening Soon" on hangar-sized buildings.
Retail vacancies fell to 3.2 percent in 1995 from 5.3 percent the previous year, according to a recent survey conducted by R.J. Brunelli and and Company, a retail leasing firm in Old Bridge.
Many analysts agree that the retail sector has rebounded somewhat after several years of slugishness. But they point out that shoppers' appetite for bargains has favored the proliferation of "big boxes," giant stores of more than 15,000 square feet with no frills and discount prices.
"If someone were to survey the new space that's been built across the country, they'd probably find that over 75 percent is big-box centers as opposed to neighborhood centers, which would typically be anchored by a supermarket or a small-strip center," said Richard Brunelli, president of the Old Bridge firm.
Those big stores have long been a staple for shoppers in the West and the South. But for years, they were absent from New Jersey because of high rents and tight space.
Then came the economic recession of the late 1980's. Numerous retailers, including the McCrory's discount chain, Herman's sporting goods, and National Brands Outlet men's clothing, filed for bankruptcy and vacated thousands of square feet of retail space. Real estate prices slumped.
That paved the way for the giants.
On Route 10, Bradlees, Sports Authority, Office Max and Computer City have built stores in the last year. On Route 46 between West Paterson and Dover, Home Depot, BJ's Wholesale Club and Comp USA have appeared. And on Route 22 between Union and Somerville, Tops Appliance City, Sneaker Stadium, Staples and Pet Food Giant are the newest tenants.
This is good news for shoppers who like one-stop bargain shopping and don't miss the personal service that shops in small downtown areas often provide.
"Value is what I look for, whether it's service or price," said Diane Bowser of Morristown, who was reviewing Petco's selection of more than 50 kinds of fish food (including frozen) on a recent evening.
But some of the success of the big discounters comes at the expense of merchants in the middle -- stores in the 10,000-square-foot range that occupy strip malls or neighborhood shopping centers.
The owner of NJ Pets, the first of the pet stores on Route 10, has felt the squeeze. "Like any retailer, you're concerned when anyone opens up," said Tom Measday, who with his brother, Jim, opened the store in 1987. Now, "the consumer gets overloaded," he said. "I wouldn't be surprised if someone had to fold."
"Before, you had department stores, off-price stores, specialty stores, discount stores, and people operated within their own niches and there wasn't much crossover," said Gene Kosack, president and chief executive officer of NBO, the Fair Lawn-based store which is closing 21 of its 34 stores. "Today, you can take the walls down and just write down 'Price.' "
The trend toward bigger stores has not translated into new retail development, however. Instead, "it's the recycling of the properties that have been sitting vacant on the market for a while," said Milt Meyerson, retail director of Weichert Commercial Realtors in Morris Plains.
With the megastores occupying more storefronts, smaller merchants have had to adjust, with lower prices, more advertising, better-looking displays and improved service.
In Roseland, Rogers & Sheldon Inc.-Lumber Barn decided to open on Sundays, renovate its showroom, and offer "best everyday pricing" to compete with Home Depot. "They woke a lot of people up in our industry," said John Misko Jr., the company president.
In East Hanover, the Hanover Pet Center will drop its dog and cat supplies when Pet Food Giant opens this summer, and specialize instead in imported coral and exotic rodents like Chilean dwarf opossums and gerbils from Egypt. "The market is definitely finite, said Mark Gaglioti, a co-owner. "We're all vying for the same customers."

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
In Lincoln Park, the Symbolism of the Siren

BYLINE: By Joe Sharkey 

 BODY:
IN TOWNS with volunteer fire departments, the cricket chirp of the electronic beeper has decisively replaced the primal howl of the municipal siren.
Yet in Lincoln Park, in the northeast corner of Morris County, those Cold War-vintage sirens came wailing back full force last week, even though all 60 of the town's volunteer firefighters carry beepers. 
 In recent years, the town's six sirens had fallen into disrepair. Occasionally , they went off on their own, triggered by a vagrant microwave from a cellular phone or garage-door opener.
"Some people have expressed extreme dismay," said the Mayor, David G. Baker Jr. On a couple of occasions, some people even shimmied up telephone poles to snip a wire or two to get some sleep.
The Mayor and some Council members inadvertently mobilized the 87-year-old Fire Department with comments at a recent Council meeting that were taken as anti-siren. "What we said was that we wouldn't have an objection to removing the fire sirens," the Mayor pointed out the other day.
Firefighters quickly doused the anti-siren talk. Last week, after hasty repairs, four of the six sirens were back in business, same as when the first siren was clamped on a downtown pole in 1923.
Why does a town with beepers need sirens?
"To signal school snow closings," said one firefighter.
"Floods," another explained.
"Civil defense," suggested a third.
Sirens, of course, are supposed to be loud and intrusive. In old industrial towns, sirens once had to compete with the factory whistles that shrieked out starting time, lunch time and quitting time. In more recent times, people raised in small towns recall their fathers sitting the family down at the table to review the fire-alarm codes: One siren blast is a brush fire. Two is more serious. Three is a big one. Short sustained toots at regular intervals? Why, that's nuclear war, kids. The Russians are coming!
In little towns on the commuter trade routes like Lincoln Park, 25 miles from New York City, cultural change accelerated in the 1980's.
"When I first came on the force in 1967," Police Chief Ken West recalled, "we would be sent out on calls not by street addresses but by people's names." Lincoln Park was then still a semi-rural town on seven square miles of flood plain beside the Pompton River. In the 80's, when the town's bucolic allure combined with its proximity to major highways to ignite a building boom, the population rose 25 percent, to nearly 11,000. Some of them became anti-siren people.
Mayor Baker, who likes to keep everybody as happy as economically possible, has staked out his ground on the issue.
"I'm in the dead middle now," he said. "In this job, I have enough people beating up on me as it is." The town's budget this year for the Fire Department is $75,000, of which the firefighters have set aside about $3,000 to keep the sirens working right. "It's their decision," said the Mayor.
Few departments now depend solely on sirens. Those that do retain sirens see them as a backup, and as a symbolic gesture to the firefighters themselves.
But symbolism goes only so far when money is tight, and towns that use sirens have had to make compromises. In Bergen County, Tenafly officials began hearing complaints about eight years ago from people who had moved into the big houses in East Hill, which was also the location of Tenafly's loudest siren. "They hollered, and the town had to move the siren to a secluded park," grumbled Harvey Eisner, chief of the Tenafly volunteer department. Tenafly now hits its sirens only between 7 A.M. and 7 P.M.
In Lincoln Park, one firefighter spoke the other day about how his young son's eyes widen when the siren goes off and Dad thunders out the door. Then he dug into his back pocket for his beeper, which he held in the palm of his hand as if it were a wet sponge. "This thing, you could leave it in the kitchen, you know?"
At the main firehouse, a small group of firefighters agreed that the sirens should always remain. "If your house goes up in flames, then that siren is music to your ears," one man said.
His colleagues nodded gravely. Then one of them recalled that a siren had gone off accidentally a few nights earlier. "I couldn't get back to sleep for an hour," he complained. His buddies glared him into silence.

HEADLINE: THE TRASHING OF PROFESSIONALISM

 BODY:
Much of Louis Menand's argument against term limits for political officeholders rests upon the notion of lack of transferability of skills from one profession to another ("The Trashing of Professionalism," March 5). Yet, the very idea of education is to transfer skills. Moreover, corporations frequently have programs to rotate workers from one position to another to cross-fertilize the organization with fresh ideas and to impart new skills to employees.
In an outstanding example of skills transferability, Adam Smith transformed himself from professor of moral philosophy to become the "father of economics"! Smith never seemed to believe in "disinterestedness" either; for he said, "it is not from the benevolence of the butcher, the baker, or the candlestick maker that we get our daily bread, but rather from their greed." 
 Modern management theory recognizes the disadvantages as well as the advantages of division and specialization of labor. Today, even production workers frequently are found to be more efficient when they have responsibility for the finished product rather than one repetitive operation.
Making pins, with "18 distinctive tasks," is not the same as serving as a U.S. Senator.
 
MARTIN LAURENCE
Professor of Economics and Finance
William Paterson College
Wayne, N.J.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

AUTOS
It Ain't Broke, but Fix It
Chrysler's message to mini-van owners, apparently, is this: Your tailgate latches are not a safety hazard, but come in and we'll replace them -- free. Huh? Why not replace the perfectly good headlights while they're at it? You'd be excused for finding Chrysler's deal with regulators a bit convoluted, but it all comes down to that ugly word "recall." Even though 29 deaths have been linked to the latches' tendency to pop open in crashes, Chrysler didn't want this to be an official recall, and it got its way. A recall, you see, wouldn't look too great in some coming lawsuits. But how, asked one safety advocate, do you get van owners to come in if you're "telling them there is no hazard"? (Don't rush in, by the way -- it'll take months to build enough latches.)

BANKING
The Biggest Get Bigger
Nomination for understatement of the week: a merger with the Mitsubishi Bank would, in the words of the Bank of Tokyo's president, "make an interesting bank." Interesting, that is, as in huge. The merger of those Japanese banks will create, by far, the world's largest bank -- with $819 billion in assets, it will have more than three times the assets of the not exactly tiny Citicorp -- and 100 times the assets of Bill Gates. Will life change for the rest of the world? Not really. Japan's always had the bank giants, and those banks have been trimming overseas activities, and that's not expected to change. In California, though, Union Bank is 70 percent owned by Bank of Tokyo, and Bank of California is owned by Mitsubishi. No doubt either they'll be merged or one will be sold.

UPHEAVALS
Will the Flag's Colors Be Next?
Americans face a wrenching adjustment. No, it isn't the death of the New Deal, the fall of Communism. It's -- brace yourself -- the colors of M&M's, a constant for nearly half a century. M&M's were born in 1941, in six colors (brown, yellow, red, orange, green and violet). In 1949, tan replaced violet, and that mix outlasted Elvis, Liberace, even Nixon. But Mars Inc. concluded that people don't like tan and ran a poll to pick a new color. And last week it named the winner: blue (even with Communism dead, people weren't ready for pink; it got just a 10 percent vote). The new mix is due in September. In the meantime, save those tans; they'll be collectors' items (if they don't melt).

EXECUTIVE SUITE
Sex. $20 Million. Read On.
Odd as it may sound, this seems to have been W.R. Grace's message to J.P. Bolduc: You've been accused of sexual harassment, so you'd better resign as chief executive, and instead of a $15 million farewell handshake, let's make it $20 million. Yes, when Mr. Bolduc quit unexpectedly a month ago, the official version featured executive-suite boilerplate: "differences of style and philosophy." Plus that $5 million bonus. But last week it turned out that a former Federal judge advising the board had concluded that, though Mr. Bolduc was vehement in his denials, allegations of sexual harassment were on solid ground. Add to that the recent resignation of J. Peter Grace as chairman, and it's not exactly a smooth passing of the baton for a $5 billion company.

TELEPHONES
Whose Long-Distance Savings?
Americans must be as sick of hearing about long-distance deals as they are of that Los Angeles trial. But at least the O.J. lawyers, pro and con, don't call you or mass-mail you or ad-blitz you with the latest twist (well, not yet). The question now is whether AT&T, MCI et al. will now rush to tell you the latest news -- that the F.C.C. last week cut by $1 billion a year the access charges they must pay local phone companies, the biggest single cost cut since the Bell breakup. The access charge is a big part of a call's cost -- 4 cents a minute, on each end -- and long-distance companies have been lobbying hard to get them down. But watch carefully to see if those savings are passed along (or -- horrors! -- pay for even more aggressive marketing).

TRAVEL
Agents' Fees: Never Mind
It's the old story. Airlines get together and trumpet some historic change, but then, under market pressure, things slip right back where they were. A few years ago, American, with much huffing and puffing about simplified fares, swept away all the nonsense of having 97 different fares for the same route, and many other carriers piped up, "Me too." But there are no simple skies, and when that became clear, the notion collapsed. Then this February came a "revolution" in travel agents' fees: No more 10 percent commissions, the airlines said -- the top fee is $50 for a round-trip domestic ticket. But cracks are already appearing: Continental is offering agents a $50 "bonus payment" for some costly tickets, and Delta's offering incentives, too. Consumer tip: while this backtracking sorts itself out, don't let yourself get steered to a high-commission fare that's not the best deal.

INCOME TAXES
It's in the Form? So What?
Tax season wasn't already complicated enough, right? Tax forms, it seems, say the self-employed can deduct 25 percent of health-insurance costs. The trouble is, that deduction expired in 1993. But the I.R.S. put it in the form anyway, assuming it would be reinstated. Well, it hasn't -- yet. Why rush? April 17 is two weeks away. The House did vote it back in last week, but the Senate has still to act. If it affects you, better not file till the last minute. . . . Also, for $250-plus donations, you can now, if necessary, get the required receipt after filing.

MARKETS
Stocks Hit a Bad Bump
The stock market heard what it wanted to hear most of the week, and the Dow industrials bumped to a few more new highs. First the Fed met without raising interest rates. Then new-home sales fell 14 percent, to the lowest point in three years -- investors like things cooling off. But Friday morning the bubble burst, partly because of a report that fourth-quarter G.D.P. had grown at a 5.1 percent rate -- too hot for comfort. This was compounded by worries about the dollar -- it rose 2 percent on Thursday after Germany cut its interest rates, but traders wanted more. As a result, the Dow plunged 60 points in the opening minutes, though it later steadied to be off just 14 for the day.

INVESTING
Ready! Set! Lose Your Shirt!
Speaking of Barings -- O.K., nobody's spoken of Barings lately; that's why an update is in order. Nicholas Leeson, who has insisted that he was being a company man when his risky trading brought down Barings, is in a prison in Frankfurt -- that's where he was arrested, en route from Singapore -- as Singapore tries to extradite him on fraud charges. Back in London, though, a stiff upper lip has curled into a sly grin: The Independent is running a "Lose Your Bearings" contest. The goal: create an imaginary Asian stock portfolio, and see how much you can lose. Whoever loses the most by April 4 gets a vacation to Singapore -- with, yes, a stopover in Frankfurt (not, presumably, in handcuffs).

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS: FUNDS WATCH;
Litmus Test For Fund Managers

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
ADD one specific set of credentials to the long list of desirable qualities in a fund manager. That is C.F.A., or chartered financial analyst.
Stock fund managers with that designation have turned in superior performance, according to a study by Ravi Shukla and Sandeep Singh, assistant professors of finance at Syracuse University and the State University of New York at Brockport, respectively. 
 In an article in the Financial Analysts Journal, the academics said they examined the returns of 223 stock funds that kept the same managers from July 1988 through June 1993. After breaking the funds into two groups, they found that the funds run by chartered financial analysts had higher returns than the others. The difference was most pronounced among aggressive-growth funds.
To become a chartered financial analyst, money managers must pass three tests on securities, accounting and similar matters. Roughly half the people who take the tests pass the first two parts, and three-quarters pass the final one. There were 28,000 candidates this year, up from 7,100 in 1987. To find information about a manager's education and training, check the fund prospectus or call the fund company.
 
Getting Together
 The merger pace is picking up. The Twentieth Century group, whose speciality is stock funds, is acquiring Benham Management International, a group that specializes in bond funds and is based in Mountain View, Calif. The deal needs the approval of Benham's shareholders. The combined group would manage $37 billion in more than 50 funds, all sold without sales charges.
The Colonial Group, Boston, is merging with Liberty Financial Companies, also of Boston, which manages 22 funds, many under the Stein Roe name.
United Asset Management picked up tiny but powerful Pilgrim Baxter & Associates, which runs PBHG Growth and PBHG Emerging Growth.
 
Breather for Bonds?
 With the dollar dipping to new lows practically every day, should bond buyers worry? Though the dollar is not necessarily healthy for the long term, the worries about its condition are overblown, said William H. Gross, an expert on fixed-income investing with the Pimco family of funds. Because Americans don't save enough, he said, the country relies on the savings of strangers, meaning long-term problems. But the Federal Reserve will probably sit tight for some time rather than raise interest rates further. "It's the perfect circumstance for a money manager who believes that bonds won't go up much, won't go down much, but will earn an attractive coupon along the way," he said.
 
Change at Fidelity
 Jeffrey Ubben resigned as manager of the $4 billion Fidelity Value fund to join Richard C. Blum & Associates, an investment firm in San Francisco. His successor is Bettina Doulton, manager of Fidelity's Advisor Equity-Income and VIP Equity-Income funds.
 
Tax Help
 Just in time for tax season, Scudder Funds has published a new version of its booklet, "Tax Issues for Mutual Fund Investors." Call 800 225-2470, extension 8444, for a free copy. "Tax Do's and Don'ts for Mutual Fund Investors" is available without charge from the Investment Company Institute at 1401 H Street N.W., Suite 1200, Washington, D.C. 20005.
 
New Funds
 Warburg Pincus Japan OTC is a way to bet on small Japanese stocks and comes from the people who brought you the top-performing Warburg Pincus International fund.
Small stocks in the United States are the province of Stein Roe Special Venture.
Price Capital Opportunity aims for capital growth and has great flexibility to buy growth and value stocks and big and small stocks, but the portfolio will be concentrated in a small number of issues, meaning greater risk.
Matthews International Capital Management, San Francisco, has started Matthews Korea, the first mutual fund here to invest heavily in South Korea.
 
In Brief
 To attract new shareholders, Investment Advisers Inc. has reduced the initial purchase requirement for its IAI funds to $1,000 from the usual $5,000 through mid-April.
T. Rowe Price Adjustable-Rate U.S. Government, never a stellar performer, moved to another investment category on March 31, when it changed its name to Short-Term U.S. Government.

HEADLINE: Goldilocks Settles In, but Will Bears Be Back?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
THIS bull market has left some investors ecstatic, and many unhappy. The bears scornfully call it the "Goldilocks market," their way of sneering at the conventional wisdom that the economy will grow just right -- not too fast, setting off inflation, and not too slow, damaging corporate profits. But the cash keeps pouring in, and prices keep rising.
This year's rise, after a lackluster 1994, is a continuation of the bull market that began in 1990, as that year's recession was ending, and can be dated as far back as 1975. It has been fueled by factors as immediate as rapidly rising profits and as long-term as the baby boom generation's growing concern with retirement. 
 The strong profit growth for many companies has depressed their need for new capital and thus served to depress the volume of new stock issues sold. Far more money is pouring into the stock market than can be absorbed by the new issues.
And long-term interest rates, after rising sharply for much of last year, have declined, making stocks more competitive with fixed-income investments. At the peak in early November, shortly before the last time the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates, 30-year Treasury bonds yielded 8.16 percent. Now they yield 7.43 percent.
Now, for money managers and individual investors who missed the sudden spurt in the major market averages, the question is whether to leap in or wait for a drop. And for those who decide to buy, the big issue is whether to chase the winners -- most especially the semiconductor stocks that have zoomed and boomed, although they stumbled late last week -- or to search among the many laggards, hoping to find bargains.
Stocks of companies with large foreign businesses -- which may see reported profits rise because the dollar has fallen so much against the Japanese yen and most European currencies -- also have done well.
Stocks of economically sensitive industries like automobiles, steel and industrial equipment -- the cyclicals in Wall Street parlance -- have done the worst in this year's rally. Morgan Stanley's index of cyclical stocks has risen, but it remains 4 percent below its peak of early 1994, before the market began to be worried about a possible economic slowing brought on by higher interest rates.
Since Thanksgiving, when the market hit its recent low, 29 of the 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average have risen, and the average is up 13 percent. The only loser in the bunch is Bethlehem Steel, but other laggards include Alcoa and Caterpillar, as well as big oil companies.
"The big surprise" of the stock market in coming months "may be that these economically sensitive stocks come alive," said Byron Wien, the chief United States strategist at Morgan Stanley. Caterpillar had been down for 1995 until last week, when Morgan Stanley put out a strong buy recommendation.
In fact, it is possible that last week marked a turnaround within the stock market. For a couple of days at the end of the week, it was the time for the biblical injunction "the last shall be first" to come true. Both technology stocks and international companies weakened, while the cyclicals showed strength and interest rates rose. Then on Friday, a report of strong growth at the end of last year scared some investors and put the stock market on a roller coaster ride that left it a bit lower.
Even with that dip, the Standard & Poor's 500, the general standard of comparison for American institutional investors, rose 9 percent in the quarter, its best showing since the first quarter of 1991. But it appears that well over two-thirds of money managers fared worse than the S.& P. In part, that reflects holdings in small stocks and foreign stocks, both of which have lagged. For a money manager, it is embarrassing to lag the S.& P., so there is less joy on Wall Street than might be expected. "You have managers way behind," said David Shulman, Salomon Brothers chief strategist, who has been bearish.
That has not been a problem for those betting on technology. The success of those stocks -- particularly the companies that make semiconductors or computer software -- has set off an amazing boom in initial public offerings. When a company decides to go public, it gives a range of prices at which it wants to sell shares. These days, tech stocks almost always raise that price before they go public, but even so the demand sends the prices up sharply after trading began. Last week brought Datastream Systems, a software company that wanted to sell stock for $11 to $13 a share, got $15, and saw the shares immediately leap to $21 in public trading.
Perhaps the most amazing performance of a stock index came from the Philadelphia Stock Exchange's index of 16 semiconductor makers. From Oct. 4 through Tuesday, the index was up 55 percent, with most of that gain coming in the last two months. But it then fell 6 percent by week's end, in what bulls called a momentary pause.
The argument for such stocks has been that the computer boom, and the ever wider use of semiconductors in other products, has made their manufacturers the growth stocks of tomorrow. And that has been aided by the rise of what is politely called "momentum investing," which means buy what goes up and sell what goes down.
MUTUAL funds have climbed on board, to the extent that many diversified funds have a third of their assets in technology stocks. It is not uncommon to see Fidelity funds with 15 percent or more of a tech company's stock. If -- the bears would say when -- such institutions turn negative, the falls could be precipitous.
Most Wall Street wisdom holds that the end is not near. Intel, the premier company in semiconductors, "is still selling at nine times estimated earnings," argues Charles Clough, the chief market strategist at Merrill Lynch, adding that the expansion of capacity in semiconductors -- typically a warning sign -- has been restrained. "I think the semicondictors still have a long way to go," he said.
All that seems absurd to money managers like William Fleckenstein of Olympic Capital Management in Seattle, which has bet against technology stocks by selling them short, and has lost money. "People forget that the technology business is one of the worst businesses you can be in," he said. "Every day, you are trying to obsolete the competition and yourself. There are very few Microsofts and Hewlett-Packards."
A few years ago, that was the conventional wisdom and many such stocks were very cheap. But it has been more than three years since technology stocks began outperforming the market. Since the end of 1991 the Standard & Poors 500 is up about one-third. The semiconductor stocks in the index have more than tripled during the same period.
It is a reasonable bet that such stocks will continue to be more volatile than the market as a whole, but most of them are by no means cheap. So it may be safer to buy stocks that have lagged. Auto stocks and many transportation companies -- rails and trucks -- have done poorly in large part because of concerns that the economy is slowing. If those concerns turn into recession fears, the whole stock market could be risky. But if instead it begins to appear that growth will continue at an acceptable level for a couple of years, those stocks could benefit.
By many traditional standards, stocks are not cheap. The dividend yield on the Standard & Poor's 500 -- the amount you would earn if you bought all 500 stocks and held them for a year during which none of the companies raised or lowered its dividend -- is 2.7 percent. That does not, of course, include any capital gains (or losses). Historically, that is near the low end of the range, but the yield has been low for three years now, with no great disaster, and few now seem to be worried.
A MAJOR reason for the flow of money into stocks -- and one that does not seem likely to reverse -- has been the growing concern about retirement of the baby boom generation. The notion that stocks are the best long-term investment -- now being pushed in television ads by Nasdaq -- is widely accepted in a way that would have seemed impossible 20 years ago, when stocks were cheap by almost all measures. (The dividend yield then was 5.5 percent.)
That has brought a flood of money from Individual Retirement Accounts and 401(k) plans coursing into stock mutual funds. In 1994, a year when most stocks made no progress as interest rates leaped, investors still put $75.6 billion into funds that invested primarily in American stocks. As recently as 1983, the total assets of such funds were less than that amount. In the first two months of this year, the flow of money into stock funds increased from the 1994 pace.
Moreover, while many companies needed cash coming out of the 1990 recession, that is no longer the case. Corporate profits, Mr. Clough of Merrill Lynch says, are running strong enough to finance capital needs internally. He points to Federal Reserve Board figures showing that in 1994 companies sold $57.2 billion of stock to investors. But during the year corporate America bought -- via share repurchases and takeovers -- $159.2 billion of shares. That left fewer shares for all that mutual fund money to chase.
"That leads me to the most absurd prediction I have ever made," Mr. Clough said last week. "We are going to see a shortage of financial assets." And that means stock prices will keep being bid up.
As Mr. Clough knows, such an idea seems unreasonable to many old Wall Streeters, who believe that while a shortage of some industrial component or mineral may be possible, it is hard to believe that printing presses will not churn out enough share certificates. But it is still a widely held idea.
"Our investment bankers are scurrying around the country trying to get business," said Mr. Wien of Morgan Stanley. "But companies don't need the money."
There is an old joke about bankers, to the effect that they will lend you all the money you can prove you don't need, but there is something of that in the current stock market. One group of stocks that seem to hold little attraction are those of companies trying to go public after leveraged buyouts. Such companies need the money to pay down debt, but even in this market there has been no rush to pay money for them.
Among the ex-buyout companies going public this year have been Fort Howard, the toilet paper giant; American Standard, the bathroom fixtures company, and Uniroyal Chemical. All had to sell shares at less than they originally sought.
PERHAPS the most interesting determinant of where the market will go from here is the dollar, which has fallen this year to new lows against the Japanese yen and the German mark, even while soaring against the Mexican peso. Indeed, a Japanese or German investor would wonder what bull market this article is talking about. In their currencies, American stocks cost a little less than they did at the end of 1994. (But their own markets have done even worse.)
A bearish argument on the dollar holds that Japanese investors, who have been burned by currency losses, will choose to get out of American assets. But for now, the scenario more widely believed on Wall Street is that a wave of foreign takeovers are likely because American stocks seem cheap to those with strong currencies.
In any case, it appears that Wall Street's stretch of historically very low volatility may be coming to an end. In 1992, 1993 and 1994 the range between the annual high and low of the S.& P. 500 was 11.9 percent, 9.8 percent and 9.8 percent, respectively. The average volatility for the index since 1945 is 25 percent in any given year, and only twice in the 12 years before 1992 was volatility less than 20 percent.
So far this year, the spread between high and low for the index has been 9.8 percent, exactly what it was for the last two full years, and there are still nine more months to go.
If volatility is back, it will mean that there are greater chances to get rich -- or poor -- by playing stocks. This is likely to be a year with plenty of excitement. And, at least for now, most of Wall Street thinks there will be more joy than sorrow to be had from that excitement.

HEADLINE: MKARKET WATCH;
Ending the Dollar's Disastrous Decade

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Growth is great for a company, but it helps to know what produced the growth. And now, at the end of a disastrous decade for the dollar, it is more important than ever for owners of some Wall Street darlings.
Take a couple of the great stocks of the last decade. Coca-Cola saw its earnings per share rise at a compounded annual rate of 17 percent a year. Johnson & Johnson had an increase of 16 percent. The gains brought ample rewards for shareholders. 
 Most of that growth has come in foreign markets. And while there is no way to quantify it exactly, it is clear that the declining dollar has been responsible for some of the good news. If your Japanese subsidiary earned 10 billion yen in 1985, you could tell your shareholders about a profit of almost $40 million. Ten years later, if yen profits have remained constant, you can brag about earning $115 million. That looks like a compound annual growth rate of 11 percent for your Japanese subsidiary. Things are even better if your subsidiary actually grew.
A decade ago the dollar was ridiculously expensive by almost any measure, a situation that was great for American tourists and horrible for American exporters. Now the situation is reversed.
To be sure, it appears that traders despise the dollar more than almost anything, save the Mexican peso, and think it will keep falling. The dollar lost more than 10 percent of its value against both the mark and the yen in the quarter just ended. Not since the last three months of 1987, when the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates after the stock market crash, has the greenback had a worse quarter.
But even if this is not the bottom -- and the bet here is that we are close to it -- it is safe to say that the dollar will do a lot better in the next 10 years than it did in the last decade.
What does that portend for American multinationals? It means reported growth is likely to slow, even if the business keeps doing just as well as before. Consider a hypothetical company that reported a 15 percent annual growth in profits. In fact, real growth was about 12 percent, with the other 3 percent coming from dollar weakness. But share buyers here have given it credit for the faster growth pace. If the dollar starts to rise, that 12 percent growth rate could look like 10 percent, even if nothing has changed. And that could bother investors.
Notice that none of this has anything to do with the real underlying fundamentals of the business. J.& J. and Coke, the two companies named above, are representative of a lot of American companies, with quality products and international success. They have also been very successful in the stock market. If you had bought Coke a decade ago and reinvested the dividends, your compound annual return would have been 28 percent; for J.& J. the figure is 22 percent. Both are comfortably ahead of the 14.4 percent posted for the stock market as a whole, not to mention well above the companies' profit gains. Investors are willing to pay up for growth.
The implications of that analysis are directly contrary to the conventional Wall Street wisdom. That holds that the weak dollar is good news for multinationals. It is, to the extent that their exports are more competitive. And profits for this year will look better because of the dollar's plunge.
But the longer-term verdict may be that multinational growth stocks will stop looking so attractive. And that could lead to a contraction of price-earnings multiples for such companies, just as the decline of the dollar led to the expansion of multiples for much of the last decade.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHINATOWN;
1,500 Dine, and Back Restaurant in Battle With Union

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
In a dramatic and unprecedented display of community solidarity against the independent union that has been trying to organize restaurant workers in Chinatown, 1,500 people packed the largest restaurant in the neighborhood Thursday night.
The event at the Jing Fong restaurant marked a rare moment of unity in politically fractious Chinatown. The participants banded together to show their opposition to Local 318 Independent Restaurant Workers Union, which represents waiters in two Chinese restaurants in Chinatown and Flushing, Queens, and has tried unsuccessfully to organize employees at Jing Fong. 
Participants, including business people, workers and community leaders from anti-Communist as well as pro-mainland factions, said they hoped to send a message to the union's adviser, Wing Lam, executive director of the Chinese Staff Workers Association, that his tactics are damaging the Chinatown economy by discouraging patronage of targeted restaurants. The union has staged mock funerals, complete with coffins, drums and dancers performing mourning dances outside Jing Fong since February.
Union advisers refused Friday to comment on the event.
During the emotionally charged evening, diners gave a 10-minute standing ovation to 140 headwaiters, waiters and kitchen workers, who marched around the restaurant.
Unions are a sensitive topic among Chinatown workers, who fear that they would lose financially under union contracts. Waiters, for example, say they fear losing salary and tips because owners would hire second shifts to avoid paying overtime. People at the dinner acknowledged that restaurant workers are often underpaid and overworked. But they said it is up to the government, not unions, to enforce labor laws.
"If there are labor problems in the restaurant, then let the government handle it," said George Hui, president of the influential Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association, an umbrella organization representing more than 70 family, business and area associations in Chinatown. "There is no need for Mr. Lam to haul out the coffin and hurt the Chinatown economy."
For their part, restaurant owners accept much of the blame for the problems within their workforce, but they say competition and low profit margins make it difficult to pay benefits and higher wages. They concede they do not make enough effort to understand Federal labor practices.
Thursday's turnout came as a surprise to Yai Chi Chan, president of the Chinese Restaurant Association, who said he had originally planned the event as a fundraising dinner for his 500 members. But people from the community also wanted to come. "Soon, the whole restaurant was all booked up -- we had to turn people away,"he said.
The union had planned its own demonstration outside Jing Fong Thursday night but no one showed up. JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;
Baffling Trusses, Flying Buses or Fishy Buttresses

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
In a sense, there are only two ways to look at the Port Authority Bus Terminal's Ninth Avenue bus ramps. The first is to see what is there: rusty steel overpasses that cut a dark, ungainly line across Ninth Avenue just south of 42d Street.
The second is to see what could be there. And there lies a window on the peculiar stuff urban visionaries' dreams are made of. 
Last fall, the terminal's manager, Ken Philmus, approached Community Board 4, asking for ideas from the community about what to do with the ramps, built in 1950 with strictly utilitarian intent. Since the overpasses were due for rehabilitation work, he thought, why not see if long-standing community complaints about them could be solved, economically and inventively, at the same time?
The board formed the Triple Bridge Task Force -- 10-strong -- and broadcast a call for designs. Now, countless (pro bono) man-hours later, the task force is delightedly wading through more than 40 submissions, from high-tech computer-aided designs to utterly impractical, delightful drawings.
"We were ecstatic when we saw what was coming in," said Jo Ann Macy, the task force's chairwoman.
The designs tend to fall into certain categories. Some try to hide the overpasses, covering them with, say, giant baffles and video screens; some try to make the most of them, painting the segments defined by the trusswork in a welter of contrasting colors. Some incorporate elements of nature, growing walls of grass or raising a subterranean creek to form a waterside concourse. Some cover them with decorations, like a road map of New Jersey. A few use the ramps as a starting point to redesign the entire neighborhood.
The task force members hope to present a report on the submissions to the Port Authority this summer -- in time to piggyback some sort of redesign to the rehabilitation work, due to start in 1996.
In the meantime, the designs will be on view soon in store windows near the overpasses and in the Port Authority bus terminal. And an open meeting to solicit neighborhood reaction will be held at 7 P.M. April 11 at the Duke Ellington Room at Manhattan Plaza, 400 West 43d Street, where the whole megillah will be on display. ANDREA KANNAPELL

GRAPHIC: Photo: A panel collected ideas to change this.
 
Diagrams: "THE HIGH STEPPING PLAN"
 Outside staircases lead to small-scale market spaces carved out of the terminal's inhuman bulk.
 
"SALUTING JERSEY"
 The terminal is about motion, specifically, motion to New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania. So a map of the destinations could ba applied to the overpasses.
 
"THE GRAND SOLUTION"
 Meant as homage to Washington Square Park and the Manhattan Bridge, the Triumphal Arch would be made of honeycombed panels, keeping it light and inexpensive.
 
"FISH AGAINST VIOLENCE"
 The idea is that an aquarium would cool the city's hot temper. "But the fish would die and the maintenance is pretty high," says Leni Schwendinger, a panel member.
 
"OUT OF SIGHT..."
 Mirrors applied to the overpass exteriors would angle up, reflecting the sky. "It's humorful," says Laura Briggs, an architecture professor on the task force.

HEADLINE: A Week to Be Fashionable by Association

BYLINE: By DAN SHAW 

 BODY:
AT the Alternative Fashion Week ball at Webster Hall on Wednesday night, models in thousand-dollar ball gowns shared a runway with men in high heels and a dwarf in a G-string. Like many events tied to the week of New York fashion shows that officially begins today, the evening wasn't really about clothes. It was about generating publicity for Absolut Vodka, the show's sponsor, and raising money for Housing Works, an organization that provides housing and social services to people with AIDS and H.I.V.
 The next night at Barolo in SoHo, the model Beverly Peele celebrated her 20th birthday along with hundreds of her admirers. Like many fashionable birthday parties these days, the evening wasn't really about commemorating a birthday. It was about having Ms. Peele photographed by paparazzi and written about by gossip columnists. To lure them to the party, Ms. Peele's public relations firm billed the fete as a "kickoff to fashion week." 
 The hoopla surrounding New York's fashion week, which runs through Friday, is beginning to resemble the hype associated with the Super Bowl: the before and after parties -- along with the advertising and marketing opportunities -- are nearly as important as the main event.

RESTAURANTS, charities, perfume companies, record labels, authors, museums and retailers have all scheduled events to piggyback on the frenzy generated by Seventh on Sixth, the festival of 49 fashion shows under tents in Bryant Park and in the New York Public Library. (Seventh on Sixth itself has become a marketing tool for its 13 sponsors, including Clairol, Evian and The New York Times Magazine, which offer their products at booths in the tent lobbies and fly their names on banners along 42d Street.)
 With journalists and television crews from around the world descending on New York to cover the fall '95 collections, many fashion-related businesses are hoping for publicity by association.
 William Morrow, the publishing house, is counting on it. Its publication of "Model: The Ugly Business of Beautiful Women" by Michael Gross was timed to coincide with fashion week.
 After the last round of shows in November, when the feud between Carre Otis and her estranged husband, Mickey Rourke, dominated the tabloids' coverage of the tent shows, Mr. Gross told his publisher that he thought fashion week would be the ideal time to promote the book. "Interest in models reaches a fever pitch during the shows," Mr. Gross said.
 He plans to offer his authorial expertise in sound bites to any reporter under the tents who will listen. "You have 800 press people in town all looking for great stories," Mr. Gross said. "It's an ideal opportunity to get the word out in a way that is economical and effective."
 For Stan Herman, the president of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, which established Seventh on Sixth, it's an opportunity to raise money and awareness for one of his favorite charities: the Hetrick-Martin Institute, a social service agency that provides counseling and education for lesbian, gay and bisexual youths. Mr. Herman is a chairman of a fund-raising auction and cocktail party tonight for Hetrick-Martin, which will be the first-ever benefit in the Bryant Park tents.
 "It was a calculated risk to try to squeeze this in during fashion week," Mr. Herman said. "But the fashion community has been very supportive of Hetrick-Martin, and if we are going to get publicity for the institute's work, it helps to do so while the out-of-town press is here."
 Allure magazine agreed to sponsor the benefit for the same reason. "It's very simple," said Paul Wilmot, director of public relations at Conde Nast, which publishes Allure. "You go duck hunting when the ducks are flying. It puts Allure in a very visible position."
 The opening of the Fashion Cafe in Rockefeller Center on Friday night will probably be visible around the world. CNN, MTV and the BBC are slated to have camera crews at the party at the 280-seat theme restaurant, whose owners include the models Naomi Campbell, Elle MacPherson and Claudia Schiffer. Tommaso Buti, the restaurant's chief executive, scheduled the opening to follow the last tent show (Donna Karan's 6 P.M. presentation) so that his party would become fashion week's de facto finale.
 Mr. Buti also regards the opening as a global photo opportunity, a chance to build name recognition around the world. "I think Fashion Cafe is an exportable concept," he said. "I want to expand to Europe and Asia."
 American Movie Classics, the cable station, is also using fashion week to drum up interest in a future project. Late last week, the company sent out fashion week "Survival Kits" -- fruit baskets with news releases -- promoting "The Hollywood Fashion Machine," a one-hour documentary that isn't scheduled to be televised until August.
 "It's about jumping on the bandwagon early," said James LaForce, the cable station's public relations consultant, who sent the fruit to 300 editors and television producers who will be attending the tent shows.
 Francois Nars, a makeup artist whose new line of cosmetics is due to hit stores in May, is giving a party for 500 at Laura Belle on Tuesday night. "It's not a product launch," said Jennie Lister, a vice president of Mr. Nars's company, Agora Cosmetics. "Barneys will do that in May. Francois is from France, and a lot of his foreign friends will be in town next week, and he wanted to have a party for them." Still, a half-dozen television crews have already promised to cover the event, lured by the fact that Mr. Nars's friends include many supermodels.
 Gee Street Records is giving a party to promote Malcolm McLaren's new album, "Paris," on Tuesday night because so many of Mr. McLaren's peripatetic friends will be in New York. "Malcolm is inextricably linked with fashion," said Michelle Feeney, the organizer of the party, whose hosts include Joan Juliet Buck, the editor of French Vogue, and James Truman, the editorial director of Conde Nast. "He worked with Vivienne Westwood. He knows a lot of fashion people, and the album was used at a lot of the Paris fashion shows, so we decided it was good to have a party when a lot of people who like his stuff could be there."

MTV's "House of Style," however, won't make it. "There's too much to cover," said Alisa Bellettini, the producer. "The only thing we're covering outside the tents is the opening of the Fashion Cafe." She won't be covering the party Wednesday night at Henri Bendel for Todd Oldham's new perfume, even though Mr. Oldham is a regular contributor to "House of Style." But Ms. Bellettini is taping a segment, on how to produce a fashion show, that will feature Mr. Oldham.
 Even the Metropolitan Museum of Art hopes to attract editors and buyers visiting New York for the collections. "Our spring show is planned to open the week of fashion week," said Richard Martin, the curator of the Costume Institute, whose exhibition "Bloom: Fashion's Spring Gardens" opened yesterday. "It's a way of showing respect to the fashion community."
 With all the ancillary activities, fashion designers can't always hold their events when they want to. Wolfgang Joop, for instance, who will show in the tents on Friday, has invited editors and buyers to his apartment tonight for cocktails. "Clearly, it's not the time we'd prefer," said Judith Agisim, who is organizing the party. "We're not trying to draw people away from the Hetrick-Martin benefit, but it was the only time that didn't conflict."
 Lauren Ezersky, a columnist for Paper Magazine, has had trouble organizing a dinner to introduce her friends and colleagues to Roberto Cavalli, an Italian designer who is showing in the tents for the first time. "We had to reschedule it three times," said Ms. Ezersky, who decided to hold her dinner on Wednesday after Todd Oldham's perfume party. "We would have loved to have had it after Roberto's show on Friday night, but who's not going to go to the Fashion Cafe? If we had the dinner on Friday, I might have skipped my own party."

HEADLINE: Word for Word / Names for an Era;
No Time Like the Present To Leave Something for Posterity

BYLINE: By SARAH BOXER 

 BODY:
Two weeks ago the Week in Review invited readers to choose a name for the time we live in, in the spirit of James Atlas's article, "Pinpointing a Moment on the Map of History." The reaction was fast and floodlike.
 A few readers were outraged at the very idea of The New York Times soliciting opinions. Someone derisively named the current age "The Era of the Audience-Participation New York Times." But hundreds of readers -- professors, students, psychologists, bureaucrats and hackers -- replied seriously. Some got carried away, unintentionally casting their votes for the Age of Indecision by sending in long lists of suggestions. One reader sent 52. 
 The responses came overwhelmingly from men and they were overwhelmingly pessimistic. The word "global" appeared in more than 40 of the names; the prefixes "dis-," "re-," "post-," "fin de" and "cyber-" (including two cyberias and one cy-barbaric) popped up repeatedly.
 There were about 20 variations on Millennial Age or Messianic Age (including "Milleni-end" and "Millenopause" and one picture of Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, who died last year). The Age of Anxiety (in deference to W. H. Auden), the Age of Uncertainty, the Age of Fragmentation, the Age of (Great and Failed) Expectations, the Age of Disillusion (and Dissolution) were popular. The ages of tribalism, fundamentalism, capitalism, regionalism, technology, deconstruction, greed and the Internet all had their adherents. Two people said the Age of Aquarius was dawning.
 Here are some of the editors' favorites. History will name the winner. SARAH BOXER
 
THE AGE OF CHUCK. Prior to this time there had been a sweeping infestation of . . . political correctness (PC), which sanitized everyday speech and suppressed humor . . . A cynical public began calling it the time of Post-Charles, "Charles" being a name they associated with . . . Victorian times. Eventually Charles gave way to "Chuck," a name used in American society to represent "one of the guys."

HEADLINE: Markdown;
The Selling Of a Used President Gets Easier

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR two years, Bill Clinton tried hard and looked as if he was trying hard. He began his Presidency with a flurry of proposals, some carefully thought out, others concocted on the fly, some enacted, some defeated, some abandoned.
 On balance, the American people did not much like what they saw. 
 But in the weeks following the Republican triumph last November, a kind of lassitude seemed to grip the White House. Mr. Clinton and his aides rejected suggestions that they draft a new program of their own as a counterpoise to the Republicans' Contract With America. Whether staging a strategic retreat or simply stunned into inaction, the President allowed Newt Gingrich & Co. to dominate the first two months of the year.
 And now the strategy (or the non-strategy) seems to be paying rewards. The Red Queen told Alice that you had to run as fast as you could to stay in the same place; in present-day Washington, does standing still get you places?
 That would clearly be an overstatement. But Robert Squier, a veteran Democratic campaign consultant, thinks it hints at the truth. He believes both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gingrich read too much into their victories, taking relatively narrow margins as broad mandates, trying to do too much too quickly, and thereby agitating an electorate that, however cynical and dissatisfied, wants evolution, not revolution.

 
 
Stress Fractures
 In a demonstration of legislative efficiency unparalleled in the three decades since the enactment of the Great Society legislation, the Republicans have managed to push the less controversial parts of their Contract through the House, and they appear to have the votes to pass far-reaching welfare reform in the Senate as well. The line-item veto seems likely to become law soon. But they have failed, at least to date, on the balanced budget amendment and (last week's defeat) term limits, two of the populist measures they most strongly emphasized last fall, and they appear to be at sixes and sevens on tax policy.
 If not yet split in two as they were in the great Taft-Eisenhower and Goldwater-Rockefeller battles, the Republicans have begun to show some stress fractures -- Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, who declared his candidacy for President last week, vs. the Religious Right; the tax-cutters vs. the budget-balancers; Representative Henry Hyde of Illinois and his old-timers vs. the Beltway-loathing youngsters; the neo-Progressives who dislike Big Business vs. the traditionalists who are its champions. Like Mr. Clinton a year ago, Mr. Gingrich says the real problem is not substance but communication; to get his message out, he plans a nationwide broadcast this week. But like Mr. Clinton, he seems part of the problem himself.
 Though most people still tell poll-takers that they disapprove of Congress, most say they think the Republicans are doing a fairly good job. But the more people know about the Speaker, the less they like him. Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, a Gingrich fan, says he regularly tells the Speaker, "Newt, cool your jets." In the latest New York Times / CBS News poll, 22 percent of respondents reacted favorably, 33 unfavorably to the abrasive gentleman from Georgia; meanwhile, Mr. Clinton's poll figures have begun to stabilize, with 43 percent giving him a favorable rating and 39 giving him an unfavorable rating. Not brilliant, by any means, but probably good enough to prevent a full-fledged challenge from another Democrat.
 The battles on Capitol Hill have given Mr. Clinton a chance to do what hard-pressed politicians long to do: change the subject. One of his strategists said last week: "We finally have people talking about tax breaks for the rich and cutting off school lunches for poor kids instead of Bill Clinton and his character problems and his capacity to govern. That can only help us."
 Though he is already looking beyond the first 100 days of Republican control, talking about a flat tax and Medicare reform and eliminating government departments, Mr. Gingrich told David Frost last week that he thought Mr. Clinton could be re-elected because "he's clever, he has energy, he's articulate, he's attractive."

 
 
Fate and Numbers
 But the President remains a long shot who does not entirely control his own destiny. To win, many leading Democrats are saying, he will need the intervention of fate, in the form of a third-party candidate, perhaps, or a crisis abroad -- or a series of errors by the Republicans. Espousal of economic policies that seem too unfeeling, brawling over social issues like abortion and gun control, the choice of a candidate who is unable to hold the center, an economy that lands softly -- those are elements of a possible second-term scenario.
 Against them, however, must be set other factors. The issues, by and large, are running against the Administration. Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore may talk about re-inventing government, but their party is seen by the public as the defender of the much-maligned status quo in Washington. The most damaging thing about the failure of health-care reform, from an electoral point of view, was its reinforcement of the public image of Mr. Clinton as the bureaucrat's friend.
 The Whitewater affair lurks just offstage. Not only a special prosecutor but several influential Republican lawmakers are sifting through evidence that could prove distracting, embarrassing, perhaps even damaging to the President in the midst of tough election fight.
 For Mr. Clinton, the numbers are also difficult. The 43 percent approval rating he scored in the latest Times / CBS poll is identical to his share of the vote in 1992; the belief is widespread in Washington that he will have trouble increasing it, which means he would need a third-party candidate in order to win.

 
 
The South, Gone
 Look at it another way, from the perspective of the electoral college: Almost all of the South, including two of the nation's four largest states, Florida and Texas, apparently lies beyond his grasp, despite his politicking there last week. The retirement of Senator Howell Heflin of Alabama and the defection of Senator Richard Shelby of Alabama are only the most evident symptoms of the collapse of the Democratic Party in Dixie. The big gains scored there at the ballot box last November by the Republicans may prove to have been the most lasting aspect of the upheaval of 1994, and they mean that Democratic Presidential nominees will have almost no margin of error for the foreseeable future. Win California and most of the states stretching from New York to Illinois, Democrats recognize, or stare defeat in the face.
 Just as Ronald Reagan did a decade ago, the young Republicans in the House are redrawing the partisan playing field. They have begun the process of shifting power back to the states. Most important of all, they have done most of what they said they would do.
 But it will be the election of 1996 that decides whether this is a political watershed or not. Presidential elections, not mid-term elections, mark the realignments that come along three or four times a century in this country. With a Republican President pounding on the bully pulpit starting in January 1997, Gingrich & Co. would have clear sailing. Failing that, the Democrats may be able to limit the "revolution" of 1994 to a modest swing of the partisan pendulum.
