HEADLINE: Drowning in The Second Wave

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich is Secretary of Labor.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"We are feeling the impact of the third great wave of change in history, and we are, as a result, in the process of creating a new civilization," writes the Speaker of the House in his foreword to "Creating a New Civilization: The Politics of the Third Wave," by his favorite futurists, Heidi and Alvin Toffler (published by the Progress and Freedom Foundation, Newt Gingrich's think-tank).
 It is Mr. Gringrich's credo. On his second day as Speaker, he issued Toffler-inspired marching orders to the House Ways and Means Committee: "I would suggest to you and to your staff, and to the witnesses you bring in, that about every policy we should ask the question, 'Does it accelerate our transition into a third wave information age, or does it slow it down?" 
 Ironically, the Speaker's own agenda does not pass this test. According to the Tofflers, third wave societies are based not on manufacturing products, but on creating, manipulating and distributing information. "Third wave operations," they say, "require diverse and continually evolving skills." Yet the Contract with America says almost nothing about skills or the workforce. Nowhere is there any proposal to help Americans struggling to swim from the second wave to the third. (The first wave was the agricultural South; the second, the industrialized North.) Instead, House Republicans are busy cutting the lifelines and puncturing the lifeboats.
 As "third wave" technologies fragment the old mass-production system, millions who used to work in or around factories need help just staying afloat. More than 11 percent of working families with at least one full-time wage earner have fallen into poverty -- up from 7 percent in the 1970's. Nearly one out of five workers who lost a full-time job between 1991 and 1993 was still without work last year. And among those who have landed new jobs, almost half are earning less than before.
 This is why the Administration has pushed for and achieved legislation to create a network of youth apprenticeships, to expand college loans and deliver them more cheaply and to combine unemployment insurance with easy access to job training. But too many Americans are still treading water.
 The Tofflers describe in futuristic terms an economic transformation that has been palpable for almost two decades. The well-skilled and well-connected already are riding the third wave. But most Americans are caught in the turbulence as the second wave crests and breaks. And that is the problem. It is not that the future is slow in coming; it's that it is coming for only some of us.
 The new Republican solution is to cut Federal funding for education, job-training and welfare, and to shift responsibility to the states. Less money but fewer strings. On the surface, the notion is attractive. Who's a better judge of what the families of Tacoma need -- Washington State or Washington, D.C.? But block grants are not the revolution their proponents promise. Ronald Reagan tried it, with disappointing results. Substituting state bureaucracies for Federal, and giving them less money to spend, won't help the millions of Americans who risk drowning in the new economy.
 There is another alternative that is genuinely radical and, in a real sense, "third wave." The key is equipping people to get jobs and to earn their own prosperity. For Americans who are unemployed, or have low incomes, we're proposing "skill grants," which are essentially training vouchers, worth up to $2,620 a year for up to two years, which can be used at any accredited institution.
 This represents a radical shift from programs to purchasing power. Instead of feeding the budgets of bureaucracies, Federal or state, the idea is to channel resources directly into the pockets of ordinary Americans so they can get the skills they need -- at the time, in the place, in the way that makes sense for them. Armed with up-to-date data on what skills and jobs are in demand, people can navigate their own careers.
 To this we would add a third wave tax incentive: making the money families spend on college tuition and job training tax-deductible, up to $10,000 a year per family. Under current law, any spending by business that can conceivably be called an investment qualifies for favorable tax treatment, including business lunches. Yet the tax code does not give families a break for investments linked most directly to raising living standards -- investments in education and lifelong job training.
 By contrast, there's nothing third wave about the G.O.P.'s proposed tax incentives. Giving corporations far larger tax deductions for purchasing equipment, machinery and buildings may indeed increase investment somewhat. But apart from the fact that this would drain the Treasury of about $169 billion over 10 years, it is far from clear that new tax breaks for capital will help working Americans adapt to a transforming economy. Spending on new machines and buildings is necessary but no longer sufficient for third wave prosperity.

The Republican proposal to cut taxes on capital gains has similar difficulties. The problem is not simply that most of the immediate benefits would go to the well-off. Evidence linking this tax break to any significant and sustained investment increase is weak. And once again, it is a policy at odds with the Tofflerian notion that "the allocation of wealth" is far less important than the "allocation of knowledge." It's essentially focused on the buying and selling of objects and has little to do with insights.
 The Tofflers argue that political conflict in the United States is largely a battle between second save groups fighting over the scraps of a decaying system. Their criticisms are bipartisan: The "Democrats' reflexive reliance on bureaucratic and centralist solutions . . . draw straight from second wave theories of efficiency." We have tried to fix that.
 But the Contract only deepens the flaw that the Tofflers diagnose in the other party: "Republicans tend to play down the potentially immense social dislocations that are likely to flow from any changes as profound as the third wave . . . Free marketism and trickle-downism twisted into rigid theological dogma are an inadequate response."
 At the close of the 20th century, there is a danger that America's well-educated third wave is losing sight of its second save compatriots. Some societies, perhaps, can endure even when their members no longer have a common culture or common prospects. But America -- at least an America recognizable as itself -- cannot. As the Tofflers put it, "We need to feel our way, leaving no group behind, as we create the future in our midst." Precisely.

HEADLINE: Journal;
AIDS on the Air

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Less than a decade ago William F. Buckley was proposing that "everyone detected with AIDS" be tattooed on the buttocks. Time has certainly marched on. This week Mr. Buckley's National Review will publish a memoir called "Positively HIV" in which David Brudnoy, the conservative ratings champ of New England talk radio and a National Review contributor since 1968, graphically describes his own near-death experience with AIDS last fall and the subsequent outpouring of affection with which his audience greeted the revelation of both his illness and his homosexuality.
 Not that everyone has been supportive. Mr. Brudnoy writes that "most conservatives take a dim view of homosexual activity" and that "some conservatives" now feel "that the Brudnoy they thought was on their side must be a fraud because homosexuals can't be conservative." 
 Mr. Brudnoy is hardly a fraud. He speaks well of Phil Gramm and touts the economic credos of the John Birch Society. "The Bell Curve" has pride of place in the studio WBZ set up for him in his Back Bay apartment.
 Yet the same libertarian conservatism that leads Mr. Brudnoy to mock Bubba and oppose big government also drives him to support gays in the military, gay marriages and condom distribution in schools. Isn't this what many of his friends demonize as "the gay agenda"? Mr. Brudnoy replies: "My only gay agenda is to live."
 Though rail-thin and requiring a cane to negotiate Boston streets, Mr. Brudnoy is back doing his five-hour radio show five nights a week, with energy left over to teach at Boston University and review movies for a local newspaper chain. (He also reviewed "Angels in America" -- loved the drama, hated the "puerile" politics.) At 54, he talks of living at least three or four more years. He exults in the limelight -- eight minutes on "Oprah," three pages in People -- and pictures a former Yale classmate, Sam Waterston, playing him in a talked-about movie-of-the-week.
 What prompted me to visit Mr. Brudnoy, though, was the prospect of tweaking him. Isn't he sitting right on the divide between economic and religious conservatives that threatens to split the G.O.P.? How can he defend Newt Gingrich, who has accused "active homosexuals" of recruiting the young in counseling programs? Could he vote for a '96 ticket that subscribed to the gay-bashing rhetoric of the religious right?
 After a lot of pressing, Mr. Brudnoy answers the last of those questions: "I'm not sure I would." He also allows that he resigned as film critic for The American Spectator in the 1980's rather than countenance its "stupidly vicious" treatment of homosexuals. He describes the religious right's rhetoric about gay people as "grotesque" -- a word he also applies to hypocritical conservatives who tolerate their own gay friends "but say everyone else is a faggot."
 While Mr. Brudnoy is politically timid, he isn't a hypocrite. He can't be mistaken for Roy Cohn or Terry Dolan of the National Conservative Political Action Committee, closeted gay AIDS casualties of the 1980's who vilified homosexuals in their public lives. Though in the closet until last fall -- to the point of making clandestine visits to a Washington doctor who treats "a couple of other well-known conservative AIDS patients" -- Mr. Brudnoy has publicly argued for gay rights since 1970.
Even so, he disdains angry confrontational politics and "gay activists." He doesn't believe in raising his voice. But he sounds almost angry when he speaks of how Barry Goldwater has been "invited out" of the conservative movement for extending his libertarian principles to bedroom issues. And Mr. Brudnoy despairs that anyone will win over the "family values" demagogues in the G.O.P. in this millennium.
 His National Review piece notwithstanding, Mr. Brudnoy says, "I don't want to be a poster boy for AIDS." He'd rather enjoy what time he has left. But the fact remains that he's a hugely popular conservative talk-show star destined to fight AIDS before a million empathic listeners in 38 states, New Hampshire included, during a Presidential campaign. Republican candidates rushing to embrace the religious right and its anti-gay agenda should at the very least stay tuned.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Unsigned Free Agents Might Have a Place To Showcase Talents

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The Players Association planned to run a spring camp this month in Homestead, Fla., for the players who were going to make their all-star tour starting next month, playing games for charity as a way of reminding fans who the real major leaguers were.
Now that the real major leaguers are on the verge of returning to work, the union plans to convert the Homestead site into a camp for free agents. Invited participants will be the slightly more than 100 players who voluntarily became free agents last fall and remain unsigned and perhaps another 100 or more who became free agents involuntarily, by being released or not being tendered contracts. 
 If the owners accept the players' offer to end their strike, the 1,069 players on major league rosters will have camps to go to for spring training. Even the more than 800 who are unsigned will be able to join their teams while their agents negotiate their contracts.
But the unsigned free agents will have nowhere to go to get themselves into shape so the union will invite them to Homestead. Details have not been worked out, but the union plans to commit formally tomorrow to a lease for this month.
The camp will be unique and could become the site where scouts from all or many of the clubs flock to scrutinize the available talent. The players haven't been seen playing since last August, and eight months is an unusually long time for players to spend off the field.
Lawyers for the owners, the players and the National Labor Relations Board fought over the voluntary free agents in court Friday, but it has been so long since the free agents became free agents that it's not certain anyone remembers who they are.
Teams looking for starting pitchers may want to send scouts to Homestead to watch Orel Hershiser, Kevin Brown, Danny Darwin, Bill Swift, Bob Tewksbury, Todd Stottlemyre, Bobby Witt, Jim Deshaies, Tim Belcher, Scott Sanderson, Fernando Valenzuela, Zane Smith, Dave Stewart, Frank Viola and Bob Welch.
They also could see Steve Ontiveros, whose 2.65 earned run average was the lowest among American League starters last season, and Terry Mulholland, whose 6.49 e.r.a. was one of the highest.
Anyone in the market for a relief pitcher could check out Dennis Eckersley, John Franco, Jeff Russell, Jay Howell and Doug Jones. Catchers they might see include Pat Borders, Benito Santiago, Brian Harper and Mike Macfarlane.
A nice collection of players for other positions may show up, too: Brett Butler, Mickey Tettleton, Larry Walker, Mark Grace, John Kruk, Mike Devereaux, B. J. Surhoff, Andy Van Slyke, Bo Jackson, Kevin McReynolds, Vince Coleman, Eric Davis, Mariano Duncan, Dave Magadan and Terry Pendleton.
Dave Winfield and Andre Dawson would add a touch of class to the camp.
Despite the eight-week ban on signings of players by individual clubs, some free agents may have deals that have been worked out but obviously not announced. One agent, Tony Attanasio, said clubs have contacted him about some of his clients and in one instance a manager called a client directly.
"I'm sure these guys have been told whatever you do don't do anything substantive," Attanasio said. "They're told you can talk, but don't sign anybody before we get though with this appeal thing."
The clubs are appealing a Federal judge's order that the Player Relations Committee cannot serve as the exclusive representative in contract negotiations. Meanwhile, the commissioner's office issued a list of talking points for club officials following the issuance of the injunction. One of the nine points regarded free agents.
"Without a collective bargaining agreement and crippled by strike-related losses, clubs will be unable to offer huge new contracts to free agent players," it said. "In some cases, they won't be able to sign free agents at all."
Hearing that point, one agent said, "It sounds a little bit like collusion to me."
 
More Recruits for New League
 In recent years, an increasing number of veteran or otherwise marginal players have failed to find jobs in the major leagues. That trend certainly will continue this year and, in fact, will probably approach epidemic proportions. Clubs will not want to expend their decreased funds or abbreviated spring training time on players they can't be certain will help them now.
Ordinarily, that would mean the end of careers for most of the unemployed. But there could be a United Baseball League in those players' futures.
Organizers of the budding league, which plans to begin play next year, couldn't have asked for a better scenario than the one that has unfolded and will continue to develop. Not only will they have a larger supply of potential recruits than they might have anticipated, but they also could benefit from the deep animosity the labor dispute has engendered.
The league had planned to wait until late summer or fall to begin signing players, but player agents have urged league officials to advance their timetable and begin signing players now, if only to future contracts.
Agents figure to be instrumental in the success or failure of the venture because they can steer players to the United League if they see it as a viable alternative to major league baseball. Already many agents like the idea that the new league promises to be player-friendly.
Base salaries won't be as high as players have become accustomed to, but players will have two unique incentives for going United. As a group, players will have an equity share in franchises, and as team members, they will receive a 35 percent share of that team's pretax profits.
League officials continue to study potential sites for teams in the New York and Los Angeles areas. Franchises already have been awarded to Washington, New Orleans, Vancouver and San Juan.
 
A Creative Spin From Bench
 When judges are called on to decide a baseball dispute, no matter who the litigious parties are, they can't resist speaking from the bench in baseballese. Judge Sonia Sotomayor, the Federal judge who put major league baseball back on track, was no different, but she at least was more creative than and not as trite as most of her predecessors.
In fact, she brought an imagery to the proceeding that probably had some of the spectators in the courtroom drooling for live, legitimate baseball.
The judge did not say "Batter up" or "Play ball," as too many jurists have. In reading her 47-minute ruling from the bench, she began this way:
"I can't help but to at least borrow some analogies from baseball as I start. The often leisurely game of baseball is filled with many small moments which catch a fan's breath. There is, for example, that wonderful second when you see an outfielder backpedaling and jumping up to the wall, and time stops for an instant as he jumps up and you finally figure out whether it is a home run, a double or a single off the wall, or an out."
"Unwillingly," she continued, "I have been drafted onto the deck of this field, with those of you watching out there waiting for one of those small moments to happen. I personally would have liked more time to practice my swing."
But when she took her swing, she whacked the owners like Dave Winfield used to hit line drives.
 
Sharing the Wealth
 The check's in the mail -- even for replacement players.
The union mailed checks from its strike fund Friday, sending money to players who had major league service time in the years the licensing money was retained. That means even players other than those on strike will receive checks, including players who took part in replacement exhibition games this spring.
Among those who did so but who nevertheless will get money from the union are Darren Reed, Hector Villanueva, Mike Schooler, Junior Ortiz, Eric Yelding, Mickey Weston, Juan Guerrero, Lonnie Maclin, Rob Mallicoat, Denis Boucher, Shawn Abner, Wayne Rosenthal, Doug Saunders and Bob Ayrault.

HEADLINE: MARKET TIMIMG

 BODY:

Monday
The Commerce Department reports personal income and spending for February. A drop in the average workweek to 34.5 hours, from 34.9 hours in January, should limit income growth. Forecast: income up 0.3 percent; spending up 0.1 percent.

Most United States auto makers report March sales for new cars and light trucks. Economists expect car sales to be at an annual unit rate of 6.9 million to 7.1 million and light trucks at 5.8 million to 6 million.

The National Association of Purchasing Managers releases its survey for March. Forecast: Continued growth is seen in manufacturing, though the index is expected to fall to 52.9, from 54.5 in February.

Tuesday
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, plans to discuss the Administration's agenda at the Senate Finance Committee hearing on trade law.

Report is due on February construction spending. Forecast: no change.

Wednesday
Report is due on Leading economic indicators for February. Forecast: down 0.2 percent.

Ford and Nissan report March vehicle sales.

Commerce Department to release wholesale trade figures for February.

Thursday
House expected to vote on a package of tax cuts and offsetting spending cuts, in what Republicans hope will be the final flourish to the Contract With America.

Housing completion figures for February are scheduled to be released.

Shareholders of the computer manufacturer Zeos International are expected to approve an acquisition by Micron Technology, a maker of computer products.

Friday
Labor Department to release unemployment figures for March. The numbers should confirm that the economy is continuing to slow. Forecast: 5.5 percent, with a rise of 225,000 in nonfarm payrolls.
 
The Federal Reserve reports consumer credit for February. Forecast: up $6.3 billion.

HEADLINE: Mexican Peso's Wake Makes Mideast Waves

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The Mexican monetary crisis appears to have foreign policy reverberations that have reached the Middle East. 
 In the wake of the sudden and precipitous devaluation of the Mexican peso last Dec. 20, and the flight of international capital as a result of that devaluation, Mexico has taken steps to stem the outflow. Austerity measures taken to stabilize the Mexican economy, coupled with an already weakened Mexican peso, have transformed Mexico's large deficit in trade before the fateful devaluation into a surplus in trade in the first quarter of 1995, which is projected to be substantial for the entire year.
 The implications of this reversal are of great consequence to the United States economy. The United States was ironically one of the major contributors to the Mexican trade deficit, most of which was accumulated as a result of American merchandise being sold to our prosperous neighbor.
 Now that Mexico is unwilling and unable to purchase our goods, compounding our own chronic trade deficit problem, the United States has to find another market.
Once again we appear to be turning to the Middle East. After a stop in Saudi Arabia, Defense Secretary William Perry visited other Persian Gulf states. He told the Saudis, Iraq's main rival, that the United States has solid evidence that Iraq has rebuilt its armed forces to a threatening level. The Saudis, with wealth derived from oil, are being urged to arm themselves to match Iraq's "buildup."
 A similar message is being delivered to Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and others in the Persian Gulf, with warnings that Iran, the gulf states' other neighboring nemesis, is deploying weapons of mass destruction in the Persian Gulf.
 There should be less menacing methods to address our trade deficit problem.
 
SHAW J. DALLAL
New Hartford, N.Y., March 23, 1995
The writer is adjunct professor of international business, Utica College.

HEADLINE: Too Often, Child Welfare System Breaks Up Poor Families;
Spiritual Poverty?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In your March 25 front-page article on the House welfare bill, you quote the unsubstantiated ideas of Representative James M. Talent of Missouri. Mr. Talent states that the public assistance system, while "trying to give people material wealth and lift them out of poverty, is luring them into a kind of spiritual poverty by destroying their families and their incentives to work." 
 This poppycock, which the Republican majority repeats with the hope that if they say it enough, it will catch on as truth, has no support from any responsible research.
 In reality, people don't work because jobs don't exist. When they can't work, they turn to public assistance for food and rent money.
 According to the Current Population Survey of the United States Census, New York City lost 300,000 jobs in 1990 and 1991. Not surprisingly, the public assistance caseload increased from 369,765 cases in 1989 to 475,850 cases in 1992. When economic expansion creates additional jobs, assistance rolls will experience a similar decline.
 I suggest that Mr. Talent and his colleagues look to the cities of Calcutta, Rio, Manila and Mexico City for proof that eliminating social safety nets leads not to spiritual enrichment but to abject misery.
 
DOUGLAS LASDON
Executive Director, Legal Action Center for the Homeless
New York, March 27, 1995

HEADLINE: You Might as Well Say 'Bon Appetit"

BYLINE: By RUTH REICHL 

 BODY:
As Congress began to debate the dismantling of the Federal school lunch program, many people looked back at their own school days and said, "Good riddance."
Childhood memories came flooding back -- of squishy spaghetti and gray hamburgers floating in an indefinable liquid. Some of us remembered the horrors of creamed chipped beef, others the ladies in hairnets who dished out the slop and the vile smell of the school lunchroom itself. 
 Personally, I can't forget the taste of the breaded veal patties that were served in my school every Thursday. I thought that if today's children hate their school lunches as much as my friends and I did, perhaps it was time to rethink the whole program.
And so, my mind firmly fixed on dreary food and the endless waste -- all that food we threw out! -- I set off to discover if school lunch was still as awful.
My first stop was Stuyvesant High School on Chambers Street in downtown Manhattan. It was a shock. I walked into the lunchroom and found myself facing a line of windows looking out over the Hudson River. The large, airy cafeteria is considerably more attractive than most corporate canteens I've seen and nothing like the lunchroom in any school I ever attended.
The sound was different, too; what I heard was the cheerful buzz of people deciding what to eat. As groups of teen-agers spread out, some lining up at the "trend bar" and others at the "deli counter," I found myself waiting in line at the "theme canteen." Here, the students and I chose between chicken chow mein with rice (it was delicious) or broccoli and pasta. Broccoli and pasta? I wondered if the people who made the food were insane: Surely teenagers don't actually eat broccoli.
Wrong. The students at Stuyvesant were happily heaping their plates with bright green vegetables and pasta. Even more surprising, the next line snaked toward a salad bar, where girls with gleaming hair pointed to a bowl of spinach with sliced mushrooms and croutons. Clearly, times have changed.
Stuyvesant's lunchroom sold hamburgers, too, but they didn't float. They came wrapped in foil, just like the ones at McDonald's and Burger King. And by the time I had drenched my low-fat patty with ketchup and sprinkled salt on the oven-baked fries, it was tasty enough to pass for a bad-for-you kind of burger. Actually, any student who feels the need for a fast-food fix is free to walk out the door. (My generation was captive to the system, but this one is not.) That the vast majority of students choose to eat at school is partly because of economics: the full price of lunch at Stuyvesant is $1, and many students receive free or reduced-price (40-cent) meals.
Credit for the lunchtime crowd also goes to Andreas Skouras, Stuyvesant's cook, who admits that he "improves" the recipes the district sends him by using lots of fresh garlic, herbs and spices. "They just love my soups," he said happily. No wonder; all the food I tasted was good.
And there is another factor: the nutritional savvy of the modern teen-ager.
"There's been a big change in the kids in the 12 years I've been in school food service," said Lynn Fiumi, school food service manager at Stuyvesant. Today's students, she said, "are very nutrition conscious." And she doesn't just mean the girls. Boys and girls alike, she notes, are anxious to fill their bodies with healthy ingredients.
"They want to know what's in everything," Ms. Fiumi said. "They love the spinach salad, they love carrots, they insist on skim milk. This is just not what I'm used to. They even want to look at the books and find out how much fat, salt and sugar there is in everything we serve. They are much more informed."
Stuyvesant, of course, is a state-of-the-art magnet high school for scientifically inclined college-bound students. I expected to find a very different situation at P.S. 137, which occupies a graffiti-scarred, rubble-strewn street in the shadow of the Manhattan Bridge.
Walking into the lunchroom, I found the principal, Ron Salazar, standing by the kitchen door chewing on a chicken leg. Boys darted under his arms munching on apples and pieces of melon, while a little girl tried to sneak past him to filch a second carton of milk from the cooler. (Extra milk is easy to get -- pupils who don't want their milk put their unopened cartons in a special place --but she wanted an ice-cold one. )
"I eat lunch with the kids every day," Mr. Salazar said. "It's a great way to get to know them." He looked down at his plate and sighed.
I nodded sympathetically and said, "It must be really difficult having to eat here."
Mr. Salazar nodded. "Yes," he replied, "it is." Then he patted his substantial belly and explained, "I'd really like to lose a little weight, but the food here is just too good."
At P.S. 137 the dining room and the gym share a single space. While one group of children ran relay races, another lined up for lunch, marching into the kitchen to choose between freshly roasted chicken or cheese-stuffed pasta shells.
I was certain that the small children who attended the school would not be interested in nutrition. Wrong again. Just above the salad bar was a sign. It said: "To the kitchen staff: Thanks for all you have done for us." It was signed, in childish handwriting, "The nutrition committee."
The nutrition committee? In elementary school?
Barbara Gulotta, director of food technology for the New York City schools, said that every school in the city has one. "We want the children's feedback," she said. "It's no good making nutritious lunches if the children don't eat them. Taste is the most powerful tool that we have."
And the New York school system seems to be turning tastes around at a time when other locales across the country have abandoned school lunch to fast-food providers.
"I can tell you that there are some major problems with the national school lunch program," said John Gleason of the Center for Science in the Public Interest in Washington., noting that Taco Bell has gone into nearly 3,000 schools nationwide and that Pizza Hut is in 3,500 of the schools that participate in the national school lunch program.
At P.S. 137, Mr. Salazar, an admitted junk-food eater, said he rarely ate the salads that are served every day, but his students were happily tucking into fat chunks of cucumbers and tomatoes.
I didn't blame them. The salads were fresh and fine and delicious. So was the chicken. And I couldn't blame the children who ignored the mixed vegetables that were doled out with the pasta and chicken; I didn't eat the dreary mixture of frozen winter vegetables, either.
Still, it was just about the only thing the children left on their plates.
"You going to eat that?" one little boy asked another, eyeing his barely tasted chicken.
His friend hunched protectively over his plate. "Yes," he replied, "I am."
The first little boy looked sad. Later, as they dashed joyously for the door and the freedom of the weekend, I heard him talking to his friend. "You know the only thing I'm going to miss about school?" he asked. Barely waiting for an answer, he shouted "Lunch!"

HEADLINE: Franchise Fervor in the Ivory Tower

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
They stood eye to eye and nose to nose for almost 40 minutes, exchanging heavy talk, soulful looks and angry glares outside Mrs. Fields Cookies at the food court entrance, he a brooding Ethan Hawke in leather jacket with white fur collar, she a waiflike Wynona Ryder in black.
It was the kind of minor mall world melodrama that plays out all the time whenever kids gather over their Whoppers, Pizza Hut personal pan pizzas and Freshens Premium Yogurt -- everywhere from Tysons Corner Center in suburban Washington to the Galleria in Dallas and Phipps Plaza in Atlanta. The only difference was that this was no shopping center, it was the student union at Boston University. 
 More and more, the Golden Arches are entering the Ivory Tower. And Metropolitan Boston, with its 250,000 students at 57 colleges and universities, reflects the trend.
At one extreme is Boston University with its glitzy new $5.7 million food court in the George Sherman Student Union and its plans to remodel the university bookstore into the first on-campus Barnes and Noble superstore.
At the other is Harvard, with its elegant 19th century dining halls where students -- or their parents -- still pay for the traditional 21-meals-a-week plan that finances the university's $22 million-a-year residential food service program. No one expects a Jack in the Box or a Taco Bell in Harvard Yard, though even Harvard will offer an upscale grazing emporium on campus this fall that includes a familiar name or two.
Across the country from Boston to California, the question is not whether to wed college and commercial culture, but how far to take the merger -- a merger that has raised revenues for many schools, along questions about the balance between economic realities and an atmosphere traditionally associated with higher learning.
Increasingly, the culture and values of the mall are coloring the culture and values of the university; even schools resisting the trend are taking note of it.
"We think the Harvard name is better than the Pizza Hut name, so we don't tend to mingle," says Michael P. Berry, director of dining services at Harvard, who also does service consulting for other universities. "But I think you'll see in general that especially in schools that have a vibrant student center or union, you'll see those student unions become increasingly malls with multiple stores. Let's face it, Main Street America doesn't exist anymore. Mall America exists. Why should collegiate life be the last bastion of something that doesn't exist anymore?"
Why indeed? Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, N.C., offers Pizza Hut and Taco Bell in its student center. And the University of South Carolina has had a 14-store shopping mall in its student center for the last 10 years. "We built a mall on campus because today's students are mall children," said Richard Wertz, the school's director of business and finance. "They grew up going to the shopping malls and looking for branded concepts. They all have VCR's and computers and everything else as opposed to 10 or 20 years ago. Colleges have to adapt to changing times." The mall has generated $1 million in scholarship money for the university.
While there has been some commercial presence on campuses for decades, with bank branches and the occasional fast food outlet in the student union, the pressures to increase the commerce have risen dramatically. Universities, under growing financial stress, are receptive to almost anything that promises to cut costs or increase revenue.
And students who have grown up eating at Taco Bell and breezing over to the Blockbuster Video have come to expect the brand name at, or near, their university. "I remember a place in Denver that used to advertise, 'No arches, no clown, just the best burgers in town,' " says David Suiter, now a reference librarian at Boston University. "You'd look at it and think, 'Naah, I don't think so.' There's something scary about a nonfranchise place."
In general, schools get a fee and a percentage of proceeds for allowing franchises on campus. The franchises also get them out of the labor-intensive and costly food service business.
Mr. Berry of Harvard said a recent study indicated that 92 percent of schools would consider bringing commercial brand names on campus, 54 percent do it and 62 percent say there is a lot of student pressure to do it.
For their part, corporations, who have already filled most of the prime commercial locations, are lusting after the roughly 12 million students on the campuses of about 3,500 colleges and universities. Denny Lynch, spokesman for Wendy's International Inc., based in Columbus, Ohio, said some fast-food companies may feign indifference to confuse the competition, but they are all eager to get a share of the campus business.
"People will lie about it, but this is a big deal, a very big deal," said Mr. Lynch, whose company operates on 13 campuses including the University of Michigan, the University of Texas, Ohio State, Rutgers and the University of Toledo. "Nontraditional sites, particularly college campuses, are very hot. There is a captive audience of your customers 18 to 24, actually 18 to 30, that is a very important customer base."
And so Barnes & Noble Bookstores Inc. (an offshoot of Barnes & Noble Inc.) now anonymously runs hundreds of campus bookstores, while youth-oriented businesses like Clinique Cosmetics, Mailboxes etc., Body Shop, Blockbuster Video and Perry Ellis clothes have cropped up at student unions.
Given President John Silber's oft-stated interest in bringing hard-nosed business practices to academia, it's not surprising that Boston University, with its sprawling 29,000-student campus on the south side of the Charles River, is in the forefront of the merging of campus and commerce.
Recent graduates say they find the new look a little disorienting when they return to visit.
"I walked in there and my jaw dropped to the floor, it was like the Prudential Center only nicer, with mahagony furnishings and TV's in every corner," said Rachelle Sanders, a 1990 B.U. graduate who is now assistant director of public relations at Trinity College in Connecticut. "I guess it's the new B.U., and I liked it, but I thought, 'This is a bit much."'
When university officials planned the student center renovation, they visited airport dining plazas and malls around the country, including the huge Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn., to get ideas for the layout and design.
What they came up with is all neon, chrome, steel and bustle. There is a convenience store built to look like a 7-Eleven or Majik Market. The food area, operated by the Aramark Corporation, the giant Philadelphia food company that caters airline meals and runs mall food courts, has a snack area, with Mrs. Fields cookies, Avanti gourmet coffee and Freshens Premium Yogurt. The central section houses Burger King, D'Angelo's Deli, Pizza Hut and four nonfranchise options -- from a Mexican food operation to something called Changing Scenes, whose electric sign changes colors and whose menu includes Cajun catfish, shrimp jambalya and blackened swordfish.
"It's better than the school I came from -- all they had was a Roy Rogers and some sandwiches," said Annemarie Foley, who recently transferred from Nassau Community College to B.U. Smoking a cigarette and sitting by one of the 13 television sets as she ate a Burger King cheeseburger, she added: "And I can watch Sally Jesse Raphael, too."
Like many schools, B.U. offers a hybrid meal plan. Students can pick from six dining options, with some heavy on traditional dorm dining and others offering more fast-food meals a week.
A number of B.U. students, like those in the Warren Tower dormitory dining room, say they prefer the slower pace of the dining halls, where the premium is more on conversation than eating and running. "I come here with a couple of friends, and we can sit and talk," says Chris Laphrop, a freshman who says he avoids the Sherman Center. "I couldn't concentrate there. It's too loud."
But given the pace at B.U., where many students live off campus and cram as much study into as few years as possible, fast food makes sense for others.
"There is a lot more pressure to make sure you have experience to get jobs to pay off your loans," said Christina Glendon, who works part time at a campus dining hall, volunteers at a museum, runs a show on a local radio station and is a full-time student. She added: "Socializing is really speeding up -- you gotta eat quick. Nobody talks anymore."
Across the river at M.I.T., all the dorms once had dining halls -- sociable islands on a campus with legendary academic pressures. But because of increasing financial strains, three of the six halls have closed in recent years, and none serves lunch anymore. M.I.T. Students either use dorm kitchens, the microwaves in their rooms or they eat at the Harold E. Lobdell Memorial Dining Room's food court -- a slightly smaller version of the lineup fond at B.U. -- Pizza Hut, Burger King and D'Angelo's.
The traditional dining halls still have a distinct following among some students at M.I.T. At Baker Hall, instead of two- or four-person plastic mall tables, kids are sitting around big round tables, in groups of five or six and actually conversing. There's boisterous, animated talk about sports or physics labs or boring lectures.
Baker Hall, built 45 years ago, was designed by the Finnish architect Alvar Aalto. It was designed not as a mall but as a dorm, with the idea that the dining hall, on the lower level of a skylight atrium, would be the principal architectural element.
"It's important for students to have a place to get together, so that a dorm is something other than a place to eat and sleep," said Adam London, a senior studying aerospace engineering who recently completed his term as dorm president. "There's so much pressure here to get good grades, to go to grad school, to go to med school, you need something like this to bring people together."
But the truth is that most students want both the mall and the dining area, and the more they gravitate toward the mall, the more dubious the survival of dorm dining halls. At Baker, students have organized a committee to try to cut costs to keep the dining hall open, and losses of $10,000 a month have been cut in half.
But, though it may be one of the nation's most prestigious universities, M.I.T. last year ran a $13 million operating deficit and hopes to trim $40 million in costs over the next three years. Some at M.I.T. fear there's a good chance the dorm dining halls will be among the things to go.
The fast-food franchises have helped both B.U. and M.I.T. financially. At B.U., food is a $28 million business, and food services have always been profitable, but the new food court led to a dramatic increase in revenues, says Craig Hill, assistant vice president of business affairs.
"It's much more profitable than it was before," said Mr. Hill, who declined to release specific figures. "It's just a more efficient operation. Labor costs as a percentage of sales are much lower, food costs are lower and sales are way up."
At M.I.T., the $10 million food operations have finally reached a break-even point for the university after years of running deficits.
Robert McBurney, Aramark's food service director at M.I.T., says every school is different in terms of what students and the university want. (Aramark serves more than 200 million meals a year at more than 350 colleges and universities) But he said outside contractors save universities money in numerous ways.
"There are reduced employee benefit costs, and employees are on our payroll and not the university's," he said. "Food purchasing power is much greater because we can do one-stop shopping with national suppliers. We have computerized food production systems and accounting systems. There's just a level of expertise that's beyond what a university can provide."
Bill Dillon, vice president for market development of Aramark's campus service division, says the company usually increases food-service revenues at universities by 10 to 15 percent.
It's a bit different up Massachusetts Avenue at Harvard University.
True, many students want some relief from the meal plan, and it seems likely that before long, such eating plans will probably include a few hundred dollars' worth of "points" that can be used outside the dorms at campus snack bars and pizza parlors.
And when the university completes its $26 million renovation of historic Memorial Hall next year, with its soaring cathedral design and $6 million of stained glass, its lower level Loker Commons will include Harvard's tony, largely non-branded, version of a food court.
There will be a sweet shop with Freshens yogurt; a Southwestern cuisine area called Cilantro, with marinated and charbroiled meats and up to six kinds of salsa; Cafe Zinc, with panini sandwiches of artichoke with provolone and roasted peppers; Harvard's in-house Greenhouse pizza in California concepts like Moo Shu Pizza and designer soups that combine zucchini with red peppers or grilled eggplant with polenta .
After all, even Harvard students sometimes want a smidgeon of mall culture. "Have you ever been to Dartmouth?" Liza Studen, a junior from Cleveland asked Jennifer Weh, a junior from Farmington Hills, Mich., over lunch at Eliot House one afternoon. "The food is so much better. It's like eating at Friday's."
But for the most part, Harvard undergraduates are not much interested in changing the venerable house system, and Mr. Berry is quick to extol its academic, intellectual and social virtues, with meals a time for conversation as much as food. Having studied at Oxford and the University of Chicago and having worked at the University of California at Irvine before he came to Harvard in 1991, he also knows that well-endowed Harvard is one of the few places where the venerable dining hall system can work.
"Our hourly wage is $15.90 an hour with benefits," he said. "The food service industry was meant to run on minimum wage." How, he asked, can most universities "run a food service on $15.90 an hour if, from a totally fiscal standpoint, the numbers don't pencil? So there are big arguments for privatizing."
As for arguments against it, Mr. Berry said, "the question is, do these outside entities understand the mission of the university or do they understand the mission of The Gap?"
So far, most of the franchise activity on campus has been in food service, but the next wave is clearly in consumer goods.
Even now, the six-story Boston University Bookstore Mall is a testament to the buying power and consumer needs of today's students. It carries MacIntosh and IBM computers, $800 Global Village One World Faxes, $33 Simpsons screensavers, $499 IBM Laserprinters, $169 Nikon Discmans, $285 Mount Blanc pens and $54.95 Braun Coffeemakers.
This summer the store, which does $20 million in business a year, excluding computers and other areas run independently, will be remodeled into a Barnes and Noble Superstore -- Barnes and Noble at Boston University, a lease-management arrangement in which the university will get a fee from Barnes and Noble, plus a share of revenues. Next door will be an outlet of The Gap, under a standard tenant arrangement: The store will pay a rental fee to operate on land owned by the university.
Already, marketing students at Stetson University in Florida operate a franchise of the Body Shop, which sells cosmetics. And last year, DePaul University opened the Chicago Music Mart, a 15-tenant mall, which includes retailers like Baldwin Piano and Organ, Carl Fischer Music, the Crow's Nest (which sells compact discs) and other shops.
So far, most schools are resisting this second wave of franchises. The University of Maryland is redoing its student union but has decided to limit its commercial service shops to stores allied to academic pursuits, like Mailboxes etc., which offers fax, copying and shipping.
And a number of older East Coast universities have held the line against franchises altogether. "I'm here to study," said Sharon Goldstein, a junior from Boston at Clark University, "not go shopping."
All this franchising presents universities with new ethical and business dilemmas.
"There are touchy questions about how far to take it," said Mr. Wertz of the University of South Carolina. "There's a fine line about how far is too far."
At Texas A&M University, a top administrator last November was convicted of soliciting benefits from Barnes and Noble Bookstores in connection with a $10 million contract awarded in 1990 to operate the university bookstore. Law enforcement officials are investigating possible impropieties in other A&M outside contracts as well.
And at Georgia Tech in Atlanta, it's not a question of misconduct, but of how much to mingle the two cultures. In January, the Georgia Tech Athletic Association and McDonald's announced a $5.5 million sponsorship program, designed to help fund a $25 million renovation that includes a $12 million upgrade of its main athletic arena, Alexander Memorial Coliseum.
But under the terms of the 25-year agreement, the coliseum can be renamed either McDonald's Center or Alexander Memorial Coliseum at McDonald's Center. McDonald's also gets the right to put its logo on the coliseum floor, the exterior of the building, the backs of players' chairs, the scoreboard and all tickets and promotional materials. And it can build a large freestanding monument as a sign and get free advertising space in all inside front covers of basketball and football programs for seven years.
In March, the Georgia Attorney General said the arrangement violated the State Constitution because it improperly mingles "the commercial name and reputation of McDonald's with the good will, property and higher education programs of the state."
University and corporate officials are trying to put together a deal that will meet with state approval. And school officials, while pointing out that the athletic association is independent of the university administration, say the issues raised are not easy ones.
"Everyone is asking the question of how far can an institution go before it becomes unseemly, tawdry, improper," said Jim Langley, vice president for external affairs at Georgia Tech. "We believe this is probably a recognition of modern realities, and we hope that it sends a signal of a university that is trying to respond to economic realities in an innovative way and doing so without taxpayer support."
Still, Georgia Tech has its limits. "In this deal we have negotiated with McDonald's, they cover the floor during commencements," Mr. Langley said. "We thought a commercial trademark at a commencement would be inappropriate."
At Harvard, meanwhile, the marketing dilemmas have more to do with what to put the university name on than with what names to bring on campus. The hot new product on campus is Crimson Gourmet Coffee, roasted exclusively for Harvard by Seattle's Best Coffee, sold in $49 gift boxes and advertised in the Harvard alumni magazine under the headline, "You went to The School. Now drink The Coffee."
"Here's something else," Mr. Berry said, handing a visitor a small box of Harvard Commemorative Chocolates. Inside were three pieces of dark sweet chocolate handcrafted by V.I.P. Sweets of Boston, each bearing the Harvard seal.
"That veritas shield," he said happily. "That's a logo as good as Coke."

HEADLINE: Embargoed Fuel Sent To Serbs via Albania

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: SHKODER, Albania, March 29

 BODY:
As the warring parties in Bosnia gear up for their expected spring offensive, vast quantities of high-grade fuel, which is used in tanks and fighter jets, are being openly smuggled across the lake here into Yugoslavia, in violation of a United Nations embargo.
The flow of jet fuel from this small country to Yugoslavia gushed a couple of months ago, and is believed to be destined for "the Serbian war machine," as one Western diplomat put it. In addition, millions of gallons of regular gasoline and diesel fuel have moved in recent months from Albania to its northern neighbor. 
 The United States has repeatedly expressed its concerns to the Albanian Government about the trade, which sanctions monitors in Europe say has reached nearly one million gallons a day at times.
The Clinton Administration is considering an official diplomatic note, as this country on the Adriatic has become the fuel highway to its pariah neighbor.
On a 20-mile stretch of bad road that runs along the lake, there are at least 20 gas stations, whose underground tanks can hold some 450,000 gallons, and more stations are being built.
This is in a dirt-poor region with little more than sheep and peasants, where yoked cattle pull wooden carts and the bicycle is a more common mode of transportation than the automobile.
While fuel is reaching Serbia by other routes, notably along the Danube, Albania is supplying more than all other countries combined, said Antonio Napolitano, the sanctions coordinator for the European Union and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, whose office is in Brussels. Mr. Napolitano, an Italian diplomat, advised the Albanian Government and foreign diplomats of this when he was here in February.
The Albanian Government denies that it is allowing sanctions violations. In an interview, President Sali Berisha said that statements by Ambassador Napolitano and the American Embassy about the high level of fuel passing through Albania to Yugoslavia were "absolutely not justified."
He said that while there was some smuggling, it did not amount to much. His Government is doing the best it can to control the smuggling, he said, given its lack of resources and police training.
United Nations sanctions prohibit the shipment of all but a few categories of goods, like medical supplies and food, to Serbia and Montenegro, the constituent states of the current Yugoslavia. Stopping imports of fuel is of particular concern because of its military uses, Mr. Napolitano said.
The sanctions were intended to punish the Serbs for "ethnic cleansing" and for Yugoslavia's refusal to recognize Croatia and Bosnia.
The fuel comes to Albania from Italian and Greek companies and enters Yugoslavia through Montenegro. The border between Albania and Montenegro runs through the lake.
It is not known exactly what happens to the fuel after that. But diplomats here say they believe that most of it does not remain in Montenegro, which they note has a border with Serbian-controlled areas of Bosnia, as well as with Serbia.
The international sanctions monitoring team in Albania, which includes Americans on loan from the customs agency as well as Italians, Belgians and Swiss, receives praise from American and European diplomats for its work. But it has no mandate to stop the trade, only to monitor and report on it.
And it is hampered in doing even that by a lack of cooperation from the Albanian authorities, a report by Mr. Napolitano's office says.
President Berisha cited steps that his Government had taken to curb the flow of fuel to Yugoslavia. These include requiring gas stations to be licensed and prohibiting trade in oil products within three miles of the lake.
Under another new law, Albanian officials must verify that a shipment is intended for a legitimate user, and then notify officials in the shipping country before the vessel is to be allowed to leave its home port.
These measures worked for a while to reduce the trade, but it has been increasing again, the sanctions monitors and diplomats here say.
A visit to this city makes it obvious that the measures are not being enforced. At least nine of the gas stations that should have been closed because of the three-mile limit are still pumping gas; most of the other stations lie not more than a few hundred yards outside the limit.
During the first two weeks in February, nearly 3.5 million gallons of fuel was imported into Albania, including 1.3 million gallons of Jet Fuel-1, Albanian customs documents indicate.
During the last 10 days in February, 100,000 gallons a day was taken into northern Albania by truck, the Albanian police have calculated. Western diplomats say the figure is a gross underestimate.
Northern Albania has only 1,583 registered motorized vehicles, according to Albania's Institute of Statistics.
This country, the size of Maryland, was kept undeveloped during four decades of harsh Communist rule by Enver Hoxha, and is the most economically backward in Europe, with two-thirds of the population of 3 million living off the land.
It has only 140,000 motor vehicles, including tractors and sidecar motorcycles as well as passenger cars and trucks, according to the statistics bureau. There is no four-lane highway in the entire country, and the only access road to the single-runway international airport goes over a one-lane bridge.
The oil trade is a major source of legal revenue for the country, which is struggling to modernize. National authorities collect customs duties on the fuel products, ranging from 70 percent to 100 percent of their declared value.
Here in this impoverished region, the local government collected $22 million in taxes in 1994, virtually all of it as result of the fuel trade, an Albanian newspaper, Zeri i Popullit, reported in February. This was up from $8 million in 1993, the paper said.
At first the oil trade with Yugoslavia was a mom-and-pop operation, but it has now been taken over by more organized criminal organizations, foreign diplomats here said.
The oil companies ship the fuel to the Albanian ports of Durres and Vlora on the Adriatic Sea, where Albanian-registered companies take control of it. Tanker trucks then make a long and arduous journey north, creeping along at maybe 20 miles an hour over a bad road. Once at Shkoder, the gas is pumped into the tanks of one of the gas stations, most of which are little more than a couple of pumps and a shack where a man sits.
It is quickly pumped out into other trucks -- the stations operate around the clock, but are busiest at night, residents say -- and taken the short distance to the shores of Lake Shkoder.
The smugglers are so confident that they will not be bothered that they often operate in broad daylight.
About noon today, a truck turned off the hard-surfaced road and headed west over a dirt road a couple of miles to the lake. It passed a border post, where Albanian soldiers carrying automatic rifles were on duty in their drab, heavy uniforms. The truck was followed by a Ford and a Mercedes, each with four men, an unusual sight in this barren land.
At the lake, less than a half mile from the border post, the fuel was transferred into 50-gallon drums in two long, heavy metal boats.
A mile or so up the shore, the system is more efficient. By means of a long black plastic tube, the fuel is transferred directly from trucks to small barges.
Today, after one truck's cargo was drained into a flat-topped barge that the operator said had a capacity of 6,500 gallons, and the truck pulled away, another truck moved into place and the process continued. Then the barge, with a 25-horsepower outboard motor, pulled away into the lake, heading for Yugoslavia.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
'If You're Breathing' You Can Get a Home Mortgage

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
GETTING a home mortgage these days can be as bewildering as negotiating a path through Alice's Wonderland. In Connecticut, as elsewhere, the array of mortgage instruments, brokers, banks, and a smorgasbord of mortgage-lending entities seems endless.
Because of the prolonged sluggish housing market competition among lenders is intense. They are reaching out by tailoring mortgage loans to meet the requirements of borrowers whose credit-worthiness may not be up to the standards of the secondary market to which loans are commonly sold. The beneficiaries may be self-employed people with erratic or unverifiable income. 
 According to David Olson, president of Olson Research Company in Columbia, Md., trackers of the mortgage industry, "self-employed people may be a lot of risk, but with all the layoffs I don't know what good a salary is anymore."
"If you are breathing you can get a loan," he said.
Beside the nationally advertised companies that promise "when your bank says no" or "just dial 1-800-loanyes" there are some home-grown varieties. Fairbank Mortgage Company, a 30-year-old Waterbury firm, does not resell its loans and therefore is able to negotiate with buyers on a more liberal basis. It caters mostly to affluent customers who will pay up to half a percentage point more in interest and make down payments of 20 percent and higher.
In the last five years Fairbank expanded into Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Long Island. "A large part of our business is the self-employed," said Craig Cooper, executive vice president of the company. "It's an extremely fast-growing segment, generated by economic conditions."
The recession and resulting layoffs of high-level employees created a pool of home-equity-loan applicants as well as first mortgage borrowers. "People have gone out and established businesses on their own," said Mr. Cooper. "They may have good credit but their adjusted gross income doesn't qualify them for a standard bank loan."
Perhaps not, but banks are also wading into the nontraditional mortgage market. "A lot of people went back to work for their old companies as freelance consultants," said Thomas W. Deutsch, loan officer with Chemical Bank in West Hartford and Stamford. "We will accommodate customers at 5.5 percent, below the treasury rate of 6.38 percent, on a 1-year adjustable loan with no points, no fees, no appraisals."
But a year from now, he added, the 30-year fixed rate will be 9.375 percent and there will be a $250 charge to borrowers who want to convert from an adjustable-rate loan.
A rating from A to D, indicating the lender's estimate of the borrower's credit worthiness and differing from lender to lender, establishes the tailoring of the loan.
"An A-rated borrower," said Mr. Cooper, "would be someone who had made a mortgage payment 30 days late only once, had a minor credit card delinquency and whose monthly mortgage, taxes, insurance and credit-card bills made up no more than 50 percent of his income. In the traditional market it would be 33 to 36 percent of income."
A C-rated borrower, Mr. Cooper said, would have been late with mortgage payments four or five times, have serious credit-card delinquencies and monthly obligations beyond the 50 percent of income. "As credit becomes weaker, the interest rate goes higher," he said.
GARY DEANE, mortgage banker for Raveis Mortgage Company, a division of William Raveis Real Estate, noted that "with 30 percent down and a decent credit file nobody cares about the customer's employment history or if he even has a job."
"The lower rated B, C, and D customers were an underserviced market," said Kathryn Freda, first vice president of the Connecticut Mortgage Bankers Association in West Hartford. "Just because someone's credit was ruined in a divorce or illness, or he lost a job, doesn't mean he shouldn't have a house to live in."
Roger Stolpen, for instance, fell into the D category. Today he runs a medical transportation and wheelchair-repair service out of his home in Stamford, but last year he was financially strapped after a divorce, and his credit had been ruined by a foreclosure on his former house two years ago.
Needing a house for himself and his business, he negotiated a 13 percent first mortgage with Fairbank last December, with 20 percent down. The current A-loan rate is just under 9 percent. He also paid 4 points, or 4 percent of the mortgage, divided between the mortgage broker and Fairbank.
"For someone with an unmarred credit rating it was high, but for my situation it's fair," he said. After one year he can try to negotiate a better rate.
About 60 percent of people who need financing use a mortgage broker, said L. Edward Viscovi, president of Fidelity Mortgage Services in Branford. "Self-employed people have the most to gain by having a broker put a package together and present it to a likely lender." Mortgage companies seek out business through the brokers, and brokers deal only with such companies, not with banks.
Carl Freyer used neither a broker nor a bank. A self-employed investment banker who owns two condominiums in St. Thomas, the Virgin Islands, but lives for half the year and conducts his business from his home in Greenwich, he needed a home-equity loan to consolidate debts.
"My income is undefinable -- from a variety of sources," he said. "I knew I wouldn't qualify at a bank." His self-employed wife, Marina, owns the house but her income as a consultant for food magazines would not qualify either.
"He owns substantial property and has good credit," said Mr. Cooper, "so we made him a large loan." The high rate, said Mr. Freyer, "wasn't important compared to consolidating loans on which I was paying very high rates."
COMPETITION among lenders has generated a rash of acquisitions, and as volume is increased through takeovers lenders can afford lower rates. Of those operating in Connecticut, Chemical Bank took over Margaretten & Company last year, and Chase Manhattan acquired American Residential Mortgage of New Jersey and Troy Nichols of Louisiana in 1993 and 1994.
"Twenty-five percent of our loans are to self-employed accountants, lawyers, doctors, small manufacturers -- the high end of the scale," said Deborah O'Brien, vice president of Chase Manhattan's Home Mortgage Corporation in Norwalk.
Intent on maximizing its options, Chase refined its operations last year by forming Chase Alternative Funding specifically for B to D quality borrowers. It has offices in Norwalk, Branford and Rocky Hill.
"We were missing a lot of good business because it didn't meet A-loan requirements," said Jay Connor, a vice president of the division. Interest on a no-points, A-rated loan under $203,150 is 8.875 percent, 11.75 for a B loan, and 14 percent for a D loan. Loans over $203,150 command a slightly higher interest rate.
Some borrowers, according to Margaret Osborn, customer service manager of McCue Mortgage Company in New Britain, split their 20 percent down payment into 5 percent cash and 15 percent that buys an annuity that funds the rest of down payment. The annuity protects the buyer from possible losses if it becomes necessary to sell the house in an unfavorable market.
Mr. Olson, the researcher, thinks that mortgage interest will drop as treasury rates back down to their 1993 levels of 5.3 percent in 1996.
"If anybody wants to wait," he adds.

The adjustable-rate loan that is offered with no points or fees and a $250 charge for conversion to a fixed-rate mortgage after one year carries an initial interest rate of 7 percent, not 5.5 percent.

HEADLINE: A Play's Invisible Character

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

 BODY:
WHEN "Having Our Say" opens at the Booth Theater on Thursday, one of the play's main characters will be off stage. She is Amy Hill Hearth of Ossining, a former contributor to The New York Times who was the co-author of the best-selling book on which the play is based.
The other authors, possibly the oldest first-time authors in history, are Dr. A. Elizabeth Delany, known as Bessie, and her sister Sarah Delany, known as Sadie, the now world famous centenarians of Mount Vernon. 
 The play is set in the house that the sisters, 103 and 105 years old, have shared for 37 years, and the actresses who portray them are Gloria Foster and Mary Alice. "They welcome the audience in, just as they welcomed me in, and they tell their story," said Ms. Hearth, who shaped 18 months of interviews into an oral history involving slavery, two world wars and the evolution of the black middle class in America.
"In the play, I am invisible; I am the audience," Ms. Hearth said. "It's very peculiar for me to watch the play, because it mimics the experience I had with the sisters in their kitchen."
Now that "Having Our Say," which broke box office records during its pre-Broadway run at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, is in its final week of previews, Ms. Hearth said she is too excited to sleep or eat. Since the book was published to rave reviews by Kodansha International in 1991, "every day is like Christmas," she said. There have been countless television, radio and newspaper interviews, book awards in adult and young adult categories and sales that so far have exceeded 350,000 copies in hard cover and 500,000 copies in paperback. The hard cover edition spent 28 weeks on The New York Times Best Seller List, and the paperback is now in its 25th week on the list.
The book has been translated into Japanese, Spanish, German and Italian, and last November Kodansha published a sequel, "The Delany Sisters' Book of Everyday Wisdom," also written with Ms. Hearth. Camille O. Cosby is a producer of the play, along with Judith Rutherford James, and Emily Mann is the playwright and director. Ms. Hearth, who said she chose not to adapt the book herself, is an artistic consultant.
The most recent honor to befall the Delanys -- the daughters of a former slave whose 10 children all went to college -- was the March 23 visit to their house by Hillary Rodham Clinton.
"I think I've finally convinced them that they are famous," said Ms. Hearth, who played the role of hostess during the First Lady's visit. The writer, who has developed a close personal relationship with the women, also persuaded the Secret Service not to upset their domestic routine too much. "You have to train people -- people don't realize what it's like to be over 100 years old," she said.
Ms. Hearth, who will turn 37 on April 10, said success has spoiled neither her nor the Delanys, whom she occasionally refers to as "the girls." The sisters live without a telephone and watch black and white television. Ms. Hearth says she herself drives the same car and lives in the same three-bedroom house on its one-third acre with her husband, Blair Hearth, a Methodist minister who is the director of gift planning for the Monmouth Health Care Foundation in Long Branch, N.J.
Her straight hairdo, secured with a plain headband, is reminiscent of Mrs. Clinton in earlier days, and she wears mid-length skirts with sensible boots. But she was interviewed behind shaded glass as a driver ferried her to the theater, and she exuded a kind of amazed delight at everything that has happened since the book, her first, was published.
Ms. Hearth met the sisters when, as a freelance writer, she was assigned to do a story about them for the Westchester Weekly. Because they had no phone, she arranged to be introduced to them by a neighbor. Then she had to persuade them to be interviewed.
"They didn't think they were important enough," she said. "I had to convince them and give this little impromptu speech -- that I thought it was very important that people from their generation be represented, especially black women who hadn't had much opportunity. I guess my enthusiasm rubbed off."
When it was published in The Times on Sept. 22, 1991, the story of Bessie Delany, one of the first black women to become a dentist in New York City, and Sadie Delany, a teacher, drew responses from blacks and whites alike. "There was this sense of joy among black Americans that these two women were being paid attention to," Ms. Hearth said. "White Americans were very interested, too. They didn't know about things from this perspective."
A White Plains teacher called to say she had changed her lesson plan for the day in order to discuss the story. Minato Asakawa of Hartsdale also called. As the publisher of the Manhattan-based Kodansha America, a Japanese-owned company, he said he was attracted to the characters in the article: the highly educated sisters, so "unusual for black women at that time," he said recently, and their father, an Episcopal bishop who "seemed to be a decent, hard-working, disciplined person -- that's not easy to find and not just in the United States."
The three women signed a book contract with Kodansha four months later, after Ms. Hearth convinced the Delanys to do a full oral history. "I wanted the sisters to speak for themselves," she said. "I was intent on capturing their personalities, which were very different." They talked twice a week in the Delanys' kitchen and in their garden. Ms. Hearth said that after a few months she turned off the tape recorder and got "rich material" simply by working alongside the women.
They talked about the humiliation of Jim Crow laws in Raleigh, N.C., where the sisters grew up; about Harlem, where the two lived together -- neither ever married -- in the 1920's and 30's, and about Sarah Delany's triumph in becoming the first black home economics teacher in a New York City high school.
Ms. Hearth brought her own memories to the conversations; she had attended a segregated elementary school in Columbia, S.C., where she said, "The white teacher would not let me write about Harriet Tubman," who was one of her heroes. "They wanted me to write about Betsy Ross or Dolley Madison," she said. "It's not just black people who have been deprived of their history. White people have too." Now, she added, "Having Our Say" is being used in the North Carolina school curriculum and has been nominated for the South Carolina Young Adult Book Award by the South Carolina Association of School Librarians.
The women had frank talks about race, which Ms. Hearth said affected her profoundly. "What we did was very daring," she said. "We agreed not to worry about each other. White people are terrified to talk about race with a black person because they are afraid of saying the wrong thing. I began to feel things on a level that was more than sympathy. Bessie said I was about as close to understanding as a white person could be."
Sometimes the conversations were very painful, and she said she "felt almost ashamed to be white."
"But they would say, 'Don't worry, child, it's not your fault,' " Ms. Hearth said. "I encouraged them to be candid, because that was the point."
The book succeeded because of the intimacy that developed among them, Ms. Hearth said. "The relationship is why the book is good," she said. "There were a lot of opportunities to test trust. They got to see they could count on me, as I could count on them."
Ms. Hearth is fiercely protective of the sisters' health and feelings and screens requests to interview them. She is especially alert, she said, to people who may ask crude questions about race or marriage, or who may not speak to them respectfully.
"One of the things of which I'm most proud is that they have been treated well," she said. "It's a fine line -- these are very independent people, and they make their own decisions."
The sisters declined to be interviewed for this article, because, Ms. Hearth said, "They said: 'Well if it's a story about you, we shouldn't be in it. It's always about us.' " Her voice bubbles with fun and admiration when she talks about them. She calls them funny, brilliant, "the smartest people I have ever met." The way she told it, it is a love story, and the listener can believe that money, a taboo subject with her , is not the most important way she has profited from this experience.
"My main goal has been to make it as fun as possible for the sisters, to make sure they get what they want," she said. "They are the boss, and when people are very old, most other people don't let that happen."
