HEADLINE: A Play's Invisible Character

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

 BODY:
WHEN "Having Our Say" opens at the Booth Theater on Thursday, one of the play's main characters will be off stage. She is Amy Hill Hearth of Ossining, a former contributor to The New York Times who was the co-author of the best-selling book on which the play is based.
The other authors, possibly the oldest first-time authors in history, are Dr. A. Elizabeth Delany, known as Bessie, and her sister Sarah Delany, known as Sadie, the now world famous centenarians of Mount Vernon. 
 The play is set in the house that the sisters, 103 and 105 years old, have shared for 37 years, and the actresses who portray them are Gloria Foster and Mary Alice. "They welcome the audience in, just as they welcomed me in, and they tell their story," said Ms. Hearth, who shaped 18 months of interviews into an oral history involving slavery, two world wars and the evolution of the black middle class in America.
"In the play, I am invisible; I am the audience," Ms. Hearth said. "It's very peculiar for me to watch the play, because it mimics the experience I had with the sisters in their kitchen."
Now that "Having Our Say," which broke box office records during its pre-Broadway run at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, is in its final week of previews, Ms. Hearth said she is too excited to sleep or eat. Since the book was published to rave reviews by Kodansha International in 1991, "every day is like Christmas," she said. There have been countless television, radio and newspaper interviews, book awards in adult and young adult categories and sales that so far have exceeded 350,000 copies in hard cover and 500,000 copies in paperback. The hard cover edition spent 28 weeks on The New York Times Best Seller List, and the paperback is now in its 25th week on the list.
The book has been translated into Japanese, Spanish, German and Italian, and last November Kodansha published a sequel, "The Delany Sisters' Book of Everyday Wisdom," also written with Ms. Hearth. Camille O. Cosby is a producer of the play, along with Judith Rutherford James, and Emily Mann is the playwright and director. Ms. Hearth, who said she chose not to adapt the book herself, is an artistic consultant.
The most recent honor to befall the Delanys -- the daughters of a former slave whose 10 children all went to college -- was the March 23 visit to their house by Hillary Rodham Clinton.
"I think I've finally convinced them that they are famous," said Ms. Hearth, who played the role of hostess during the First Lady's visit. The writer, who has developed a close personal relationship with the women, also persuaded the Secret Service not to upset their domestic routine too much. "You have to train people -- people don't realize what it's like to be over 100 years old," she said.
Ms. Hearth, who will turn 37 on April 10, said success has spoiled neither her nor the Delanys, whom she occasionally refers to as "the girls." The sisters live without a telephone and watch black and white television. Ms. Hearth says she herself drives the same car and lives in the same three-bedroom house on its one-third acre with her husband, Blair Hearth, a Methodist minister who is the director of gift planning for the Monmouth Health Care Foundation in Long Branch, N.J.
Her straight hairdo, secured with a plain headband, is reminiscent of Mrs. Clinton in earlier days, and she wears mid-length skirts with sensible boots. But she was interviewed behind shaded glass as a driver ferried her to the theater, and she exuded a kind of amazed delight at everything that has happened since the book, her first, was published.
Ms. Hearth met the sisters when, as a freelance writer, she was assigned to do a story about them for the Westchester Weekly. Because they had no phone, she arranged to be introduced to them by a neighbor. Then she had to persuade them to be interviewed.
"They didn't think they were important enough," she said. "I had to convince them and give this little impromptu speech -- that I thought it was very important that people from their generation be represented, especially black women who hadn't had much opportunity. I guess my enthusiasm rubbed off."
When it was published in The Times on Sept. 22, 1991, the story of Bessie Delany, one of the first black women to become a dentist in New York City, and Sadie Delany, a teacher, drew responses from blacks and whites alike. "There was this sense of joy among black Americans that these two women were being paid attention to," Ms. Hearth said. "White Americans were very interested, too. They didn't know about things from this perspective."
A White Plains teacher called to say she had changed her lesson plan for the day in order to discuss the story. Minato Asakawa of Hartsdale also called. As the publisher of the Manhattan-based Kodansha America, a Japanese-owned company, he said he was attracted to the characters in the article: the highly educated sisters, so "unusual for black women at that time," he said recently, and their father, an Episcopal bishop who "seemed to be a decent, hard-working, disciplined person -- that's not easy to find and not just in the United States."
The three women signed a book contract with Kodansha four months later, after Ms. Hearth convinced the Delanys to do a full oral history. "I wanted the sisters to speak for themselves," she said. "I was intent on capturing their personalities, which were very different." They talked twice a week in the Delanys' kitchen and in their garden. Ms. Hearth said that after a few months she turned off the tape recorder and got "rich material" simply by working alongside the women.
They talked about the humiliation of Jim Crow laws in Raleigh, N.C., where the sisters grew up; about Harlem, where the two lived together -- neither ever married -- in the 1920's and 30's, and about Sarah Delany's triumph in becoming the first black home economics teacher in a New York City high school.
Ms. Hearth brought her own memories to the conversations; she had attended a segregated elementary school in Columbia, S.C., where she said, "The white teacher would not let me write about Harriet Tubman," who was one of her heroes. "They wanted me to write about Betsy Ross or Dolley Madison," she said. "It's not just black people who have been deprived of their history. White people have too." Now, she added, "Having Our Say" is being used in the North Carolina school curriculum and has been nominated for the South Carolina Young Adult Book Award by the South Carolina Association of School Librarians.
The women had frank talks about race, which Ms. Hearth said affected her profoundly. "What we did was very daring," she said. "We agreed not to worry about each other. White people are terrified to talk about race with a black person because they are afraid of saying the wrong thing. I began to feel things on a level that was more than sympathy. Bessie said I was about as close to understanding as a white person could be."
Sometimes the conversations were very painful, and she said she "felt almost ashamed to be white."
"But they would say, 'Don't worry, child, it's not your fault,' " Ms. Hearth said. "I encouraged them to be candid, because that was the point."
The book succeeded because of the intimacy that developed among them, Ms. Hearth said. "The relationship is why the book is good," she said. "There were a lot of opportunities to test trust. They got to see they could count on me, as I could count on them."
Ms. Hearth is fiercely protective of the sisters' health and feelings and screens requests to interview them. She is especially alert, she said, to people who may ask crude questions about race or marriage, or who may not speak to them respectfully.
"One of the things of which I'm most proud is that they have been treated well," she said. "It's a fine line -- these are very independent people, and they make their own decisions."
The sisters declined to be interviewed for this article, because, Ms. Hearth said, "They said: 'Well if it's a story about you, we shouldn't be in it. It's always about us.' " Her voice bubbles with fun and admiration when she talks about them. She calls them funny, brilliant, "the smartest people I have ever met." The way she told it, it is a love story, and the listener can believe that money, a taboo subject with her , is not the most important way she has profited from this experience.
"My main goal has been to make it as fun as possible for the sisters, to make sure they get what they want," she said. "They are the boss, and when people are very old, most other people don't let that happen."

HEADLINE: PROFILE;
A Pair of Presidents Keep It All in the Family

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN

 BODY:
As Fraternal Twins, the Shapiro brothers grew up sharing the same room and the same schoolteachers, but not the same interest. Harold was the athlete, two championships, played basketball, loved soccer. Quieter, more studious Bernard got better grades and showed a marked lack of interest in sports.
 "My parents were very careful not to treat us as if we were the same person just because we were the same age," Bernard Shapiro recalled, sipping tea in his wood-paneled office at McGill University in Montreal. 
 Yet the brothers, now 59 years old, have virtually the same job: Each leads a prestigious university. Bernard J. Shapiro was installed as McGill's president in November. Harold T. Shapiro is president of Princeton University.
 Of course, these academic twin peaks are not identical posts. McGill is a large public university with nearly 15,000 undergraduates, compared with 4,500 at Princeton. McGill has 11 schools and 3 affiliated theological colleges. Princeton, which has no law or medical school, has long focused its attention on undergraduate study.
 And the brothers persist in their separate interests. At Princeton, where he has been president since 1988, Harold Shapiro closely follows his teams' fortunes in the Ivy League. At McGill, Bernard Shapiro still shuns sports. So intense is his dislike that when the school's football coach asked him to perform the ceremonial kickoff for the first game in the fall, he declined. "I believe my actual response was, 'In a pig's eye,"' he recalled. "I said, 'I've never had any interest in athletics. I don't want to pretend I have. I don't want to pretend to be other than what I am. What you see is what you get."' (In the ned, his wife, Phyllis, a professor of education, donned a red McGill sweatshirt and kicked off the game.)
 But in their different ways, the presidents Shapiro face many of the same challenges: Both are concerned with soaring costs and rising tuitions, as well as increased public scrutiny. Both worry about quality, accountability and access. And both want to re-examine the role played by higher education in the community.
 The two say they talk frequently to each other about the joys and trials of heading a university. "You can call up on a basis that you can't call anyone else up, and talk about issues that you have in common or sometimes on which you just want advice," Bernard Shapiro said. "It's so congenial and so easy, and there's never any hidden agendas."
 The brothers were born in Montreal in 1935. Their father, Max, had grown up in a small village near Warsaw, but left early, seeking work. He stopped first in Odessa, eventually made his way to Toledo, Ohio where he worked in an automobile factory, and finally moved to Montreal, where he met Mary, his second wife. The twins are the couple's only children.
 Although Mary and Max stressed education, neither imagined that their sons would dedicate their lives to higher learning.
 "Did I think they were geniuses when they were young?" asked the boys' mother, Mary Shapiro Kantor. "No." Still the two were good students, she said. "Bernard was the born scholar; it wouldn't make any difference what kind of mother or father he had, he would have been that. Harold developed over time." Over time, both boys pursued academic paths -- but not before taking an unusual detour. Shortly after they graduated with honors from McGill, their father died. So the two took over his stake in Ruby Foo's, a Chinese restaurant that is legendary in Montreal. "Even my children, who have never put their feet in there because it was gone long before they grew up, have heard of it," said Gretta Chambers, chancellor of McGill.
 But neither considered making the business a career. "I loved it," said Bernard Shapiro. "I learned an incredible amount, primarily about other people and how to relate to them. It was fascinating. But I knew I didn't want to spend a lifetime doing it."
 For Harold Shapiro, the five-year ownership of Ruby Foo's was a time to nurture the idea of pursuing a scholarly life. Encouraged by his then-girlfriend, Vivian (now his wife, and mother of the couple's four daughters), he began part-time graduate study at McGill in economics and Russian history.
 "Vivian really showed me what the rewards of a thoughtful and scholarly approach to a topic were," he said, "and what one could contribute to the world with scholarship and ideas to make this a better place for us all. She was very influential in that sense."
 After the brothers and their partners sold the restaurant, Harold enrolled at Princeton to pursue his doctoral degree in economics.
 Bernard went to Harvard to earn a master's degree in education and perhaps become a high school teacher or a librarian. Once there, however, he decided, with the encouragement of his professors, to pursue a doctoral degree.
 "I knew I loved to read and I knew I loved to think about what it was I was reading." he said. "And it seemed to me an academic career would make the most of that love, because it would be central to what it meant to be decent in that area."
 Max Shapiro would have been both pleased and perplexed by his sons' decision to become academics., Harold Shapiro said -- pleased that they were doing what they wanted, but perplexed by their desire to teach long hours, at the pleasure of some department head or faceless president, for a relatively modest salary.
 "He very much wanted me to be a businessman," Harold Shapiro said. "I remember he and my mother took us to Europe once, in the days when you still went by boat. I remember standing on the rail of this boat, looking out at the sea, and my father saying to me, 'There's one thing that's wonderful about being in business. Here I am sitting on this boat and I'm still making money."'
 After receiving his Ph.D from Princeton, Harold Shapiro joined the faculty at the University of Michigan (Vivian Shapiro became an associate professor at the School of Social Work). In his 24 years at Michigan, he served as chairman of the economics department, vice president for academic affairs and, finally, university president from 1980 to 1988.
 Bernard Shapiro began climbing the academic ranks in the schools of education at Boston University and the University of Western Ontario in London, Ontario. He also spent years in public life in the Ontario government, serving as the Deputy Minister of Education. It was, he says, an interesting exhilarating change from academia.
 "In academic life you think of your influence or the consequence of your actions in terms of generations," he said. "Whereas in public life, although the things you do may have enormous generational effect, the particularly jolting part is they can have an effect tomorrow.
 You do something and there it is!"
 Bernard Shapiro's call from McGill came last year, when he was all set to retire from the University of Toronto, where he was teaching education and public policy. He and his wife have a daughter and a son.
 As university presidents, the Shapiro brothers are both described as quietly decisive in meeting their goals. Both speak (in literally identical voices) of shepherding their universities through a time when higher education is changing from a small, elite social system to a larger and more accessible one.
 At Princeton, Harold Shapiro has pushed faculty and students to grapple with questions of diversity and race relations. In speech after speech, he urges the university to take "voyages of discovery in a pluralistic society."
 His promotion of racial and ethnic diversity at Princeton, he said, stems in part from his belief that even private universities are civic institutions that should serve society.
 "If all we did at Princeton was train a terrifically well-qualified and very smart group of white males, we would be failures," he said. "It's as simples as that. At one time that was an acceptable way to meet civic responsibility. But at this time and this place, we have the responsibility to do better than that."
 Ruth Simmons, Princeton's deputy provost, says she considers Harold Shapiro a courageous leader who does what he believes is right even when that action is unpopular or unheralded. "A lot of people will do it when they're going to get a lot of play," she said. "But the reason I respect it so much is he's doing things which are courageous when no one else knows."
 For example, she says, when hiring recommendations are made, he often asks whether women were included in the pool of candidates. "In one case, I heard him really questioning the presenters quite severely about some of the assumptions they were making, because he is acutely aware that women get judged differently in this environment," she said.
 Dr. Simmons said she also considers Harold Shapiro a mentor who has helped prepare her for the challenges she will face as the newly appointed president of Smith College.
 "I would trust his judgment on moral issues more than just about anybody else," she said. "He's a wise man, but in a quiet way."
 At McGill, Bernard Shapiro faces essentially the same battles. One of the challenges is to manage an Anglophone institution in a Francophone province.
"McGill generally behaves as if it could as easily be in Paris, London, New York, San Francisco or Beijing," Dr. Shapiro said. "That's wrong. It ought to behave as if it is here in Montreal."
That means, he says, that McGill ought to attract a significant number of French-speaking Quebec students who want to study in English.
His objective is to raise that student population from the current 19 percent to about 25 percent. He also wants McGill to establish links with Francophone universities in Montreal to share resources and programs.
"If you become an integral part of a community, everybody has a stake in your future," he said.
With that in mind, he has instituted a library policy for East Asian studies with the University of Montreal. "It's quite simple," he said. "Any book they buy, we don't buy. Any book we buy, they don't. We share. And there are a whole series of things like that -- each one small and inconsequential in its own right, but it turns out to add up over time."
Dr. Chambers, who is both chancellor and chairwoman of the search committee that hired Bernard Shapiro, says he approaches tough decisions with an open mind.
"That's very unusual among academics," she said. "Usually they come with a theory. He asks, 'What would be the sensible thing to do here?' "
And although Dr. Shapiro is somewhat shy, she says, he is still accessible.
Dr. Chambers recalled that he once spent an entire evening talking with the student council about what it could and could not expect from the university.
"He got there around 6 P.M. and stayed until about 9 P.M., but he could have been there until midnight," she said. "It was almost as if they were dying of thirst -- they wanted more. It was because he was really giving them the goods. He was not condescending. He treats them exactly as if they were grown up and fully responsible."

It ought to behave as if it is here in Montreal." (Robert Galbraith/Canadian Press for The New York Times)(pg. 21);

HEADLINE: Who Is Major Enough For the Major Leagues?

BYLINE: By TY AHMAD-TAYLOR

 BODY:
What makes a city ready for the Major Leagues? Phoenix and Tampa must have it. Three weeks ago they were picked as homes to the newest teams in Major League Baseball. Do other cities have it, too? And what exactly is it, anyhow?
 The question isn't idle, its economic. And the way Major League Baseball has answered it over the past 80 years has a great deal to do with the impasse that resulted in the 232-day strike the players ended Friday when a Federal judge ordered the owners to restore salary arbitration and other parts of the old contract. Without a lockout, the season could open later this month with the regular team rosters. 
 Money and fans are just two factors in deciding where teams play. Some cities that have threatened legal action against baseball's anti-trust rules have been awarded franchises. While political and emotional forces always play a role, formulas allow an objective look at a city's ability to be in the big leagues.
 Economists say a team can make it in a metropolitan area with: a population over one million; a high percentage of men between 18 and 54, baseball's core audience; per capita income above the national average; high population growth; and a high proportion of businesses with more than 500 employees - businesses most likely to buy stadium luxury suites. These criteria are not absolute predictors of success. Good marketing, business acumen and fan loyalty also help.
 Some cities with teams miss these benchmarks. And of the four cities recently awarded Major League franchises, only Phoenix and Denver measured up. TY AHMAD-TAYLOR

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CONEY ISLAND;
Boardwalking: Carnies in Gear For Next Ride

BYLINE: By JOHN DeSANTIS 

 BODY:
By night, the streets that jut from Coney Island's wide wooden boardwalk are as empty and barren as the newly groomed sand on the beachfront. Shuttered metal gates hide the entrances to clam joints and ice cream stands, and the mechanical rides are still, naked skeletons stripped of their canvas wraps.
But during these spring days, the gentle pounding of the surf is drowned out by the hammering and chatter of workers. Coney Island's carnival subculture is rustling up, preparing for the season that will start in two weeks, on Easter Sunday. Young workers, mostly men but a handful of women, daub gallons of paint and whitewash, screw in hundreds of colored light bulbs and walk all 3,000 feet of Cyclone track, checking the roller coaster for safety. 
 Many of these workers will operate and repair the rides once the season begins and the boardwalk teems with families, tourists, hawkers and sunbathers. Most say they are happy being silent partners in the one-day vacations of millions. No one says what he earns.
"I operate, fix, anything that's here," says Angel Colon, 23, as he stands near the Polar Express ride. "I got taught by somebody else. Before that I was working jobs like Toys 'R' Us, Nathan's."
Mr. Colon's friend, Tirell Johnson, 19, says his speech, which comes in loud bursts, helped get him a job hawking games of chance to passersby in 1990. "I started out in Astroland, the game where the hands go up and down and I was talking on the mike. So one day I came over here and talked to the boss and asked if there was an opening, and he said 'Yeah, come by.' "
He also runs the Polar Express, sometimes playing the ride's rock and rap music so loudly that residents of nearby high-rise buildings complain to the local precinct commander. The work, Mr. Johnson says, is hard, but there are rewards.
"The thing that I like best is 'showboatin,' " he says. "That's when the ride is moving and the people have to sit down on the ride, we stand up. Just to bug out, to keep the crowd excited. But if the ride is going a certain speed, then you know you can't do it."
Despite his almost boyish excitement with such escapades, Mr. Johnson seems to have an eye tilted toward the future.
"This ain't gonna be my whole life," he insists. "Atlantic City, I thought about it. I was out there last week," he said. He filled out applications. No one has called back.
Although the police say that gangs like the X-Men, Dog-Pound and the more organized Latin Kings are active on Coney Island's streets, most who work the boardwalk play down the gangs' hold on the area. Many young men in the neighborhood, they say, are gang wannabe's.
Kenny Vazquez, 27, is a ride operator during the season and does whatever is needed to get the rides at Astroland running. He's grateful for work in a local economy pretty much bare of opportunity.
"I wouldn't trade it for anything or anybody," he says. "It's very hard to find any type of jobs here, and this is the last resort." Occasionally, he says, he does wish the future would hold something just a little different. Maybe a job at Six Flags-Great Adventure, the New Jersey amusement park. "It's the same job we do here but bigger," he says. "They've got a lot of the same rides we've got. Just let me know when they get the biggest ride there is. I'll be there." JOHN DeSANTIS

HEADLINE: Manhattan Business Districts Lift Quality of Life at Small Cost

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your report on Manhattan business improvement districts (news article, March 27). As I advised you before that: 
 (1) The "management report" delivered March 17 was a preliminary, confidential draft for comment by management. It has been revised.
(2) As to outside employment of district managers, there is a specific protocol approved in 1993 by the Grand Central and 34th Street Partnership boards allowing them to spend up to 15 percent of their working time on ouside activities. Similar protocols exist at leading universities permitting professors to devote up to 20 percent of their time to outside activities. Such activities can help the public and enhance the professor's experience. Universities do not require reimbursement for the time, as do the partnerships.
(3) With regard to Jersey City, any program will be submitted to each business improvement district board for review and cannot proceed without approval.
(4) The Jersey City business improvement district has paid for all disbursements on its behalf.
(5) There have never been special arrangements to meet the requirements of a particular building owner. All programs offered by the partnerships are offered generally -- to encourage owners to improve public spaces around their buildings.
(6) The floodlighting of Grand Central Terminal and the sidewalks surrounding it has greatly enhanced security, as well as the beauty of Grand Central Terminal. Four buildings have permitted installation of massive floodlights without charge.
The number of lights and the size of the support structure installed on the Lincoln Building are substantially greater than those of the other three buildings. The location on the Lincoln Building selected by the independent lighting consultant was a narrow setback, which required additional safety precautions.
There was no direct benefit to any building.
The Grand Central and 34th Street Partnerships -- which recently expanded beyond the boundaries on your map -- have significantly enhanced the quality of life for those who work, live in or visit the districts, with great cost-effectiveness.
They have demonstrated that the public areas of Manhattan can be safe, clean, well lighted and intelligently directed. The cost is only a few cents per square foot per year, a very small fraction of the real estate tax and an amount most owners and tenants are more than willing to contribute.
 
PETER L. MALKIN
Chairman, Grand Central and 34th Street Partnerships
New York, March 27, 1995

HEADLINE: Many Haitians Fearful Despite U.N. Presence

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 2

 BODY:
Despite the new United Nations mission of establishing a "safe and stable environment" in Haiti, there is growing nervousness among its people about the future. The unease stems from an increase in crime and the lack of any immediate and widespread economic relief nearly six months after Jean-Bertrand Aristide was restored as President.
"On balance, the American presence here has been positive," said Necker Dessables, executive director of the Justice and Peace Commission, the human rights arm of the Roman Catholic Church in Haiti. 
 But he said the American-led force, which transferred authority to the United Nations on Friday, had been "late in reaching a will to disarm" the paramilitary groups created by the military dictatorship. This delay, he said, "gave them time to hide their weapons and go underground and organize."
Now it is up to the 6,000 soldiers and 900 police officers who make up the United Nations operation in Haiti to blunt the threat posed by the remnants of that repressive apparatus. Yet they must do so with fewer troops and equipment, with virtually no Haitian law enforcement or security force to assist them and in the face of skepticism about their ability and willingness to act.
In a report issued on the eve of President Clinton's visit on Friday, two human rights groups, Human Rights Watch/Americas and the National Coalition for Haitian Refugees, warned of the problems that might lie ahead.
"Political tensions are increasing," the report said, "and far from having brought stability, the U.S.-led force can point only to a fragile security that impending parliamentary and presidential elections may rupture."
The threat to stability has been underscored by a recent surge in street crime, which Haitian Government officials attribute in part to former soldiers and police officers, and that has created some disaffection with the foreign presence.
"If they're not going to protect us, then why are they here at all?" asked Claudette Armand, a shop clerk here.
Such sentiments may be even more pronounced in the countryside, where there has been a steady barrage of complaints about "collaboration" between American troops and sympathizers of the dictatorship.
A national conference of peasant groups loyal to President Aristide, for instance, adopted a resolution last month calling the foreign military deployments a "useless presence" and "a waste of money" because they had failed to root out paramilitary gunmen.
Mr. Aristide himself remains enormously popular, and moves freely among the people without apparent concern for his own safety. But his Government, led by Prime Minister Smarck Michel, has been slow to address economic problems and meet growing demands for improved living conditions. People blame the current Government for many of the country's ills, even though the army maintained effective control of Haiti in the three years after the overthrow of President Aristide in September 1991.
Despite Mr. Aristide's return, food prices are still rising sharply with no sign of leveling off, jobs continue to be scarce with the unemployment rate approaching 75 percent, foreign investment has been slow in returning and 1.2 million people are still being fed by international relief agencies.
At the same time, basic services like electricity, water, transportation and health remain tenuous at best.
"Aristide has done nothing to improve our lives since he returned," said Ronald Charles, 23, who is unemployed and lives in a squatter settlement near the port here. "Yes, we no longer have to worry that the army will kill us or beat us or steal from us. But it was the Americans who made that possible, not Aristide."
Discontent with the slow pace of economic development has led to frequent street demonstrations in recent weeks against the high cost of living and mounting criticism of the way Mr. Michel and his economic team are dealing with the problem.
"If this Government has a strategy, the people are not aware of it," said Chavannes Jean-Baptiste, a peasant leader and longtime political ally of and adviser to Mr. Aristide.
In a country as poor and scarred as Haiti, most of the capital required to rebuild the economy and infrastructure will also have to come from foreign sources.
More than $1.2 billion in such assistance has already been pledged, but the Haitian bureaucracy, which diplomats and foreign economists describe as laden with talent at the very top but barely competent at other levels, has found it difficult to decide how to apply the bonanza that is in the pipline.
"They simply expect us to give them money with no questions asked," one foreign aid official said. "You can ask them all you want what they plan to do with it, but it is hard to get much beyond vague answers."
But some basic preliminary steps have already been taken. More than 1.2 million people have been immunized against diseases, $83 million in foreign debt arrears have been paid off and some 30,000 temporary jobs have been created.
But on the left, some of Mr. Aristide's supporters are complaining of what they describe as his loss of ideological zeal and excessive deference to his foreign patrons. As Mr. Jean-Baptiste put it, referring to President Aristide by his nickname, "When the peasants compare the Titid of before with the Titid who returned with the multinational force, they see a big difference."
Nonetheless, American officials and Mr. Aristide have frequently disagreed on many basic issues, especially those relating to security. From the start, they have argued over the size and composition of the police force that is to replace the Haitian armed forces, which Mr. Aristide has dismantled despite American pressures to retain some sort of military entity.
The potential for further discord can only grow, Haitian and foreign analysts predict, with the entry of the United Nations into the picture.
"This has been an all-American show up to now," a Latin American diplomat said. "But all of us are going to be forced to make adjustments in this next phase, and it is not going to be easy."

HEADLINE: Trying to Cut Welfare the Ohio Way

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, March 27

 BODY:
When Gov. George V. Voinovich of Ohio proposed deep cuts in welfare benefits for able-bodied adults four years ago, he predicted that many recipients would finally get off the dole and find a job. Welfare advocates, meanwhile, spun doomsday scenarios about large increases in homelessness, crime and even death on the streets.
Neither prediction came true, according to welfare officials and researchers here. But in New York, where Gov. George E. Pataki is pushing for similar cuts, the same arguments are now framing the debate. 
 "If you create incentives, and in fact demand work, I think you'll see people move into the work force," Mr. Pataki said in a recent interview. "I mean, how many low-income, low-skilled jobs go to immigrants, or go begging?"
On the other side of the debate is Shelly Nortz, director of state policy for the New York State Coalition for the Homeless, who notes that there are 584,000 unemployed New Yorkers, and welfare is often the only thing that keeps them off the streets.
"We think that about a third of the people who lose their benefits are going to end up requiring some kind of government-supported emergency shelter because they become homeless and have no alternatives," Ms. Nortz said.
The cuts made in Ohio and proposed in New York would affect state-financed programs that primarily serve single adults. Most needy mothers qualify for the Federal Government's Aid to Families With Dependent Children program, which the Republicans in Congress are seeking to trim back.
The cuts proposed in New York by Mr. Pataki are part of a broader plan to trim the rapid growth in the state's welfare cost. Mr. Pataki would also like to reduce benefits for welfare mothers and the elderly, as well as making reductions in Medicaid benefits.
The experience of Ohio, and of other states that have made similar cuts, has been far less clear-cut. A Case Western Reserve University study of the impact of Mr. Voinovich's cuts in Cuyahoga County, which includes Cleveland, found that virtually the same percentage of able-bodied welfare recipients were employed before and after they were forced off the rolls, indicating that welfare recipients either were unsuccessful in looking for jobs or did not seek them. The study also found only a slight increase in the percentage of people who did not have permanent housing, from 23 percent to 27 percent.
But researchers in Ohio and elsewhere have concluded that most former recipients simply totter on the edge of subsistence. With few job skills, and often with disabilities and addictions, they somehow just manage to get by, frequently with the help of the underground economy, family members and friends.
"They find ways to cope, but there may be impacts on the families that help," said Linda Crowell, one of the Case Western Reserve researchers. "A wife may be abused right now because someone was back in the home that shouldn't have been."
It also remains to be seen whether state governments that restrict welfare benefits create expensive new burdens that devour any savings. "If you're a governor doing cost-benefit analysis, my question would be how many former welfare recipients are showing up in mental institutions and prisons and homeless shelters," said Joe R. Garcia, director of the Cuyahoga County Department of Entitlement Services. "That's real money."
The cuts enacted by Mr. Voinovich and proposed by Mr. Pataki involve a program known around the country as general assistance. Financed solely by state and local governments, the programs exist in some form in 31 states, with 22 states requiring it statewide.
General assistance provides welfare benefits to needy people who do not qualify for the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program. Besides single adults, the recipients include childless married couples and disabled people.
A heavy share of general assistance recipients -- in New York, about half -- are considered employable. During the last four years, that has made the programs a popular target for Republican governors seeking to trim welfare budgets. Michigan and Illinois have eliminated their programs altogether. A number of other states have cut benefits and restricted eligibility.
In Ohio, Mr. Voinovich, as a freshman Republican Governor in 1991, pushed through legislation that limited general assistance benefits to six months in any 12-month period. He also cut the monthly grant from $148 to $100 and created a new welfare program, called Disability Assistance, that paid $115 a month to those considered unemployable.
The time limits in Ohio succeeded in reducing the number of people on general assistance from about 142,000 in 1992 to 68,000 in 1994. Another 52,000 are on Disability Assistance. The cost for the programs declined from $421 million in 1992 to $198 million in 1994, including medical expenses.
This year, Mr. Voinovich has proposed eliminating general assistance and restricting eligibility for Disability Assistance to save an additional $100 million a year. A new state health-care plan would provide medical insurance for most of the poor.
New York, which calls its program Home Relief, is now one of only three states, along with Alaska and New Jersey, that provide ongoing assistance to able-bodied adults without children. With 387,000 recipients in an average month and a cost to the state of almost $1.2 billion a year, including Medicaid spending, it is by far the largest and most expensive program of its kind in the country.
Because the cost of Home Relief has doubled in the last 10 years and now eats up nearly 4 percent of the state's general fund budget, it quickly grabbed the attention of Mr. Pataki's budget director, Patricia A. Woodworth, who helped her previous boss, Gov. John M. Engler of Michigan, eliminate that state's program. And because New York splits its Home Relief costs with local governments, the cuts are also supported by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City, which is home to 77 percent of the state's recipients.
Mr. Pataki's proposal would save $204 million for the state and a similar amount for local governments. After first proposing to limit Home Relief benefits for able-bodied recipients to 90 days in any 12-month period, he has now agreed with the Republican-controlled Senate on a 60-day limit. While on Home Relief, recipients would be required to work in public service jobs, like cleaning parks and government buildings.
Recipients would lose their Medicaid health care coverage when they leave the rolls, relegating many to seek treatment in the emergency rooms of public hospitals. And the basic monthly grant of $137.10 would be cut by 25 percent, to $102.82. Recipients also receive a shelter allowance -- $215 in New York City, meaning that the total grant there would decrease from $352 to $318.
In the ongoing negotiations over the state budget, the Democratic-controlled Assembly has been silent about Mr. Pataki's proposed cuts. Traditionally viewed as the protectors of the poor, Albany's Democrats have responded to the rightward swing of last November's election by positioning themselves as defenders of the middle class. Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, declined repeated requests last week to explain his position on Mr. Pataki's welfare proposals.
Mr. Pataki said he does not expect homelessness to increase because of the cuts. But in his budget, he added $26 million in new spending for the homeless just in case.
In other states, Mr. Pataki said, "the vast majority of the Home Relief population was able to make successful alternate arrangements to continue to live. They weren't on the streets. They weren't in the shelters. Those stories of dread just didn't happen."
In some cases, that is true. In others, it is not.
For instance, Maurice B. Tiff, a 47-year-old portrait artist from Cleveland, has lived with his elderly parents while receiving general assistance benefits intermittently since 1991. He acknowledges that he can survive without the monthly $100 check, and that he has continued to reapply successfully for benefits because no one has stopped him from doing so.
In essence, Mr. Tiff said, he works when he feels like it, while taking care of his parents. "It's not that I'm not capable or willing," he said. "I'm probably one person who shouldn't have been on assistance to begin with."
But it is different for Darnell Alexander, an unemployed 40-year-old alcoholic and drug addict who has been on general assistance for seven years. Until Mr. Voinovich imposed time limits, Mr. Alexander always managed to scrape up the $120 he needed to pay rent for a room in a boarding house, usually by supplementing his welfare check with income from occasional dishwashing jobs.
Since the cuts, he has been constantly on the move -- staying with friends, doing time in jail, even sleeping on benches in downtown Cleveland. "It's been a struggle," he said.
Mr. Voinovich said that proposing the cuts "was one of the most wrenching experiences I have had."
"We had large demonstrations outside the Statehouse," he said. "I was accused of being insensitive, un-Christian and so forth."
But he said the results of the last three years have convinced him that he was right. "People really didn't understand that what I was doing was because of tough love," he said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: BASEBALL OWNERS QUIT FIGHT; OPENING DAY IS SET FOR APRIL 26;
Replacements Ambling Back To Anonymity

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

DATELINE: DENVER, April 2

 BODY:
They ambled across the marble floors of the hotel lobby in their suits and ties this morning, still acting like members of the New York Yankees yet still wondering where their charter plane was headed. The Yankees had not officially told their replacement players where they were flying.
Some carried briefcases that held their minor league contracts, some made telephone calls to their wives describing their anxiety and some sipped coffee, boasted about the experience and called it the most exhilarating six weeks of their once-dormant careers. The 36 replacement players figured that their status as Yankees would disappear by the time they arrived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., tonight. 
 "It kind of stinks it came down to the last day," said pitcher Doug Cinnella. "The owners got the living starch beaten out of them, so they're taking their frustration out on us."
But Kent Wallace, another pitcher who is headed to the minor leagues, said: "I got to do things I've never done before. I'd do it again."
Once the owners decided Saturday to release replacement players from their contracts, scenes like this were acted out throughout major league baseball as the real players inched closer to returning to work, while those who substituted for them inched closer to oblivion.
Half of the Yankees will return to being minor leaguers, another handful will probably be offered minor league contracts and the others will return to being salesmen, coaches, teachers or unemployed. None will be given the chance to play for the real Yankees anytime soon. The players won't receive the handsome salaries they had desired, settling instead for the $5,000 bonus they received for signing.
The concept of replacement players became a hot-button issue in the longest strike in sports history, meshing modern labor realities with the fanciful aspirations of would-be baseball players. But around the country today, the replacements themselves were looking more and more replaceable.
In the hotel lobby here, 270-pound Matt Stark took pictures of his soon-to-be former Yankee teammates. In Clearwater, Fla., Joe Cipolloni played an April Fool's joke on his Phillie replacement teammates by telling them the team would leave for its game in St. Louis today. And in a Port St. Lucie, Fla., hotel, replacements complained about waiting three hours to meet with General Manager Joe McIlvaine to find out their fate.
"I can't believe I did this and this happened," said one player, requesting anonymity. "I really goofed up."
Wallace, however, will savor his designation as the planned opening day starter for the Yankees. "That's a compliment," he said. "That's something I'll never forget."
Everywhere, players lamented about how agonizingly close they had come to making $25,000 in bonuses. Players who signed replacement contracts were owed $5,000 signing bonuses. But by releasing the replacements from their contracts, the clubs saved about $800,000 each because players were supposed to receive another $5,000 for making the opening day roster today and $20,000 in severance pay when the major leaguers returned.
One club, the Florida Marlins, created some good will with the replacements by paying them the $25,000, anyway. And at least five clubs told the players they will pay the $5,000 as a good-will gesture. One of them was the Mets, who though they kept the replacements waiting tonight at least sent them on their way happy.
But the Yankees, who had not decided whether they will pay bonuses, were worried enough about potential hostility from players that they removed alcoholic beverages from their flight.
Since their trip to Arlington, Tex., for the season opener had been canceled, the replacement Yankees, who were registered in the hotel here under aliases to protect them from potential harassment, lingered in the lobby searching for answers. Even though the assistant general manager, Tim McCleary, said the players would remain in Florida under minor league contracts to presumably be available should something go wrong, Showalter said, "I think they are basically being dispersed once we get there."
Requesting that the replacement players remain as a safety measure might be a ticklish issue since one claimed he felt "like a piece of meat hanging on a hook," and five had already returned home instead of going to Florida. Bill Lindsey, a catcher, added, "They better come up with some more money if they want us to do that."
Several replacement Mets, who admitted to nursing hangovers today, wanted to collect their $5,000 signing bonuses and leave. Jeff Edwards, a car salesman who quit his job in Nashville, did not feel the money was enough after enduring Manager Dallas Green's rigorous spring training. "I could have made $8,000 selling cars," he said.
Frank Eufemia did not want to leave. The 35-year-old pitcher thirsts for a Class AAA job with the Yankees and feels he pitched well enough with an 0-1 record and 3.95 earned run average to secure that chance. Eufemia, who has purposely been silent this spring because he wanted to be viewed as a professional and who even turned down the chance to be photographed for The Sporting News, said being a replacement player was not always pleasant.
"It was difficult, at times, to get psyched up to pitch," Eufemia said. "When I don't have butterflies, I know something is wrong. There were a lot of mixed emotions when you went out there. You didn't always know who you were pitching for."
In recent days, the replacement Yankees gathered around the television whenever labor news was being announced and badgered reporters for information about their future. Some of the Yankees had pictures taken of themselves at Coors Field, one lasting reminder of their brief flings in pinstripes. Pitchers Eufemia, Daryl Smith, Guillermo (Willie) Hernandez and Dave Pavlas and Stark, a designated hitter, could be offered Class AAA contracts.
"How many people can say they spent a whole spring with the Yankees?" asked catcher John Kroeger. "How many people can say they played at Coors Field? We had a good time playing baseball, we got $80 a day meal money and we stayed in nice hotels. You can't beat all that. I don't think the players have anything to complain about."
But some Yankees were upset because they became replacement players to make money and, at this point, were only assured of their signing bonus and whatever meal money they saved. Cinnella was one of them. He showed reporters the contract he signed on Jan. 18 and said he would ask for the $25,000 based on the reasoning that, on the day he signed it, opening day was scheduled to be April 2.
"We are not committed on that condition," said McCleary, the assistant general manager.
Told that his argument might not hold up, Cinnella shrugged, put the contract in his briefcase and seemingly figured it was another part of a frustrating day. The team bus was leaving for the airport and the replacement Yankees were descending the escalator and about to be sent into history. Even Cinnella sensed it as he pondered his other job.
"I'll give you guys a call," he told reporters. "I might have a press release you can print about my baseball school."

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
Tax Cut Edges Out Deficit As G.O.P.'s Guiding Tenet

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
There is considerable evidence in public opinion polls that Americans put a greater priority on balancing the budget than cutting taxes. At the same time, there is considerable anxiety among Republican lawmakers that their promise to produce a balanced budget by the year 2002 will be substantially complicated by their pledge to also provide nearly $200 billion in tax cuts over the next five years.
But this week, the Republican majority in the House is expected to set aside those concerns and approve a huge tax cut proposal as the final act of this Congress's first 100 days. Yes, there are last-minute jitters in the House, and an out-and-out wariness toward the idea in the Senate. But behind the drive for a tax cut are some powerful political forces in the Republican Party, born of years of conservative theology, internal struggles for the soul of the party and searing experiences on the campaign trail. 
 The theology is simple enough: "It's a fundamental divide between what Republicans and Democrats believe," Representative Robert S. Walker, Republican of Pennsylvania, contended in an interview last week. "Democrats, through their policies and their language, believe all wealth generated in this country is ultimately the Government's to distribute. Republicans believe it belongs to the people and they should be allowed to keep as much of it as possible."
This article of faith was regularly invoked during the tax cuts of the Reagan years, and was at the heart of George Bush's legendary sound bite of the 1988 campaign: "Read my lips: no new taxes." To many conservatives, when President Bush broke that pledge in his 1990 budget agreement with the Democrats, he set an inevitable course for his party's defeat in 1992. The Republican Party, according to this school of thought, lost its identification as the party of lower taxes, succumbed to the thinking of the old party establishment and paid an immense price for it.
"Bush ran on a Reaganesque platform in 1988, reverted to pre-Reagan Republicanism in '90, and got clobbered in '92 by a Democrat promising a tax cut," said a conservative strategist, William Kristol. "Call me simple-minded, but I think it's better to cut taxes."
For many conservatives, the House vote this week will represent an important moment in the rightward redefinition of their party and the restoration of its Reaganesque glory. "We've been burdened since 1990 as being the party that promised not to raise taxes, and did it," said Representative Walker. "As of next week, we'll be the party that promised to cut taxes, and did it."
There are, as Mr. Kristol and Mr. Walker suggest, serious campaign implications to this vote and this issue. Republicans hope to position themselves as the party that delivered the middle-class tax cut that Mr. Clinton promised during the 1992 campaign and then abandoned after taking office because of the magnitude of the deficit.
In a memorandum circulated last week, Mr. Kristol wrote, "It all comes down to this: In mid-1996, campaigning for larger House and Senate majorities and for the White House, Republicans must be able to tell voters that 'a Democratic Congress and President raised your taxes in 1993; a Republican Congress cut your taxes in 1995.' "
The Republican strategist added: "Reducing the deficit more than Clinton won't be an effective Republican platform. It will always be an uncertain claim, in any event, given the macroeconomic exigencies of interest rates. And let's face it -- deficit reduction has a patchy record as a political bragging point. Ask our current President, who's just devoted the first half of his Administration to that goal, with notably disastrous results."
There is another important political judgment at work: At a time of vast cynicism about politicians -- specifically, about their ability to keep promises -- Republican strategists are adamant about abiding by one of the best-known pledges in their Contract With America.
"The American people have been lied to in two successive Presidential elections," said Grover Norquist, an adviser to Speaker Newt Gingrich and president of the conservative group Americans for Tax Reform. "And the Republican Party stood up in '94 and said: 'This is a contract. We know you've been lied to before, and that's why we're putting this in writing. And if we don't do what we said, fire us.' "
Representative Sam Brownback, a freshman Republican from Kansas, said he recalled one voter after another who simply did not believe that Mr. Brownback would do what he had promised to do. "There's no faith that anything said during a campaign will be delivered," Mr. Brownback said this week. "It's a question of trust, faith, and that's an enormously important quality in a representative democracy."
For Mr. Brownback, that means he will live up to his promise and vote for tax cuts, although he worries about the deficit.
Many conservatives also maintain that only Democrats and nervous opinion leaders see balanced budgets and tax cuts as mutually exclusive; the solution is simply to cut spending, they say. This, they argue, was the mistake of the Reagan years; not in cutting taxes, but in not cutting spending enough.
Still, even in a House Republican Conference where conservatives rule by a wide margin, there are qualms. Martha Phillips, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a bipartisan group devoted to eliminating the deficit, asserted, "Member after member has told Concord Coalition members that they personally don't approve of a tax cut at this point but have to go along, and they're sure the Senate will save them." She added, "This is absolutely the wrong time to be doing tax cuts."
But Ed Gillespie, press secretary for the House majority leader, Dick Armey of Texas, asserted that such arguments were an old "siren song" in Washington -- the plea to set aside the promises of a campaign and "do the responsible thing." Mr. Norquist talked about the susceptibility of the "weak-kneed -- the ones who wake up in the morning and think, 'Oh my goodness, what will The Washington Post and The New York Times think of me today?' "
He added, "The good news for the Republican Party is there aren't too many of them anymore."
Indeed, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, who has voiced considerable skepticism about tax cuts in the past, said on the CNN program "Evans and Novak" on Saturday that if the budget could be balanced without touching Social Security or harming the economy "then there is room for a tax cut."
Conservatives, in short, are rallying their troops for the last push in the contract -- one that resonates with 15 years of political history.

HEADLINE: Mubarak's Challenge

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: CAIRO, March 31

 BODY:
President Hosni Mubarak's visit to Washington in the coming week will take place as he is being confronted at home with rising discontent and mounting accusations of human rights abuses, governmental corruption and mismanagement that are driving away foreign investors.
Despite a recent crackdown that has curtailed violence by Islamic militants in Cairo, critics who include Western diplomats describe this country of 56 million as on the brink of crisis. They point to dismal economic growth and a refusal by Mr. Mubarak to share power as among the main elements for creating further social upheaval. Many Western diplomats now contend that the Government is too weak to sustain the shock of serious reform. 
 "The Egyptians tell us that if they hold free elections the Islamic militants will win," a senior European diplomat said. "They tell us that if they sell off the state industries and throw people out of work there will be riots. And they tell us that if they divide the currency their economy will collapse. All this is true."
Mr. Mubarak's Government, which is among America's closest allies in the Middle East, presentsitself as a modern, Western-style democracy; in fact, it more closely resembles the military dictatorships throughout the Arab world. For the past 50 years, power has remained firmly in the grip of the governing National Democratic Party, although under various names.
Mr. Mubarak was re-elected for a third six-year term in a 1993 referendum that did not permit any opposition. Many Cabinet ministers have remained in office for more than a decade. Nepotism and patronage determine advancement. And the President's pronouncements and image are given more and more prominence in the state-run media, reinforcing what critics say is a growing personality cult.
The largest opposition party, the Muslim Brotherhood, is outlawed and 34 of its leaders have been imprisoned without charges over the last few weeks, including 5 on Thursday. The Government, concerned over victories by Islamic militants in a spate of elections at university and professional unions, has moved to wipe the names of suspected militant sympathizers off the lists and annul the votes.
In February, in one of several efforts to curb the influence of the Islamic movement, a government court dissolved the leadership of the 220,000-member Engineer's Union and sequestered its assets; hundreds of engineers staged a sit-in in their headquarters.
"There is still a measure of freedom here, although it is growing smaller," said Magdi Hussein, the editor in chief of the opposition newspaper Al Shaab.
"But no Egyptian is allowed to criticize, or even question, the President or any member of his family. We are sliding closer and closer to an absolute dictatorship, and as we are, we are sliding closer and closer to an explosion."
The refusal to give the average Egyptian a stake in the Government has been matched by increasing repression. Human rights groups like the Washington-based Human Rights Watch say the Egyptian security forces torture suspects, abduct relatives of suspected militants until they surrender and carry out extra-judicial executions. In the last three years Egypt's military courts have sentenced 62 people to death, hanging dozens of them.
The tough measures by the police, while crippling the militant movement in Cairo, have failed to quell rebellion in southern Egypt. The violence there erupts in almost daily gun battles with Islamic militants, including one on Thursday in which five suspected militants were killed. The mud-walled towns and villages in southern Egypt look like armed camps, with troops lumbering down dirt roads in American-supplied armored personnel carriers, and public buildings surrounded by soldiers who crouch behind sand bags and are armed with heavy machine-guns.
"The tactic now is to kill as many of the local police and security officials as possible," said a militant leader. "We are no longer going after the top officials. We are under-cutting the Government's base. None of these people, who are poorly paid, have any incentive to fight. The morale of the security forces, especially in southern Egypt, is bad. And we are talking to a lot of these young recruits, trying to get them to join us."
But the most potent source of strength for the militant movement is governmental corruption, which many businessmen and Western diplomats say has spiraled out of control. It is driving away foreign investors and has helped stall economic reforms that were aimed at creating a vibrant private sector.
"We are forced to pay thousands, or tens of thousands of dollars," a Lebanese businessman said, speaking on the condition of anonymity.. "The corruption has wiped out many smaller businesses." Bloated and inefficient state-owned corporations dominate 80 percent of the economy, although many are losing money. The bureaucracy is so torpid that it can take weeks to get permission to make simple customs transactions or receive import licenses.
The United States Embassy said in a report this month that there would be no acceleration of economic growth unless the Government began carrying out promised structural reform.
"The desultory nature of the economic reform program in 1994 has led some observers to argue that the program has stalled," the report said.
The failure to devalue the currency, Western economists contend, means that Egypt will probably experience a crash, which could double prices overnight. The currency is overvalued, the economists say, by about 40 percent.
Only 15 percent of hard currency earnings in Egypt now come from goods and services. Suez Canal receipts, oil exports and tourism bring in about $6 billion a year. Remittances bring in $5 billion a year. But the growth of the population is now rapidly outstripping that of the economy, which has experienced less than 2 percent growth in the last three years.
"Egypt's economy was based on barter trade," one Western diplomat said. "It produced shoddy goods and dumped them on the Communist bloc in exchange for oil and other commodities. The Communist bloc doesn't exist, but the state factories keep turning out junk no one wants."

HEADLINE: Worries About Military Readiness Grow

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
The Pentagon is spending less on new weapons and equipment than at any time in nearly 50 years, prompting many lawmakers and senior officers to warn that the Clinton Administration may soon jeopardize combat readiness.
The debate over military preparedness poses a vexing problem for the White House. Last year, the issue focused on Republican accusations that the Administration was cutting the Pentagon budget too far, too fast. Subsequent Congressional hearings suggested that such concerns were exaggerated, but to avoid appearing weak on military matters, the White House added more than $10 billion for training, spare parts and salaries. 
 In fixing one problem, however, the Administration may have created another: Administration officials had to dip into money earmarked for replacing aging equipment and weapons.
"The Administration continues to make decisions that worsen the long-term prospect for cost-effective modernization," said Representative Floyd D. Spence, a South Carolina Republican who is chairman of the House National Security Committee.
Senior officers, concerned with potential problems in the future, have clashed with their civilian Pentagon superiors over these shifts and turned to Republicans and conservative Democrats for help. For Republicans, who have advocated deep spending cuts in areas from welfare to foreign aid, the Pentagon remains largely a sacred cow.
The issue of readiness is a complex one that spans training, spare parts, planning for new weapons and more, and it involves not only being ready today, but also being prepared for the combat of the future. And just in the last few days the issue's political dimension was underscored when President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, had a sharp exchange of letters over the failure of Congress to approve an emergency spending bill to cover unexpected operations in Haiti, Somalia and Bosnia.
Defense Secretary William J. Perry has proposed spending $39.4 billion in the 1996 fiscal year, or 16 percent of the total $246 billion military budget, on new equipment and weapons. It would be the lowest purchasing level, adjusted for inflation, since 1950.
In 1985, for instance, at the height of the Reagan-era buildup, spending on new equipment accounted for 34 percent of the $402 billion budget.
Under next year's budget, the Army would buy no new tanks, the Air Force no new fighter jets and the Navy just three new combat ships. But that is largely by design. After the collapse of the Soviet threat, the Clinton Administration decided the shrinking military could safely afford to live off cold-war stocks for a while. The question is, how long can the Pentagon wait before buying new generations of weapons to keep a smaller military technologically superior?
Ideally, the Pentagon seeks a balance between fielding well-trained, well-equipped troops and preparing for future weapons and equipment. But to help pay for short-term problems, the Pentagon's budget for new weapons in the 1996 fiscal year has $9 billion less than what the Administration said a year ago it would allocate for that purpose.
Some Democrats say senior officers are overstating the readiness risks to keep their budgets high. "We should avoid buying new systems that maintain the United States and the world on a treadmill of weapons development," said Representative Ronald V. Dellums, a California Democrat on the House National Security Committee.
But postponement of these long-term investments has sounded alarms at the highest levels of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. "The dangers are very, very real and very great," Gen. John Shalikashvili, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told the Senate Armed Services Committee recently. "The last year we can afford that is this year."
Ships, tanks, planes and trucks bought during the military buildup under President Ronald Reagan are showing signs of wear, their life spans compressed by unexpectedly high use in the Persian Gulf, Haiti, Bosnia and Somalia. Shrinking budgets have required the Defense Department to delay buying new weapons, like helicopters and amphibious troop-carrying tanks, and forced commanders to patch up aging equipment that costs more to maintain.
The Marine Corps, for example, is still using 50-year-old canvas tents, old leather combat boots and bulky, Korean War-era sleeping bags. The Marine Commandant, Gen. Carl E. Mundy Jr., told Congress last month that he did not have enough money to buy new gear.
To be sure, the American armed forces are still the most formidable in the world and are in no danger of being surpassed anytime soon. Since the Persian Gulf war in 1991, the military has greatly improved its laser-guided bombs, communication systems and intelligence networks.
The military is shopping smarter, largely by modifying existing equipment to extend its usefulness. But even the best equipment eventually needs to be replaced, usually after 15 or 20 years. Because it takes more than a decade to develop and build a new fighter jet or warship, the military has to plan far ahead. Technology developed in the 1970's and 1980's like radar-evading planes and night-vision goggles was not fielded until the 1990's.
Mr. Perry has an ambitious plan to modernize the force, increasing spending for new equipment and weapons by 47 percent, to $58 billion a year, from 1996 to 2001. But many senior officers, in unusual bursts of candor, warn that these increases will not be enough.
"At some point in the near future, the current funding strategy will ultimately undermine the Corps' ability to meet war-fighting and peacetime presence requirements," said the Marine Corps inspector general, Maj. Gen. Richard L. Phillips.
The Army Chief of Staff, Gen. Gordon R. Sullivan, echoing views of the other Joint Chiefs of Staff, said the situation was not a crisis now, but "I am concerned for the long term." Many senior officers say serious problems may crop up as early as 1997 or 1998.
Even senior civilian Pentagon officials acknowledge that their approach has flaws. "We are not doing an adequate job for modernization, pure and simple," John Hamre, the Defense Department comptroller, said at a meeting of military contractors and Pentagon officials last month.
The Defense Department's modernization plan through 2001 includes about $77 billion for each service's big-ticket priorities: the Air Force's F-22 fighter and C-17 cargo plane; the Navy's new attack submarine and destroyer and remodeled FA-18 attack plane; the Army's M1 tank upgrade, and the Marines' V-22 transport aircraft.
Each service makes tradeoffs in setting such priorities. While General Mundy says he will not have enough money next year to pay for 129,440 new sleeping bags at $118 apiece (a total of $15.3 million), the Marines are spending $762.5 million on the V-22.
The larger problem of allocating money to the services falls to Mr. Perry and John M. Deutch, the Deputy Defense Secretary. The Pentagon is relying heavily on savings from base closings, a streamlined weapons-purchasing system and bigger budgets to pay for the weapons of the future. "This is the biggest management challenge of the department," Mr. Deutch said in an interview.
Many military analysts express doubt that the Pentagon can achieve its projected savings. Moreover, analysts say it will be difficult for the Defense Department to afford a 1.4-million-member military, sustain today's high readiness levels and spend billions of dollars on new weapons.
"We can't afford to have force structure at today's high readiness level and have all the modernization programs they have on the books," said Steven Kosiak, an analyst at the Defense Budget Project, an independent research organization.
To slash costs, the military is trying to buy more off-the-shelf commercial products, build planes and missiles that more than one branch of the military can use, increase training on simulators and rely more on modifying existing weapons. Air Force B-52's built in 1961, for example, are still flying, thanks to improved electronics and other modifications.
Tighter budgets have inspired clever money-saving innovations. At Camp Lejeune, N.C., for example, Marines expect to save $385,000 a year by retreading truck tires instead of buying new ones. Commanders are planning to spend $490,000 to replace lithium truck batteries with rechargeable lead batteries, an investment that will save $364,000 a year.
Maj. Gen. James L. Jones, the Second Marine Division commander, is urging troops to wear flak jackets on exercises only when needed, saving wear on the protective vests, which cost $396 each.
Other marines, like Capt. Catherine Cabrera, the head of an electronic maintenance company, make do with older equipment, like a 12-year-old copy machine. "We'll hold on to it until it breathes its last breath," she said.
Lieut. Col. Mike Applegate's battalion of 208 amphibious assault vehicles may not have that option much longer. The 22-year-old troop-carrying amphibious tanks are breaking down more and more.
"If we don't fix this in three or four years," Colonel Applegate said, "this fleet will be on its knees."
