HEADLINE: In Frail State, Knudsen Taps A Rescue Pro

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
The Morrison Knudsen Corporation, struggling with the worst crisis in its 83-year history, yesterday named Robert S. Miller Jr. as its new chairman.
Mr. Miller, 53, a former vice chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, helped negotiate the auto maker's financial rescue in 1980. He also advised Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the Reichmann family's real estate empire, during its protracted debt negotiations in 1992. 
 Mr. Miller fills the position vacated two weeks ago by William P. Clark, who had been Morrison Knudsen's acting chairman.
"Morrison Knudsen is one of America's great national treasures," Mr. Miller said in a telephone interview yesterday from his home in Sun River, Ore. "It would be a great tragedy for us all if it were to disintegrate. If I can help avoid that disaster, I can't resist the challenge."
Mr. Miller will head a leadership team that includes Robert Tinstman, Morrison Knudsen's president and chief executive and a 20-year veteran of the company, and Denis Slavich, the chief financial officer, who has experience at the Bechtel Group and at Fluor Daniel.
His appointment comes as Morrison Knudsen, which helped build national landmarks like the Hoover Dam and the San Francisco Bay Bridge, is engaged in critical negotiations with 28 banks, led by the Bank of America, a unit of BankAmerica Corporation, and the Mellon Bank, a unit of Mellon Bank Corporation.
The Boise, Idaho, company already owes the banks $235 million and is negotiating for at least $50 million in fresh credit at a time bankers' confidence in the company and its leadership has been severely shaken.
Last summer, in the sixth year of William J. Agee's controversial term as chairman and chief executive, the public picture of Morrison Knudsen's finances began to deteriorate sharply. Mr. Agee had pushed the company into highly visible but ultimately unprofitable mass-transit equipment projects; aggressive asset sales screened the worsening problems until July, when the value of important transit-car contracts was abruptly and sharply reduced.
By October, despite Mr. Agee's predictions of a turnaround, the company no longer complied with the terms of its loan agreements. On Feb. 10, Mr. Agee was forced to resign, and soon after, the company predicted that its 1994 loss would be $175 million.
That was just the beginning. On March 20, the company warned Wall Street analysts that its 1994 loss would be closer to $310 million, and on the same day, announced the resignation of Mr. Clark, a board member who stepped in as acting chairman the night Mr. Agee resigned.
Yesterday, Mr. Miller said: "I have talked with a number of the bankers to get a sense of their attitudes. They are a bit stunned by the suddenness in the downturn in the fortunes of the company" and by "the leadership vacuum" created by Mr. Clark's abrupt resignation.
Wall Street, too, has been shaken. The company's stock, which traded at nearly $30 a year ago, has fallen about 80 percent since then, closing Friday on the New York Stock Exchange at $6. That decline has hurt the company's institutional investors, which own 56 percent of its shares, and has frightened the thousands of current and retired employees who own shares through executive retirement programs and employee stock plans.
Tobias M. Levkovich, an analyst at Smith Barney, said Mr. Miller's appointment would probably be greeted with cheers in the market today. "It will be seen as a very positive development that they have attracted somebody of Mr. Miller's caliber," he said. "But we still think they're going to have a very difficult time keeping this thing together. Mr. Miller has got to make people believe he can keep this company from going under -- it all comes down to confidence and credibility."
The company has not yet released its final audit for 1994 and is trying to raise cash through the sale of its 65 percent stake in MK Rail, its 46.5 percent share of MK Gold, and its Australian construction subsidiary, McConnell Dowell. And it must arrange a viable exit from the troubled MK Transit subsidiary.
In outlining his view of the choices facing Morrison Knudsen's bankers, Mr. Miller was just as blunt as he had been in his celebrated confrontations with the 400 or so domestic and foreign banks that were involved in the Chrysler talks.
"The overpowering thing is that it makes so much more sense to keep the company going than to stop the music," he said. "Since the value of the franchise and the prospects for the banks' ultimate satisfaction both depend on continuing the enterprise, I'm reasonably confident that a way will be found to find the new funding" the company needs.
Mr. Miller, known as Steve, was a rising star at the Ford Motor Company in 1979 when he was asked to become Chrysler's chief financial officer at the onset of Chrysler's brush with bankruptcy. Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman then, recalled in his memoirs that Mr. Miller's role was "absolutely critical."
His task was to get hundreds of lenders to agree to take less than they were owed. Unless they agreed, Chrysler could not tap the Federal loan guarantees that underwrote the rescue plan. He succeeded, Mr. Iacocca recalled, by using both tough bargaining and lively humor -- at one point, holding a toy gun to his head and threatening to fire if a key concession was not accepted.
His most effective prank, however, was at a critical meeting with bankers on April 1, 1980 -- 15 years before his acceptance of the Morrison Knudsen job. Mr. Miller opened that Chrysler meeting by announcing that the economy was so troubled and the company had gotten so little support from its lenders that it had decided to file for bankruptcy anyway. He quickly reminded his audience that it was April Fool's Day.
"It got everybody in the room to focus on the larger picture and to consider the consequences of no agreement," Mr. Iacocca noted.
After leaving Chrysler in 1992, Mr. Miller briefly joined the investment banking firm of James D. Wolfensohn Inc., where he worked on the Olympia & York negotiations. Since 1993, he has helped run his family's lumber business in Bandon, Ore., declining several job opportunities because they seemed "too ordinary," he said.
But he remained friends with two Morrison Knudsen directors -- Gerard D. Roche, chairman of the executive-recruiting firm Heidrick & Struggles, and Peter S. Lynch, the retired mutual fund manager whose Fidelity Magellan Fund had been a major investor in Chrysler stock. They were instrumental in bringing his name to the board's attention, he said.
A few of Morrison Knudsen's banks worked with Mr. Miller in the Chrysler negotiations in 1980. "That was an experience that all the bankers seemed to take great pride in, like going through a war," he said, noting that he would be attending a party at the Sky Club in New York in June to mark the 15th anniversary of the bank agreement.
"One or two of the bankers in the Morrison Knudsen case are in that group," he added. "That might help."

HEADLINE: Symbols of Policy Ills, Public High Rises Fall

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, April 2

 BODY:
They once represented the promise of urban renewal. But today, two buildings in the Christopher Columbus Homes here were turned to dust, a symbol of well-intentioned housing policies turned bad.
The Newark Housing Authority dynamited the two long-vacant high rises today to make way for new homes at the site. The 13-story buildings, each with 200 apartments, collapsed upon themselves, just as the demolition experts, Controlled Demolition Inc., of Phoenix, Md., had planned. 
 "High-rise public housing was not a good idea for urban America," said Harold Lucas, executive director of the housing authority. "These buildings haven't worked anywhere. They generated high crime and had a negative image."
Under a 1989 court agreement, the housing authority is building homes to replace each public housing unit it tears down. Four Columbus towers were demolished in March 1994, and Mr. Lucas said he hoped that the remaining two would be torn down by the end of the summer. About 300 town houses are to be built on the Columbus site, he said.
The housing authority's goal is to build 1,777 town houses throughout Newark to replace the 1,600 apartments that existed at Columbus.
Mayor Sharpe James said the public housing high rises were "a blight on the community."
"They were reservations for the poor," he said. "Now we are building safe, affordable housing where people can live in dignity."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Making room for new town houses like those in the foreground, two of Newark's Christopher Columbus public housing towers were demolished yesterday. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Losing Hope of Regaining Senate, Democrats Focus on House

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
Many leading Democrats have all but given up hope of regaining control of the Senate in 1996 and are concentrating on persuading wavering House members to run again in the hope of recapturing that chamber.
The Democrats' worries, which have been building since last November, intensified when 73-year-old Howell Heflin of Alabama announced last week that he would retire from the Senate after three terms. He will be the fourth Democratic Senator to retire next year, and others may well follow. 
 Seeking to prevent the same thing from happening in the House, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, and Representative Martin Frost of Texas, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, have begun holding one-on-one strategy sessions to persuade wavering House Democrats to run at least one more term. Although the campaign committee is still paying off a $2.5 million debt, Mr. Frost said he was promising to give these members, who, by some estimates, number close to two dozen, whatever financial assistance possible to help them.
"We're talking individually with any member who is even considering retirement," Mr. Frost said, "and at least urging that member to run one more time."
Mr. Gephardt has also assembled a group of former House members to try to persuade their old colleagues not to give up, and to help recruit new candidates. Former Representative Dennis E. Eckart of Ohio, who retired from Congress in 1992, said he had had several such "confessional talks" with incumbent lawmakers.
"A lot of members call me and say, 'Gosh, how do you like it? Is there really life out of Congress?' " he said.
Yet Mr. Eckart said his hunch was that most Democrats were ready to fight to win back the House. "Both sides are really ginning up for 1996 to become almost a holy political war," he said. "Republicans see this as a year in which they can lock in majority status. The Democrats know that because they have the largest minority in 40 years, this is their chance because otherwise they could get locked into minority status."
But Mr. Eckart and many other analysts concede that the Republicans have the edge, particularly in keeping the Senate.
"I've long suspected that there was going to be a mad rush for the door," said Charles Cook, who tracks Congressional campaigns for his nonpartisan political newsletter. "The chances are greater of Republicans getting 60 seats than Democrats recapturing control of the Senate. In the House, they're on pins and needles. My suspicion is that you'll see an exodus there as well."
Democrats are particularly concerned about retirements because open seats are much more difficult to hold than a seat with an incumbent seeking re-election. Before the 1994 election, six Democrats decided not to seek re-election to the Senate and the party lost all those seats.
Even as Democrats are still adjusting to being the minority, many readily acknowledge that winning back the Senate anytime soon may well be out of the party's grasp.
"Candidly, I think we're in a better position to regain the House," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, general chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "That's just a question of numbers and of retirements. But obviously, a large amount of this depends on how we do at the top of the ticket and in gubernatorial races. Who would have anticipated at this time two years ago that the House Republicans would win 55 seats?"
Despite the party's assurances of help, a continued parade of retirements would not be surprising given that many Democrats do not relish being in the minority, or the other hardships of political office these days, like the interminable fund raising. In fact, fund raising is almost certain to be more difficult for Democrats because the Republicans in power are demanding support, and allegiance, from political action committees.
Now that two Democratic Senators have switched to the Republicans -- Richard C. Shelby of Alabama and Ben Nighthorse Campbell of Colorado -- the current Senate lineup is 54 Republicans and 46 Democrats. Three other Democrats besides Mr. Heflin have announced their retirements: Senators Jim Exon of Nebraska, J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana and Paul Simon of Illinois. Alabama, Louisiana and Nebraska are increasingly considered Republican-leaning states.
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, has identified three more Democrats who face re-election in 1996 and might retire: Senators David Pryor of Arkansas, Sam Nunn of Georgia and Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island. There are 15 Democratic and 18 Republican seats up next year. Only one Republican Senator, Hank Brown of Colorado, has announced that he will retire next year.
Tom King, a Democratic consultant, echoed many of his colleagues in saying he was more hopeful about the House than the Senate.
"It's a tough road in the Senate, but in the House, we have a shot at it," he said. "But I think there's a fighting mood and people are more optimistic than they were two months ago. Newt Gingrich will be a great foil to run against."
So far, no House Democrats have announced their retirements. Generally, senators give more notice because of the fund-raising and organizational requirements for those in their party who might seek the seats.
The Republicans have only a 26-seat edge in the House, and 12 Democrats and Republicans were elected to that chamber last year with less than 50 percent of the vote. Still, Republicans have set their sights on picking up even more seats, especially in the South. Mr. Cook has already identified 22 possible Democratic retirements next year, as opposed to 10 among Republicans.
Mr. Frost said he was hopeful about winning back the House, but he did not see 1996 as a race for dominance over several terms. "It's possible for us to take the House back in '96 and for them to potentially take it back in '98," he said. "It is my sense that the House is going to be up for grabs every two years for the rest of the decade."
While Vice President Al Gore and Hillary Rodham Clinton are playing hosts to fund-raising events next month for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, several Democrats said White House officials were too preoccupied with the President's re-election effort to do much now to regain the House and Senate. But more than anything else, the popularity of Mr. Clinton in 1996 could have a lot to do with which party ends up controlling Congress.
But Glen Bolger, a Republican pollster, suggested that it might be in the long-term interest of Democrats to lose the White House next year.
"The Senate's gone for them -- you look at those seats," he said. "The best thing the Democrats can hope for is for the Republicans to win the White House in '96 and hope for an economic downturn. Then they can storm back and take the Senate in 98."
But in Alabama, the state Democratic chairman, William B. Blount, refuses to give up after Mr. Heflin's retirement.
"I don't think Howell Heflin could have been beat," he said. "Now, it's a flip of the coin. But we've got several good candidates looking at it -- including me."

HEADLINE: Throngs of Boat People to Be Sent Home to Vietnam Soon

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, March 30

 BODY:
Governments throughout Southeast Asia are to begin sending Vietnamese boat people home within weeks, with the United Nations breaking tradition to help in the effort to push tens of thousands of the migrants back to Vietnam by the end of the year, diplomats and United Nations officials say.
Alarmed by violence this month among Vietnamese detained in Hong Kong and the Philippines, governments across the region are beefing up the police presence in the detention camps, where most of the 46,000 boat people are expected to face eviction by the end of the year. 
 In protest this week, a group of boat people set fires in a Hong Kong camp and a group of asylum-seekers in the Philippines threatened suicide again. Several slashed themselves with knives this month when they were forced to move from one camp in the Philippines to another.
The first large wave is expected to take place in April or May, with the program reaching its full monthly quota of 3,600 by midsummer, said Werner Blatter, director of the Asia division for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
"We will soon see some important movements of people," Mr. Blatter said in an interview. "We feel sure that it is now time for these people to go home. It's time to wrap this up."
He said the goal was to empty virtually all of the detention camps in Asia, except those in Hong Kong, by the end of the year. In Hong Kong, where about 25,000 boat people are detained, officials said they might not complete the repatriations until the middle of next year.
Although United Nations employees will be not be personally involved in forcing the Vietnamese onto airplanes or boats, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has agreed to cooperate with the repatriation program. The move is a sharp break for the United Nations, which in the past has refused to involve itself in programs to force refugees or economic migrants to move against their will.
"From a public relations standpoint, there's some queasiness within the United Nations about taking part in something like this," said a Western diplomat involved in the program. "But I think the U.N. people are comforted to know that the international community is behind them."
The United States, which long opposed sending the Vietnamese home and has provided hundreds of millions of dollars since the end of the Vietnam War for the upkeep of the camps, is now eager to see the last of the boat people return to Vietnam -- voluntarily or not.
In a statement intended to dash any lingering hope among the boat people that they might find a home in the United States, the State Department said on March 17 that the Vietnamese "whose claims to asylum have not been upheld have no option but to return to their country of origin."
Vietnam is also eager to see the migrants back home, if only to put an end to its image as a country so poor and so repressive that people would rather take to rickety boats on the high seas than remain in their homeland. The return of the last boat people will signal the end of a 20-year exodus that led more than a million Vietnamese to a new life abroad, most in the United States.
Virtually all of the Vietnamese left in detention camps in Southeast Asia -- the largest camps are in Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand -- have been labeled economic migrants, not political refugees.
Ruth Marshall, a spokeswoman in Geneva for the High Commissioner for Refugees, described the situation of the Vietnamese left in the camps as "a nonrefugee problem."
"There is no moral or legal principle that requires the international community to continue to assist a large population of illegal immigrants," she added.
She said the High Commissioner's Office was eager to close the Asian camps because of far more pressing needs elsewhere, particularly in parts of Africa where civil war and ethnic strife have displaced millions of people in just the last year.
"There are real refugees out there crying out for a lot more help than we can given them right now," she said. "We have to draw a line."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: For Stocks, Winners Outnumbered the Losers by 2 to 1 in This Year's First Quarter

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
After a dismal 1994, investors may have needed a reason to party. So far this year, they certainly have, celebrating the least bit of good news by sending the stock market to new highs and individual issues soaring in the first quarter. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 companies, which serves as a general proxy for the market, rose 9 percent in the first three months of 1995, compared with a loss of 1.3 percent last year.
The general euphoria seems to have extended to most of the stocks trading at more than $5 a share on the three major markets: the New York and American stock exchanges and the Nasdaq market, according to data compiled by Media General Financial Services. The number of winning stocks outnumbered the losers by the rate of almost two to one. Among the 6,014 issues tracked by Media General, 3,853 closed up in price, compared with just 1,959 losing stocks. 
 Not even last week's jitters over the falling dollar managed to significantly dampen the enthusiasm, led by the strong performance of large multinational consumer companies and technology firms.
While investors may be in for more volatility than they have been used to during the last few years, few market optimists were predicting a real about-face from this year's highs.
"I think a lot of it is noise," said Alfred Kugel, the senior investment strategist for Stein Roe & Farnham, a Chicago money management firm. "The bottom line is, not much has changed." The economy's growth seems to have slowed without halting, and the companies based in the United States that sell goods and services abroad are benefiting from the cheaper dollar.
While some highfliers felt the pull of gravity in the last few days, investors who were in from the start were still looking at some sizable gains. The shares of semiconductor maker Micron Technology, for example, werestill one of the quarter's hottest performers, up 72.5 percent -- even after falling $9 in the last three days of the quarter. Among other technology stocks leading the way were two semiconductor companies: Alpha Industries, which trades on the American Stock Exchange, up 80 percent, and Orbit Semiconductor, which trades on Nasdaq, up 110 percent.
Many of the biggest gainers this quarter fueled investors' enthusiasm by reporting strong profit comparisons for the quarter or by announcing an exciting new product or contract. The Corrections Corporation of America, for example, a Nashville company that manages prisons, was the top-performing stock on the New York Stock Exchange.
Crime certainly paid: the stock nearly doubled, from $16.13 to $30.63, in the quarter as investors reacted positively to a 71 percent increase in the company's quarterly earnings, followed by news of a $23 million contract to manage a 2,000-bed jail in Texas.
Hudson Technologies, which recovers and reclaims the refrigerants that environmental regulators are worried about in air-conditioners and refrigerators, saw its stock more than triple, closing the quarter at $17.25, up from $5.50. Shares of the company, based in Hillburn, N.Y., took off after it said that it had a contract with the Carrier Corporation, a leading maker of air- conditioning systems that is a subsidiary of United Technologies Corporation. Hudson's earnings are also up.
Among the quarter's other top performers were several medical technology companies, like the Sofamor/Danek Group, the Memphis producer of spinal implant devices, and Thermo Cardiosystems, the Woburn, Mass., maker of heart implant devices.
With Wall Street favoring the stocks of large pharmaceutical companies again, investors received any news of a settled lawsuit or favorable action by the Food and Drug Administration by bidding up the prices of medical technology stocks.
The surge in takeover activity also resulted in big gains for some issues. The stock of Chicago and North Western, the railroad company, saw its shares jump 78 percent after the Union Pacific Corporation's rail division bid $35 a share in cash in mid-March. Other stocks swept up in merger bliss included Shawmut National, the Hartford bank holding company that announced in February its intention to combine with Fleet Financial Group of Boston.
Wellcome, the British drug maker, saw its shares rise by more than half after it was pursued by Glaxo Holdings, Britain's largest pharmaceutical company. And the shares of American Maize-Products rose 60 percent once Eridania Beghin-Say, a subsidiary of chemical giant Montedison, decided it wanted to take over the Stamford, Conn., company.
All the biggest losers on the New York Stock Exchange were Mexican companies hurt by the plummeting peso. Investors decided to take their losses and go home. As a result, Grupo Elektra, which sells low-priced appliances and furniture, saw its shares drop from $14.13 to $4, despite the company's 68 percent rise in earnings in the quarter. If it was in pesos, it just didn't count.

HEADLINE: PULSE;
New York City Tourism

 BODY:
By all indications, 1994 was a banner year for tourism in New York City. The weak dollar, an improving economy and big events like soccer World Cup and the Gay Games healped attract almost 25 million visitors to the city. Travel experts also credit the continuing decline in crime and the reduction in the tax for hotel rooms for the surge in tourism. The combined city and state tax fell to 13.25 percent plus $2 a room from 19.25 percent plus $2 on Dec. 1. But hotels and travel agents began to see an increase in bookings months earlier, when the cuts were announced.

HEADLINE: Rhode Island Is Moving To Protect Homosexuals

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, March 30

 BODY:
While anti-discrimination laws are being challenged elsewhere, Rhode Island is bucking the national trend by advancing a bill that would grant protection to homosexuals in employment, housing, public accommodations and credit.
"Rhode Island has always been contrary," said State Senator William P. Fitzpatrick, a Democrat from Cranston who is gay and will shepherd the bill through the Senate, where it is given a good chance of passage. The measure was approved 57 to 41 on Wednesday by the House of Representatives, and Gov. Lincoln C. Almond, a Republican, has said he will sign it. 
 The Governor's communications director, Jim Taricani, said Mr. Almond "has a longstanding belief that no one should be discriminated against, and he thinks this law is unfortunately necessary."
Mr. Fitzpatrick said Rhode Island "will be viewed as progressive in what is appearing to become a regressive country." But he added that he did not underestimate the opposition, since such legislation has failed four times in the state since 1990.
Challenges to existing or prospective local anti-discrimination laws have been mounted in Colorado, Florida, Idaho, Maine, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon and Washington, among others. Some have been successful, some not and some are pending.
Opponents like State Representative Charles T. Knowles, Democrat of Narragansett, who voted against the Rhode Island bill, say anti-bias laws designating homosexuals as a protected minority effectively create "special rights for well-educated, economically advantaged people."
State Senator Michael J. Flynn, a Smithfield Republican who serves as minority leader and also opposes the bill, said the gay people he knew "live in some of the best locations and certainly have mortgages and jobs."
"I see no need for these special rights," Mr. Flynn said. "I think if we pass this legislation, we're validating a life style."
Advocates respond that homosexuality is not a life style but an innate characteristic and that homosexuals constantly suffer discrimination that is almost impossible to measure. A woman dismissed from her job because she is a lesbian, for example, would probably not make a public issue of it, for fear of jeopardizing future employment prospects.
"We in the gay and lesbian community of Rhode Island hear many, many stories of discrimination, especially in employment and housing," said a teacher, Ralph M. Perry. "But most people won't come forward for fear of receiving publicity and being identified."
When Mr. Perry came forward earlier this month to testify for the bill and publicly disclose his homosexuality, it was front-page news in Rhode Island. That is because he is the state's Teacher of the Year.
"My success and reputation in my field are not enough," Mr. Perry told the House committee on special legislation. "Despite my recognition as a good teacher, I can legally be fired tomorrow for testifying here tonight. This is not right."
State Representative Francis A. Gaschen, Democrat of Cumberland, a co-sponsor of the bill, said Mr. Perry's testimony "answered the question, 'What do we need this for?' "
Mr. Perry, 42, teaches reading, writing and mathematics to first and second graders at the Aquidneck Elementary School in Middletown. Known familiarly as Marty, Mr. Perry has worked in the Middletown public schools for 17 years and was that system's Teacher of the Year in 1994, before winning the statewide designation last December.
Although he studied for the Roman Catholic priesthood, Mr. Perry said his volunteer work with the deaf and mentally retarded convinced him that "teaching was my true calling."
After years of keeping his homosexuality a secret from friends and family, Mr. Perry met Bob Fulghum in 1982. "We decided in 1983 to spend the rest of our lives together and wanted to share that with family and friends," Mr. Perry said. However, he refrained from talking about his personal life at school, he said, "for fear of repercussions from parents."
Last year, when the bill was before the Legislature, Mr. Perry planned to testify. But he said a lawyer for the National Education Association, the teachers union, "couldn't warn me in strong enough terms" not to do so, out of concern for his job.
"I really felt by not testifying that I let down the gay and lesbian community," Mr. Perry said, and resolved to come forward this year. Since his appearance two weeks ago, he said, he has received "nothing but support."
Sharon Osborne, the special assistant to Rhode Island's commissioner of education, who oversees the Teacher of the Year designation, said there had been "no backlash at all" from Mr. Perry's testimony.
If the State Senate passes the anti-discrimination bill, Rhode Island would become the ninth state to adopt such a statewide law. Wisconsin was the first, in 1982, said Robin Kane, of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force. Massachusetts followed in 1989; Connecticut and Hawaii in 1991; California, New Jersey and Vermont in 1992, and Minnesota in 1993.
New York does not have such a law, as Republican leaders in the State Senate have blocked the bill from reaching the floor for a vote. Gov. George E. Pataki has said he believes the measure should be considered by the full Senate but would veto the bill if it passed.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Owners End a Battle, But the War Isn't Over

BYLINE: By Claire Smith 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
As Bud Selig tried to walk away at last from the most ignominious chapter in the history of sports labor relations, a lone voice called out to baseball's harried interim commissioner with some unsolicited advice yesterday.
"Lock 'em out, Bud." 
 Selig, the man who banked on rewriting the rules when it comes to player salaries only to have to concede the war to a victorious players union, didn't even break stride.
There was no use stopping. There was no fight left. Not in the owners, at least. The damage that had come from a nearly eight-month-old fight with striking players had been assessed. And the assessment wasn't good.
Yes, the owners had learned how to match the players' resolve. "I think we've both proven how strong we are," Jerry McMorris, the owner of the Colorado Rockies, said. But, an obviously world-weary McMorris said, "I think we've severely damaged our game."
And because enough owners obviously agreed, the battle was over, for now.
The war had started in 1974 when the first players were granted free agency and their employers, eager to buy success, stopped caring about controlling costs or their fellow owners' economic concerns.
The war, which has run hot and cold ever since, resumed with open hostilities last Aug. 12, when the players struck. History will show that on April 2, 1995, 234 days later, the longest work stoppage ended not with a bang but a whimper, not with lasting peace but with uncertainty.
There still is no Basic Agreement, no accord with the workers. And, to the chagrin of small-market clubs, there is no increased revenue sharing because big-market clubs still link revenue sharing -- which could distribute $58 million -- to major concessions by the players.
Still, enough owners, big market and small, are now obviously convinced that for now there can be no gain on any front, even if the players were locked out. So they accepted the players' offer to return, and didn't even have to vote on it.
"The clubs sat patiently and listened to all the information and in the end came off without very little debate, really almost no debate, on what were the best ways for us to restore order but continue to keep moving toward a solution to our problems," Selig said. "And the course of action we took today is what we believe to be the most viable solution to all that."
And, Selig added, any talk of who won and who lost was childish. Yet there are winners, although very few among the ranks of the owners. Conversely, the varying degrees of loss were obvious.
Small-market owners, hard-line executives, like Jackie Autry of the Angels, walked by with tight lips and precious few comments.
"I'm not sure comfortable is the word," Bill Bartholomey of the Atlanta Braves -- a hard-line club -- said when asked to describe the tenor of the afternoon. "But under the circumstances, it was a good meeting."
But for big-market executives, the relief showed in their walk and in their talk. "There is ongoing concern," said McMorris, who voiced opposition to a lockout throughout the weekend. "We still have to have the right economic improvements in the industry. I think everybody knows that. But we need to get the '95 season going."
Peter Angelos of the Baltimore Orioles, once the lone holdout against total war, went in today knowing that McMorris and Fred Wilpon of the Mets, George Steinbrenner of the Yankees, the Blue Jays and more didn't want an escalation in hostilities. They just wanted to play ball, and with their regular players, not replacements.
So there was no lockout vote that many had predicted would be close. Instead, the owners said yes -- with delight, Selig said more than once -- to the players' offer to come back if the rules of the expired Basic Agreement are adhered to. Then, Selig said with much hope, an agreement that gives the owners what they want in terms of financial security will come, anyway, without another work stoppage and labor carnage.
As for Round 8, did what the owners do yesterday constitute total surrender?
As it turned out, that was the one question that didn't delight Selig. And it certainly didn't cause him to turn a deaf ear.
"I don't regard it as a surrender," Selig said, voice and dander rising. "The players were on strike. They made an unconditional offer to come back. We accepted that offer. We also said there are also many other things working.
"The fact is, we believe that we have to come to some fulfillment in our long-term economic problems. There are many ways to do that. But we believe that right now it's important to get the focus of the game back on the field for all parties. Period. It's in our best interest for us to do that."
In thinking of their own best interests, the owners have stumbled on what was right for the game, too. The best interests of baseball, a dust-covered concept, had made a return.
The best interests came back, hand in hand with some sanity and rational thought. And as it did, it passed replacement players, salary cap imbroglios and total war with the union, on their way out the door at last.

HEADLINE: The Baseball Truce

 BODY:
Just when it seemed the highlight of the summer sports season might be videotape of Michael Jordan's return to basketball, Major League Baseball has been forced to snap out of its stupefying labor dispute. The resumption of baseball, even for an abbreviated season that may make 15-game winners the paradigm of pitching excellence, is cheering news for baseball fans, many of whom feared a summertime choice between lawn mowing and watching hapless replacement players.
But the resumption of Major League Baseball does not signal an end of the economic and labor issues that have divided the players and owners and badly wounded America's most ingenious sport. This is a reprieve, not a resolution. If a new labor agreement is not reached in the weeks ahead, there is a good chance play will be suspended again in coming years. 
 It may be hard to summon great sympathy for either side in a dispute over how to divide the kind of riches most Americans can only read about, but the players are justified in fighting for the freedom to sell their skills in an open market. The salary inflation that imperils teams in smaller cities that offer less lucrative television contracts was propelled by the owners themselves as they signed .250 hitters to multimillion-dollar deals. If some redistribution of wealth is required to keep the poorer franchises competitive and in business, the owners should finance it. It offends principle to ask the players to prop up weak franchises by restricting their right to bargain for higher salaries.
Even the temporary peace produced over the weekend represents a failure of collective bargaining. The two sides decided to play ball not because they had narrowed differences but because Federal Judge Sonia Sotomayor left little choice. She found the owners had unfairly established new work rules during the baseball negotiations by suspending salary arbitration, free-agent bidding and anti-collusion provisions in the old agreement. After she ordered the provisions reinstated, the players ended their strike. A lockout by the owners was untenable because it could cost them $5 million a day in back pay and damages if the National Labor Relations Board ultimately were to rule that they engaged in unfair labor practices.
Baseball has been in an uncontrollable skid since 1992, when a group of owners, led by Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox and Bud Selig of the Milwaukee Brewers, decided they had had enough of a competitive marketplace and player rights. They fired Commissioner Fay Vincent, who was trying to work out a new labor agreement, and under the protection of baseball's antitrust exemption started dictating to the players instead of bargaining with them.
The only way to resolve the crisis in baseball is with a new collective bargaining agreement, and with elimination of the antitrust exemption. But for now, let the April optimism of fans from Boston to San Francisco flower anew.

HEADLINE: Hillary Clinton Meets Man Who Gave Her 2 L's

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: DHAKA, Bangladesh, April 2

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton has practiced law, raised a daughter and tried to change one-seventh of the American economy by reshaping health care. But in the last 24 hours she has ridden a bull elephant with Secret Service radio escort, and met the man responsible for making her a Hillary with two l's.
At an airstrip in Katmandu, Nepal -- just after an overnight tiger safari and just before her departure for this poverty-ridden pocket of South Asia -- Mrs. Clinton shook hands with Sir Edmund Hillary, the New Zealander who conquered Mount Everest with Tenzing Norgay in 1953. He was passing through town on his way to visit schools and a hospital in the Himalayan highlands financed by a foundation he heads. 
 "To be honest with you, in America, before if anybody recognized the name Hillary, it's always been me," Sir Edmund, 75, told reporters just before greeting Mrs. Clinton. "And now they say, 'Oh, you must be a lady!' "
For her part, Mrs. Clinton confessed that her mother, Dorothy Rodham, had read an article about the intrepid Edmund Hillary, a one-time beekeeper who had taken to mountain climbing, when she was pregnant with her daughter in 1947 and liked the name.
"It had two l's, which is how she thought she was supposed to spell Hillary," Mrs. Clinton told reporters after the brief meeting on the tarmac, minutes before her Air Force jet flew past the peak of Everest itself. "So when I was born, she called me Hillary, and she always told me it's because of Sir Edmund Hillary."
Sir Edmund was to have joined Mrs. Clinton overnight at the Tiger Tops Jungle Lodge, a rustic hotel in the Royal Chitwan National Park that has played host to guests from Queen Elizabeth II to Goldie Hawn. But mechanical problems delayed his plane from New Zealand and he barely made it in time for the airport handshake today.
So he missed the sight of Mrs. Clinton and her 15-year-old daughter, Chelsea, ensconced in a padded howdah atop Shamsher Bahadur, a 9-foot, 8 1/2-inch elephant whose name means Brave Tiger, in a sunset search for a tiger in the grass on Saturday. They were trailed by three Secret Service agents -- with sunglasses, wrist walkie-talkies, earphones and all.
"Fancy meeting you all here," Mrs. Clinton called out to reporters from under a wide-brimmed straw hat as her elephant approached a river bank for a picture-taking session that had been negotiated with her reluctant staff in the plaintive entreaties and blunt demurrers generally reserved for nuclear disarmament talks.
Informed that the reporters, aboard their own fleet of rolling trunks and giant toenails, had seen three mother-daughter pairs of armor-plated Asian rhinos, Mrs. Clinton quickly brought the topic around to the business of her trip: encouraging the education of girls and women.
"Mothers and daughters?" she exclaimed. "Are they sending their girls to school?"
In fact, it must be reported, Mrs. Clinton's day off -- sandwiched between 12 overloaded days of visits to schools, clinics and the leaders of five nations -- induced in the captive press corps accompanying her a degree of sympathy rare for traveling journalists.
So it was all the more puzzling that her aides had ever resisted letting her be photographed in such a quintessential subcontinental setting. Some suggested they were reluctant to invite comparisons with Jacqueline Kennedy, the last American First Lady to make a solo trip to this region. She rode an elephant in Jaipur, India, 33 years ago last month.
One ride of an hour and a half was enough for Mrs. Clinton, though Chelsea went out again this morning. Neither spied the big quarry, the endangered royal Bengal tiger, but they did see rhinos, spotted deer and a peacock perched in a tree.
The forest was also thick with wild hogs, whose cousin, the Arkansas Razorbacks, impelled Mrs. Clinton's attempt at contact with the outside world from the remote lodge: she brought a short-wave radio, hoping to catch word of the game between the University of Arkansas and North Carolina, but couldn't find any broadcasts in English. In the end, the White House communications staff traveling with the First Lady reached the President's entourage in Little Rock and learned that Arkansas had won.

HEADLINE: Poor Town Finds an Angel in a White Coat

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: BAYOU LA BATRE, Ala., April 1

 BODY:
The old man swore he saw angels.
It was a year or so back, the day 79-year-old Emile Lyons suffered an abdominal aneurysm. "The day my insides busted," he said. The bony commercial fisherman had lived through hurricanes, heart bypasses and his 50th wedding anniversary. But that day, he really believed the Lord had called him home. 
 As two paramedics loaded him into the ambulance, "I saw angels and lights and everything," he said. Through the haze of pain he found a familiar face, his doctor, Regina Benjamin. She had jumped in the ambulance with him, and treated him on the tortuous 30-minute drive to the nearest emergency room, in Mobile.
"She saved my life," Mr. Lyons said. "Could be she's an angel, too."
It seems like everyone in this impoverished fishing village on Alabama's Gulf Coast has a story to tell about this woman who stitches their shark bites, watches over the babies and comes running when accidents at the docks or shipyards injure husbands and sons. She makes house calls in a Ford pickup and checks in on shut-ins by telephone.
When they cannot pay -- which is often -- she tells them to pay when they can, what little they can. With envelopes containing single $5 bills, they come by her office: whites, blacks, Vietnamese, Cambodians, Laotians, people who would be turned away by doctors who put proof of insurance ahead of healing.
At a time when the nation's health care industry is becoming dominated by huge insurance companies, for-profit hospital corporations and massive health maintenance organizations, Dr. Benjamin, 38, is a throwback long thought to be extinct: a country doctor with a heart. She serves an isolated pocket of Alabama that is desperate for doctors, where only people who drag a living from the Gulf -- and a few lost travelers -- ever go.
"We didn't have anyone before her," said Bill Menton, a retired state senator who can afford to travel to see any doctor but prefers Dr. Benjamin. "We were just a bunch of shrimp pickers that no one cared about."
She is the only doctor here, and about 80 percent of her patients live below the poverty line. What little they can pay would never cover the costs of her staff of two nurses and an office manager or the overhead of the bare-bones clinic that shares the sidewalk with a pool hall.
But she found a way to make the clinic go, and for that, said medical experts and patients, the people of Bayou La Batre can thank Dr. Benjamin's business savvy more than her healing hands.
She opened her own practice in 1990, paying the way with late-night shifts as a traveling doctor in emergency rooms. But she soon realized that she needed to know as much about business and government red tape as she did about anatomy, so she made the 250-mile round-trip commute to New Orleans twice a week to earn her M.B.A. While in school, Dr. Benjamin discovered a little-known provision in a 1977 health clinic law that made Federal money available to help pay for the operation of a clinic or office in places like Bayou La Batre (pronounced lah BAT-tree), where medical help was badly needed.
Now, after serving on several state and national medical association panels, she gets calls, letters and visits from others who want to know how to do the same thing in towns and backwoods places around the country. She speaks at seminars. But mostly, she treats the sick of a tiny town. She has had offers to join big-city practices and hospitals but has declined.
Dr. Benjamin said she chooses to work in Bayou La Batre because there is a need, and because it is a place where one doctor's presence can make a difference.
"She wants to help people more than she wants to make a bunch of money," said Dale Hammac, 27, cradling his 10-month-old baby who had cried herself to sleep with an ear infection.
Like others in this town of 2,500, Mr. Hammac will fight you if you speak badly of his doctor.
Dr. Benjamin is a soft-spoken woman, quick to smile, slow to brag, too good to be true it seems. Instead of talking about successes, she talks about failures.
"What I hate," she said, "is writing a prescription for someone who can't get it filled because they don't have any money. People can't buy medicine, they can't buy anything."
Some say the town's economic plight is a result of the Federal Government's closing the local oyster beds after bacteria showed up in tests. Others blame yet another layoff at the shipyards. The Vietnamese say their nets are empty because the gods are angry.
In one way or another, everyone here is tied to the water. At quitting time at the packing and canning plants, the streets are filled with people in white uniforms and white rubber boots that people here call Bayou La Batre Reeboks. But the work is seasonal.
"Older people choose between buying medicine or eating," Dr. Benjamin said. "They like to be sick more in the summer than in the winter, because they live on food from their gardens in the summer."
Dr. Benjamin grew up not far from here in the little town of Daphne. Her family owned land that was gradually sold off. She was raised on food from the nets, like fried mullet and shrimp, and never even knew she was poor.
She did not grow up wanting to be a doctor. In high school, she heard the term "international lawyer," and thought it sounded good, so she wrote to Yale Law School. "They said it might be a good idea if I went to college first," she recalled.
She wound up in a premed program at Xavier University in New Orleans, then medical school at the Alabama School of Medicine in Birmingham. To help pay for her schooling she signed on with the National Health Service Corps, which pays tuition in return for a commitment to work three years in places in dire need of doctors. They sent her to Bayou La Batre.
She stayed.
Dr. Benjamin has treated a man on a commercial fishing boat who had slashed his hand open and stuck the wound together with Super Glue. She said it seemed to be healing nicely so she left it alone. She regularly treats cases of frostbite among the workers in seafood plants, who get it from walking in and out of giant freezers.
She treats patients with liver failure and cancer, and people who contracted their sickness in the bottom of a bottle.
"She cries when they die," said one of Dr. Benjamin's nurses, Nell Bosarge, 65, who retired last week.
Because the hospital is so far away, emergency cases walk in the door regularly "and drop," said Dr. Benjamin's other nurse, 20-year-old Lynn Gainey. The staff stabilizes them and sends them to Mobile.
Dr. Benjamin treats ornery Emile Lyons whether he thinks he needs it or not. When she told him his blood pressure was high, he brushed it off like a sand flea.
"I'm just worried, is all," said Mr. Lyons, whose wife, Gladys, had been treated recently with chemotherapy for lung cancer and seemed to be responding to it.
Dr. Benjamin just nodded her head. She asked Ms. Gainey to check it again, but Mr. Lyons had started talking about Republicans, a subject that always makes his blood pressure jump even more.
"Nothing wrong with my blood pressure!" he said defiantly. But as soon as Dr. Benjamin was safely out of hearing, he leaned forward and said, almost in a whisper, "I love that woman."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Along Alabama's Gulf Coast, Dr. Regina Benjamin is a throwback: a country doctor with heart, and with a willingness to make house calls. At her bare-bones clinic in the town of Bayou La Batre, Dr. Benjamin, right, examined Gidget Jackowski, 8, as the girl's mother Lisa watched. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Gingrich Is Seeking To Restore Gay Ban In Military Services

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
The Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, said today that Congress would reopen the issue of homosexuals in the military and would seek to undo President Clinton's two-year-old policy, known as "don't ask, don't tell, don't pursue."
The old policy, which flatly prohibited homosexuals from serving in the armed forces, has been ruled unconstitutional several times in the last three years. And last week, a Federal judge in New York struck down Mr. Clinton's new policy, enacted in 1993, saying it was discriminatory and played to the fears of heterosexual troops. 
 The latest ruling notwithstanding, the Joint Chiefs of Staff have said that they are happy with the current policy and that in practice it proved to be not much different from the former policy. Homosexuals are discharged from the military about as often now as they were before the change.
Mr. Gingrich's remark, which he made on the ABC News program "This Week," came as something of a surprise because there has been virtually no clamoring for reinstatement of the old policy, except from Representative Robert K. Dornan, a conservative Republican from California.
"The fact is that we're going to probably go back to the rules that existed prior to President Clinton changing them," Mr. Gingrich said. "Now, he may well veto that. I mean, this may get to be an argument.
"But I'd be very surprised if you don't see a Republican Congress saying that serving in the military has a unique set of requirements, and if the military feels that in fact it's inappropriate, we're willing to abide by the military judgment."
The Clinton policy allows homosexuals to serve in the military and bars commanders from pursuing investigations of homosexual activity unless they have compelling evidence that such activity has occurred. But it continues the military's longtime ban on homosexual acts and requires gay service members to keep their sexual orientations private. Declaring homosexuality in a public forum is considered evidence of an intent to commit homosexual acts and is therefore grounds for discharge.
Last Thursday Judge Eugene H. Nickerson of Federal District Court in Brooklyn dismissed the Government's argument that morale and discipline would suffer if openly homosexual men and women were allowed to serve. He said the Clinton policy violated the First Amendment rights of homosexuals and was discriminatory because it did not prohibit heterosexuals from declaring their sexual orientation.
On the television program, Mr. Gingrich also rebuked fellow Republicans who had criticized Mr. Clinton's $52 billion bailout plan for Mexico.
"I don't think this is a game," Mr. Gingrich said, in apparent reference to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, chairman of the banking committee, who last week tried to reduce the amount of the United States contribution to the Mexico bailout.
Mr. Gingrich reaffirmed his support for the President's agreement with Mexico and said: "I think having Mexico collapse and having 5 to 15 million Mexicans decide to walk north would be catastrophic. And I think the people who think it's an easy vote ought to ask themselves what their reaction is going to be if this Government in Mexico collapses and if the Mexican economy collapses."
He added that undermining the deal with Mexico could produce "a secondary effect in all of the soft-currency markets around the world."
"And if you suddenly start having a similar impact in Argentina and Brazil and India and Eastern Europe," Mr. Gingrich said, "I think this is a very dangerous, very serious situation."
While Congressional leaders have supported President Clinton's plan, promising $20 billion from the taxpayer-financed Exchange Stabilization Fund and more than $30 billion through the International Monetary Fund, the bailout has been stalled by members of Congress who say the plan is unwise. The issue may be resolved this week.
Mr. Gingrich, who has appeared on a flurry of television programs recently as Congress completes its first 100 days under the new Republican majority, also suggested that the Republican effort to cut taxes would pass the House this week largely intact.
Many Republicans are unhappy over the details, especially the leadership's insistence that a $500-per-child tax credit be extended to everyone with taxable incomes of less than $200,000 a year. Many moderate Republicans want the credit limited to families with incomes of less than $95,000.
"We don't have a compromise yet," Mr. Gingrich said of the dispute. "We're still arguing. I'm not sure we'll get to a compromise. I mean, we may just bring the bill up and see what happens. And my guess is the House will vote for it."
He also said he expected Congress to take up some sort of "religious freedom" bill this year that would include school prayer.
On an ethics issue, he declared that members of Congress would keep the frequent-flier miles they earn on public business for their personal use, a practice that has been criticized. "We feel that if a younger member who has a couple kids, and they don't have very much money, and they have to maintain, you know, two households, if they have one minor benefit that allows their family to come to Washington, we think it's a good thing," Mr. Gingrich said.
He noted that Capital Cities/ABC, the company that owns ABC News, allowed its employees to keep their miles. Reminded that the bonus miles for members of Congress are paid for by taxpayers, Mr. Gingrich responded: "No. In our case, this is a pro-family benefit. I suspect, given the amount of work we're doing right now, the average taxpayer has far less passion than you do on this issue."
Mr. Gingrich said his fellow House Republicans had pleaded with him not to stage a second "100 Days" with a new batch of legislative initiatives, saying everyone was exhausted. The first 100 days technically ends in the second week of April, but because he wanted the House to be "family friendly," Mr. Gingrich set the first 100 days to conclude on April 7, which is the 93d day, when a three-week recess begins.

HEADLINE: Mischief on Mexico

 BODY:
Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York is recklessly threatening to block the Administration from providing Mexico loans and loan guarantees. The threat by the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee could be enough to scare off skittish foreign investors, driving the peso lower and worsening Mexico's recession. If Mr. D'Amato got his way, and Congress cut off the loans, the Mexican economy could collapse.
The Clinton Administration, fearing imminent bankruptcy and Congressional inaction, decided in February to use $20 billion in a Treasury fund under its control to aid Mexico. Mr. Clinton received support from Speaker Newt Gingrich, Bob Dole, Senate majority leader, and Democratic leaders. The maneuver was justified because financial collapse in Mexico would hurt the United States. Tens of thousands of workers here would lose jobs in export industries, and citizens, whose pensions and savings are in mutual funds, would see their wealth drop. Mr. D'Amato's charge that the bailout serves only currency speculators is wide of the mark. 
 Mr. D'Amato also charges that the bailout is a failure. That is, for now, also untrue. Mexico, with help from Washington, launched tough reforms that have in two months wiped out its huge trade deficit, brought its federal accounts into surplus and clamped down on the money supply to keep inflation under control. Investors have noticed: stock markets are up and the fluctuations of the peso have dampened.
Loans by the United States and the International Monetary Fund to Mexico are key to investor confidence. The cash reassures foreigners that Mexico will have reserves when they choose to cash in their investments. In this fragile environment, Mr. D'Amato's remarks are incendiary.
President Clinton might be confronted with the sickening choice of reneging on his promise to Mexico or vetoing a crucial piece of legislation, such as a budget bill, to which Mr. D'Amato plans to attach his pernicious amendment. The better course would be for Mr. D'Amato to withdraw the threat.

HEADLINE: Underwriting on Wall Street Remained Sluggish in Quarter

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Beset by layoffs and losses, Wall Street has been hoping that its bread-and-butter business -- the underwriting of stocks and bonds -- may finally have hit bottom.
There is, therefore, a glimmer of hope for the securities industry from its sales of stocks and bonds for the first quarter of 1995. The industry's underwritings of such securities rose 17 percent to $138.7 billion, compared with $118.9 billion in the last quarter of 1994, according to statistics compiled by the Securities Data Corporation. 
 That is about all the relief the numbers provide, though. Compared with the first quarter of 1994, when the securities business was still buoyant, underwriting remains very much in the doldrums. First-quarter volume this year was down by slightly more than 50 percent, compared with the first quarter of 1994 when the industry sold $282.5 billion of new securities.
"It was a relatively slow quarter," said Grant Kvalheim, who heads Merrill Lynch & Company's debt capital markets business. He described the recent declines in long-term interest rates as "manna from heaven" for the markets, but said they had not had as much effect as brokerage firms had hoped. Declines in long-term interest rates tend to encourage borrowers to tap the bond markets, giving a lift to the debt-underwriting business.
There were also only a few big securities offerings that helped to bolster the weak market, including a $2 billion debt offering for the American Home Products Corporation and the AT&T Corporation's $1.8 billion issue of stock.
And underwriting fees were down substantially, too. The industry's disclosed fees, measured by gross spreads, totaled $904.2 million, compared with $2.122 billion in the first quarter of 1994, according to Securities Data. Though Merrill Lynch was the lead underwriter for the first quarter in terms of volume of securities underwritten, Goldman, Sachs & Company generated bigger underwriting fees, $175.6 million, compared with $138.0 million at Merrill Lynch and $83.5 million at Morgan Stanley & Company. Goldman managed to keep roughly level with its $173.6 million fees for the first quarter of 1994, but Merrill Lynch slipped substantially from $421.3 million for the year-earlier quarter, while Morgan Stanley's fell by more than half from $192.9 million in the 1994 quarter.
The fall in industry fees is partly attributable to the growing proportion of underwriting business that Wall Street did for Government-sponsored agencies like the Federal Home Loan Bank and the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae. Such business earns only meager fees. Bond underwriting for such Government-sponsored agencies accounted for $44.9 billion, or 77 percent, of bond sales for the quarter, compared with 49 percent for the year-earlier quarter.
In contrast, initial public offerings for companies generate much fatter revenues. But these choicer morsels were much harder to come by: the securities industry underwrote $3.77 billion of initial public offerings in the first quarter of this year, compared with $8.13 billion in the quarter a year ago.
Wall Street's last big unincorporated partnership, Goldman, Sachs, however, romped to the top of the initial public offering league, underwriting $1.33 billion of such offerings. That was more than the next six ranked competitors put together -- Morgan Stanley; Smith Barney, a unit of the Travelers Corporation; CS First Boston; Merrill Lynch; Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a unit of the Equitable Companies, and Alex. Brown & Sons. These firms together accounted for $1.31 billion of the quarter's underwriting of initial public offerings.
The big Wall Street firms that dominate the securities business have suffered particularly from the downturn in the underwriting business. The top 10 underwriters of United States corporate securities, for example, sold $115.4 billion in the first quarter, compared with $200.4 billion for the year-earlier period. As a whole, the securities industry's managing underwriters slumped to $138.7 billion for the first quarter this year, compared with $282.5 billion for the first quarter of 1994.
Recent lower interest rates are one promising sign for the industry. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond has declined to about 7.4 percent from about 8.15 percent late last year, helping to lift the bond markets. This, though, has not yet had that much effect on business volumes, said Mr. Kvalheim of Merrill. He says that should change, and he expects business volume to be "a bit better" in the second quarter.
The first-quarter underwriting numbers also provided further evidence of how a few commercial banks are succeeding in building successful securities businesses. J. P. Morgan & Company ranked seventh among the nation's leading underwriters, up from 11th in the first quarter of 1994. And First Tennessee Bank, a unit of the First Tennessee Corporation, jumped to No. 10, from 16th in the first quarter of 1994.
But Corporate America has been quite profitable recently, meaning that there is not that much appetite to issue stock to raise money.
Analysts also do not see much hope in the marginally higher business volumes for the first quarter. Perrin Long, a securities industry analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, late last week changed his recommendation on the shares of several large securities houses to "sell" from "hold."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 4, 1995, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about the performance of Wall Street underwriters mislabeled the rankings of the leading securities underwriters. They were for the first quarter of 1995, not the second quarter of 1994.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
BASEBALL OWNERS QUIT FIGHT; OPENING DAY IS SET FOR APRIL 26

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 2

 BODY:
Major league baseball owners, faced with no viable alternative, today accepted the players' offer to return to work, ending the longest work stoppage in professional sports history on the day the 1995 season was supposed to open.
The owners' decision, announced after a four-and-a-half-hour meeting, ended the players' strike after 234 days, or 9 days short of eight months. The longest previous work stoppage was the 50-day baseball strike in 1981. The National Hockey League locked out its players for 103 days at the start of this season. 
 Players can begin reporting to spring training on Wednesday on a voluntary basis, with the mandatory date for reporting to camps in Florida or Arizona coming Friday. The season, which had been scheduled to begin tonight with a game between the Mets and the Marlins in Florida, will start April 26.
Each team will have a 144-game schedule, reduced from the regular 162 games. After April 26, some teams will have games canceled or added, mostly added, to enable them to conform to the 144 total.
Katy Feeney, the National League's schedule maker, said opening day games have not been determined, but added that it will feature a "close-to-full" schedule. Officials hoped to complete the schedule by the end of the week.
The players, whose strike last Aug. 12 wiped out the last 52 days of the season and the World Series for the first time in 90 years, will go back to work without a new collective bargaining agreement but with the protection of an injunction forcing the owners to reinstate elements of the expired agreement.
It was the owners' unilateral decision to eliminate those elements -- salary arbitration, individual bargaining between clubs and players and the anti-collusion provision of the free-agency rules -- that prompted the National Labor Relations Board to find that the owners had not bargained in good faith, issue a complaint and seek an injunction.
"The players are back, the game is back and we are very happy about that," Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, said in announcing the owners' acceptance of the players' offer to end their strike. He added, "We hope to resolve our dispute so that we and our fans never have to go through the heartache we've endured for the past eight months."
From his comments, it was clear that Selig had decided to treat the development in an upbeat manner. Missing were the agonized and sometimes acrimonious comments about the union and its negotiating style. He tried to deflect questions about the continuing dispute over the owners' efforts to change the game's economic system.
Donald Fehr, the union leader, was not at home, but Gene Orza, the associate general counsel, said, "I'm obviously gratified that those were their decisions, both with respect to the lockout, but more important with respect to the replacement players, which would have been a telling blow to the future relationship of the parties."
He added: "None of that detracts from the continuing priority of getting a collective bargaining agreement. The players are committed to that objective and this development doesn't diminish that objective."
The owners' lawyers will go before a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on Tuesday to seek a stay of the injunction while they appeal it, but even management people gave the stay effort little chance of success.
Some owners had portrayed the meeting at the O'Hare Hilton today as a session at which they would vote on a lockout or, failing that, the use of replacement players in regular-season games until the regular players were ready to play. But, as developments showed, their characterization turned out to be erroneous. No votes were even taken.
"No vote was necessary," said Peter Angelos of the Baltimore Orioles, who was the only owner who had refused to field a replacement team and had faced sanctions from the American League for his stance. "The matter was discussed and it was unanimously decided there would be no lockout and there would be no replacement players playing between now and April 26."
Angelos said the owners discussed "the pros and the cons and the in-betweens," and he said he believed everyone in the end was united.
"There were no real decisions to be made," a management official said. "There was no appetite for a lockout. People realized for a number of reasons they didn't want to do it. It just wasn't the thing to do."
Some owners had talked about securing a no-strike pledge from the players before allowing them to return, but management lawyers never asked the union to provide that pledge.
At a meeting on Saturday with lawyers for the players, the owners' lawyers asked about the idea of a no-strike, no-lockout agreement but did not request a pledge. They didn't want to condition the players' return on such a pledge, labor lawyers explained, because it could be illegal for the owners to place such a condition on an acceptance of an unconditional offer to return to work.
Basically, a person familiar with the meeting said, the owners' lawyers asked what the union's intentions were in regard to a strike and the union people replied that the players would comply with their obligations under the law.
Addressing the no-strike issue, Angelos said: "I think there's a commitment, but an unwritten one, on the side of the players, as well as the owners, that we will not have this kind of work stoppage in the future. And we'll finish the '95 season and the World Series."
When Selig was asked about such a pledge he said: "It's important we have a season without interruption. Those are things we'll have to work out."
In reality, the owners' course had been set in a conference call last Friday after Judge Sonia Sotomayor issued the injunction in Federal District Court. On the call were members of the executive council, the eight-owner body that rules the major leagues in the absence of a commissioner; the Player Relations Committee, the owners' labor arm, and the negotiating committee.
Hanging up from that call, the owners knew they would not lock out the players and they knew they would not begin the season with replacement players. The labor committee issued a directive to clubs Saturday telling them to release their replacement players from major league rosters, but to assign them to minor league teams.
The labor strategists wanted to keep the replacements as a precautionary measure in the event the players would walk out again, after a negative result on the injunction appeal, for example.
Asked about the possible future use of replacements, Selig said: "Replacement baseball, as of this time, is gone. If you're asking ever, I can't give you that."
Selig also thanked the replacement players, "who interrupted their lives to help us out."
The P.R.C. directive went out while the lawyers were discussing back-to-work issues. After two sessions, management lawyers prepared a document outlining such matters as spring training dates and length and the start of the season and the schedule, and delivered it to the union late Saturday night.
Union officials reviewed the document and offered their reaction to it yesterday in a series of telephone conversations.
The return to work brings with it a unique circumstance in baseball history. More than 800 players of the 1,069 on major league rosters are unsigned, and another 200 or so are free agents without jobs. Clubs and players most likely will begin negotiating contracts immediately, and the two sides will have to work out a procedure for salary arbitration for eligible players.
The union plans to establish a training camp for free agents in Homestead, Fla., so that they can work out while their agents seek jobs for them.

HEADLINE: Professors Battling Television Technology

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Questions about the extent to which technology will displace college professors have led to the resignation of the chancellor of the University of Maine in what some see as a forerunner to conflicts at other colleges.
Under a plan by Chancellor J. Michael Orenduff, the University of Maine would have created an eighth campus, this one with no buildings or professors, only two-way televised classes. Rather than adding a class in, say, economics at one campus, a class from another campus would simply be broadcast to students. Ultimately, some students would get their degrees from the video campus. 
 The plan had been approved by the university's 16-member board of trustees in January, but faculty members on all seven campuses objected vigorously and, in the last three weeks, passed votes of no confidence with the chancellor. They maintained that he had failed to engage them in the planning of what is often called distance learning.
The chancellor's resignation was accepted by the board at a hastily convened meeting on Sunday, and was effective immediately.
Mr. Orenduff did not return telephone calls yesterday.
"The question of how technology can substitute for the human element in education is a huge issue, and one over which major battles are going to be fought," said Patrick M. Callan, executive director of the California Higher Education Policy Center. "What happened in Maine may frighten off other presidents from becoming involved in this. It's one more issue where, if presidents attempt to exert leadership, they may come into conflict with faculties and wind up looking for a job."
Throughout the country, colleges and universities are experimenting with video-conferencing -- the use of two-way television and two-way audio to replicate the classroom while permitting students to remain at home or at remote places. The University of Maine system became one of higher education's early leaders in distance learning when it began the Education Network of Maine in 1989.
But, as the use of this and other technology has grown, so too have the concerns about staff, quality control and class size (whether one professor could end up teaching a class of thousands, or whole departments could be eliminated on one campus because subjects could be taught by video from another).
With shrinking budgets and increasing enrollments, many faculty members worry that universities will see distance learning and other technology as a way to lower the cost of education.
The California State University system has created a commission to explore the increased use of technology on its 20 campuses, and has already begun a two-year experiment using two-way broadcasts with voice-activated cameras to share business administration classes among four campuses. The State University of New York has also begun using videotaped courses at some of its 64 campuses.
At both systems, faculty representatives have expressed concerns.
"We're in favor of distance learning provided we have equal control," Bill Scheuerman, president of United University Professions, the SUNY faculty union said in an interview a few months ago. "We'll support it if it provides quality of education and doesn't put our positions in jeopardy."
In a nearly unanimous resolution at the University of Maine, the 736 faculty members at the flagship campus in Orono declared that Chancellor Orenduff had "jeopardized the academic integrity of all the institutions" in the university system "by proposing academic accreditation of the Education Network of Maine and by calling for a centralization of control over academic programs."
James Gilbert, a professor of wildlife ecology and president of the faculty senate, said in an interview yesterday that the faculty was not unalterably opposed to distance learning.
"We developed a 24-page paper in March that supported the concept," he said. "But we didn't want accreditation and we didn't accept the particular technology that was being pushed on us. It wasn't interactive two-way television, but one-way television and two-way voice."
John Diamond, a spokesman for the university, said that while there are a limited number of two-way video and two-way audio devices in the system, Mr. Orenduff's expectation was that more would be added in the future. Now, most network professors can hear but not see their students.
About 3,000 of the 25,000 students in the seven-campus system are involved in the video learning program.
Mr. Diamond also said the faculties were angry with Chancellor Orenduff's proposals to the State Legislature to consolidate the system by such means as having one dean serve two academic schools, publishing a common catalogue for all seven campuses and conducting "exit examinations" to determine how much students had learned.
"These things were proposed with a lack of involving the faculties in the process," Professor Gilbert said.
The chancellor's proposals to expand the Education Network of Maine were approved by the trustees at a meeting on Jan. 23, resulting in a vote of no confidence in the trustees by the faculty committees at the Fort Kent and Farmington campuses.
Because the proposals were so controversial, no steps were taken to put them into effect immediately, university officials said. Currently, the network offers such courses as the principles of economics, United States history, elementary French, abnormal psychiatry and advanced soil mechanics, and beams them by satellite to be distributed to campuses around the state.
The system also receives as well as sends. This means the entire curriculum for a master's degree in library science is provided by satellite from the University of South Carolina.
Mr. Diamond said the trustees would meet in Bangor tomorrow to discuss the appointment of an interim chancellor, and would visit the Orono campus on Thursday to hear the opinions of students and faculty members.
