HEADLINE: Senate Extends Deduction for Self-Employed

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
The Senate agreed today to extend a tax deduction for self-employed workers, clearing one of the political hurdles that had unexpectedly stalled debate on $15 billion in midyear budget cuts and a vote on an emergency $3.2 billion appropriation to the military.
Anxious to bring the budget cuts to a vote before the start of next week's spring recess, Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, said the Senate would vote on Tuesday on another contentious issue -- a Republican amendment to the budget-cut bill that would scuttle the Clinton Administration's $20-billion bailout of the Mexican peso. 
 But Mr. Dole did not say when or whether he would allow debate on a controversial amendment proposed by Senator Jim Exon, Democrat of Nebraska, to limit the use of Federal money to pay for abortions in cases of incest and rape.
Mr. Dole warned today that there were about 100 pending amendments to the midyear budget cuts -- 70 from Democrats -- and that unless some were withdrawn, it would take this week and next before the Senate could vote on the cuts, or rescissions.
"I have something else planned for next week," said Mr. Dole, who is scheduled to formally announce his candidacy for President on April 10.
The tax legislation, contained in a House-Senate conference report, cleared the Senate by a unanimous voice vote. It now goes to President Clinton, who is expected to sign the bill. The legislation would allow an estimated 3.2 million self-employed people to deduct 25 percent of the cost of their health insurance premiums for tax purposes.
The conference committee of the House and Senate had agreed on the legislation on March 28 and two days later, the full House adopted the conference report by voice vote. But the report ran into unexpected trouble in the Senate last week when Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, tried to restore a provision that would have taxed wealthy Americans who renounce their citizenship to avoid taxes. At the request of House Republicans, the provision had been dropped. Democrats said that closing the loophole, which affects about two dozen taxpayers, would raise $3.6 billion over 10 years.
Saying that he supported closing the loophole, Mr. Dole promised today that he would allow Mr. Kennedy's legislation to be voted on this week as a separate amendment. But Mr. Kennedy and his fellow Democrats continued to run up political points over the issue, saying that the Republicans had sided with "Benedict Arnold billionaires."
The tax legislation would also repeal a tax exemption offered through the Federal Communications Commission to companies that sell broadcast outlets to minority investors.
The partisan flap over the Mexican loan package arose unexpectedly last Thursday when Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, introduced an amendment effectively preventing President Clinton from providing further loans to Mexico without Congressional approval. Critics said such a move would wreck the Mexican economy and cause upheavals in world markets. Democrats asserted that the amendment was intended to embarrass Mr. Clinton. It seemed today that the Democrats, who control only 46 Senate seats, had found enough support among Republicans to block the measure.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Weak in March, In Spite of Rebate Programs

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 3

 BODY:
Despite widespread rebates, many auto makers reported today that car and truck sales in March failed to pull out of their winter doldrums.
Led by a big drop in car sales at the General Motors Corporation and lower truck sales at the Chrysler Corporation, the industry sales that were reported today were down 9.8 percent from the strong levels of March 1994, to 907,652 units. 
 Sales of Japanese cars built in the United States gained strength in March, but the strong Japanese yen hurt sales of imported models.
When the Ford Motor Company and other auto makers report sales for March later this week, some analysts said, the annual selling rate for the month could fall to lower than 15 million units for the third consecutive month.
The strongest sales month last year was March, with a selling rate of nearly 15.8 million units.
Auto makers have offered rebates in the last month, including discounts of $1,000 or more on several vehicles. But consumers remain wary, because of higher interest rates and nervousness about the health of the economy, analysts said.
"I don't think these rebates have had enough time to do the trick," Kurt Brown, an analyst at DRI/McGraw-Hill, said.
Today Ford doubled the rebates on its best-selling Taurus and Sable sedans, to $1,000, matching the $1,000 rebate on the Dodge Intrepid, Chrysler Concorde and Eagle Vision sedans made by Chrysler.
The overall sales at G.M., excluding Saab, fell 9.2 percent, to 440,285 units, with total car sales off 12.8 percent and total truck sales down 3.5 percent. Analysts attributed the drop in car sales partly to the continued reductions in fleet sales.
Sales at Chrysler fell 9.1 percent, to 209,370 cars and trucks. The domestic car sales of the company fell 5.1 percent, while its domestic truck sales, hurt by the model change to its new 1996 mini-vans, fell 10.4 percent.
Reflecting on the first-quarter sales, the chairman of Chrysler, Robert J. Eaton, said, "There's no doubt the market has gotten tougher."
"We're seeing a leaner mix and providing more incentives to bring customers into our showrooms," Mr. Eaton added. "These higher incentives will likely continue throughout this model year and, while helping us to maintain a strong market share, these added costs will adversely affect our first-quarter and first-half earnings."
Japanese auto makers reported gains in sales of the models built in the United States, but declines in sales of imports.
The overall sales at the Toyota Motor Corporation fell 13.2 percent, to 89,608 units, with domestic car sales up 6.2 percent and imported cars off 34.2 percent.
Sales at the Honda Motor Company rose one-tenth of 1 percent, to 68,020 units, with domestic car sales up 6.9 percent and imported cars off 19.1 percent. Sales at the Mazda Motor Corporation fell 19.8 percent, to 33,014 units, with domestic car sales up 20.5 percent and imported cars off 34.3 percent.
In addition to Ford, the other car makers that are scheduled to report sales this week include the Nissan Motor Company, Volkswagen A.G., BMW A.G., Jaguar Cars Ltd. and Porsche A.G.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
U.S. Intervenes To Back Dollar, But Move Fails

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration ended more than a month of currency inaction and sought to defend the battered dollar today by pouring some $1 billion into markets in Asia and the United States. But it failed to stem an assault on the currency by speculators around the globe.
The support for the dollar was matched by public statements that seemed intended to dispel perceptions that Washington had no intention of taking drastic action to rein in the large trade and budget deficits that contribute to the dollar's weakness. 
 "This Administration believes a strong dollar is in America's interest," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said, "and we remain committed to strengthening the fundamentals that are ultimately important to maintaining a strong and stable currency."
But in private, Administration officials conceded that there was little they could do beyond trying to talk the dollar back up. Faced with a gaping budget deficit and a $150 billion gulf with other nations in goods and services, the White House remains reluctant to endorse the painful measures needed to help mop up some of the surplus dollars flowing overseas.
"The issue is whether we view a strong dollar as truly central to our role as a world superpower," one senior Administration official said today, "and I don't think anyone in the White House is really able to answer that question."
So far, despite a 13 percent fall in the value of the dollar against the Japanese yen and the German mark since the beginning of the year, the Administration has not treated the decline as either a political or an economic crisis. But many private analysts and some Administration officials say that could change if the full impact of the stunning drop in the dollar becomes evident later in the year. That could take the form of inflated prices for imports, a cheapening of American assets in the eyes of foreigners, and a slippage in the levers of global power available to Washington apart from its military might.
Mr. Rubin, who once directed currency trading at Goldman, Sachs & Company, is widely regarded as one of the most knowledgable strategists on exchange rate policy ever to sit in the Treasury Secretary's office. When he was trading on Goldman's account, he developed a keen sense of the psychology of the markets by trying to outguess his predecessors at the Treasury.
Since taking office, Mr. Rubin has shown extraordinary restraint in using the Government's funds to prop up the currency by buying dollars in the open market. With world exchange markets swapping a trillion dollars in currencies almost every day, government interventions of $1 billion or so are a weapon of limited range and little power unless they are used at just the right moment. At those times, when the driving force behind a currency movement has run its course, Mr. Rubin has indicated, even a comparatively small commitment is capable of propelling the volatile exchange markets in a desired direction.
The dollar had stabilized in recent days, and presumably Mr. Rubin -- talking frequently over the phone with Lawrence H. Summers, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs -- decided his moment had arrived. But by midday, that appeared to be a miscalculation.
As word spread among traders of the buying spree by the Federal Reserve, which almost always acts at the request of the Treasury Department, the dollar rallied briefly. But traders immediately turned around and sold, locking in a quick profit. By the end of the day, the dollar closed in New York at 86.07 yen, down from a close of 86.55 on Friday. The dollar gained slightly against the German mark, closing at 1.3723 marks, up marginally from Friday's close of 1.3715. The dollar lost ground against the British pound.
"This shows that jawboning will get nowhere," said Allen Sinai, the chief global economist at Lehman Brothers. "The hope was the U.S. could come in and form the bottom. But the overall movement in our currency is downward, and nothing that has happened yet will change the markets' view of the direction we are taking." Mr. Sinai said he would "not be shocked" to see the dollar at 80 yen in the near future.
The causes of the dollar's dive against its rivals for global influence are hotly debated among analysts of a market where perception is often more important than reality.
But the most talked-about reasons are stark in their simplicity: Investors, after flirting in debt-laden emerging markets like Mexico and Spain, are fleeing to countries that save enough to run sizable trade surpluses, that follow strict monetary policies and appear to have put the worst of their problems behind them. There are precious few. Germany is seen as moving beyond the shock of reunification now that the Berlin wall has been down for more than five years. It stands poised to dominate trade with Eastern Europe. And Japan, despite economic recession, political paralysis and religious cults, is still seen as a nation of 120 million prepared to sacrifice for the common good.
By those standards, the United States falls short. The defeat of the balanced budget amendment last month, along with the talk of tax cuts, punctured the belief that the new wave of Republicans in Washington would wash away the nation's chronic budget deficits. And even though United States industry is enjoying a record export boom, Mexico's economic collapse and China's growing trade influence are likely to undermine any gains elsewhere.
Meanwhile, there is little to tempt foreign investors to return to United States capital markets. American interest rates seem frozen or headed down, and the Japanese Government has passed up opportunities to lower rates there. Without such actions, Tokyo remains a tempting place for Asian investors to park funds while the United States is less appealing.
That leaves Mr. Rubin, as the man chiefly responsible for defending the dollar, with few cards to play.
The Japanese, in seeming defiance of the logic of textbook economics, appear to be selling their American holdings after years of recycling big surpluses back into investments in everything from Treasury bonds to Rockefeller Center and MCA, the owner of Universal Pictures. But now, with many Japanese banks teetering on the edge of failing to meet new requirements for the cash they must keep on hand, there is little lending under way for purchases here. What money Japan is sending abroad is going elsewhere in Asia.
"This is not a dollar crisis made in America," Richard Koo, the chief economist of the Nomura Research Institute in Tokyo, said at an economic conference here last week. "It is a yen crisis, and it is made in Japan."
In fact, the strong yen hurts Japanese producers worst of all, making their products more expensive in world markets. But that pain is often overstated in the West. There is virtually no political pressure on the Japanese Government to solve the trade problems -- and the United State is viewed as holding diminishing leverage. Last week Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, made a compelling case that the long-term solution to both the dollar's woes and America's trade deficit is a breakthrough opening of the Japanese market.
But Japanese thinking on these issues often runs in opposite directions: To many Japanese manufacturers, the weak dollar primarily means that they will make less profit selling in the United States, where there is great pressure to cut prices if companies want to retain market share. Thus, it becomes more important than ever for them to keep walls up around Japan's domestic market, where their profit margins have always been higher.

Tokyo Markets Firmer
 TOKYO, Tuesday, April 4 (Reuters) -- The dollar regained some stability against the Japanese yen in Asia today after falling sharply to new lows in early trading. And Japanese stocks rebounded moderately from their plunge on Monday.
At midday, the dollar was quoted at 86.18 yen, after trading at a record low of 85.68 yen. The dollar closed in New York at 86.07 yen on Monday.
On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Nikkei index of 225 issues finished the morning trading session ahead 107.19 points, or 0.70 percent, at 15,488.48. On Monday, the Nikkei plunged 758.66 points, or 4.7 percent, on continuing concerns about the weakness of the dollar and its implications for the Japanese economy.

HEADLINE: More Dire Warnings About Social Security

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration said today that the Medicare trust fund that pays hospital bills for the elderly would run out of money in 2002, and two independent trustees said the Medicare program faced a financial crisis in the near future.
By contrast, the trustees said the Social Security trust funds, which pay retirement and disability benefits, would run out of cash in 2030. 
 The annual report to Congress was slightly less pessimistic than last year's, which predicted that Medicare's hospital trust fund would be exhausted in 2001, while the Social Security trust funds would be depleted in 2029. The new report says the condition of the Medicare trust fund "remains extremely unfavorable."
The report says nothing about the political changes of the last year. In April 1994, President Clinton was trying to reshape the entire health care system to control costs and guarantee health insurance for all. Since Congress rejected his plan, Mr. Clinton has proposed no new initiatives, and Administration officials have shunned discussion of possible changes in Medicare.
The Administration said that Medicare's hospital insurance program was "severely out of financial balance" and that there was an urgent need for Congress to address the problem. But it recommended no specific measures.
Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, said: "This report should sound alarm bells across Washington and throughout the nation."
Medicare pays hospital bills for 37 million people at a cost expected to reach $176 billion this year. The trustees said Medicare's hospital trust fund would experience "increasing annual deficits," beginning in 1996.
The report was prepared by actuaries and submitted to Congress by the six trustees of the two trust funds. Four trustees are Administration officials; two represent the public.
The public trustees, Stanford G. Ross and David M. Walker, expressed grave concern about Medicare's finances. They said the Hospital Insurance Trust Fund, which pays hospital bills, and Medicare's Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund, which pays doctors, showed "alarming financial results."
In a joint statement, they said: "The Medicare program is clearly unsustainable in its present form. We had hoped for several years that comprehensive health care reform would include meaningful Medicare reforms."
Mr. Ross, a tax lawyer, was Social Security Commissioner in 1978 and 1979. Mr. Walker is an expert on employee benefits at Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm.
Some measure of the problem can be gleaned from statistics in the report. For example, it said, to keep Medicare's hospital trust fund in sound condition over the next 25 years, outlays would have to be reduced by 30 percent or payroll taxes increased by 44 percent. The current tax is 1.45 percent of earnings for the employer and employee each.
The report says the Social Security trust funds, which pay retirement and disability benefits to 43 million people, are in better condition than Medicare. The balance in the Social Security trust funds will increase for 25 years, but will then begin to decline, and the trust funds will be depleted in the year 2030, it says.
Social Security outlays now exceed Medicare outlays. But health costs are rising much more rapidly than retirement benefits.
The report shows that the balance in Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund, $133 billion at the end of last year, will rise to $136 billion this year, but will then decline as the fund runs larger and larger deficits. The Government has no authority to pay hospital bills for Medicare beneficiaries after depletion of the fund, expected in 2002.
The surplus in the Social Security trust funds for retirement and disability benefits will grow in the next decade, the trustees said. The assets of the two trust funds, now $436 billion, will rise to $1.3 trillion in 2004.
Trust fund assets are generally invested in special Government securities, and thus lent to the Treasury to be used to finance general Government operations, reducing the amount that must be borrowed in credit markets.
The Medicare trust fund that pays doctors' bills is sound, in part because it has access to general revenues, the report said. But the trustees said premiums paid by beneficiaries would account for a declining share of total income for this part of the program: 17 percent in 2004, compared with 31 percent last year.
The Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund took in $56 billion last year and paid out $60 billion. The trustees expressed great concern about the cost of this part of the program, which increased more than 50 percent in the last five years and is expected to rise by more than 70 percent in the next five years.

HEADLINE: With a Passion for Tax Cuts, and in Power

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

 BODY:
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Dan Rostenkowski's first instinct when it came to tax legislation was that the rich should pay more and the poor less.
Because Congressional committees adopt the coloration of their chairmen, that was the main view of the House Ways and Means Committee, the most powerful committee in the House, during the dozen years Mr. Rostenkowski dominated it. 
 The current chairman, Representative Bill Archer, could hardly be more different in background, temperament and ideology.
"The engine that pulls the train must continue to be fueled," Mr. Archer said at a committee meeting last week. What he meant, he explained in an interview later, was that affluent taxpayers must receive tax breaks because they are mainly the ones who invest money and create jobs for others.
Since the Ways and Means Committee controls tax legislation, Mr. Archer's views will be on full display this week when he manages the House debate on the Republicans' tax bill. The measure would give families with annual incomes above about $20,000, and below $200,000, a $500 tax cut for each child. The legislation would also lower the capital gains tax, abolish the minimum tax on corporations and offer other tax breaks to individuals and businesses.
If Mr. Rostenkowski was the archetypal big-city liberal, with deep roots in his Polish neighborhood in Chicago and in the city's Democratic machine, Mr. Archer is the archetypal conservative Texas Republican.
As trim and natty as Mr. Rostenkowski was beefy and rumpled, as gentle and affable as Mr. Rostenkowski was gruff and intimidating, Mr. Archer has roots in the wealthy River Oaks section of Houston.
If Mr. Rostenkowski's typical constituents were butchers and bartenders, Mr. Archer's are bankers and oil company executives. His district, once represented by George Bush, is one of the half-dozen most affluent in Congress.
Mr. Rostenkowski was the master of the art of deal-making. He used his skill to get the tax and budget legislation of Presidents of both parties through Congress. He lost his chairmanship last year after he was indicted on corruption charges, and he was then defeated in his race for re-election.
In contrast, Mr. Archer has often placed conservative principle over political compromise. He voted against President Ronald Reagan's Social Security bill in 1983 and his Tax Reform Act in 1986. He surprised his friends by supporting the Bush budget in 1990, which lowered the Federal deficit by raising taxes and cutting spending. But he fought against the Clinton budget in 1993, which did the same thing.
Questions have never been raised about his probity. He refuses campaign contributions from political action committees or donors outside Texas, a stand made easier by the fact that he has never had formidable opposition since he was first elected to the House in 1970.
He also fills out his own income tax returns each year, exhibiting a patience that for Mr. Rostenkowski would have been unimaginable.
His core philosophy, Mr. Archer said as he leaned forward in the chairman's chair in the Ways and Means conference room across the hall from the House chamber, is "the less taxes the better; the smaller Government the better."
That is in accord with the dominant Republican view espoused by Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia and the band of young conservatives who were elected to the House in November. But Mr. Archer, who is 67, has acquired none of the populism and revolutionary zeal that also characterizes the new majority.
Last week, for example, he voted against a constitutional amendment that would have limited the number of terms members of Congress could serve.
The parts of the tax bill before the House this week that he is most enthusiastic about are those that would sharply reduce capital gains taxes, which are the taxes on profits from investments, and abolish the alternative minimum tax that corporations must pay if they have so many write-offs that they would otherwise owe little, if any, taxes.
He is somewhat ambivalent about the $500-per-child tax credit, saying, "I think you can make good arguments on both sides."
But he said he would defend every penny of it. "My responsibility as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee," he said, "is to see that we keep the promises of the contract as they relate to tax provisions."
He was referring to the Contract With America, the campaign platform of Republican candidates for the House last fall. Some Republicans want to lower the maximum income at which families would be entitled to a tax cut for their children, but not Mr. Archer. "If you lowered the $200,000," he said, "it would be reneging on a specific commitment in the contract."
His ultimate goal as chairman, he said, is to "tear out the income tax by its roots and discard it and replace it with a new form of taxation."
What he prefers, he said, is essentially a sales tax in one form or another that would tax people 15 to 20 percent on almost everything they buy. Americans would then be taxed on what they spend rather than on what they earn. That, he said, would encourage saving and investment and improve America's competitive position in the world economy.
He said that he was working to develop such a plan, but that he did not think it could be enacted "until we have a new President."
Mr. Archer said he was not concerned that his tax plan might benefit rich people, who can afford to spend a smaller percentage of their income than others on the essentials of life.
"I wish you wouldn't say 'rich,' " he told an interviewer without a smile. "I wish you'd start saying people who are higher income rather than lower income."
Asked if he thought of himself as rich, Mr. Archer, who is worth more than $2 million according to his most recent financial disclosure statement, replied: "No, not really, I don't. I think of myself as someone who has been frugal and saved and tried to provide for his own security and someone who bore the responsibility of putting five kids through college."
He then related the story he often tells of his father, who lost his job during the Great Depression and was virtually penniless but was able to borrow some money and start what became, because of his father's hard work, a prosperous livestock feed business.
"My economic and tax philosophy," he said, "reflect what has become a proven fact in the world -- that the capitalistic system, which includes the opportunity to move up and to achieve to where everybody does not have the same amount of money, produces in the end the most good for the most people. Our country should be looked at as one of equal opportunity to achieve, not necessarily equal results."
Politicians who fret because some Americans are much better off than others are practicing "the politics of envy," Mr. Archer said.
If Mr. Rostenkowski were still in Congress, he would be calling Mr. Archer's philosophy an example of "the politics of greed."

HEADLINE: Bengali Women Are Candid With Hillary Clinton

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: DHAKA, Bangladesh, April 3

 BODY:
A group of women of the untouchable class reached across a gulf of language and culture today to pepper Hillary Rodham Clinton with questions about her status and self-reliance as a woman.
"Do you have cattle in your house?" asked one woman in Moishahati, a dusty hamlet in southwest Bangladesh that has been transformed by the Grameen Bank, which makes small loans to poor people without collateral in exchange for promises of productive work and monitoring by other borrowers. 
 "No," Mrs. Clinton smiled in acknowledgment of a world in which the difference between one cow and a few cows in a household is the difference between night and day. But the next question was trickier, touching on many of the compromises Mrs. Clinton, a lawyer and the first First Lady to have a professional career before entering the White House, has had to make.
"We earn our income and that's how we make our families," another villager said at a meeting under a bamboo and tin-roofed hut built for Mrs. Clinton's visit. "Whose income do you live on?"
Mrs. Clinton answered evenly: "I started to work when I was 13 years old, and I always earned my own income. And there were some years when I earned more income than my husband. Now that my husband is the President, I am not earning my own income. But I will later, again, earn my own income."
Mrs. Clinton seemed to relish the moment as she answered questions with her 15-year-old daughter, Chelsea, at her side.
"Do you intend to have any more children?" another woman asked, reflecting a pressing concern in a country where 120 million people are crammed into an area about the size of Wisconsin.
"I would have loved to have had one or two more children," Mrs. Clinton replied, putting her arm around Chelsea.
In a 12-day tour encompassing tightly scripted photo opportunities, visits to schools and clinics and ceremonial handshakes with heads of state, today's encounter, while still elaborately choreographed, stood out for its authenticity.
With the bank's 54-year-old founder and guiding light, Muhammad Yunus, an economist trained at Vanderbilt University, interpreting at her side, Mrs. Clinton heard a Bengali version of "It's a Wonderful Life," with Dr. Yunus in the role of Jimmy Stewart.
The idea for Grameen (the Bengali word for rural) was born in the mid-1970's, when Dr. Yunus was teaching at Chittagong University in southern Bangladesh and found himself implored for money by beggar women. He decided the answer was access to enough capital to win a toehold on life, and in 1976 he made his first loans ($30 divided among 42 people) from his personal money, eventually setting up an independent bank.
Now Grameen has more than 1,000 branches in 34,000 villages. Last year it made $369 million in loans, the vast majority to women, with the largest loans being typically about $600 for a home. Repayment rates are higher than those of commercial banks here and the idea has been copied in a handful of places across the United States, including Arkansas, where Bill Clinton helped start the Arkansas Development Bank when he was Governor.
"The woman who has completed the loan is completely different," Dr. Yunus said. "The whole world was telling her, 'You are no good, you are a woman.' Now comes the First Lady of the world to talk about it. It is a validation of what they are doing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hillary Clinton and her daughter, Chelsea, meeting with women in Moishahati, Bangladesh, yesterday. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Do Transit Rail Cars Need U.S. Label?

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

 BODY:
The mounting problems at the Morrison Knudsen Corporation have raised an important if little noticed question about America's industrial future: Does this country need a passenger rail car manufacturer?
Morrison Knudsen is the country's last producer of rail cars, the last of an industry that once included the Pullman Company, St. Louis Car and the Budd Company. American companies were leaders in the industry as recently as the 1970's, but most have now been sold or shut down and the leaders come from Canada, Japan and Germany. 
 Morrison Knudsen, the big construction company in Boise, Idaho, entered the rail car manufacturing business only six years ago. It was encouraged by transit authorities around the country that sought a domestic manufacturer that would put a plant in their home districts, thus generating jobs.
But its strategy of heavily underbidding on many big contracts, from New York City to Chicago and San Francisco, in an effort to win a sizable share of the market, turned into a disaster. Of the $310 million Morrison Knudsen lost last year, more than $200 million came from MK Transit, as the unit is known.
Though Morrison Knudsen had earlier said that it was firmly committed to the rail car manufacturing business, with the arrival of a new chairman, Robert S. Miller Jr., who was named to the position on Sunday, it is now an open question whether the unit will be kept open or even sold. For now, the company will say only that it is undecided. Mr. Miller replaces William P. Clark, who had been acting chairman since William J. Agee was ousted by the board in February after the company announced big losses for 1994.
"MK has received indications of interest for a number of its noncore businesses and is considering alternatives," said Mark Armstrong, a company spokesman.
The idea that the United States may leave this industry, even as the Clinton Administration pushes the proposal that the country must build its international competitiveness, has left experts in industrial policy and the transit industry divided.
Not only will American companies fail to benefit from the huge sums being spent on rail cars -- as much as $18 billion in the United States during the next decade, according to the American Public Transit Association. But also, experts say, it will be increasingly difficult for American companies to enter the market, leaving critical technologies outside the grasp of American concerns.
It takes huge investments in research and technology to become competitive. Faced with the need to invest billions of dollars over many years, few companies would be willing to enter the fray.
"The problem with R& D is very important," said Kenneth Mead, director of transportation issues for the General Accounting Office. "This is not a stable technology. It's changing very fast. You don't just walk into this business and say, 'Hey, I'm going to make trains.' "
Lawrence Gilson, a former senior executive of Amtrak and now head of Venture Associates, a consulting firm, added, "The truth is it's almost impossible for a company to get started because of the R& D costs."
That has created several problems. Mortimer L. Downey, Deputy Secretary of Transportation who is a former top executive of the New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said that American companies were losing out on some big overseas orders because of their inability to provide rail cars as well as other parts of big transit projects.
He cited a recent example in Guangzhou, in southern China, where he said some American companies offering electrical equipment lost contracts because they could not combine their products in a package that included the cars.
"This is of concern to us in large part because we think rail car building is something Americans ought to be able to do well," Mr. Downey said. "And that's not just for our own needs, but for export. There is a very big market there."
Proponents of free-market economics scoff at such arguments. If the business is really profitable, they say, clever companies will find a way to participate.
"There is no possible conceivable reason why the U.S. needs a rail car business," said William Lewis, a senior partner at McKinsey & Company and an expert on competition policy. "The global system is so big, so robust, so open that anything one person denied us we could get somewhere else."
Some have argued that the United States will lose jobs if the industry fails, but Mr. Lewis dismissed that view, too. "We don't need those jobs," Mr. Lewis said. "We're paying too much to keep them."
Most talk of industrial policy focuses on businesses like electronics, but the question of whether America needs to make its own rail cars has been a hot-button issue for years. Three years ago Los Angeles canceled a $121.8 million contract with the Sumitomo Corporation of Japan after facing complaints for giving the work to a foreign concern.
But MK Transit's deep problems demonstrate the complexity of the problem. If the company actually charges what it costs to build its rail cars, it may never win another contract. If it underbids to keep the orders flowing, its losses will mount.
Larry E. Salci, president of the unit, which is based in an old Pullman factory in Chicago, has thus argued for some form of government support, though he insisted that handouts would not be necessary. He maintained that foreign companies received substantial support from their governments. It comes, he said, through export subsidies and a steady flow of orders from big, nationally owned transit systems. Mr. Salci said the Government should create what he called a level playing field by fighting to eliminate benefits that foreign companies received in their home markets.
MK Transit has received help only in the form of up-front payments from transit districts that in effect provide working capital, he said.
Clearly, MK Transit brought many of the problems on itself. At its peak, it had more than 60 percent of the market for certain rail cars. It hoped follow-up business and government encouragement would turn the business profitable and give the United States a toehold in this important global industry.
MK Transit has built cars that some transit authorities like; it has, for instance, received plaudits for the M-6 cars it is manufacturing for Metro North's New Haven Line. But it is behind on nearly all of its contracts -- 18 months on the M-6 cars. And several transit authorities have refused to exercise options to purchase more cars from MK Transit, a harsh blow to its plans.
"We have stumbled badly, frankly," Mr. Salci said. "We went too far too fast. We're going to have to spend the next couple of years digging out from this hole."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Morrison Knudsen's problems have raised the question of whether America needs a maker of passenger rail cars. The company has been praised for the M-6 cars it is making for Metro North's New Haven line, but is 18 months behind on the contract. A train recently left the line's Larchmont, N.Y., station. HEADLINE: RUSSIA SAYS SALE OF ATOM REACTORS TO IRAN IS STILL ON

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 3

 BODY:
The Russian Government made clear today that it would go ahead with the sale of light-water nuclear reactors to Iran over fierce American protests, repeated here by the visiting Defense Secretary, William J. Perry.
Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin shares American concerns about Iran's nuclear ambitions, Mr. Perry said in a news conference this evening, and agreed to arrange meetings of Russian and American experts concerned about the spread of nuclear weapons and the transfer of nuclear technology to Iran. 
 But the Russians "did not agree to change their position to proceed with that sale," Mr. Perry said. "They did state that they will take actions to reduce the proliferation risk."
Earlier in the day, Mr. Perry had said he did not want to discuss ways to make the sale less dangerous. "Our first objective is to stop the sale," he said. "I consider constraints a very poor second choice."
While the Russian position appeared firm, senior American officials said tonight that they did not consider the issue closed. They said Washington would continue to bring up its objections at lower-level meetings and at the summit meeting between Presidents Clinton and Boris N. Yeltsin scheduled for next month.
The United States has been pushing Moscow for weeks to cancel its agreement to sell at least two and possibly four light-water nuclear reactors to Iran, a deal worth $800 million to $1 billion.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher has warned Russia that it will "rue the day" it provides nuclear technology to its neighbor, Iran.
But it is unclear what penalty Russia will suffer if it does not cancel the deal. On Sunday, Mr. Perry said he favored continuing aid to Russia even if he got nowhere on the nuclear question.
Washington has provided Moscow a written intelligence report on Teheran's alleged ambitions to build a nuclear bomb, and has promised the Russian Atomic Energy Ministry tens of millions of dollars in projects to compensate Russia for abandoning the Iran contract.
But the Russian Atomic Energy Minister, Viktor N. Mikhailov, said today after meeting with Mr. Chernomyrdin and Mr. Perry that the reactor sales would go ahead "in full measure."
Mr. Mikhailov, who is skeptical of American intentions toward Russia, said the Iran deal met the standards of the International Atomic Energy Agency.
The Clinton Administration objects to the Iranian project even though American officials say the type of plutonium produced by the light-water reactors that the Russians plan to build is far harder to use in nuclear weapons than the plutonium produced by older varieties of reactors, like the gas-graphite reactors used by North Korea. The United States is leading an international consortium to build light-water reactors in North Korea, asserting that those reactors will be a welcome substitute for the North's existing reactors and its program to develop atomic bombs.
The Administration insists that the biggest problem from the reactors planned for Iran will be the nuclear expertise the Iranians gain from the project, rather than the plutonium produced by the reactors. American officials say they fear that once Iran has the new reactors it will become much easier for Teheran to import so-called "dual use" nuclear equipment that can be used to develop nuclear weapons.
Even though the plutonium produced by light-water reactor is hard to use in bombs, Administration officials said they feared that Iran would not turn the spent plutonium over to the Russians, as promised, and would eventually become sophisticated enough to turn it into weapons-grade material.
Mr. Perry said the International Atomic Energy Agency's regulations were not sufficient to prevent this. "The problem lies in having some assurance that Iran would stick to the agreement to release the plutonium when the time came," he said.
The Americans have forced Conoco to give up a legal $1 billion agreement to pump more oil from Iran and have called for harsher sanctions against the country.
The American pressure is "absolutely unacceptable," Mr. Mikhailov told the Interfax news agency. "A disruption of the contract may result in a number of Arab states' refusal to extend the nonproliferation treaty."
Perhaps more important to Moscow is the hard-currency profit and the chance to keep its nuclear industry at work.
The contract is for nearly $100 million more than the total request for aid to Russia that President Clinton is putting to a skeptical Congress for the next fiscal year. It is double the amount of money for the programs that aid the conversion of Russian military industries to civilian production and help pay for the dismantling of Moscow's nuclear arsenal as called for under arms control treaties.
Sunday night, Mr. Mikhailov told Russian television that the United States now controlled half the world market in nuclear technologies.
"They're not going to let us earn even a little bit of money," he said, echoing a similar argument made by Russian arms manufacturers, who complain that America controls half the world's arms sales and objects to every sale that Moscow tries to make.
Mr. Perry acknowledged Moscow's quandary, saying: "This sale is a big economic factor for them. It is a very hard decision for them to make."
Last year, Washington complained of Moscow's sale of quiet diesel, Kilo-class submarines to Iran. Mr. Perry said that that sale, with two subs delivered and another to come, would continue, but that Moscow had reaffirmed a promise to sell no more subs to Teheran.
On the breakaway region of Chechnya, Mr. Perry said Moscow had spurned American and European demands for a cease-fire and talks with the rebels. But he said Defense Minister Pavel S. Grachev supported demands for a permanent human rights mission in Chechnya of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.
General Grachev also supports Russia's membership in NATO's Partnership for Peace program, Mr. Perry said.

HEADLINE: House Backs Board for Capital

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
The House approved a bill today to create an oversight board to help the District of Columbia out of its financial crisis.
The bill, passed by voice vote, would give the board veto power over District spending, limiting the home-rule authority that Washington has had since 1973. The board would have five members, Presidential appointees who would not be paid, and would be abolished after the city paid all its debts. 
 Representative Thomas M. Davis 3d, the Virginia Republican who heads the Government Reform and Oversight Committee's panel on the District, said: "There are no viable alternatives. We are, in effect, pulling the District's credit card with the U.S. Treasury and setting conditions for borrowing that can lead to economic recovery."
The bill, which now goes to the Senate, would give the board authority to reject District spending and borrowing plans and withhold money if budget goals were not met.
The bill requires that the District make substantial progress toward a balanced budget over the next three years and begin achieving a balanced budget in the fiscal year 1999.
The District's 600,000 residents would still elect a mayor and City Council, but the mayor would be required to submit budgets to the board for approval.
The District's nonvoting delegate to the House, Eleanor Holmes Norton, proposed the concept of financial review after Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. revealed that the city was $722 million in the red, putting it in its worst budget crisis in history. Ms. Norton, a Democrat, said the bill retained the integrity of self rule.
Congress demanded last fall that the District cut its $3.25 billion budget by $140 million and 2,000 positions.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 10.72 as U.S. Vainly Tries to Prop Up the Dollar

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration tried unsuccesfully to keep the dollar from falling to another record low against the yen, the stock and bond markets seemed to respond, if only slightly.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.72 points, to 4,168.41, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.14 points, to 501.85. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 0.84 point, to 818.05. 
 Bond prices rose, too, and the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 7.38 percent from 7.43 percent.
But the broader stock market did not rally much. On the New York Stock Exchange, advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks by only 1,129 to 1,080. The Russell 2,000, which tracks the performance of the nation's 2,000 largest stocks, finished at 260.81, up 0.04 point, or a change of only 0.02 percent.
And the kinds of stock that gained yesterday seemed to indicate that traders were betting on continued weakness in the dollar.
For example, traders bid up the Dow component stocks of Walt Disney, Coca-Cola, Philip Morris, and I.B.M., all of which have large foreign operations. And drug, soft drink, and computer microchip companies led the S.& P. 500. When these multinational companies receive revenues in strong currencies like the mark and yen, they get more dollars as the value of the dollar weakens.
Trading volume, at 296.4 million shares, was relatively modest yesterday, indicating that some traders may be on the sidelines, especially after a hectic Friday, when stock prices swung widely.
With the exception of Friday's employment data, there are few market-moving economic reports this week.
"The market is poised to go wherever the news goes," said Bill Allyn, director of listed equity trading at Jefferies & Company. He nonetheless expects the market to go up, if haltingly, because he says portfolio managers are withdrawing capital from the troubled markets in Mexico and Latin America.
"Ever since the emerging markets became submerging markets, these guys have to throw money at U.S. stocks," Mr. Allyn said.
After falling to historic lows against the German mark and Japanese yen on Friday, the dollar got a jolt from the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve early yesterday as the Fed bought dollars in Asia and Europe.
Traders estimated the money spent by the Fed was between $1 billion and $2 billion in a market whose daily average is often about $1.5 trillion. The Fed's intervention was worth about one-tenth of a penny for every dollar traded. The American currency lifted substantially for less than 30 minutes in the morning in Tokyo.
Still, the market intervention by the Fed is respected by currency traders as an important policy signal, despite the relatively small sum of money deployed.
The intervention "prevented a free fall" in the dollar, said Robert A. White, senior vice president, foreign exchange, at Standard Chartered Bank. Moreover, he said, "since 1985 each major round of intervention has resulted in the direction desired by the central banks, whether down or up.
"But it's important to add this caveat -- there was some fundamental economic, fiscal, or monetary change, like interest rates, to help the central banks get what they wanted."
And, Mr. White added, the larger the currency markets get, aided by high-speed and high-performance computers, the more difficult it is for the Fed, or any central bank, to influence the markets.
The dollar, after trading near Friday's lows against the Japanese yen and German mark, ended mixed against major currencies. In New York, six hours behind Frankfurt and 13 hours behind Tokyo, the dollar settled at a record low of 86.07 yen , down from 86.55 yen on Friday, and 1.3723 marks, up slightly from 1.3715 marks.
Among the biggest gainers yesterday was E-Systems Inc. which rose 18 5/8, to 64, after Raytheon, the military contractor, agreed to acquire E-Systems, a military electronics company, for $2.3 billion. Also rising was Continental Medical Systems Inc., a hospital management company, which rose 3 3/4, to 11 3/8, after Horizon Healthcare agreed to buy Continental for $502 million in stock.
Among the biggest decliners were the American depository receipts of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the huge Japanese electronics company. Matsushita A.D.R.'s fell 4 1/2, to 153 1/2. Each A.D.R. represents 10 shares. Matsushita is reported to be considering selling all or part of its MCA film studio business.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Cover-Up Chronology

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The evidence is now in -- not all of it yet, but enough to prove that the U.S. Government knew a year in advance that Mexico was headed for financial disaster. The chronology shows that the Administration used the year to keep the information secret and feed the American public a false, knowingly deceptive line about the strengths of the Mexican economy. 
 The cover-up went on until Mexico was only a day or two from bankruptcy. Then, announcing that an emergency existed, the President ordered a $20 billion American loan, plus another $20 billion or so of "international" money, much of which will also be paid by U.S. taxpayers.
Even after the bailout, the Administration is still withholding full documentation, and real candor. But why should it worry? After President Clinton ordered the loan out of special funds, without debate or vote in Congress, the Republican and Democratic leadership in Congress, grateful at avoiding responsibility, told him how fine, how brave he was for going over their heads.
However, nine senators, led by Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, have had the gall to hold hearings in the Banking Committee. They are trying to get through the still-heavy Administration smokescreen of secrecy and evasion.
Mr. D'Amato has introduced a bill putting a $5 billion cap on the loan. That would still be 5 times larger and for 10 times longer than any faintly similar past loan.
But the $5 billion cap is not the real issue. If the senators want more, they can amend the D'Amato bill. Mr. D'Amato is trying to get them to face what they ran from last year: a vote on the bailout, and if yes, for how much.
My working-class soul rebels at the thought that without a by-your-leave the Government is entitled to spend even $20 billion of my money to meet a crisis it had concealed. So here is part of the still-emerging chronology of deception coming out of the hearings and other sources:
Summer and fall 1993: U.S. pushes through the North American Free Trade Agreement by proclaiming Mexican economic stability.
February 1994: The International Monetary Fund privately warns that Mexico is living like a credit-card addict.
March 23: U.S. lends Mexico $6 billion for quick-fix peso bolstering.
Spring: C.I.A. privately warns Treasury of dangers of Mexican collapse.
July, August: Treasury privately warns Mexico.
September: Lloyd Bentsen, then Secretary of Treasury, privately warns Mexico himself. Publicly he expresses support for Mexico.
Dec. 9: Mr. Clinton praises Mexico, publicly, as fine example of economic development.
Dec. 20: Mexico devalues peso; U.S. taxpayers learn of crisis.
Jan. 12, 1995: President suggests Congress enact $40 billion loan; finds Congress vastly reluctant.
Jan. 31: President and Congress acknowledge emergency, President allocates $20 billion. Congress surrenders right to vote or debate.
By now Mexico has already spent $5 billion of American money making good on its high-interest bonds and is readying another $5 billion. The money has whipped from Washington to Mexico to Mexican and foreign investors and currency speculators, and from them out of the country. As unconsulted lenders, Americans at least should know who they are, and how close to the Mexican or U.S. Government.
As for Mexican workers, they know they will also have to pay -- in taxes, lost collateral, lost jobs. At least they have the good sense to be surly about the whole mess.
Real concern for Mexico would have meant public warnings from Washington as soon as trouble was discovered. Legitimate confidentiality does not include deceiving the world. But that would have brought embarrassing revelations at the very time Mexico and the U.S. were both preparing for elections.
Washington insists it did nothing wrong. This deprives Americans even of the small satisfaction of knowing that the responsible officials and their political masters have learned anything at all from the great U.S.-Mexico combination plate, catch-up with botch-up.
April 3: Senator D'Amato supplies me with his New Yorker's sum-up of American and Mexican behavior: "The king has no suit."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Tax Cuts for Political Gain

 BODY:
Speaker Newt Gingrich says the House will pass a big tax cut this week because "every person in the U.S. is overtaxed." Other Republican leaders offer the same justification, but they ignore an inconvenient fact. The United States ranks next-to-last among the 24 leading industrialized countries in rate of taxation on income.
The Republican tax-cut bill is not about alleviating onerous tax burdens, sparking investment or any other lofty purpose. It is a political maneuver. The Republicans want to promise tax cuts no matter how damaging the long-term consequences, then watch President Clinton squirm as he either signs the bill or tells voters he took away their tax cut for the sake of long-run prosperity. 
 The House Republicans would cut taxes $500 a child for most families. They would also cut rates on capital gains income, corporate investment and retirement savings. These measures would harm the economy. The child credit would encourage consumption over saving, the opposite of what the economy needs. The tax cuts explode in future years, making the deficit balloon despite G.O.P. promises to balance the budget. The specific investment and savings subsidies are poorly designed and would do more to enrich wealthy families than to stimulate productive investment.
Liberal Democrats are not the only politicians to wince at the tax package. Some conservative and moderate Republicans have acknowledged that the bill betrays the party's pledge to balance the budget by 2002. To meet the target, Congress would have to cut more than $300 billion a year -- 30 percent of cuttable programs. To raise the hurdle an extra $40 billion to $60 billion a year by cutting taxes puts the target out of reach. That matters little to the tax-cutters to whom it is an article of faith that President Bush lost office because he reneged on a campaign promise to keep taxes down.
The announcement yesterday that the two Republican camps had reached agreement does little to reconcile their differences. Under the agreement, tax cuts will not kick in unless Congress passes a budget bill later this year that would send the deficit to zero over seven years. But the agreement builds in no enforcement mechanism and amounts to little more than pious disinformation.
There is still a chance that common sense will block Mr. Gingrich's tax cut. But if the House approves and the Senate goes along, the G.O.P. will march into the 1996 elections as the party that cut taxes. Mr. Clinton will be tarred as the leader who raised them. Sadly, that may be all the typical American knows about the debate, since polls indicate many Americans support the Contract With America without knowing what it contains. Cynical tax cuts may work as campaign strategy. But they will prove destructive in the long run.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Doubts About Dollar Limit A Rally in U.S. Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities rallied yesterday on data suggesting that the economy's growth is slowing and that inflation remains subdued, but a weaker dollar limited the day's gains.
A higher-than-expected index report for March by the National Association of Purchasing Managers showed the monthly production component fell to 51.4 from 54.5 in February -- the lowest level since September 1993. Economists had expected the index to drop to 52.9. Other parts of the report showed inflation and employment were down. 
 The 30-year bond rose 19/32 , to a price of 10230/32 for a yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, of 7.38 percent, down from 7.43 percent on Friday; shorter-maturity bills also improved in price.
"A moderating economy, coupled with diminishing inflation pressures, was a big positive for the fixed-income market," said Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at the CS First Boston Corporation.
"It was an impressive piece of data, with the production index the lowest in 18 months," he said. "This showed a very dramatic slowing compared to where we were in November, the peak of the cycle."
But the dollar's slide and volatility trouble market participants, Mr. Alexy said, adding that "we don't know yet where the bottom is for the dollar."
Indeed, some traders said that the Federal Reserve's purchase of dollars yesterday in international currency markets did not seem to make much difference.
The Commerce Department also reported yesterday that consumer spending increased one-tenth of 1 percent in February and that personal income posted the smallest gain in three months in February, five-tenths of 1 percent. Both reports provided more evidence that the economy's growth is slowing, but they had only a moderate impact on the market, Mr. Alexy said.
In addition to yesterday's producer data, which took the market to the day's highs, Mr. Alexy said the most important economic reports this week would be automobile sales and employment figures.
"Slower economic growth could lower the yield of a 30-year bond to 7.15 percent in the next six weeks," Mr. Alexy said. But without more conclusive evidence, traders said, there is a likelihood that the yield on the long bond will float around 7.40 percent.
The Treasury sold $24 billion of new three- and six-month bills yesterday, with the average rates higher than those of last week. At auction, the rate for a three-month issue rose 12 basis points, to 5.76 percent, the highest since early last month, while a six-month bill increased 10 basis points, to 5.90 percent, the highest in two weeks. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In the municipal bond market, yields dropped a bit, even amid speculation that investors would not aggressively pursue some of this week's supply of housing revenue bonds.
Of the $935 million of securities expected to be sold this week, the State of Washington is the largest. Washington is scheduled to sell $371 million of general obilation bonds through a negotiated offering through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.
The Bond Buyer's index of 40 municipal issues showed the average yield to maturity was down a basis point, to 6.36 percent, from 6.37 percent last week.

HEADLINE: Data Indicate Higher Rates Are Slowing the Economy

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
Consumer spending in February grew at the slowest rate since last April, while factory activity last month slowed to the weakest performance in a year and a half -- signs higher interest rates are putting a damper on the economy.
"We're facing a string of consistently weaker economic data," said William Feezer, co-head of trading at Sanwa Securities (USA) in New York. 
 Consumer spending increased one-tenth of 1 percent in February, down from a seven-tenths of 1 percent gain in January, Commerce Department figures released today show. After adjustment for inflation, February's increase in spending translates into a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent.
At the same time, Americans' incomes posted the smallest gain in three months in February. And the five-tenths of 1 percent increase would have been less than half as large without bonus payments made to auto workers and larger Government subsidies to farmers.
Another sign of slowing came in factory output for March. The National Association of Purchasing Management said its manufacturing index -- which tracks factory orders, production, hiring, inventories and prices -- declined to 51.4 last month, the lowest level since September 1993. In February, the index stood at 54.5 percent.
A purchasing managers' index of 50 or more indicates the manufacturing economy is expanding. A reading below 50 signals manufacturing is contracting.
The purchasing managers' report also suggested inflation remained under control since the number of manufacturers reporting price increases slowed markedly in March from February.
Taken together, today's reports provide a clear picture of an economy that is decelerating. As a result, the Federal Reserve "doesn't have to worry about tightening right now," said Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York.
Today's Commerce Department report is an important gauge of the American economy's strength. Consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of United States business activity, helped power the economy to its strongest performance in a decade in 1994.
For all of 1995, many economists are projecting a growth rate equal to half of last year's pace. "February reflects a pretty strong pullback by consumers," said Peter Kretzmer, an economist at Nationsbank in New York.
In its report, the Commerce Department also said disposable income, or the money left over after taxes, increased five-tenths of 1 percent in February -- compared with analysts' expectations of one-tenth to two-tenths of 1 percent -- while the savings rate rose to 4.9 percent during the month.
Meanwhile, another Commerce Department report showed factory profits strengthened in the fourth quarter.
Manufacturers' after-tax profits increased to 6.1 cents for each dollar in sales in the fourth quarter from 5.5 cents in the third quarter. The figures are adjusted for seasonal variations. During the fourth quarter of 1993, manufacturers' profits ran at 3.6 cents for each dollar in sales.
Meanwhile, retailers' profits after taxes rose to 2.9 cents for each dollar in sales in the fourth quarter from 1.8 cents during the third quarter.
Today's Commerce Department report also showed that consumers' interest payments to businesses -- counted separately from consumer spending -- increased by 1.7 percent during February.
January's reported seven-tenths of 1 percent rise in consumer spending represents an upward revision from the four-tenths of 1 percent gain initially announced a month ago.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Federal Reserve Intervenes, But Dollar Falls Again
The United States poured an estimated $1 billion into currency markets in an effort to defend the battered dollar, but the move had little effect on the markets. 
 As word of the Federal Reserve's intervention spread, traders briefly pushed up the currency, but then immediately turned around and sold. By the end of the day, the dollar settled at 86.07 yen and 1.3725 marks, both down from Friday. A1.
 
Auto Sales Fall in March
Auto sales for March fell below their strongyear-ago levels. Led by a big drop in car sales at G.M. and lower truck sales at Chrysler, industry sales were down 9.8 percent. D6.
 
Deal Clears Way for Tax Cuts
Newt Gingrich agreed with dissident Republicans to link his tax-relief legislation to future reductions in the Federal deficit, removing a big barrier to passage of the $189 billion package of tax cuts. A1.
 
Raytheon Makes Bid for E-Systems
Raytheon agreed to pay $2.3 billion in cash, or $64 a share, for E-Systems, a military contractor, in a friendly acquisition. D2.
 
Kemper to Sell Securities Unit
Kemper will sell a 55 percent stake in its securities brokerage firm to its employees for $72 million and spin off almost all the remaining unit to stockholders. D3.
 
Spending Weakens; Factories Slow
Consumer spending in February grew 0.1 percent, the slowest rate since last April, while factory activity slowed to the weakest performance in a year and a half, signs that higher interest rates are putting a damper on the economy. D2.
 
Sybase Says Profit Below Estimates
Shares in Sybase lost nearly a quarter of their value after the company said its first-quarter earnings and revenue would be far below Wall Street's estimates. D3.
 
Senate Extends Health Tax Break
The Senate agreed to extend a tax deduction that allows an estimated 3.2 million self-employed people to deduct 25 percent of the cost of their health insurance. D23.
 
Wellpoint, Health Systems to Merge
As expected, Wellpoint and Health Systems have agreed to combine in a stock-swap deal valued at nearly $1.9 billion. D4.
 
United Revamps Management
United Airlines announced a restructuring that it said would eliminate unnecessary management and cut costs. D3.
 
Corruption at Honda Called Broad
A former executive of American Honda testified that he believed the company's president knew he was taking bribes, adding he suspected the president, too. Honda dismissed the suspicions as gossip. D6.
 
Future in Doubt for Rail Car Industry
Morrison Knudsen is the United States' last producer of rail cars, and its continuing struggle for survival has raised an important question about America's industrial future: Does this country even need a manufacturer of rail cars? D4.

Major Leaguers Report to Camps
Major league players are returning to Florida and Arizona, and by the end of the week spring training camps will be in full swing. A1.
In the baseball strike, team owners deployed permanent replacements, a tactic other employers have used with more success. Experts say the mere threat of replacements has sent union memberships plunging. A16.
 Advertisers, teams and the sport itself face a daunting task in trying to restore baseball's luster. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D9.

William Aramony, the former United Way chief, was found guilty of stealing $600,000. A1.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Plan to Cut $189 Billion in Taxes

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
The Republican tax bill the House of Representatives plans to take up on Wednesday would reduce the Federal income taxes of people and companies by $189 billion over the next five years and, according to Treasury Department estimates, $630 billion over the next decade.
The bill would give most families with children a $500 tax cut for each child. It would also lower the capital gains tax and provide a variety of other tax breaks for individuals and businesses. 
 The Republican sponsors of the legislation maintain that the bill would reduce spending by more than enough to offset the revenue loss in the first five years. They have also promised that none of the tax measures will go into effect until Congress has approved a budget plan setting forth a "clear path" to a balanced budget by the year 2002.
But the tax reductions are described with great specificity while the spending cuts are little more than promises.
The biggest single saving, for example, would be $100 billion over five years from lowering the overall annual ceilings on discretionary spending. This is all Government spending -- for everything from pencils to submarines -- except the spending for programs like Social Security and Medicare for which money is paid to everyone who meets the eligibility requirements. The bill does not specify which programs will be cut.
In addition, the Republicans are assuming a $65 billion saving over five years from cuts approved by the House last month in welfare and other programs for the poor.
Republicans and Democrats offer different statistics -- accurate but from different perspectives -- to illustrate who the main beneficiaries of the tax reductions would be.
For example, Republicans have produced a study showing that taxpayers with annual incomes between $30,000 and $75,000 would receive a tax cut of 4.3 or 4.4 percent, while the taxes of those with incomes above $200,000 would be reduced by only 2.9 percent.
Democrats have figures showing that under the Republican bill, the wealthiest 1 percent of taxpayers would get 20 percent of the tax reduction and that the wealthiest 10 percent would get 47 percent.
What follows are the main items in the bill, most of which would take effect next year:
 
Individuals
 FAMILY TAX CREDIT Most families with annual incomes below $200,000 would get a $500 tax credit, or tax reduction, for each child under 18. Families with incomes between $200,000 and $250,000 would get a gradually reduced credit. The credit would be available only to the extent that families owe income taxes. That means families with incomes below about $25,000 would get at most a partial credit. Cost: $105 billion.
MARRIAGE PENALTY Married workers would be entitled to a credit of up to $145 on their joint tax return to help offset the additional taxes that are often owed when single workers marry. Cost: $8 billion.
RETIREMENT ACCOUNTS A new form of individual retirement account would allow workers, regardless of income, to deposit up to $2,000 after taxes that could be withdrawn at retirement without additional taxes on the accrued interest and dividends. In addition to penalty-free withdrawals when the taxpayer reaches 59, money could also be taken out without penalty after five years to pay for college tuition, first-time home purchases, medical bills and long-term care insurance. The Treasury would get $2 billion more in the first five years as taxpayers converted their existing I.R.A.'s to the new kind and paid taxes on the money, but revenue losses in later years would be substantial.
SPOUSAL I.R.A.'s Nonworking spouses could contribute up to $2,000 to the existing form of retirement account in which taxes are not owed on the contribution but must be paid on money that is withdrawn. Cost: $500 million.
CAPITAL GAINS Taxes would be assessed on only 50 percent of all capital gains, which are the profits from investments. The result would be to lower the maximum rate to 19.8 percent from 28 percent. The value of assets would be adjusted annually for inflation so that no tax would be owed on the amount of profits that resulted solely from inflation. Taxpayers who sell their homes at a loss could deduct the loss. Cost: $32 billion, including the corporate capital gains rate cut described below.
SOCIAL SECURITY Increased income taxes enacted in 1993 on the Social Security benefits of many middle- and upper-income retirees would be repealed. The amount retirees age 65 through 69 could earn without having their benefits reduced would be raised gradually over five years to $30,000 from the current $11,280. Cost: $23 billion.
ADOPTION Families with incomes below $60,000 who adopt a child would be entitled to a $5,000 tax credit that year, and families with incomes up to $100,000 could get a partial credit. Cost: $1 billion.
ELDERLY CARE Families who take care of a disabled elderly relative in their homes could get a $500 tax credit each year. In addition, tax breaks would be provided for the purchase of long-term care insurance, and terminally ill taxpayers could claim their life insurance without owing taxes. Cost: $8 billion.
ESTATE AND GIFT TAXES The amount that could be excluded from estate and gift taxes would be increased to $750,000 from $600,000. Cost: $6.8 billion.
 
Businesses
 MINIMUM TAX The alternative minimum tax for corporations would be repealed over five years. (Its purpose is to make sure that companies with large write-offs still owe some taxes.) Cost: $17 billion.
CAPITAL GAINS The top corporate capital gains rate would be reduced to 25 percent from 35 percent. The value of corporate assets would be adjusted for inflation.
DEPRECIATION The bill would allow companies that buy machinery and equipment to take smaller deductions in the first few years after the purchase but to claim much larger deductions in later years. This would increase revenue by $17 billion in the first five years but cost much more afterward.
SMALL BUSINESSES Businesses could write off the entire cost of machinery and equipment costing $35,000 or less in the year of purchase. That is double the current limit of $17,500. Cost: $8 billion.
HOME OFFICES A deduction for the cost of offices at home would be allowed if the taxpayer used the office for administrative work and had no other fixed place of business. Cost: $1 billion.
 
Spending Cuts
 DISCRETIONARY SPENDING This is now frozen at slightly less than $550 billion a year. The bill would lower that by an average of $20 billion a year, but it does not indicate which programs should have less money. Saving: $100 billion.
MEDICARE Several cost-saving measures enacted in 1993 on a temporary basis would be made permanent. Saving: $11 billion.
ENRICHED URANIUM The bill would allow the Clinton Administration to sell the United States Enrichment Corporation. The corporation produces enriched uranium for nuclear power plants. Revenue gain: $2 billion.
BROADCAST LICENSES The Federal Communications Commission would be authorized to continue for two more years, 1999 and 2000, its practice of auctioning the rights to portions of the radio spectrum. Revenue gain: $2 billion.
GOVERNMENT WORKERS Federal employees would have to make larger contributions to their retirement plans. Revenue gain: $11 billion.
