HEADLINE: U.S. PRESSES DRIVE ON IRAN AND IRAQ

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration moved against two of its Middle Eastern adversaries today, as President Clinton charged that Iraq could be regaining the ability to develop weapons of mass destruction and his national security advisers met to consider whether to impose a near-total trade ban against Iran.
The stepped-up campaign against the two countries has a dual purpose: to keep together the anti-Iraq coalition at the United Nations and to throttle Iran's economy as it tries to rebuild its military capability. 
 But it also highlights the fact that 16 years after Iran's revolution and more than four years after Iraq's humiliating defeat in the Persian Gulf war, the United States appears to be incapable of controlling or moderating what it considers the unacceptable behavior of both governments.
In pursuing its strategy, this Administration has cast the two countries as regional threats of equal importance.
The Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, is a secular, totalitarian Arab leader who came to power by force, spent tens of billions of dollars on his military machine and continues to rule by terror, while the Iranian President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, is an Islamic Persian clergyman who was popularly elected and who has invested much less money in his weapons program.
But in the eyes of the Administration, they are simply "those two rogue states," as Secretary of State Warren Christopher called them in a speech to the Anti-Defamation League today.
"There's absolutely no room for complacency about Iran's efforts," Mr. Christopher said, referring to Teheran's weapons programs. "Just remember Iraq. Five years ago, too many were willing to give Saddam Hussein the benefit of the doubt. We must not make the same mistake with Iran."
In a joint news conference with the British Prime Minister, John Major, after a meeting at the White House, Mr. Clinton expressed his determination to maintain strict global economic sanctions against Iraq until its Government is in complete compliance with United Nations resolutions that require it to abandon offensive weapons programs and allow permanent intrusive inspections of military installations.
But Mr. Clinton also took pains not to overstate his case, saying he did not have evidence that Iraq had the ability to rebuild its nuclear, chemical, biological and ballistic missile programs. "I didn't say they had the apparent ability," he told reporters in reference to their rebuilding those programs. "I said they could be regaining it."
Adding to the confusion, Mr. Christopher deviated during his speech from his prepared remarks to assert that Iraq is now trying to develop offensive biological weapons.
"We now have strong evidence that Iraq is conducting a large program to develop biological weapons for offensive purposes, and yet today, confronted with that evidence, the Iraqi officials just continue to dissemble and to lie," Mr. Christopher said.
In remarks prepared for delivery, Mr. Christopher said Iraq "was conducting" such a program, implying that it is no longer doing so. A senior State Department official explained that Mr. Christopher had made an inadvertent mistake because he was reading from a teleprompter, and that the "evidence" Mr. Christopher was referring to was a United Nations analysis in late February that Iraq has concealed evidence of a biological weapons program.
Iraq has never accounted for 17 tons of biological cultures that could be used for developing tuberculosis, cholera and the plague.
As for Iran, the Administration remains split over whether to ban most trade, senior officials said today. The issue has taken on new urgency because of Republican-sponsored legislation and a campaign led by the country's most powerful pro-Israel lobbying group.
Cabinet officials met at the White House today to discuss a variety of options, including banning American oil companies and their subsidiaries from buying Iranian oil on the open market and from investing in projects in Iran.
But they failed to come up with a recommendation for Mr. Clinton, a senior Administration official said.
"The bottom line was that no decisions were made," the official said. "I don't want to suggest consensus on any part of this. Options are still being shaped for the President."
The official added that the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, who headed today's meeting, has not decided whether to convene another Cabinet-level meeting on the issue.
Perhaps because of the strongly held views of different agencies, Mr. Lake intends to give Mr. Clinton a series of options. A senior Administration official said it might be weeks before the options went to Mr. Clinton's desk.
Mr. Christopher and Madeleine K. Albright, the American representative at the United Nations, who are pushing the near-total trade ban, argued today that it is the best way to make the current American strategy to isolate Iran work better.
Both officials favor a sweeping executive order that would send a strong signal to the Congress and Iran's trading partners that the United States is determined to thwart Iran's ability to purchase weapons and related equipment.
But other agencies, including the Energy and Commerce Departments have resisted taking any action that will not directly punish Iran. Both agencies believe that Iran will find other customers for its oil.
The Pentagon has argued that further isolating Iran may further radicalize the country. It is unclear what position the Deputy Defense Secretary, John Deutsch, took in today's meeting.
Mr. Clinton never has made a secret of his conviction that economic sanctions rarely have an impact unless they are globally imposed, and his views on this issue are not known. But the Iran policy debate has come to have more to do with politics and symbols than with any belief that new American economic sanctions will change the behavior of either Iran or America's allies.
The issue is complicated by two bills introduced by Senator Alfonse D'Amato, the New York Republican, to prohibit American companies or their subsidiaries from doing business with Iran and to impose sanctions on foreign companies that do business with Iran.
That legislation is supported by the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, which has distributed a 74-page argument for sanctions that seeks to seize on a wave of anti-Iran sentiment sweeping Congress.

HEADLINE: Kool-Aid, Not Soda: Living on Food Stamps

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: SHELBYVILLE, Ky.

 BODY:
The children love Doritos, but at $2.89 a bag at the Save-a-Lot discount store, where Linda Snider buys most of her groceries, they are too expensive. Instead, she buys two bags of generic potato chips for 89 cents, Kool-Aid instead of soda, pork chops instead of steak. Once a month she splurges on a half-gallon of ice cream.
"I buy a lot of macaroni and cheese for 19 cents a box," said Mrs. Snider, a 36-year-old emergency room aide who lives in a small garden apartment with her two daughters and a grandson on income of $222.89 a week and $160 a month in food stamps. "A 10-pack of hamburger meat, I can get six or seven meals out of. A pack of chicken gives me four. That's the only way I can shop." 
 Here in the rolling hills of Shelby County in central Kentucky, Mrs. Snider is among nearly 1,700 people, about 6 percent of the county's population, receiving assistance under the Federal food stamp program, which, after years of rapid growth, is in for some significant tightening if the House of Representatives has its way.
The welfare overhaul bill passed by the House in March would limit cost-of-living increases in food stamp benefits to 2 percent a year. Most legal immigrants would be declared ineligible, a provision that would remove 1.1 million people from the program's rolls. And all able-bodied adults who have no dependents would be required, after 90 days of assistance, to work at least 20 hours a week, not merely be enrolled in job training or be seeking a job as at present. That change would make an additional 800,000 recipients ineligible.
All this is aimed at saving $20 billion from the $150 billion that the program would otherwise cost over the next five years. A total of 27.5 million Americans, about one in 10, now receive food stamps, an increase of 36.8 percent since 1990 alone despite an improving economy and a lower unemployment rate.
Like about a fifth of the recipients nationwide, Mrs. Snider has a job and a family. She also has a dream that her children will "rise above my raising," and feels ashamed to have needed public assistance so long -- her parents were on welfare -- but angry at any perception that all food stamp recipients abuse the welfare system.
Despite Shelby County's modest living costs and job growth that has held unemployment at 4 percent or less for more than a year, Mrs. Snider and other recipients say they have no choice but to take food stamps: their jobs simply do not pay enough to make ends meet.
Many earn little above the minimum wage of $4.25 an hour and say their food stamp allotment is essential to keeping their homes and families intact. Many also say they are frightened by the possibility that their stamp allowance will not keep up with the rise in food prices.
Jerry Buehner, manager of the Kountry Pic-Pac Market, one of three supermarkets in Shelbyville, said that as much as 30 percent of the store's revenue was now in food stamps, about double the proportion of a decade ago.
For 20 years Janie Harrod, a case worker at the Shelbyville office of the state welfare agency, the Kentucky Department for Social Insurance, has been counseling food stamp recipients as well as those receiving cash assistance through the Government's primary welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children.
"Sure, we have our abusers," she said of food stamp recipients who refuse to work, who have babies to increase their benefits or who hide income or trade their stamps for drugs and alcohol. "You're always going to have a small group of people who abuse the system or wait for someone else to take care of them. And I get fed up with all the abusers. But they're not the majority. The majority of people really need the help."
Mrs. Harrod says stamp recipients -- whose benefits vary according to complex calculations of family income (up to $1,604 a month permitted for a family of four) and assets like a savings account, a car or a house -- fall into no particular category. There are single mothers getting no child support, recently separated or divorced people, retired people supporting grandchildren or children who cannot find work, and disabled people.
Most have a high school education, she said, but an increasing number of applicants have college degrees.
"You see everything," Mrs. Harrod said, pulling out folders that recorded a wide range of circumstances, from an 86-year-old man living alone who gets only $10 a month in food stamps because he has savings of $2,500, to a young working couple with six children who get $379.
Then, as she opened another file, her face tightened. "Here's a couple who just reapplied," she said. "He's 30, unemployed. She's 25 and works at a local day care center. When they brought in their checking account, it showed $36 a month for each of them to belong to a fitness center.
"Some people just don't know how to budget," she continued. "They're not making ends meet, and they want to keep their HBO and call-waiting."
Mrs. Snider, who separated from her third husband 10 years ago, knows few such luxuries. The biggest treat she gives the family is a rare evening at McDonald's, where a double cheeseburger, small fries and a Coke cost about $2. She pays in cash, since restaurant meals -- like alcohol, tobacco, vitamins and pet food -- cannot be bought with food stamps.
Her apartment is neatly decorated -- "Wal-Mart and yard sales," she said -- but cramped. She sleeps on the living room couch so Elvina, 18, who quit school after ninth grade, and Elvina's 3-year-old son, Brandon, can have the larger bedroom. Felicia, 10, sleeps in the other. Brandon's father, who is not married to Elvina, is 18 and lives with his grandmother.
For years, Mrs. Snider's life was a patchwork of rearing children, working menial jobs, drinking too much, moving into and out of her mother's apartment and, as her parents had, depending on food stamps and cash welfare to help pay bills.
Then, in 1989, she found work as a housekeeper at the Jewish Hospital in Shelbyville. Within two years she was promoted twice, enabling her to stop receiving cash welfare payments. She now earns $6.19 an hour and has her sights set on getting off the food stamp program.
"I'm embarrassed by this for the children," she said of her need for food stamps. "When I didn't have the right clothes in school, they'd call me Rag Doll. I realized I wasn't doing better than my parents. I've sat Elvina down and told her, 'Don't throw your life away; don't do what I did, bring a baby into this world and give it a whole lot of nothing.' "
While some recipients, like Mrs. Snider, have received food stamps for decades, many others say they expect to use them only briefly, until unforeseen or unavoidable setbacks begin to ease.
Toni Brown, a 24-year-old single mother receiving $169 in food stamps each month, is living in a subsidized two-bedroom apartment in Shelbyville with her 4-year-old son, Brandon, while she works at Wal-Mart and attends the University of Louisville, 38 miles away. A sophomore majoring in chemistry and Spanish, she has made the dean's list.
Like Mrs. Snider, Ms. Brown shops carefully, skipping name-brand cereals, which cost more than $4 a box, in favor of $3 store brands. But unlike Mrs. Snider, she knows that her earning capacity as a chemical researcher will get her off welfare quickly after graduation. And nothing angers her more, she said, than people who milk the system with no intention of quitting. Some, she said, are her neighbors.
"It makes me really hot," she said the other day before picking up Brandon at the Childtown Day Care Center. "I see them just sit around, watching soapies all day. I see the drug dealers. One girl in my community, a teen-ager, I heard her say, 'When I have my next baby, they'd better give me a three-bedroom apartment.' These people have no ambition."
Yet she also criticizes lawmakers who would reduce benefits. "It scares me," she said. "Not for me, because I'll be out soon, but for others. If the Government takes anything away, it just hurts the kids."
Patricia Kearney and Ruth Mahoney agree. Losing even a small fraction of their food stamp allowance would hurt their dependents, they said.
Ms. Kearney, a 30-year-old unemployed and unwed former assembly-line worker who attended a business college for two years, has five children, all under 8 years of age. Because of her need to care for them, she said, she has little expectation of taking a job soon. A food stamp recipient for seven years, she now gets $370 a month.
She said she felt "kind of bad" over the need to take public assistance, which includes $791 a month in other welfare benefits.
"Would I do anything different?" she said. "I wouldn't jump and have these kids. I love them, but I wouldn't have had them. I'd have given myself a chance."
Mrs. Mahoney, 56, has been rearing two grandchildren since 1983, when her 24-year-old daughter died of cancer.
The same year, Mrs. Mahoney was divorced from her husband, leaving her as the sole supporter of the children. She gets $66 a month in food stamps.
"I can't work," she said. "I've had three heart attacks, the last one in 1989, and I didn't think I was going to make it. I've got a bad back, and I had a tumor removed from my left arm. I've got cataracts and glaucoma. If they change the benefits, it's really going to be hard on me."
Pam Compton, 36, never imagined she would have to work, let alone need public assistance. She was married for 14 years to a trucker who earned as much as $50,000 a year. They lived in a middle-class neighborhood, in a three-bedroom house with their two children.
But their marriage broke up last May, and Mrs. Compton said she and the children, now 13 and 12, had moved 14 times to elude her husband, who wants custody. Two months ago, with nowhere else to go, they moved into a shelter. Now, she said, she receives $285 a month in food stamps and $156 a month in cash welfare.
She left her first two jobs -- at Pizza Hut ($2.30 an hour plus tips) and a local factory ($4.25 an hour) -- because the pay was so low. She said she expected to find a higher-paying factory job.
"I do feel a little shame about this," Mrs. Compton said, holding back tears. "I'm not taking care of them. The state is.
"It's been wonderful here," she said of the shelter, "but I want a normal life."

Chart: "REWRITING WELFARE LAW: Food Stamps"
 
THE GOAL -- House Republicans want to slow the growth of the Federal food stamp program, which has served as an income supplement for poor people, including those without children who would not qualify for other welfare programs.
 
THE PROPOSAL -- The bill passed by the House and set to be considered by the Senate this spring would tighten eligibility and, after 90 days' assistance, deny food stamps to able-bodied adults who have no dependents unless they work at least 20 hours a week; it would also cut most legal aliens from the rolls and limit cost-of-living increases to 2 percent a year.
 
CURRENT LAW -- Food stamps are indexed to inflation, most legal aliens are eligible for benefits, and able-bodied adults with no dependents are required only to be looking for a job or enrolled in job training.
 
SAVINGS -- The House bill would save almost $20 billion over five yoears, from a projected budget of $150 billion. Originally the program was to be scrapped altogether, with the states given block grants to spend on welfare as they saw fit. But farm-state Republicans stopped that effort. (pg. A16)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Rolls Past 4,200 As Bull Market Continues
 An ebullient stock market hit record levels, with the Dow rising 33.20 points to close above 4,200 for the first time, at 4,201.61. Bonds and the dollar also rose, with traders anticipating stable interest rates, low inflation and higher corporate earnings. 
 But the stock market's bullishness did not extend to technology issues, which took a beating as many traders became fearful that prices were climbing too high too fast. D10.
 
Disney's New Finance Chief
 Walt Disney named a new chief financial officer: Stephen Bollenbach, the chief executive of Host Marriott. Mr. Bollenbach previously played key roles in transforming the company that started the Holiday Inn chain into a leading casino operator and then in salvaging the casino and real estate empire of Donald J. Trump.
Despite hiring a longtime casino company expert, Disney officials insisted that the company had no plans to enter the gambling business except, perhaps, on cruise ships. D8.
 
Blunders Blamed in USAir Crash
 Federal investigators said the USAir DC-9 crash in Charlotte, N.C., in July could have been avoided had air traffic controllers warned the plane about wind shear, or if the captain had not told the first officer to lower the plane's nose. A1.
 
Management Shake-Up at Apple
 Apple has named David Nagel head of product development organizations. Ian Diery, who led the company's domestic sales organization and its hardware division, is resigning after losing an internal struggle. D5.
 
Construction Spending Falls
 Spending on U.S. construction projects fell 0.5 percent, to $523.3 billion, in February, the second consecutive monthly decline. D2.
 
Ford and Nissan Sales Rise in March
 Ford said its sales rose 3.3 percent in March, with truck sales up a record 16.5 percent. Nissan's sales were up 9.2 percent. D2.
 
Trade Ban Against Iran Considered
 President Clinton's national security advisers met to consider whether to impose a near-total trade ban against Iran in an attempt to throttle its economy as Iran tries to rebuild its military capability. A1.
 
USA Mobile Jumps on Buyout Bid
 Shares of the USA Mobile Communications rose $1.50, to $15, after Arch Communications said it would buy the paging company for $253 million in cash and stock. D4.
 
Inquiry Into Drop of Alden Stock
 The New York and American stock exchanges are investigating the decline in the stock of John Alden Financial on Thursday. The company told analysts that afternoon it would report bad news after the market closed, and almost immediately the stock began to fall. Floyd Norris: Market Place. D10.
 
Germany Warned on Economy
 German economists are warning that because of a strong mark, the country's economy is on a path toward lower growth. D6.
 
Salomon Seeking Help at the Top
 Trying to recover after a year of losses and departures, Salomon Brothers is starting a search for a deputy to assist its chairman. D5.
 
Golf With a Huge Water Hazard
 Royal Caribbean launches its cruise ship, Legend of the Seas, next month and on board is the first floating 18-hole golf course. The course's topography and proportions are scaled down from a normal golf course, and the longest hole is 32 feet long. Edwin McDowell: Travel. D7.

HEADLINE: Court Allows Plan to Merge Housing Force

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Two days after consolidating the transit police into the Police Department, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday overcame the final hurdle to merging the housing police as well.
In a unanimous decision, the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, ruled that the Mayor had the power to move ahead with the merger, a ruling that cleared the way for a single superforce of more than 38,000 officers within a month. 
 The court rejected an argument by the union for the housing police that Civil Service laws prohibited the transfer of its 2,500 officers and civilians from the quasi-independent Housing Authority to the city payroll.
With the decision in hand, Mr. Giuliani said that on May 7, the city would consolidate the housing force, which was created in 1952 with 47 officers to patrol projects. The Mayor has already received the necessary approval from the Housing Authority and the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, which pays $70 million, or 40 percent, of the costs of the force.
The merger of the smaller transit and housing forces into the Police Department will complete one of Mr. Giuliani's core campaign pledges -- one that has been debated for decades but that eluded two predecessors, Edward I. Koch and David N. Dinkins.
The merger will most likely leave Mr. Giuliani's signature on policing for years. "The merger assures all New Yorkers a coordinated and unified police protection whether they live in a housing development, whether they ride the subway, whether they are using the streets or public spaces of the city," the Mayor said at City Hall. "Crime and criminals don't recognize the boundaries between housing developments, the transit system or the streets."
Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, who will command more than 38,000 officers and 6,000 civilians, said the merger would allow the city to eliminate duplicate functions, freeing 200 officers for patrols in the 337 housing projects. The merger of the transit police, he said, would free 300 to 500 officers.
A primary fear of opponents, who include some elected officials and tenants' groups, has been that policing would drop in housing projects as the larger Police Department focused its attention elsewhere. Some tenants' leaders have threatened to conduct a rent strike if the merger proceeds, contending that city officers do not want to patrol their projects.
The Mayor's aides have stressed that the merger would allow increased patrols in the projects, where crime has remained steady or risen in some categories in recent years, even as it has dropped significantly citywide.
"This gives us an opportunity to stem that kind of crime behavior," said the Mayor's counsel, Dennison Young Jr., who has spearheaded the merger plan.
In the agreement with the Housing Authority, which was reached last September, the Mayor's office pledged to maintain at least the current level of policing. The accord, however, did not set a specific target, as did the agreement reached last week with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the state agency that controlled the transit police until 12:01 A.M. Sunday, when the transit police merged into the larger force.
For that reason, some opponents remained wary. Councilman Anthony D. Weiner, Democrat of Brooklyn, said, "The stakes are higher" for the 560,000 residents in the projects.
They are "more likely to fall victim to violent crime and less likely to see a police officer," he added.
"I hope that the merger is not seen as an end but a means to greater attention to the economically and politically vulnerable residents," Mr. Weiner said.
The Council, which has sought to delay the merger but does not have the power to stop it, has scheduled a hearing on policing in the projects for tomorrow evening at the Beach 41st Street Houses in Far Rockaway, Queens.
After the court decision, the president of the Housing Police Benevolent Association, Timothy L. Nickles, conceded defeat in the fight, which delayed the merger from its originally planned schedule of October 1994. Mr. Nickles said he feared that despite Mr. Giuliani's promises, future mayors would not be bound to maintain policing for some of the poorest residents in projects with some of the most intractable problems.
"We have a lot of faith in Bill Bratton," Mr. Nickles said, noting that the Commissioner headed the transit police from 1990 to 1992. "It's not tomorrow or next year we're worried about. But what's going to happen two or three years from now?"
On May 7, the housing police will officially become a bureau in the Police Department, like merger of the transit police. The bureau will be led by the current head of the housing police, Chief Joseph R. Leake, who will become one of seven three-star chiefs under Mr. Bratton.
The officers in the housing bureau will continue to operate from the nine precincts in housing projects. As with the transit officers, officials predicted a smooth transition that would go unnoticed by most New Yorkers.
Mr. Giuliani said one of the first priorities of the combined force would be to combat drugs and crime in the projects.
The chairman of the Housing Authority, Ruben Franco, a mayoral appointee, said the merger would enhance safety by bringing in the full force and resources of the Police Department. "We've had a good police force," Mr. Franco said. "But it simply isn't big enough."

HEADLINE: Clinton and Major Patch Up Quarrel on Northern Ireland

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
With British-American relations at their lowest point in years, President Clinton and Prime Minister John Major emerged from nearly three hours of meetings today and declared that the two countries had largely patched up their differences.
Seeking to put the best face on their recent quarrel over Northern Ireland, the two acknowledged that some disputes were inevitable. 
 "It's honest and open and it endures occasional disagreements," Mr. Clinton said of America's relations with Britain at a news conference. "But the agreements are far more numerous, and over the long run should be the shaping factors of our relationship."
Although the two leaders tried to give the impression that they had buried their differences, they could not help but squirm when a reporter asked about the health of their personal relationship.
"I think we have a good personal relationship," President Clinton said. Mr. Major was less bullish, saying, "We know one another well enough, and the relationship is good enough, to have those disagreements, and it doesn't affect the broad swath of agreement that exists between the two countries."
Relations took a serious turn for the worst last month when President Clinton, rejecting Mr. Major's recommendations, invited Gerry Adams, the head of the Irish Republican Army's political wing, to the White House and allowed him to raise funds in the United States.
Mr. Clinton's aides said those moves would nudge the Northern Ireland peace process forward, but many Britons expressed outrage that Mr. Clinton was embracing someone they viewed as a supporter of terrorism.
Despite the good will that both men displayed publicly, officials said that in one or two private meetings Mr. Major made it clear that he still resented the President's invitation to Mr. Adams. He said he would not allow the rift over the Northern Ireland issue to spoil London-Washington relations, but the officials quoted him as pointedly saying at one stage, "I do not use the phrase, 'special relationship.' "
As evidence that the British-American relationship is strong, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Major pointed today to several areas in which they agree. They said economic sanctions should be extended against Iraq, that Russia should not build nuclear reactors in Iran and NATO should be expanded gradually and openly.
The two leaders also said the war in Bosnia was being prolonged by the Bosnian Serbs' intransigence and warned that the recent surge in fighting would only cause more bloodshed and a continued stalemate. They urged Bosnia's Serbs to accept a peace plan proposed by the so-called contact group on the Balkans, which consists of the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Russia.
In London, those five nations agreed today to pressure Bosnia's Muslim-led Government to agree to extend a rapidly fraying four-month cease-fire that is scheduled to expire on April 30.
"Throughout this century, the United States and the United Kingdom have stood together on the great issues that have confronted our people," Mr. Clinton said.
Seeking to put their differences on Northern Ireland behind them, Mr. Clinton echoed the British leader's call for the I.R.A. to move quickly to start surrendering its weapons. He also said that the conflict over Ulster was closer to reaching a just and lasting settlement than at any time since it began nearly 26 years ago, "thanks in large measure to the vision and courage of John Major."
Tensions between the two allies over Northern Ireland grew so serious last month that Mr. Major took five days to return a telephone call in which Mr. Clinton tried to mend fences. The two leaders had previously disagreed over Bosnia, with the British leader rejecting American calls for air strikes against Bosnia's Serbs.
Aggravating matters further, the British were annoyed when Mr. Clinton decided to go to Moscow instead of London in May to mark the 50th anniversary of the Allied victory over Nazi Germany in World War II.
Officials familiar with the talks today said that Mr. Major also asked President Clinton to back Britain's efforts to have a former British Foreign Minister, Lord Owen, named Secretary General of NATO.
NATO's current head, Willy Claes, a former Belgian Economics Minister, is under pressure to resign because of a bribery scandal involving arms manufacturers and Belgian Government officials. Mr. Claes denies any involvement in the affair.
One official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Major also informally proposed establishing a free trade agreement between the United States and the 15-nation European Union, though the Prime Minister has not discussed the idea with other European leaders.
During his two-day visit, Mr. Major went twice to Capitol Hill to meet with leaders of the new Republican-led Congress. He met with Bob Dole, the Senate Majority leader, to urge him to abandon his drive to lift the arms embargo against Bosnia's Muslim-led Government, but Mr. Dole said he was not persuaded.
"The British position on that is well understood," Mr. Major said at the Pentagon on Monday. "We think lifting the embargo would be a mistake."
Britain and France, both of whom have troops in the United Nations force in the Balkans, say that lifting the arms embargo on the Bosnian Government would only fuel the fighting in Bosnia, soon to enter its fourth year, and put the United Nations soldiers there in greater risk.
Even as Mr. Major and Mr. Clinton sought to repair the special British-American relationship that flourished under Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher, the new Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, sought to claim that he was now the one with the special relationship with Britain's Conservative leader.
"We do feel a special kinship," Mr. Gingrich said of Mr. Major.

HEADLINE: G.M. Agrees To Sell Car Rental Unit

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its National Car Rental System operation to an investor group led by William E. Lobeck, the former president of the Chrysler Corporation's group of car rental companies and a former owner of Thrifty Car Rental.
Industry analysts estimated the sale price of National, the fifth-largest car rental company in the United States, at about $1 billion. G.M. did not disclose the terms of the deal. 
 G.M. said the sale of National reflected its strategy to focus more resources on its core automotive business, and automotive industry analysts said they applauded G.M.'s decision.
"Investors want to see G.M. become more focused, more efficient and more liquid from a balance sheet perspective," said Thomas M. Galvin, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence. "Completing the sale of National is confirmation that management is sticking to its game plan."
G.M. emphasized yesterday that its agreement with Mr. Lobeck's investor group, the NCR Acquisition Corporation, was definitive. In January, G.M. said that its plans to sell National to a group led by Vestar Equity Partners had collapsed. That deal was first announced in September.
NCR won out over Alamo Rent-A-Car Inc., which had been considered the odds-on favorite. An acquisition of National would have given Alamo more of the airport locations it had been seeking to serve business travelers. Alamo primarily focuses on leisure travelers with rental offices that are away from many airports.
Besides Mr. Lobeck, the NCR investor group includes Alvin Swanner of New Orleans and Archer McWhorter of Houston. Certain National licensees may also join the investor group, G.M. said.
Mr. Lobeck, along with four other investors who included Mr. Swanner and Mr. McWhorter, purchased Thrifty Car Rental in 1981. Thrifty was acquired by Chrysler in 1989.
According to the terms of the sale to NCR, the new owners will continue to employ National's 6,400 workers, and will continue to buy cars from G.M.
Although G.M. said that National turned a profit in 1994, the auto maker's decision to sell the subsidiary marks its final move to sever a close tie to the car rental industry. That long-term relationship has been both good and bad for G.M. and other car companies.
Auto manufacturers have long looked at car rental companies as a showcase where potential customers can test-drive new cars and as a convenient market to absorb cars when the auto makers built far more than individual customers demanded.
But as the car rental companies started selling a growing number of their own late-model cars to individual buyers in the late 1980's -- creating overflowing used car lots that competed with established car dealers -- those dealers started complaining.
So the car rental companies largely stopped the practice of selling their own cars and returned them to the manufacturers, who would then sell them at auction. Fewer cars were sold to the car rental companies. Sales of these so-called program cars reached their peak in the 1991 model year, when 1.5 million such cars were sold; for the 1995 model year, just over a million such cars are expected to be sold, according to Auto Rental News, a trade publication based in Redondo Beach, Calif.
"It got out of control in the beginning of this decade with the program cars," said Jon LeSage, executive editor of Auto Rental News. "They seemed to have come back to some kind of balance point."
But before that balance point was reached, the industry economics grew so poor that G.M. considered liquidating the subsidiary a few years ago.
In late 1992, the car company reported a $744 million charge related to losses and the write-off of good will at National. G.M. then hired a turnaround specialist, and the unit returned to the black in 1993.
Other big car companies may also be looking to get out of the business. Chrysler is expected to announce shortly its plans to sell Dollar Systems Inc. and Thrifty Car Rental, according to a person familiar with the company's plans. A Chrysler spokesman said, however, that no active discussions were under way to sell the subsidiaries.
Of the Big Three car companies, the Ford Motor Company appears the most committed to the business. Last year, Ford announced its plan to buy the remaining 46 percent of the Hertz Corporation that it did not own to gain full ownership.
The G.M. deal was announced about two hours after the stock market closed. Earlier, G.M.'s shares ended trading down $1.125, at $43.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: A Legal High-Wire Artist Takes On Silicon Valley Giants

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
It is probably safe to say that Jim Manzi and Bill Gates, who seem to have little to agree on as the chief executives of Lotus Development and Microsoft, both wish they had never heard of Gary Reback.
A lawyer with the Silicon Valley firm of Wilson, Sonsini, Goodrich & Rosati, Mr. Reback wrote a brief that was influential in the decision by Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin in February to reject the Justice Department's settlement of its antitrust case against Microsoft. Last month, Mr. Reback helped Borland International Inc. win a ruling in a copyright infringement case brought by Lotus, when a Federal appeals court panel overturned a lower court's ruling that could have required Borland to pay crippling damages. 
 Both Microsoft and the Justice Department have appealed the decision by Judge Sporkin, and Lotus has said it will appeal the Borland case to the Supreme Court. However temporary his victories might be, Mr. Reback has drawn the kind of attention not commonly focused on specialists in such arcane areas as antitrust and intellectual property law.
This is hardly a case of David versus Goliath, however. The client list of Wilson Sonsini is a virtual Rolodex of the big players in Silicon Valley, and Mr. Reback has enjoyed his share of high-profile cases. Lawyers at competing firms say Mr. Reback's high-wire act in taking on Microsoft and the Justice Department is only possible because Wilson, Sonsini has so many clients that have a vested interest in seeing the software giant taken down a peg or two.
"Mr. Reback and his law firm are to law firms in this area what Microsoft is to software," said a lawyer at another Silicon Valley firm, who requested anonymity, "and the great irony is that their own monopolistic practices go unchallenged. They completely dominate the market in Silicon Valley."
In the appeal in the Microsoft case last month, the Justice Department argued that Judge Sporkin had greatly overstepped his authority and that his decision was "an invitation to anarchy." Lawyers for Microsoft requested that the judge be disqualified from the case, contending he had relied on a popular book about the company -- "Hard Drive," by James Wallace and Jim Erickson -- for much of his information.
In a brief filed last Friday in response, Mr. Reback argued that neither Microsoft nor the Justice Department had provided Judge Sporkin with adequate information to determine if the proposed settlement was adequate. A Federal appeals court panel in Washington has scheduled oral arguments for the case at the end of the month, but a decision could take several months.
On another front, Mr. Reback has filed documents stating that the planned $1.5 billion acquisition of Intuit Inc. by Microsoft would allow the giant software company to use its dominance in desktop computing to create a monopoly in electronic banking and commerce. A Justice Department ruling is expected later this month, and should the acquisition be blocked that would be another coup for Mr. Reback.
Brian Kahin, a law professor at Harvard University, said the briefs filed by Mr. Reback in the Microsoft cases raised "some very important issues that we don't really have a policy framework to address."
Standards -- hardware or software specifications that are either widely used or officially sanctioned -- present a challenge to regulators, Mr. Kahin said, and the briefs "illustrate the power that standards have when they reach a certain critical mass."
In the meantime, Mr. Reback is unfazed by a Microsoft publicity campaign to refute his claims. "Microsoft engaged in illegal acts for six years," he said, referring to what he and others maintain were predatory practices that gave the company a virtual monopoly in operating systems for desktop computers. "As a result," he said, "they prevented competitors from acquiring an installed base of their own."
The entire installed base of Microsoft "is tainted," he said.
"Using that tainted installed base they leverage it into new markets," he added.
Microsoft, Mr. Reback said, created pricing systems that coerced computer manufacturers to pay for licenses on each machine they sold, whether or not the company's operating systems were loaded. He also said the company engaged in the practice of promoting "vaporware" by announcing nonexistent products for the purpose of stalling sales of a competitor. And, he added, Microsoft uses undocumented features in its operating systems that give the company's other software products an edge over those of its competitors.
Mr. Reback's arguments in both Microsoft cases are similar, relying on a combination of conventional antitrust analysis and a relatively obscure economic theory called "increasing returns" or "network economics." According to this theory, a monopolistic company is freed from the diminishing returns suffered by most products over time in a free market because its customers are locked in and will buy new goods and services even in the presence of superior alternatives.
Having achieved its monopoly in operating system software, Mr. Reback contends, Microsoft can now use that dominance to achieve similar positions in new markets, like corporate computer systems and the on-line industry, through its planned Microsoft Network on-line service. Mr. Reback said the consent decree against Microsoft forbade per-unit license fees for its MS-DOS and Windows operating systems, but excludes Windows NT, a more advanced system.
Mr. Reback, who is 45, suggested that Microsoft could combine the dominance of Windows, its desktop operating system software, with the market leadership of Intuit in personal finance software to achieve instant dominance in the emerging market for electronic on-line commerce. "I took one look at Intuit and said this is pure network economics," he said. "In conventional economics, someone can have a third of a market and be a player; in increasing returns it turns out to be all or nothing."
Perhaps more controversial than his use of advanced economic theories is Mr. Reback's lack of a named client in either filing against Microsoft and his reliance on accounts in the news media of the company's tactics. He maintains the document in the Intuit case was a white paper, or an explanatory document, submitted at the request of the Justice Department; the briefs in the Microsoft case were filed on behalf of three rival software companies, which chose to remain anonymous because they feared retaliation.
Some lawyers at competing firms have said the filing was as much a promotional effort for Wilson Sonsini and Mr. Reback as it was an act on behalf of clients.
"The allegation that this is a publicity stunt is particularly offensive to me, " Mr. Reback said. "What motivates me here is something very serious. All the multibillion-dollar clients I have came into existence during my legal career -- the last 20 years -- because in Silicon Valley we have an environment in which that can happen. If you let one company endanger that, we're all going to be enormous losers."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After winning the early rounds of two highly publicized software industry lawsuits, Gary Reback has drawn the kind of attention -- and criticism -- specialists in intellectual property and antitrust law rarely get. (George Olson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
German Economists Fear a Slowdown From Strong Mark

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 4

 BODY:
Economists around Germany this week have issued the darkest warnings to date that the excessively strong mark is setting the German economy on a path toward radically lower growth, with exports dropping and employment stagnating this year and next.
With the dire predictions, growth projections have been reduced by one-third, in the aftermath of last week's unsuccessful attempt by the nation's central bank to bolster the dollar by cutting German interest rates. 
 This week, the mark continued to set new highs against the dollar. And the promises of politicians that German economic growth would not be affected could hardly be heard amid the warnings by some of the country's most prominent economists and business leaders.
On Monday, for example, as Chancellor Helmut Kohl said in Hanover that the economy would grow 3 percent this year, Hans-Olaf Henkel, head of the country's most influential business trade group, the Federation of German Industry, said he had scaled back his group's forecast to 2 percent growth because of the expected effects of the strong mark.
And today, as Economics Minister Gunter Rexrodt reiterated the 3 percent forecast, the chief economist of Deutsche Bank said his giant bank's internal estimates called for a persistently high mark through the end of the year, with even lower projected growth.
"Instead of the 3 percent, we may only achieve growth of 1.8 percent," the economist, Norbert Walter, said in an interview with the daily Berliner Zeitung that was released a day before publication.
He said the drop in exports, a result of the strong mark making Germany's exports too expensive for many buyers, would be felt as soon as the second half of this year. Mr. Walter also said that the dollar would probably remain around 1.37 marks through the end of 1995. [Late in New York trading Tuesday, the dollar settled at 1.3762 marks.]
These predictions come as Germany is just a year into recovery from its worst postwar recession, and struggling with persistently high unemployment.
Mr. Walter said the German currency's strength would make it nearly impossible for unemployment in the country's western region -- now officially 8.2 percent, but unofficially closer to 10 percent -- to fall.
The mark's high valuation and the poor prospects for the dollar have preoccupied German policy makers, as they realize that there is little they can do to change market sentiment against the dollar, barring a reduction in the American budget deficit or the resolution of the Mexican financial crisis.
Though most of the focus here has been on the dollar's weakness, officials at the central bank, the Bundesbank, say their paramount concern about German competitiveness relates to the value of European currencies like the Italian lira, the Spanish peseta, the French franc and the British pound, because more than 70 percent of exports go to European countries while less than 10 percent go to the United States.
Officials are particularly worried about the lira, which has fallen almost 20 percent against the mark this year. "Italy is a very competitive supplier of machinery and other items that Germany also produces," a central bank official said. "At current levels, German exports to Italy just aren't competitive."
Some business executives here say it is almost impossible these days to sell German-made products in Italy because they are so expensive in lire. "You now have to produce in Italy to be able to sell there," a banker said recently.
The pound and the peseta have again taken big dips, making German exports to those countries less competitive, as well.
The Bundesbank's chief economist, Otmas Issing, today called the mark's value exaggerated, yet warned, "No one knows how long we will have to live with the current exchange rates."
Reflecting the dark mood among German officials, Mr. Rexrodt, the Economics Minister, took the unusual step of calling for American policy makers to do something to bring up the dollar's value.
The rise in the exchange rate of the mark "goes far beyond what is justified by fundamental factors," he said in a statement. "It is therefore all the more important that stabilizing signals be given by United States economic and fiscal policy, which make this clear and calms the market."
This was interpreted as a call to the Federal Reserve to again raise American interest rates.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Increase as Fed Buys Some Treasury Issues

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
ond prices were bolstered and interest rates slid to levels of a week ago yesterday as a result of the dollar's stronger performance in currency markets and an announcement by the Federal Reserve that it was buying various Treasury securities in the open market.
A few times a year, the central bank comes to market and buys certain maturities to add cash to the banking system. It is a way to address seasonal shortages of reserves that if left unattended may cause short-term rates to move higher than the current Fed policy warrants. 
 The process, called a coupon pass, also presents dealers with an opportunity to sell Treasury securities that have been piling up in inventory. It is not a signal of any change in monetary policy.
In the last coupon pass on Nov. 29, the Fed bought $4.2 billion of notes and bonds. The Fed will disclose the size of yesterday's pass at its weekly news conference on April 13. Yesterday, the central bank was buying securities with maturities of April 1996 or later.
The 30-year bond rose 2/32 , to a price of 103 for a yield of 7.37 percent, down from 7.38 percent on Monday, with shorter-maturity bill rates down an average of about two basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In currency markets, the dollar recovered some ground against most leading currencies after tumbling on Monday despite interventions by central banks.
Also yesterday, a construction spending report by the Commerce Department showed a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent in February, slightly more than the four-tenths of 1 percent decline economists had expected. Analysts said it was yet another report from the market's perspective that the economy was slowing.
Spending in January was also revised to reflect a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent from the previously reported decline of two-tenths of 1 percent.
This Friday's payrolls report is expected to give the market a better idea where the economy is headed. Some economists believe employment conditions are probably the best indicator of the current pace of economic growth.
Traders said the expectation that the Federal Reserve would begin to buy securities in the open market yesterday was an early positive for the market, especially for shorter maturities.
So-called short-covering early in the session also helped bond prices edge higher ahead of the construction spending report. Traders who sell short borrow securities and then sell them, hoping to replace them later with securities bought at lower prices and make a profit on the difference. Yesterday, some of these players were forced to buy back these securities, or short-cover, to limit losses, as prices rose instead of fell.
Alan Kral, portfolio manager at Trevor, Stewart, Burton & Jacobsen Inc., a New York investment management firm, sees the market trying to digest the events of the last few trading sessions, including the weakness in the dollar, the rise in gold prices, higher commodity prices and data that suggest the economy is slowing.
"I don't think the Fed will act to raise interest rates based solely on what is happening in the currency market, but I expect it to remain a concern of the market that they will," Mr. Kral said. That concern, he thinks, can only stop through the passage of time.
The coming economic numbers, Mr. Kral believes, will disclose a slowdown from the fourth quarter, though not necessarily enough to slow down inflation more than the pace of 2.5 percent the Fed would like. "However, we think that the trend of news announcements going forward will be positive enough to satisfy the targets and strategies of the bond vigilantes who are quick to lynch the Fed," Mr. Kral said.
Noting that recent data, including the construction spending report, continued to reflect a slowing economy, Jack McIntyre, senior fixed-income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said: "The credit market's true test will come Friday when the employment situation for the month of March will be released. The bond market will need to see weakness in the labor sector of the economy if the 1995 rally is to continue."

HEADLINE: New Construction Spending Falls 0.5% for 2d Month

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
Spending on new construction projects declined in February for the second consecutive month, the Government reported today, as higher interest rates and winter weather slowed the pace of home building to its lowest level in more than a year.
Construction spending fell five-tenths of 1 percent, to $523.3 billion, at an annual rate in February, the Commerce Department said. In January, construction spending declined a revised five-tenths of 1 percent, initially reported as a two-tenths of 1 percent decrease. 
 The first back-to-back decline in a year reflected "an erosion of residential activity" pegged to the rise in long-term interest rates, said Raymond Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J.
Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgage rates are about two full percentage points higher today than when they bottomed out below 7 percent in the fall of 1993.
In addition, the weather turned colder in February after an unusually mild December and January in many parts of the country, said Lynn Reaser, chief economist at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles.
Before today's Government report, many analysts had been expecting little or no change in construction spending for February.
Many economists saw little reason for concern in the construction figures. The outlook for commercial real estate remains healthy, said Gene Sherman at the New York investment firm of M. A. Schapiro & Company. "Corporate profits remain strong, and as long as they remain strong, capital spending will continue to grow," he said.
Additionally, Mr. Sherman said housing could stage a modest recovery in the spring because mortgage rates have fallen below 9 percent, prices are steady year over year and jobs remain plentiful.
By category, spending on residential buildings and home improvements fell five-tenths of 1 percent in February as single-family home construction declined to the lowest level since January 1994.
But spending on commercial projects, such as factories, rose 3.3 percent in February. Businesses continue to spend heavily on improving plant and equipment because it is "less interest-rate sensitive than housing," Mr. Stone said. "Housing tends to be the most interest-rate sensitive sector," he added.
Spending on public projects, such as municipal water works and public housing projects, fell 1.1 percent in February, the Commerce Department said.
The slowdown in construction spending follows declines in several other areas, such as new home sales and factory output, as the economy absorbs the effects of the seven interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve since February 1994.
The increases have made it more expensive to borrow for everyone from builders to home buyers. For example, sales of new single-family homes fell 14 percent in February to the lowest level in almost three years.
Additionally, starts of new housing construction declined in February to the lowest level in almost a year. Permits for new housing construction also dropped during the month.

HEADLINE: Way Ahead in the Space Race;
Europe's Arianespace Builds on Decade-Old Lead

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
It seemed a secure American domain: launching satellites to feed a growing world hunger for space-age telecommunications. But the Challenger disaster in 1986 effectively shut down the American space program for more than a year, leaving customers little choice but to look elsewhere.
Where many of them looked was to Arianespace, the European consortium that had set up shop in the early 70's and was starting to expand rapidly by 1986. After the Challenger, its business surged, aided by sharp business tactics and generous government financing, and it now dominates the worldwide business of launching commercial satellites. 
 And Arianespace may soon get an even tighter lock on the business and doom the two main American rocket makers, the Lockheed Martin Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, to permanent also-ran status in this strategically and symbolically important corner of the aerospace industry.
Late this year the French-led group will launch its first Ariane 5 rockets, the fifth generation in a series developed by European governments and companies specifically to break the long American stranglehold on lofting commercial satellites into orbit.
Developed for about $7 billion, the Ariane 5 is more powerful than the current Ariane 4 and designed to allow more efficiency in preparation and launching. Already, Arianespace and the European Space Agency are planning a $1-billion-plus upgrading to the new rocket that could by the turn of the century leave it with an ever greater advantage.
Arianespace's ascendancy owes something to that accident of timing after the Challenger. But it is also a case history in how Western European governments have proved willing to make consistent, long-term commitments to subsidizing and nurturing what they consider key technologies and industries.
Despite budget pressures like those that have led to cuts in the American space program, the major Western European governments, which pay for developing and testing the rockets before turning the technology over to Arianespace, have stuck doggedly to their plans and met all their financial promises.
As a result, Arianespace ranks alongside Airbus, the French-led commercial aircraft consortium, as the greatest success of European industrial policy. "Technologically, Ariane 5 is doing nothing that the United States is not capable of doing," said Barry Zilin, president of Practical Innovations, an aerospace consulting firm in Woodbridge, Va., that recently did a study of American and European space efforts.
"The difference is one of Arianespace taking advantage of many lessons they've learned from observing the U.S. space program and streamlining operating procedures," he said. "They've developed five new launch vehicles and three new launch pads, each time learning from the one before. We in the U.S. haven't been able to match those investments."
Arianespace, a partnership of 40 European aerospace companies, led by Aerospatiale of France and the French space agency, has had its problems, including two launching failures last year and delays this year.
But Arianespace, which sent up its first rocket in 1979 and did not begin commercial launchings in earnest until 1984, accounted for nearly half of all commercial launchings between 1989 and 1994, and holds 55 percent of the launching orders for coming years.
Lockheed Martin, which makes the Atlas rocket, the main American commercial launcher, and McDonnell Douglas, which makes the medium-sized Delta, together have less than 30 percent of advance bookings. The Russian Proton and the Chinese Long March rockets have the rest.
Aerospace executives in the United States trace Arianespace's success in part to an ability to price launchings aggressively.
While prices are a closely held industry secret, analysts say an Ariane 4 launching could range from $80 million to $120 million, depending on the number of satellites carried, the customers and the value of the dollar relative to the French franc. An Atlas launching might cost just $65 million, but where Atlas normally carries only one satellite, the Ariane 4 usually carries two, with the cost split between them.
The Atlas and Delta were originally designed to deliver nuclear warheads, and American aerospace companies still look a lot like military contractors, with all the associated costs and inefficiencies. Arianespace, by contrast, has always been purely commercial.
The differences show up in large ways and small. Arianespace has French chefs at the launching site in Kourou, French Guiana, to keep customers well fed while awaiting launchings. It offers them up-to-date facilities for preparing their satellites. And it runs a lean operation.
The Atlas program, for example, requires most preparatory work to be done on the launching pad, where working conditions are far from ideal and solving problems can be difficult. Most preparatory work on Arianes occurs in huge hangars, with the rocket and its payload rolled out to the pad only after nearly everything is checked out.
James Wynn, a George Washington University graduate student who is in Paris this year studying Arianespace, said the consortium used about 200 people to prepare and launch a rocket. American launchings, by contrast, require 500 people or more, he said, although their efficiency has been improving as the military adopts more commercial practices to save money.
"The U.S. system requires a lot of redundant oversight and checks," holdovers from the military days, Mr. Wynn said. "The French have found they need to do that for the first test series, but not once everything is up and running."
Just as it has tailored operations to commercial uses, Mr. Wynn said, Arianespace has also adapted technology to its customers' needs.
"Everyone assumes Ariane is wonderful new technology," Mr. Wynn said. "It's an old technology tailored to the commercial market. They've sized the tanks and the engines to the needs of commercial customers. They've simplified pumps and valves to make things more reliable. It's the same old stuff we're using, but put together in a way that's just right for launching commercial satellites."
Arianespace is extending that approach. The Ariane 5, which is expected to be launched for the first time in November or December and to begin commercial launchings late next year, is more powerful than the Ariane 4, but simpler in many ways. It has one main engine instead of the four on the Ariane 4. It will be able to carry nearly seven tons of payload into the type of orbit needed by telecommunications satellites, up from four and a half tons.
The Ariane 5 will thus be able to carry two spacecraft of nearly three tons, the average for a telecommunications satellite, plus their associated equipment. But satellites are growing larger, and are expected to be three and a half tons in the next decade. As a result, Arianespace plans to upgrade Ariane 5 to carry eight tons or so -- a capacity no other launcher will be able to match.
"If Ariane 5 proves reliable and matures quickly, which I expect it will, then the overall economic equation will be visibly improved for users who contract with Arianespace," said Ralph Jaeger, the consortium's senior vice president for marketing and international affairs.
Moreover, Mr. Jaeger said, the plans to squeeze costs are aimed not just at competing against other launchers, but at helping Arianespace's customers compete against alternative technologies like ground-based fiber optic cable. Those customers are almost exclusively companies that need satellites to relay television and telephone signals, both rapidly growing markets.
To be sure, the United States retains powerful advantages. Washington will for the foreseeable future use American rockets for its military and scientific satellites that do not ride the shuttle into space, providing a base of orders that should keep production lines and launching teams intact no matter what happens in the commercial business.
But Washington has proved unwilling to provide the American industry with the kind of direct support Arianespace receives. As a result, Arianespace executives and analysts said, the stiffest competition in future years might come not from the United States but from Russia, which is eagerly taking advantage of its low cost base.
A failure by the United States to support its launching industry "could portend a lesser ability for us to compete effectively against a clearly aggressive French commercial market competitor," said Brian D. Dailey, a vice president in Lockheed Martin's Washington office.
The Clinton Administration is now studying whether different rocket programs could be combined and slimmed down into a single family capable of both Government and commercial launchings.
But for Lockheed Martin, the key to competing may be held not by Washington but by the Russians. Lockheed has a joint venture to market the Russian Proton launcher to satellite users, and so far has been modestly successful at it. The Proton could become an even more potent competitor, analysts said, if Lockheed can develop a launcher with Russian costs and American levels of customer service.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Court Backs Injunction And Pushes for Talks

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The President, the Secretary of State and the mediator appointed by the President have tried to get the baseball owners and the players to bargain successfully. Yesterday, the chief judge of a Federal appellate court tried his hand.
Judge Jon Newman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit was not trying to broker an agreement, but in making his judicial point, he elicited answers from lawyers that added weight to the contention of union officials that they are eager to resume negotiations and the owners are not. 
 At the conclusion of a 66-minute hearing in Manhattan, Newman and the other two members of the panel, Judges Ralph Winter and J. Daniel Mahoney, denied the owners' request for a stay of the injunction that prompted players to end their strike over the weekend and return to work without a new collective bargaining agreement.
All three judges were so severe in their questions and comments to Frank Casey, the owners' lawyer, that the appeal of the injunction the owners will present to a three-judge panel next month would seem to have virtually no chance of success.
The denial of the stay and the likely denial of the appeal would enable the shortened 144-game season to proceed with no possible interruptions or problems in the near future.
Typical of the comments from the bench was one made by Winter in response to an argument Casey was trying to make about mandatory subjects for bargaining. "Mr. Casey," Winter said, alluding to the court's previous decisions, "I think you're in the wrong circuit."
Later, when George Cohen, representing the union, rose to address the court after Ellen Farrell had argued against the stay for the National Labor Relations Board, Winter said, smiling, "What's the matter, counsel, you don't like the way the argument has gone so far?"
The judges especially were critical of the owners' view, as presented through their legal team, that the injunction issued last Friday by Judge Sonia Sotomayor of United States District Court somehow inhibited or prevented the two sides from negotiating.
In an affidavit submitted for the case, Casey said the injunction, if not stayed, would "end collective bargaining for the foreseeable future." The union, he said, would have "no incentive to negotiate until the late summer or early fall, when it again will be advantageous for the players to strike."
But Newman referred to a letter Donald Fehr, the union leader, sent to Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, last Friday, two hours after Sotomayor granted the injunction. In the letter, Fehr told Selig that the players were prepared to continue bargaining and asked him to "give me a call so we can arrange to return to the bargaining table."
"The last thing we have here," Newman said to Casey, "is Mr. Fehr's letter saying they want to resume collective bargaining. When can you do that?"
Casey: "As soon as we can do it."
Newman: "Starting today?"
Casey: "As soon as we schedule it."
The judge later raised the subject with Cohen. "Are the players ready to resume collective bargaining?" he said.
"Absolutely, your honor," the lawyer replied emphatically.
But the resumption of talks has not been scheduled. Selig has not called Fehr to arrange a return to the table, not after last Friday's letter and not after a subsequent letter from Fehr.
The judges unanimously criticized the owners' position on bargaining and the injunction as stated by Casey. At one point, Newman asked the lawyer what it would take for his side to understand otherwise.
"Do you want to hear it from Judge Sotomayor?" the judge said.
"Do you want to hear it from us?" Newman added later, "When you're telling us that the injunction is stopping you from negotiating a collective bargaining agreement, you're telling us something that isn't so."
The other two judges suggested to Casey that the owners and their lawyers squandered an opportunity to act when they might have succeeded.
Winter mentioned the owners' decision of Feb. 3, in a deal with the labor board to avoid a complaint being issued against them, to withdraw their implemented salary cap and to restore the previous work rules.
"You're the one who entered the agreement to restore the status quo," Winter said. "You could've fought that in court and you would've had a heck of a case. You didn't."
At another point, when Casey argued that the owners were prevented from negotiating the economics for 1995 and now couldn't do anything until 1996, Mahoney said, "You had the possibility of pursuing that with the N.L.R.B. and you threw in the towel."
In another problem labor area, a four-hour meeting in Philadelphia on the leagues' lockout of the umpires went nowhere.
Richie Phillips, the umpires' lawyer, said he told Robert Kheel, the leagues' negotiator, that the owners are "like bullies who can't win a fight so they want to pick on the smallest kid on the block" and beat him up.
"I said the umpires will not allow themselves to be bullied at the bargaining table," Phillips said.
 
Networks Vying for Games
 ABC, NBC and Major League Baseball -- the partners in The Baseball Network -- will meet next week to determine which network will broadcast the All-Star Game, the World Series and the playoffs this year. Although NBC is scheduled to televise the 1995 World Series, ABC would like it, having missed last year's. The partners must also determine whether to extend TBN's contract beyond 1995.

HEADLINE: Ford and Nissan Report March Sales Rise

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 4

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Corporation reported healthy March sales increases today in contrast to earlier reports of declines from most other major auto makers.
Despite the signs of strength, stocks for the Big Three weakened on Wall Street as investors reacted to the earlier reports. The Chrysler Corporation closed down $2.125 at $40. General Motors Corporation shares were off $1.125 at $43.50 and Ford was down 62.55 cents at $26.50. 
 Investors are getting mixed signals -- the growth in consumer spending and lower income -- Government data show. But there is evidence that consumers are increasingly confident and more Americans plan to buy cars.
"One thing is for sure: A year ago the industry was inflated at what everybody said were unsustainable levels," Joel Pitcoff, an analyst for Ford, said.
The industry's United States sales of cars and light trucks in March were down 5.3 percent from a year ago. Most analysts still expect the auto makers to equal or exceed last year's deliveries of 15 million light vehicles.
Ford's sales were 3.3 percent higher in March, with record truck sales, up 16.5 percent, offsetting a 9 percent decline in passenger car deliveries.
Nissan sales, including those of its luxury Infiniti division, were 9.2 percent higher. The Altima, one of Nissan's three high-volume sedans, was up 77 percent.
On Monday, Chrysler reported March sales off 9.1 percent, and its chairman, Robert J. Eaton, said the company's profit in the year's first half would be reduced because of increased spending on rebates and other buyer incentives.
G.M. said its sales were down 9.4 percent and Toyota's slid 13.2 percent. Of the top five Asian auto makers, only Honda reported an increase -- its sales were up one-tenth of 1 percent.
Ronald Glantz, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said consumers had been reacting to increases in variable-rate credit card and mortgage interest, and remembering periods when interest rates made monthly payments more expensive.
The Federal Reserve has repeatedly increased interest rates in the last year in an effort to head off inflation. If rates stabilize or decline later this year, "people who held off buying a car in February and March will come back into the market," Mr. Glantz said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Up Some Ground With No Signs of Intervention

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar recovered some ground yesterday after Monday's tumble, ending higher against most leading currencies as dealers watched for signs of further intervention by central banks.
While there were no signs that the Federal Reserve entered foreign exchange markets yesterday to buy dollars, the expectations of such interventions bolstered the dollar, dealers said. On Monday, the Federal Reserve spent about $1 billion to prop up the value of the dollar. 
 "The dollar has benefited from the threat of continued intervention," said John McCarthy, manager of foreign exchange for ING Capital Markets in New York. Indeed, the threat of intervention helps the dollar more than the actual purchases, he said. "The ironic thing is that when intervention comes, people are less concerned, because the deed is done."
After slipping to a postwar low of 85.68 yen in intraday trading in Tokyo, the dollar recovered to 86.20 yen in New York trading late yesterday, up from 86.07 yen on Monday. The dollar edged up to 1.3762 German marks from 1.3723 marks. The British pound slipped to $1.6067 from $1.6189.
The Bank of Japan, which bought dollars alongside the Fed in Asian trading yesterday, bought again yesterday, traders said. Japan's central bank has bought dollars repeatedly in recent weeks to try to keep the yen from strengthening. The strong yen hobbles Japan's economy by making its exports more expensive.
Speculation that the dollar may have fallen too far, too fast also helped the currency rebound today, dealers said.
The dollar's decline "has been overdone for a long time," said Richard Vullo, currency sales manager at the Bayerische Hypotheken und Wechsel Bank in New York.
With American stock and bond markets advancing, the economy growing, and "the only inflation fears coming from the dollar itself, the U.S. should be an attractive place to invest, and the dollar should be doing O.K.," Mr. Vullo said.
Though stronger today, many traders said the dollar's swoon would not end until the United States took more drastic steps to slow its decline, like raising interest rates. Higher interest rates often help a currency by making bank deposits denominated in the currency more attractive.
"There is plenty of room for the dollar to fall" before the Fed holds its next meeting on monetary policy on May 23, said Betsy Reetz, manager of currency sales to fund managers at the National Westminster Bank in New York. The dollar could fall as low as 1.30 marks by then, she said.
