HEADLINE: In America;
The Wrong Target

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
One of the many important issues to emerge battered and distorted from the insidious cavern of political demagoguery is affirmative action. If you listen to the latest crop of compulsively deceitful politicians, or tune into the howling degradation of talk radio, you might become convinced that the biggest problem of discrimination in the United States today is bias against white men.
The complaint is that legions of African-Americans, women and assorted others are taking jobs, promotions, classroom slots, theater tickets and the best seats on the bus from the folks who really deserve them -- white guys. 
 The arguments against affirmative action are almost always crafted in racial terms because the demagogues know that race is the way to get the emotional flames roaring. In fact, the primary beneficiaries of affirmative action are women. If all parties would lower their voices and try to communicate in good faith, it could be pointed out that while there are problems with affirmative action -- including some serious problems of fairness -- the negative impact on white men has not been great, and the problems are correctable.
What you do not want to do, in a country where there are still prodigious amounts of race and sex discrimination, is abandon a long and honorable fight for justice in the face of political hysteria.
The Federal Glass Ceiling Commission recently reported that 95 percent of top corporate management positions in the United States are held by white men. Throughout corporate America, women, blacks and Latinos are paid less than white men for doing the same work. And if you believe there is a bias against white males in hiring, just pair up a white guy with a black guy and send them off in search of the same job.
Racism against blacks and sexism against women abound. And yet the outrage we hear today is about discrimination against white men.
A report on discrimination in employment commissioned by the Labor Department found very little evidence of employment discrimination against white men. The report was prepared by Alfred W. Blumrosen, a law professor at Rutgers University. It found that a "high proportion" of the so-called "reverse discrimination" claims brought by white men were without merit.
The politicians will tell you that the attack on affirmative action is a cry for racial justice. That is not so. It is an expression of the anger and frustration felt by large numbers of overwrought and underemployed white men. Their anxiety is understandable, but affirmative action is not their enemy. Downsized to the point of despair, their wages stagnant or falling, their prospects dim, these men are caught up in the treacherous world of technological innovation, economic globalization and unrestrained corporate greed. Buffeted by forces that seem beyond their control (forces that are affecting everybody, not just white men), they listen to the demagogues. It's the blacks doing it to you. It's the women. They're getting your piece of the pie. Otherwise you'd be O.K.
The Clinton Administration, under pressure, is reviewing Federal affirmative action programs. Fine. Let whatever abuses exist come to light. Scrap whatever programs are unnecessary or unfair. Where affirmative action is being used to help the disadvantaged, remove the racial or ethnic requirements. There are white kids all over the country who are economically and educationally deprived. Give them a hand.
But neither Bill Clinton nor anybody else should back off from the commitment to fight what is still an enormous and debilitating problem -- discrimination against blacks, other ethnic minorities and women. Where affirmative action is needed to counter the effects of discrimination, let it be.
The United States is going through a period in which the politics of meanness is in the ascent. In many circles, it is unfashionable to be compassionate. Putting down others is the dominant mode of political expression, preferably with a vicious remark accompanied by cruel laughter.
All of this will pass. Eventually we'll find our higher selves and chase the dogs of bigotry and fear and ignorance from the yard. I am convinced this will happen. We are Americans, after all. We are better than we have been behaving lately.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Cuba Blockade Supporters Cling to the Past

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Senator Connie Mack insists (letter, March 24) on considering the United States policy of blockade against Cuba as the most effective means to achieve his aspiration, and that of an ultra-right-wing sector of Cuban migrants in Florida: to change the Cuban political system in line with his interests. 
 The failure of such a policy for more than 36 years and its rejection in the United Nations by 101 countries, as well as by increasingly wide sectors of United States society, are not sufficient arguments for the Senator from Florida, who presupposes that he is right simply because 20 other senators support the increase in pressures against Cuba.
According to a recent Gallup Poll among "common citizens" of Cuba, for those whose well-being supposedly concerns Senator Mack, 58 percent believe that the revolution has had more successes than failures, and 43 percent expressed being very satisfied with their personal life.
Those same "common citizens" enjoy social security, health and education standards well above those existing in Florida, the state that elected Senator Mack.
Cuba is immersed in a wide-ranging and irreversible process of change, but it is not the United States Congress that will decide the future of Cubans.
Senator Mack and those who support him are making this process more difficult by insisting on anachronistic ideas of times long gone and are underestimating the intelligence of your readers by affirming that Cuba constitutes a threat to the United States.
 
EDGARDO VALDES
Press Attache
Cuban Mission to the United Nations
New York, March 31, 1995

HEADLINE: On the San Andreas Fault, an Ideal Spot for Vines

BYLINE: By BILL STAGGS 

 BODY:
AS Pat DeRose guided visitors around the winery at his family-owned Cienega Valley Vineyards, he pointed out the tanks, barrels and other equipment of a typical wine-making operation. But his guests were drawn to the cracked floors and warped walls, and to a small box in the corner. Inside were seismic monitors from the United States Geological Survey, instruments whose needles wavered frequently because the powerful San Andreas fault runs smack under the winery, slowly splitting it in half.
The vineyard is set in a quiet valley dotted with walnut groves and other wineries, 10 miles south of the town of Hollister and 100 miles south of San Francisco. "The west side of the building has moved 24 inches in about 30 years," Mr. DeRose said, pointing out a gap between two walls that once were one. The west side is moving north and the east side is inching south. 
 Mr. DeRose is just one of many food and wine producers who do business along a 120-mile stretch of the San Andreas fault -- from the dry slopes of the Gavilan Mountain Range south of Hollister to the shores of Tomales Bay, north of San Francisco. Nowhere else along the fault do the temperature, soil and climate come together so agreeably for agricultural pursuits.
These farmers conduct their businesses with varying degrees of concern about their tectonic neighbor -- from reverence to indifference -- and reap the rewards of nature fully aware of the risks in setting up shop next to such a force.
Not many of them are old enough to recall the San Francisco quake of 1906, but most can remember the Loma Prieta quake of 1989. And still they stay.
Allan Lindh, a seismologist with the geological survey in Menlo Park, south of San Francisco, views the San Andreas fault not as the region's ultimate bogyman but as "perhaps the best thing that ever happened to the state." He doesn't consider it strange that people still want to establish businesses in such a risky zone.
"The San Andreas created California about 100 million years," Mr. Lindh said. "It has been assembled out of a million little pieces, creating an enormous range of economic and esthetic benefits, an endless variety of little valleys in which you can find almost any set of conditions you might be looking for, especially for agriculture."
He pointed out, for example, the limestone soil, so perfect for vineyards, that "rafted in" from areas hundreds of miles to the south as plates shifted, and the steep slopes of new mountains that created streams to fill valleys with rich, alluvial soil.
"Without the Coast Ranges and the Sierras that were thrust up by tectonic movement, all that rain from the Pacific would be falling somewhere over the Midwest," he said.
Mr. Lindh attributes his theory to Perry Byerly, a geology professor at the University of California at Berkeley, who suggested in the 1930's that earthquakes might do good as well as harm. Mr. Lindh acknowledges the injuries and destruction that occur with major quakes, but his scientific perspective helps him weigh the damage against the economic benefits.
"Losses of $15 billion or $20 billion are nothing compared with the benefits we have realized from the power of the San Andreas over time," he said.
In the picturesque Cienega Valley, Mr. DeRose, for example, is unfazed by the slow splitting under his building. He has adapted to the shifting earth by bracing interior walls, essentially turning the halves of the winery into separate structures that can move independently.
Just two miles south of Mr. DeRose's place is the Calera Wine Company, owned by Josh Jensen.
Mr. Jensen, who said his 20-year-old enterprise was "a Frisbee toss away from the fault," bought the land after a two-year stay in France working for the Burgundy producers Romanee-Conti and Dujac. He returned to California to scout limestone plots similar to those that yielded the best grapes in France. Today, he makes five pinot noirs that frequently win prestigious tastings.
Mr. Jensen knew about the potential hazards of being so near the fault when he carved his winery from an abandoned rock-crushing plant. His only precautions were steel and concrete reinforcements. So far, his improvements have held through quakes large and small.
"There's not a lot you can do, really," he said. "We all accept a certain level of risk simply by living in California."
Eighty miles north, in the Santa Cruz mountains, lies Ridge Vineyards. Paul Draper, a wine maker and the company's chief executive, has lived and worked alongside the fault for 25 years.
He said the Loma Prieta quake jolted everything -- people, barrels, tanks -- straight up and straight down. Yet, despite the winery's proximity to the quake's epicenter, only three bottles of 1987 Ridge Geyserville Zinfandel, from Sonoma County, were broken.
Mr. Draper has a keen awareness of the geologic forces underfoot.
"At least once a week I bike down into the canyon along the fault," he said. "There's an old split-rail fence, and the line of the fence is offset by 12 feet. That fence gives you a very real sense of how things move.
"Working on the fault makes you realize that there is this force that is greater than you. You deal with it with respect, doing everything you can. We make efforts -- from building special tanks to securing barrels -- but we realize it's a force that can't be predicted."
On a clear day, a visitor on a Ridge hilltop can look to the northwest and follow the San Andreas -- across the San Francisco peninsula and the choppy Pacific off the Golden Gate -- to see all the way to the Point Reyes peninsula on the coast of Marin County. Warren Weber grows organic produce on Star Route Farms, where the fault strikes land at Bolinas lagoon.
Douglas Gallagher, who manages the 100-acre farm, was in his house changing his son's diaper when Loma Prieta vibrated northward along the fault.
"The field crew saw waves start out in the lagoon," he said, "then continue across the marsh and ripple right under the farm like somebody was shaking out a carpet."
"It sounds strange, but I kind of enjoyed it," he said. "It's a phenomenon that makes you feel kind of small, that gives you a new perspective."
The farm suffered no damage, but Mr. Gallagher said he was stuck with two days' worth of produce because many restaurants in San Francisco were closed.
Twenty miles farther north, past the town of Olema -- the epicenter of the San Francisco quake of 1906 -- the village of Marshall hugs the eastern edge of Tomales Bay.
The town is home to the Straus Family Creamery, with its barns and pastures on the shore and its bottling plant four miles inland. Albert Straus and his family have run this organic dairy since February 1994.
Ellen Straus, Albert's mother, extols the virtues of the region. "The dairies always liked to blend our milk with interior valley milk because ours tasted better," she said. "It has to do with the cool, foggy climate," she added. "Our cows are not stressed by high temperatures like they are inland."
The Hog Island Oyster Company, a newcomer to this fault-created bay, sits near the land where the Straus's 220 cows roam.
The oyster company is owned by Michael Watchorn, Terry Sawyer and John Finger, all marine biologists. They chanced upon this stretch of shoreline 10 years ago.
Mr. Sawyer said Tomales Bay -- with its cool, shallow waters and it's elongated shape -- provided the ideal climate for their needs. "The rapidly moving cold waters at the mouth of the bay make for a better oyster," he said.
Their oysters -- European flats, Atlantics, Kumamotos and Pacifics -- have made such a splash in California restaurants and markets that the men have to ration them to insure enough for customers.
"I'm not wild about earthquakes," Mr. Finger said, "but I've learned to deal with them. I'd much rather be here on the shore of Tomales Bay during a quake than in a tall building in downtown San Francisco."

HEADLINE: The Dow Rolls Past 4,200 as Stocks, Bonds and Dollar Rally

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
As the financial markets head into the corporate earnings season, stocks, bonds and the dollar rallied yesterday, with traders expecting stable interest rates, low inflation and higher corporate earnings.
But the weak dollar, which rose slightly yesterday on expectations that the Federal Reserve and other central banks would again defend it, could be the financial markets' undoing over the next few weeks. 
 Still, an ebullient stock market hit record levels yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average finished above 4,200 points for the first time, at 4,201.61, up 33.20 points. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 3.39 points to finish at 505.24, also a record high.
American markets are currently outperforming other financial markets. "U.S. stocks are the only game in town right now," said Thomas Gallagher, head of equity trading at Oppenheimer & Company. "You don't want to be in Japan. You don't want to be in Europe."
To Alfred E. Goldman, director of market analysis for A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis, "The big picture is that it's still a bull market."
"But April is going to bring some classic showers," he added, "a timeout for stocks, probably in the third or fourth week of the month."
For one thing, analysts said, traders may be incorporating the expectation of higher first-quarter earnings into stock prices. Thus, when companies report strong earnings later this month, their stock prices may actually fall and drag down the rest of the market with them. If the earnings are less than expected, the drop will likely be steeper.
Yesterday, high-technology stocks took a beating on similar concerns, sending the Nasdaq composite index, rich in high-tech stocks, falling 4.33 points, to 813.72.
Stock traders, fearful that prices may be climbing too high too fast, were troubled by the collapse of some high-tech stocks that had led the market for months.
Sybase dropped 16 1/8, to 23, and was the day's most active stock with 32.2 million shares traded. The headlong plunge in price, caused by a troubled outlook for the company's data base software, wiped out more than $800 million of what used to be $2 billion worth of stock. It also contributed to the sharp fall in the Nasdaq index.
The dollar rose above Monday's post-World-War-II low of 85.85 Japanese yen and last Friday's postwar low of 1.3720 German marks. In New York, the dollar rose to 86.20 yen, from 86.07 yen on Monday, and to 1.3762 marks from 1.3723 marks.
Bonds edged higher, with long-term interest rates falling, deflecting more money toward stocks. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 7.37 percent from 7.38 percent. Since March 14, rates have been relatively stable at about 7.4 percent.
So far, the Dow is breaking milestones at a far faster rate than in the recent past. For example, after edging past 3,000 points on May 30, 1991, it took the Dow more than six months to cross 3,100 on Dec. 27, 1991, and six more trading days to cross 3,200.
By contrast, the Dow crossed 4,000 points on Feb. 23 and took only 21 trading days to cross 4,100, and eight days to cross 4,200.
The major stock indexes indicate that the market may be at a crossroads. The rally so far has concentrated mainly on blue-chip stocks. Since March 9, the Dow has consistently risen, advancing from less than 4,000.
By contrast, the S.& P. 500 has been flat at about 500 points for eight sessions in a row. And the Nasdaq composite index, consisting of some 4,900 stocks has been down or flat for five sessions in a row at below 820.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was normal, with 330.6 million shares changing hands.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.80 points, to 273.29, with advancing stocks outnumbering decliners by 1,437 to 846. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.31 points, to 467.30.
Among the biggest gainers, Moorco International, a specialized equipment maker, saw its shares rise 7 3/4, to 21 3/8, after the FMC Corporation offered to buy Moorco for $20 a share, or $223 million. FMC fell 1/4, to 60 3/4.
Shares of Valujet Airlines, rose 4 1/4, to 54 3/4, after the carrier reported gains in capacity for March. The American depository receipts of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the Japanese conglomerate, continued to gain in speculation about Matsushita's possible negotiations to sell MCA, the huge film studio. The securities gained 4, to 157 1/2.
Among the biggest decliners was the Pittston Minerals Group, a mining company. Its shares fell 3 5/8, to 14, after a Merrill Lynch analyst lowered his assessment to "below average" from "above average." Shares of Timberland fell 3 3/8, to 22 3/4, after the footwear company said earnings would be below Wall Street expectations.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 428 words

HEADLINE: He Cheated a Charity, Unchallenged

 BODY:
William Aramony was president of the United Way of America for 22 years, until an embarrassed board of directors forced him out in 1992. He now stands convicted of siphoning off more than $600,000 of United Way funds for himself.
The Aramony scandal hurt local United Ways all over the country, although they had no hand in it. More important, it signaled the businessmen and women who sit on charity boards -- Mr. Aramony's and others as well -- that they are guardians of the public's trust, and must not treat the responsibility casually. 
 The United Way of America is not general headquarters for the 1,900 local United Ways, and does no public fund-raising. It is a separate organization that offers training and marketing services to help the United Ways that are its members -- 1,400 of the 1,900 -- charging them a fee for the services they use. Mr. Aramony and two colleagues skimmed from those fees and from the profits of a spinoff unit they created to handle some services.
It is commonly acknowledged that Mr. Aramony did much to strengthen the United Way of America. This may have blinded his directors to his shortcomings, but blind they were. They paid him $390,000 a year, plus $70,000 in perks and benefits, and approved a lucrative pension -- in addition to what he is convicted of taking illegally. Testimony at his three-week trial spun a tale of dalliances with at least four lovers -- one of them just out of high school -- cruising on the Nile, gambling in Las Vegas and weekending in an Upper East Side condo in Manhattan with a chauffeured car.
A former chairman of the United Way of America board -- Edward Brennan, chairman of Sears, Roebuck -- testified that he had received an anonymous letter in 1990, warning that Mr. Aramony was looting the organization and romancing a teen-ager. But a year later, when reporters were raising questions about Mr. Aramony, the board reportedly gave him a "resounding vote of confidence." He was forced out within three months.
Since then, with a new president, a reconstituted board that includes local United Way representatives, stricter controls and lower fees, the United Way of America has regained the local member organizations that pulled out at the time of the Aramony troubles. Total United Way fund-raising -- hurt by the recession as well as the scandal -- is almost back where it was before, at roughly $3.2 billion.
The United Way of America may be clean these days, but only because of a crisis that could have been avoided if its trustees had not been so trusting.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 2948 words

HEADLINE: History on the March;
New Standards, Attacked on the Right, Stress the Neglected

BYLINE: By JO THOMAS 

 BODY:
Jaime Kleinman, 16, took another look at the American Revolution and surprised herself by arguing that the British were right.
"They did everything for the colonists," she said. "They didn't deserve to be turned on." Many of her classmates at a Long Island high school, however, argued just as strongly that the British were wrong. 
 In a Brooklyn high school, a history class examined a drawing of the Boston Massacre by Paul Revere. "Where's the black man?" one student asked.
Absent, along with the snow that historians say was on the ground that day, was the Revolution's first American casualty, Crispus Attucks, a former slave. The class pondered this, along with the use of the word "massacre" for five deaths.
The schools are miles apart geographically and far apart economically. Yet both share new approaches to teaching American history similar to those recommended in voluntary standards proposed last fall by a task force at the National Center for History in the Schools at the University of California at Los Angeles, for which revisions are now under consideration.
The standards, which have been criticized by conservatives, suggest additions to course content to include the lives and contributions of Americans who have been underemphasized in the past. Students might be asked to assess the contributions of Prince Hall and Absalom Jones, former slaves who helped newly freed slaves in the 18th century.
Students are encouraged to bring a historical perspective to bear on the present, through debate and the use of the Socratic method, approaches long used by some of the best teachers to challenge students. They might be asked to describe the effects of the Declaration of Independence and the French Declaration of the Rights of Man on 20th-century revolutions in Mexico, Russia, China, Cuba and Vietnam.
Marshall Smith, an undersecretary of education, said the proposed standards "should be seen as the starting point of a reasonable and disciplined dialogue." Instead, they came under a heavy attack from conservatives led by Lynne V. Cheney, the former chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, which originally commissioned the standards.
She and others argued that the new standards strayed too far from the subject matter of traditional American history, emphasized obscure figures in the name of political correctness and lacked the affirmative tone they say American history deserves. The authors responded that Mrs. Cheney mischaracterized the content, but the United States Senate voted 99 to 1 in January not to endorse the standards.
Yet far from the glare of the political debate, visits to six high schools in the New York metropolitan area found that history teachers in the classroom are already embracing the spirit of the standards.
Not always with success. In one city high school, a class divided into groups to analyze the New Deal but did not seem to know much about it. In a suburban school, a teacher asked students to pretend to be workers and managers in a late 19th-century factory. But none of the students knew the meanings of the words "ostentatious," "appalling," "barter," or "scab," much less about how 19th-century workers or managers might have approached labor negotiations.
For the most part, though, the new approaches to American history seemed to have a profound impact.
"When I teach American history," said Diana Javis, assistant principal at the John F. Kennedy High School in the Bronx, and a fan of the new methods, "I ask them: 'What will your grandchildren ask you about? History is a living story. It's your story.' "
She even asks students to interview their parents. "Parents love it," she said. "As one young lady was questioning her mother, the phone rang, and the girl got up to answer it. Her mother was very upset. She said, 'I'm talking about my life!' "
Steve Shultz, an assistant principal who has been teaching for more than 22 years, the last 12 at the Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn, said: "Change makes us uncomfortable. But history is changing anyway. That's what history is all about."
 
 
Stuyvesant High
Debating Point: Hamilton's Vision
 From the windows of Stuyvesant High School's new building overlooking the Hudson River, students can see Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty. Stuyvesant, with 2,800 students from every borough, is itself a monument to optimism and excellence, called by many the best public high school in America. All the seniors expect to go to four-year colleges. By late fall, it is not unusual to meet Ivy League scouts in class.
Two classes crushed into a room one morning for a debate over Alexander Hamilton. In Hamilton's time, Alan Krinsky, the moderator, said: "We were a rural nation, beset with problems. In 1789, North Carolina and Rhode Island reluctantly ratified the Constitution. The smart money was not on American survival. Alexander Hamilton was the first Secretary of the Treasury."
The debate: Whether or not Hamilton's vision was the right one for the time.
Speaking for Hamilton were Eugene Babenko, 16, and Christina Chan, 17. Speaking against him were Elaine Kung, 17, and Danica Lo, 16.
"Hamilton was a stand-up politician," argued Eugene. "His views, which may have been monarchist and pro-British, alienated his comrades at the Constitutional Convention, but this did not stop him." He went on to praise Hamilton's support for Federalism and his insistence that the central government assume the debts of the states.
"States like Virginia, which had paid their debts, now had to pay for others," Elaine retorted. "His economic policies benefited merchants at the expense of farmers."
"Hamilton protected an infant democracy," Christina argued.
"He protected the rich," Elaine shot back.
Ultimately, judged on evidence, reason, delivery, pertinence and quality of rebuttal, the moderator decided that the anti-Hamilton arguments had won by a narrow margin.
A few doors down, Warren Donin's African-American history class, an elective, was full, with 41 students jockeying for seats. This day's main discussion was over the word 'Holocaust,' and whether it should be used to describe the experiences of African-Americans or whether using the word trivialized the experiences of the European victims of the Nazis. The students failed to resolve the question, spilling out into the hallway at the end of the class, still passionately arguing.
When the students don't know what they think, Mr. Donin makes them take a position and defend it anyway.
"He turns everything into a question," Nick Malis, 17, said later. Is the Declaration of Independence a great document? I say, 'Sure. Why wouldn't it be?' 'Well, all 'men' are created equal. What does it mean?'
"When I come to this class. I'm happy. It's my favorite class. It's really changed the way I see."
Gary S. Laveman, the assistant principal, who oversees social studies, said of the standards' approach: "This is nothing new. I think you have to deal with American history realistically. When the Pilgrims came here, other people were living here. You're not inventing or reinventing anything. You're looking at what is here. The question is the emphasis. When Crispus Attucks gets as important as George Washington, we have a problem."
 
 
Robeson High
Crispus Attucks: Absence Noted
 It was the absence of Crispus Attucks that bothered the students in Keith Walter's class at the Paul Robeson High School for Business and Technology in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
Students at the school are participating in the American Social History project underwritten by City University, the Aaron Diamond Foundation and the Board of Education. The project emphasizes the role of working men and women in American history.
On this morning, passing by signs ordering them not to wear hats or bandanas or Walkmen at school, the students watched "Tea Party Etiquette," a video that included the reading of an account from George Robert Twelves Hewes, a Boston shoemaker who saw the Boston Massacre and three years later took part in the Boston Tea Party.
The students found the British accents hard to understand, but they got the point that resistance to British policies came not only from George Washington, Thomas Jefferson and John Adams, but also from ordinary people.
On the day that British soldiers, attacked by a mob, opened fire at what became known as the Boston Massacre, many young apprentices were in the crowd. The students looked at several renderings of this scene. Attucks appeared in only one depiction. The scruffy apprentices appeared in none.
"How can three pictures of the same event look so different?" Mr. Walter asked the class. "Why did they resort to violence?"
The students gathered in groups to talk about the questions and write their answers. The project stresses working together. The history classes are coordinated with literature classes for the same period.
"Our approach is student-centered," said Roberta Koza, assistant principal for communication arts. She teaches the literature part of the American Social History project. "We start with the self," she said. "Most of the self in this building is African-American. We're getting people to start making connections, to understand that they bring something to the table as well."
Last year, Ms. Koza taught two classes in this program, one regular class and one for honors students. To her delight, the students in the regular class, unaware they were not honors students, performed almost as well as the honors class.
"They rose to the occasion on all levels," she said. This year, all the juniors in the school are included.
 
 
Dix Hills, L.I.
Whose Liberty? Whose Tyranny?
 It was 9:10 A.M. in a comfortable schoolroom at Half Hollow Hills East High School in Dix Hills, a wealthy Long Island suburb. The dates chalked on the blackboard were 1763 and 1776. If anything looked like a traditional American history class, this was it. Then Gloria Sesso, who was among the teachers who helped draft the new national history standards, turned from the board to the students, and the illusion disappeared.
At the end of the French and Indian War, Mrs. Sesso said: "England passes the Proclamation Line of 1763. No one can go past the Appalachian Mountains. This land belongs to the Native Americans. Do you think it's a good idea?"
"It appeases the Indians," Benjamin Oren said.
"The British can't afford to keep troops there," Mrs. Sesso said. "It will create more trading privileges. She walked slowly up an aisle between the desks. "This sounds wonderful, but the colonists shout 'Tyranny!' Why do they think it belongs to them?'
"They fought for this land," one student answered.
"They thought they had the right to expand."
Mrs. Sesso stalked back to the blackboard, not satisfied.
"Why did they think the Proclamation Line was imprisoning them?" she asked. "Would you have supported the Proclamation Line? Who's right? Is England being unfair? Tyrannical?"
The answers to the questions were not in the textbook.
"It's important for someone to have control after a war, to maintain order," Brett Sherman said. "They were right in preserving order."
"Imprisoning them," said Mrs. Sesso in the tone of a district attorney. "You're really into freedom and democracy." The students shifted uneasily in their chairs.
"Next step," Mrs. Sesso said. "England has a program. They propose a stamp tax in 1765 to help pay for the war. The colonists think the Stamp Act is tyranny. Why?"
She handed out photocopies of arguments written at the time for and against it. "Who do you think has the stronger argument?" Hands shot up.
"The British case is destroyed by the colonists' case," said Duane Koh. "Everyone in England could have a say in Parliament, but a colonial person had no representative in Parliament. The colonists were right."
"The colonists were English," said Matthew Wurse, disagreeing.
"They were English, but now they're Americans," David Scheine said. "They have a different society."
"Is it tyranny?" Mrs. Sesso asked. "Patrick Henry gets up and says we should tax ourselves. All of a sudden, George Grenville is being hung in effigy. What does it mean to be hung in effigy? Is it a legitimate form of protest?"
"In Massachusetts, they go to Governor Hutchinson's house screaming 'Liberty! No stamps!' and they burn it down because he's in cahoots with the stamp tax. What's the matter?"
"It would make the British come down on them," Melissa Sharoun said. "They're being radical and challenging the social order."
"Who's exercising tyranny here?" Mrs. Sesso asked. "England or the mob burning down the house?"
There was no letup as Mrs. Sesso drew almost every student in.
"In most other classes, teachers tell you something, and you daze out," Lauren Chernick, one of Mrs. Sesso's students, said later. In history class, she said, "You're up. People want your opinion. It makes you want to understand it."
The heart of the morning's lesson, Mrs. Sesso said later, was the concept of liberty.
"I want them to identify that the nature of freedom means different things to different people," she said.
"You don't separate details from ideas," she said. "Otherwise, you're discussing hot air."
"There's a difference between education and indoctrination," she said. "I think American values are reinforced with the ability to choose and think. That's what freedom is about, making choices."
 
 
Boys and Girls High
Bitter Lessons Of a Slave Ship
 The sculpture outside the Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn looks like it might be one more security device, three gently curving slabs of concrete, side by side. Few of the 4,600 students bother to take a closer look as they go in and out of the nation's 14th largest high school.
Steve Shultz, a history teacher, goes outside with his classes and asks them to look again. Up close, they see a narrow band of bronze bas-relief showing families in chains. One figure kneels in agony. Perhaps it is a person being branded, perhaps whipped, perhaps both. The students look closely.
Then Mr. Shultz asks them to walk between the slabs, to crowd together inside the narrow curves. They see other strips of bronze filled with small faceless figures, despairing, packed together in the narrow hold of a slave ship. Some try to comfort others.
The figures have ropes around their necks. The loose ropes belong to the captives who have died. The students begin to talk. Up close, the stone reminds them of the sea, of the sky, its surface the texture of prison.
The students were not used to standing so close together, they said afterward. Because they had studied slavery, they thought about those who endured a passage to America and bondage.
Last year, the students were so moved that they sent poems, essays, drawings and letters to the sculptor, Ed Wilson, professor emeritus in art at the State University at Binghamton. They put these, with his answer, in a book they published themselves.
"History is more important than facts," Mr. Shultz said. "History is feelings. If you're doing it from a textbook, you can't capture that feeling."
Keeler Dunbar, one of Mr. Shultz's students, said: "In slavery, to give slaves knowledge was to give them power." She said the sculpture made her think "maybe they could be going through what I'm going through."
"My mother dropped out early in her third year," she said. "She always said education was No. 1. I'm going to live out some of her dreams."
Boys and Girls is a high school with few amenities, but Mr. Shultz helps his students learn to do outside research. The proposed standards also suggest that students take advantage of community resources.
Selena Judge went to the library of the New York Historical Society to look for answers to a quiz of 30 little-known history facts. "It was so fascinating," she said. "I found that Adams and Jefferson died on the same day in the same year.
"We take class discussions outside the class," she said. "Sometimes I drive my mother crazy, applying history to everything in the house."
Another student said Mr. Shultz's class had so inspired her she went "from a 34 to a 95 average in one semester."
"It's not cheerleading," Mr. Shultz said. "The kids see they're dealing with real history, their history. When you see the value, it goes beyond history."
 
The Journey, the Struggle The Tale of Our Past
 By Denetra Taylor
 
Everyday we complain about how
 hard life is
Everyday we die by the hands of our
 own race.
Everyday we are called niggers by
 people who are the same color as us.
Everyday we are on a journey.
I bring a tale unlike others those of our African sistgern and
 brothers.
Our ancestors were brought here
 against their will.
Many survuved, but many were killed.
They spent many months on a slave
 ship.
Their backs were blody from the
 white man's whip.
Bound together day and night.
Many of them never saw the light.
The men were humiliated
The women were raped
They were stripped of their humanity
 and they didn't know their own fate.
Aboard these ships were men, women
 and children.
They were treated like cargo and not
 like humans.
But this didn't stop them they went on
They strived and struggled for a new
 dawn.
For this reason we must go on and
 stay alive
We must go on, we must survive.
 Denetra Taylor, a 1994 graduate of Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn, was part of a history class that produced a literary booklet about a sculpture outside the school that depicts a slave ship crossing.

HEADLINE: Mexican Aid Cutoff Pushed Into Defense Appropriations Bill

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
House and Senate conferees agreed today to a $3.1 billion supplemental defense appropriations bill requested by the White House but unexpectedly added a Republican-drafted provision that threatens to cut off all future loans and guarantees to Mexico.
The sponsor of the amendment, Representative Christopher Cox of California, said it was in retaliation for President Clinton's refusal to provide detailed information on his financial aid plan for Mexico that Congress demanded a month ago. 
 The measure, which would need the approval of the House and Senate, would take effect only if the Administration failed to make the documents available. "Given their lack of compliance so far, I am skeptical that they can comply," Mr. Cox said in a telephone interview.
The Administration was already facing a deadline of Friday to provide a broad range of documents, many of them classified, about contacts with the Mexican Government and the past use of the Exchange Stabilization Fund, which President Clinton drew upon to provide the aid without Congressional approval.
The fund operates under his discretion, and it is ordinarily used to stabilize the dollar in foreign exchange markets.
An Administration official said that he expected that various agencies of the Government, from the Treasury to the White House, would be in "substantial compliance" with the mandate by the weekend. "This is a bit broader," the official said, "but nothing we can't work with."
By attaching the new provision to the Pentagon money bill, the Republicans appeared to be trying to increase the pressure on the White House, which has urged quick passage of the military authorization.
But Administration officials said tonight that it was possible that the passage of the amendment could defuse some of the pressure on the Senate on a far tougher amendment that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York has introduced to cut off all further aid to Mexico.
Senator D'Amato tried unsuccessfully to get the Senate to act on his provision, which was included in proposed midyear budget cuts, but it has not been taken up. The Republican and Democratic leaders of the Senate agreed tonight on a compromise to the midyear cuts, and part of the deal was an agreement to set aside Mr. D'Amato's measure.
The President moved on Jan. 31 to authorize a $20 billion loan through the Exchange Stabilization Fund to help stabilize the Mexican peso. He acted on his own after opposition mounted in Congress to an earlier plan that required its approval.
Congressional leaders initially gave Mr. Clinton's initiative its blessing, but grumbling continued among both Republicans and Democrats. And Republicans in particular have sought to embarrass the Administration by demanding inquiries into what the White House and Treasury knew of Mexico's crumbling economic condition before the peso was devalued last December.
By a 407 to 21 vote, the House of Representatives on March 1 adopted a Congressional resolution of inquiry that gave the White House until March 15 to provide all documents pertaining to the Mexican deal. The White House missed the deadline.
Members of the House and the Senate are scheduled to begin the first major recess of the 104th Congress on Friday. Amid the pending legislation is the emergency spending bill for the Pentagon that the Congressional negotiators agreed on today. The full House and Senate are expected to vote on the measure before the recess. The money is to cover the costs of unexpected operations in Haiti, Rwanda, Bosnia, Cuba and the Persian Gulf.

HEADLINE: Index of Leading Indicators Falls to Soft 0.2% Landing

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
The Government's main gauge for predicting the economy fell two-tenths of 1 percent in February, the first decline since October and the biggest since mid-1993, the Commerce Department reported today.
The index of leading indicators now stands at 102.3, exactly where it was in August before settling into a pattern of small changes that offset each other. This pattern seems to have presaged the slackening from the unsustainably rapid economic growth of more than 5 percent in the final quarter of 1994. 
 "The leading indicators are right on track, not only confirming the emerging slowdown but also showing what sectors are being affected," said Gordon Richards, economist at the National Association of Manufacturers. He pointed to lower materials prices as a result of reduced demand, diminished orders for consumer goods reflecting a buildup in inventories, less optimism among shoppers because of rising interest rates and debt loads, and the toll that rates have taken on home building.
Analysts suggested that the deceleration shown in these and other indicators was likely to lead to an economic soft landing, in which growth would slow to less than 3 percent but the economy would not fall into a recession.
"You'd need to have a string of sizable declines" before worrying about recession, said Michael P. Niemira of Mitsubishi Bank in New York. He said the chance of such a downturn this year remained under 5 percent.
And while some analysts believe the Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates at least once more this spring, and possibly again during the summer, to keep inflation in check, today's report was quite reassuring on that score.
One reason was that the prices of items particularly sensitive to the business cycle was by far the biggest contributor to decline in the leading index. Another is that the proportion of companies reporting slower deliveries from suppliers fell slightly in February and, based on a report earlier this week, sharply in March.
This makes three straight months in which deliveries were made more speedily, a sign that industry is avoiding bottlenecks that fan inflation. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, is known to pay special attention to this vendor performance indicator. The February decline was so small, however, that it was rounded to zero.
The other downward forces in the index for February were a drop in the money supply, a decline in new orders to factories for consumer products, a drop in the University of Michigan's index of consumer expectations, a shortened workweek, the issuance of fewer building permits and a rise in first-time claims for unemployment insurance.
Three components moved positively, with the surge in stock prices as represented by the Standard & Poor's 500 about twice as important as the other two combined. These lesser contributors were a rise in unfilled orders for manufactured durable goods and higher value of contracts and orders for new plants and business equipment.
The report on leading indicators had only a slight impact on the stock and bond markets, which ended the day with little change.
Companion indexes made up of components that tend to move at the same time as the overall economy or after it both moved higher at the latest reading. The index of coincident indicators rose three-tenths of 1 percent, its 13th straight advance following a two-tenths of 1 percent rise that was the first for any January since 1989.
The index of lagging indicators jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent, the biggest increase in two years. This was unsettling to some analysts since it meant a second straight decline for the ratio of the coincident index to the lagging index. This ratio is regarded as a better predictor of turning points in the economy than the leading index itself.
About a year ago, in an effort to better capture cyclical changes, the department stopped applying an upward adjustment for normal economic growth but failed to persuade economists that this would make the leading index more useful as a forecasting tool.
"It's a coincident indicator at best," said Raymond A. Worseck, chief economist at A. G. Edwards, the St. Louis-based brokerage house.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1716 words

HEADLINE: HOUSE VOTES TO CUT TAXES BY $189 BILLION OVER 5 YEARS AS PART OF G.O.P.'CONTRACT'

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
The House tonight approved a Republican plan containing the heftiest collection of tax breaks in 14 years, overwhelming Democrats who denounced the package as a fiscally reckless gift to the nation's moneyed class.
The 246-to-188vote, largely along party lines, put the House's stamp on a plan that would reduce tax revenue by $189 billion over five years, with fully $105 billion of that in the form of a $500-a-child credit to taxpaying families. Billions of dollars more would go to breaks aimed at retirees, investors and corporations. 
 The bill now goes to a Senate, which is far less inclined toward major tax reduction this year, but whose leader, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, faces strong pressure from within his own party to follow the House's lead. The same conservative groundswell that was the engine behind the tax legislation is likely to be vital to Mr. Dole's own campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination.
But the Senate and Mr. Dole were in the shadows tonight. Today belonged to House Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the architect of his party's success. He began it in symbolic fashion, reviewing a parade of circus elephants across the Capitol grounds, and ended it with the passage of what he has called the crown jewel of his party's political manifesto, the Contract with America.
"This is a good bill," Mr. Gingrich said late tonight. "It is paid for. It helps to create jobs. It strengthens families. it does what we ought to be doing. And it's the last step in the Contract."
Democrats tried four times to block or change the bill.
By a vote of 229 to 204, they failed to defeat a crucial procedural rule, setting the terms for the day's debate, that would have had the practical effect of keeping the tax bill from reaching the floor. They tried to replace it with their own substitute, written by the minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, but scores of Democrats joined Republicans to trounce that effort, 313 to 119.
They then tried to send the bill back to the Ways and Means Committee with orders to trim the breaks given wealthier taxpayers. But scores of Democrats joined Republicans to defeat that, too, 265 to 168.
Finally, they sought to block the bill on technical grounds, arguing that two clauses in the bill were actually tax increases, requiring approval by three-fifths of the House under the new House rules that Republicans changed in January with the explicit aim of discouraging tax hikes.
Three-fifths was a margin that Republicans could not hope to amass. But the chair ruled that the Democratic complaint was groundless.
With the action tonight, Republicans insured that they leave on Congress's spring break this weekend armed with the claim that they have fulfilled a fall campaign promise to vote on every item in the contract. Moreover, they will carry the rosiest sort of political news: a promise of the biggest tax break since Congress voted a $748 billion five-year tax cut in 1981, in President Ronald Reagan's first year in office.
Democrats, who showed unusual solidarity in battling the tax bill, were left to cultivate what they hope will be a major issue in the next campaign: a perception that Republicans are using their new-found power to shift billions from the poor to the rich.
All day, it was the theme of Democratic speeches.
"Finally, the end of the Contract," Representative Joseph Moakley of Massachusetts, a leading Democratic orator, said with unconcealed sarcasm, adding that for 92 days Republicans had "gutted school lunches, home heating assistance and student loans."
"And for what reason," he asked. "To pay for tax cuts for rich Americans. From the mouths of babes to the pockets of billionaires."
Republicans saw it differently. "The American people resent the fact that more of their money and more of their power and more control have been sent from where they live to this city," said Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the Budget Committee chairman. "They want their money given back to them."
Representative Porter J. Goss, a Florida Republican, said he and fellow Republicans were "keeping our promise: to reduce taxation, to curtail Uncle Sam's persistent, depressing reach into American pockets and wallets."
Indeed, Republicans and Democrats spent much of the day locked in statistical battle over which classes of Americans benefited most and least from the Republican tax breaks.
Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, which produced the bill, said three-quarters of the tax cuts would go to households and the remaining 25 percent to "job creation," which is to say corporations. And three-quarters of the biggest tax break, the child credit to families, would fall to households earning less than $75,000, he said.
Democrats unfurled their own calculations: that taxpayers earning $200,000 would get an average break of $11,266 annually, while a $30,000-a-year family would net a paltry $124 a year.
Regardless, the practical effect would be to undo much of the $240 billion in higher taxes that the Clinton Administration and a Democratic Congress imposed for a five-year stretch in 1993. Republicans lost no time in pointing that out today.
"Join us in righting the wrongs of '93," cried Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority whip whose duty was to round up enough votes to pass the bill.
Mr. Archer said: "When this bill is passed, the tax-raising legacy of President Clinton and his party will officially be over."
The debate that began at midmorning, unrolled past sunset and droned long into the night, was at times passionate. But mostly, it bore the air of an argument with a foregone conclusion -- a chance not to change minds, but to lay out in stark terms basic differences in economic policies, and to play to powerful constituencies.
The Democratic argument was simple: We are the party of the working man; they are the party of the rich.
"For 16 years, all but the top fifth of Americans have seen their wages fall and their standard of living decay," said Mr. Gephardt of Missouri. "Each of us was elected to do the greater good, not to line the pockets of the wealthiest Americans. But that is exactly what the Republican bill does. Nearly half the benefits go to taxpayers earning $100,000 a year or more."
The Republican argument was equally spare: We are the party of economic opportunity; they represent Big Government.
"We provide fuel for the engine that pulls the train of economic growth by cutting capital gains taxes, repealing the alternative minimum tax, and by changing expensing for small business," Mr. Archer said. "The Democrats, who never met a tax they didn't hike, will again go off the deep end complaining about tax cuts. I have a simple message for the Democrats: it's not your money. It's the taxpayers' money.
The Democrats lost their best chance to thwart the tax bill at midafternoon when they lost the procedural vote on the legislative rule that set the terms of the floor debate.
All week, Mr. Gingrich and other Republican leaders had openly fretted over the prospect that the Republican factions unhappy with parts of the bill might use the procedural vote to express their dissatisfaction. One faction wanted to restrict the biggest tax break, for families with children, to middle-income taxpayers. Others opposed a clause that raised the pension contributions of Federal workers, or simply argued that granting tax breaks would make it harder to reduce the Federal deficit.
Had the groups united with Democrats to defeat the procedural rule, the tax bill would have remained bottled in committee, presumably until it was changed to make it more palatable. But when the vote came, only 9 of the 230 Republicans bolted and opposed the rule, and they were more than offset by 11 Democrats who joined the Republican majority.
The second vote was a foregone conclusion. Scores of Democrats deserted the party and joined Republicans to vote against the tax bill written by Mr. Gephardt.
Mr. Gephardt's substitute would have granted a far-smaller array of tax breaks, totaling $32 billion over five years, to help middle-income households that are facing college expenses or who are building retirement savings. Most of the cost of the tax breaks would have been offset by a $27.3 billion cut in Federal spending.
If Republicans advertised the tax cut as an investment in the nation's economic future -- some wore buttons proclaiming "Do it for our children!" -- the measure also fulfills the fondest tax-code aspirations of the party's most conservative and influential interests.
The religious right and other social conservatives won the tax credit for children. Families that care for an elderly member in their homes would receive another $500 tax credit. The party's anti-abortion wing secured a $5,000 tax credit for families earning less than $60,000 a year who adopt a child. That credit phases out at $100,000 in earnings.
The business interests who make up the party's core supporters were given more favorable terms for writing off the cost of equipment purchases. The bill does away with the alternative minimum tax, designed to catch profitable corporations that use loopholes to escape tax liability.
Investors and the financial companies that serve them won a lower rate on personal capital gains, new tax breaks for retirement accounts and an increase, to $750,000 from $600,000 in the amount of assets that can be shielded from estate and gift taxes.
According to the Treasury Department, those and other breaks would cost the Government $189 billion in lost tax revenue by 2000, and $630 billion by 2005. Republicans would pay for the first five years primarily by cutting $100 billion from the projected $2.7 trillion in spending on discretionary programs like highways, education and environmental cleanup. Which programs would be cut has yet to be decided.
Another $65 billion would come from changes in welfare programs that passed the House last month. And the remainder would be collected by raising Federal workers' pension contributions, making several temporary cuts in the Medicare program permanent, and selling off the rights to use difference frequencies of the broadcast spectrum.

(Associated Press) (pg. B10)

HEADLINE: Tarkwa Journal;
Land Is Made of Gold, but Jobs Are Precious Few

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TARKWA, Ghana

 BODY:
Nine years ago, when Lucien Gerard began prospecting in the scrubby hill country on the edge of this old mining town, officials of Ghana's antiquated gold industry smirked at the thought of gullible Americans taking over what everyone here assumed to be a marginal property.
"It was sort of like a joke to them," Mr. Gerard said on the veranda of his white villa, which sits on a hilltop overlooking outsize earth movers that eat away day and night at the mountainsides below. "Look at the Americans pouring money into a low-grade area thinking they know what they are doing." 
 Indeed, the skeptics had their day in the slow early years of Mr. Gerard's company, Teberibie Goldfields, when, rather than digging for the gold nuggets commonly found just underground across much of this country, a small team of expatriates took their time methodically testing rock samples and surveying the hillsides.
But nowadays, with an annual production of more than 250,000 ounces and an estimated $350,000 a day in revenue, few feel anything but envy toward what has rapidly become Ghana's second-largest gold mining operation, ranking just behind the Lonrho corporation's huge Ashanti Goldfields Company.
"We figure we have about 6.7 million ounces of known reserves here," said Mr. Gerard, a leather-skinned Long Islander who is managing director of Teberibie, a subsidiary of the Pioneer Group, a Boston-based investment company. "That's a little bit deceptive, though, because every time we sink a new hole, we find more gold."
Teberibie's operations have been at the forefront of a mining boom that has swept much of this region, touching no place more than Ghana, whose colonial name was the Gold Coast.
Taking advantage of efforts throughout the region to open up long-closed economies, mining outfits from the United States, Canada, Australia and South Africa have rushed into the area over the last two years to start up new mines or take over old ones in Mali, Burkina Faso, Ivory Coast and a handful of other West African countries.
Ashanti, a formerly state-owned mine that was privatized last May, has taken off in Ghana under the management of Lonrho, the operation's largest shareholder. Like Teberibie, its annual production has jumped. It amounts to 1.4 million ounces now, up from 300,000 ounces less than a decade ago.
The explosive growth of Ashanti has led the company to branch out and compete with big outsiders for new contracts in the region. In January, the Ghanaian giant won the rights to develop a major new mine in Mali.
"There have been mines in Ghana for hundreds of years, but in the past 10 or 12 years this has been seen as an emerging market, because the sector had been dormant for decades," said John A. Clarke, executive director of Ashanti Goldfields. "Now we are seeing other African countries decide to use their mineral sector as an engine for development. We've already been there, so we feel we have an advantage over our competitors."
As impressive as the Ashanti Goldfields record has been since privatization, mining experts say newer operations with more advanced mining methods represent the wave of the future because they require 60 percent fewer workers per ounce of production.
At Teberibie, rather than digging deep for rich veins, surface rock is fed into a conveyor-belt crusher. The resulting pebbles are washed on the plastic-draped hillsides in a cyanide solution that spurts from an intricate sprinkler system. Finally, the ore is extracted from another solution using electrolysis.
Where one might imagine the sound of pickaxes and shovels burrowing into a deep mine pit, virtually the only workers to be seen on Teberibie's 16-square-mile site are the drivers of trucks with tires as tall as a man that roll back and forth across the moonscape carrying ever more quarry to the automated crusher.
"We recover gold from rock that holds as little as a half a gram per ton," Mr. Gerard said proudly. "You don't see any gold until we're ready to pour the bars. That's what you call getting the squeak out of the pig."
But if such technological prowess cheers shareholders, many in this old mining region wonder if the march of progress is intended to deprive them of jobs.
"It used to be that when any mining site opened up, people would come from far and wide to look for work," said John Quarko, a retired manganese miner who now washes cars in the lot of Tarkwa's one motel. "It seems these new companies that are coming in are only interested in hiring watchmen and computer people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gold-mining is a robust activity in Ghana, but new technology means fewer jobs at plants where automated equipment crushes slabs of rock. (Robert Grossman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ex-Members Of Gang See Defeat at Polls In Chicago

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 5

 BODY:
After weeks of tense and sometimes ugly campaigning, two former street gang members running for the City Council were handily defeated at the polls on Tuesday.
But today, as the backers of Mayor Richard M. Daley were celebrating his easy re-election to a third term, the young supporters of the gang candidates were promising better organized campaigns. We will keep trying, one vowed, "until we win and take us some power." 
 About a month ago, the two newcomers from the bleak housing projects and broken boulevards of the city's South Side had shaken the political establishment by forcing the incumbents into run-off elections in neighborhoods hard hit for years by unemployment, drugs and neglect.
Both the newcomers were backed by a political group with ties to the state's largest street gang, Gangster Disciples. Gang members by the dozens were recruited, trained and dressed in new shirts and ties and sent into the streets as political foot soldiers, passing out campaign literature and driving voters to the polls in a fleet of rented vans, a rolling display of democracy, Chicago style.
"We learned a lot about how politics works," said Mike Johnson, a 20-year-old volunteer in the campaign of the former gang member Wallace (Gator) Bradley. "We ain't going nowhere. We're going to keep fighting until we win and take us some power. That's the American way, right?"
One of the incumbents who survived Tuesday was Shirley Coleman of the 16th Ward. In what was considered to be a close race, Ms. Coleman beat the other former gang member, Hal Baskin, by a margin of 2 to 1. In an interview today, Ms. Coleman acknowledged the concerns and discontent of the young.
"This election," she said, "gives us a challenge to involve young people in the political process without them having turn to the gang image to do that."
Alderman Dorothy Tillman, who defeated Mr. Bradley by a margin of 2 to 1 in the Third Ward, said today that her victory was a clear message from the people to the gangs and their supporters.
"We're saying to the Bradleys of the world, leave our children alone," she said. "I'm fighting for the minds of our children. A parent can't compete with someone who is buying their children Nikes."
In addition to being a former gang member, Mr. Bradley is also a former prison inmate. In the city primary in February, he was one of five former convicts running for the City Council, a record number of convicted felons seeking public office in Chicago.
Only one of the five, Walter Burnett Jr., who served two years in prison for bank robbery, was able to win a council seat. He won over Wallace Davis 3d, the son of a former alderman who was sent to prison several years ago on corruption charges.
Mr. Burnett was endorsed and helped to victory by what is left of the once mighty Chicago Democratic machine, which also carried Mayor Daley to his victory.
Mr. Bradley and Mr. Baskin, who works for an anti-violence program in a public school, were opposed by loose coalition of regular Democrats and civil rights workers who cut their political teeth fighting City Hall. The two men were hurt at the polls by their rash statements and because of doubts about their ties to gangs, which continue to send people to the cemeteries and hospital rooms in this city.
The campaign between Mr. Bradley and Alderman Tillman had been one of the most widely watched in the city in an election when most Chicago voters stayed home.
Mr. Bradley, who is a 43-year-old grandfather, was a former enforcer for the Gangster Disciples. But he has also been heavily involved in the national gang truce movement.
Although, the police in Chicago and several other cities denounce that effort as a charade, youth workers like Autry Harrison of the Boys and Girls Club in the Robert Taylor public housing development say the truce movement and Mr. Bradley's role in it should be praised.
"There's less killing now, no doubt about it," Mr. Harrison said. "Gator is a big part of that. I wish he had won. He couldn't do no worse than who we got now."
Mr. Bradley and his supporters ordered 300 shirts, ties, skirts and blouses for his campaign workers to wear in place of their normal hooded sweat shirts and other clothes associated with the city's street gangs. Many of the young men, however, still wore their pants baggy and low around their hips.
On Tuesday, Mr. Bradley drove through his stronghold in Robert Taylor, checking on his workers.
"We don't want to do anything that will intimidate the voters," Mr. Bradley said, explaining why the ties were ordered. "We didn't have the ties for the primary. We learned."
Mr. Bradley saw a teen-age campaign worker dressed in a flowered colored shirt opened at the neck.
"You should put a tie on that," Mr. Bradley said.
"We ran out of ties," the boy said.

The campaign poster of one of them, Wallace (Gator) Bradley, remained yesterday near the Robert Taylor public housing development. (Todd Buchanan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Cheating the Reformers: Ins and Outs of Welfare

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
SHON-DU has a little bulletin for the Mayor. He can crack down on welfare, impose all the rules he wants, fingerprint both of Shon-du's hands and put him through workfare hoops from here to his home in Brownsville and back. The Mayor can do that and more, but Shon-du will still manage to beat the system because he knows it inside out.
"They can't win," said the 27-year-old Brooklynite, who will only allow himself to be identified by his street name. "I'm ahead of them." 
 Shon-du was standing on the sunny steps of 330 Jay Street in Brooklyn one day this week, passing the time while his girlfriend applied for benefits upstairs. Jay Street is welfare central, the place where new applicants for Home Relief undergo their Employment Verification Review as part of the Giuliani administration's stepped-up effort to root out fraud and put welfare recipients to work.
Jay Street seemed the perfect place to get some firsthand testimony from people having trouble with the new system, which requires the "able bodied" on Home Relief to work 23 hours a week. Many on Home Relief are shaky people, disabled, addicted or so unfamiliar with work that workfare is anathema to them. The vast majority are legitimately in need, and adjusting to a new policy can be difficult. But on this particular day, Shon-du was at 330 Jay Street -- one of a small minority in the system, but just the kind of welfare cheat Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wants to throw off the rolls.
"I only got on welfare because it's easy," Shon-du explained. "Then, when you get used to it, you become addicted. Truly, I don't need it." Shon-du says it's been two years since he went on Home Relief, the welfare program for childless adults -- those presumed the most able to work. Shon-du can work. He is working.
IN fact, he has two jobs. "I'm loan sharking -- I won't lie," he admits, nearly two hours into our talk. He lends money to welfare clients, at 100 percent interest. "They come to me for drugs, Pampers, food, because they have no bank." He has the money for loan sharking because he saved up when he was a drug dealer and because of his other enterprise: he uses some of his welfare payments -- $176 twice a month, and another $116 a month in food stamps -- to help him buy counterfeit jeans and T-shirts.
"We go to the black market and get designer stuff," he said. "The stores in Chinatown, they got fronts." Shon-du has no peddler's license, so he borrows a van and sells his goods in Baltimore, where he won't get hassled by the police. "They see you're not selling crack, they give you some respect," he said.
He figures that if his girlfriend gets on welfare, he can get off and spend more time working.
Why not just go straight right now? "It takes money to put yourself in business." More money than he has, though he has more than he should to receive welfare -- about $8,000 stowed away, he claims.
THE Giuliani administration says it is investigating fraud more aggressively and will eventually catch up with the Shon-dus of the city. "I think we have a system with about as much integrity as you can build in," said Richard J. Schwartz, senior mayoral adviser. "We have found a significant number of people trying to defraud the system."
They have not found Shon-du yet, and he is not alone, he suggested. "A lot of these men can work," he said. "Welfare ain't enough, but it's a base."
Some of his friends are working for him, he said. All of them would lose their benefits if the authorities got wise. "But it's all off the books, so it's hard to prove." Shon-du says he keeps the welfare bureaucrats happy by keeping his appointments and doing his paper work. He even held a workfare job in the pre-Giuliani days. He worked in building maintenance for a year, hoping to get a full-time job. It never came through. Now Shon-du is on 30-day medical leave, exempt from workfare because of hemorrhoids, from which he really does suffer (though, he concedes, he can work).
"Workfare don't work, because they don't give you the job," he said. "They said in six months they'll get you a job, and then they don't. If they would give me a permanent job just mopping floors, I'd go to work. You know the best way to get rid of cheating? Guarantee every welfare recipient a job."
That's the funny thing about Shon-du. He works hard at his scams, but this former drug dealer and crack addict, smart enough to give up drugs, is also smart enough to know that he is functioning on the edges of society. For all his talk, this articulate young man with the copy of "The Autobiography of Malcolm X" under his arm and spotless new Nikes -- "I got me new shoes from hustling" -- keeps returning to his dream. It has nothing to do with hustling.
"I want into the construction union," he said. "They call me, and I'm out of here. That's my future. I just need an opportunity. I got so much power and control in my neighborhood, you'd be surprised. But I see better things in life. I'd rather be totally legitimate. I'm praying to get into the union. That's my way out of this misery."

HEADLINE: Tax-Cutters Finish First;
Gingrich Alters the Context of U.S. Politics, But the Power Lies With Clinton and Dole

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
With the passage tonight of a $189 billion tax-cut measure by the House of Representatives, Speaker Newt Gingrich has all but completed his self-decreed 100 days in the center ring of American politics.
He calls the tax bill the crowning jewel of his Contract With America. But for all his considerable achievements in the last three months, he lacks the power to assure that Americans will keep more of their paychecks. In a nice piece of political congruence, that power lies to a large degree with the two men considered most likely to compete for the White House next fall: President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader. 
 Both will inevitably hear the echoes of recent Presidential campaigns, when a permissive line on taxes has often proved fatal, as they weigh their strategies and ponder their impact on the campaign ahead. One thing is clear to them and to most other leading politicians here: Like Ronald Reagan a decade ago, Mr. Gingrich and his young followers in the House have succeeded by their boldness in drastically altering the context of American politics.
Now more than ever, it is perilous for politicians to oppose lower taxes.
"The days of tax and spend are over," said Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, in today's House debate. "The days of smaller government and less taxes are at hand."
Fewer and fewer people here are disposed to argue with him.
Yes, the mood of the Senate remains less fiery than that in the House. If the Senate passes a tax-cut bill, it will almost surely be less sweeping and less tilted toward rich taxpayers. But there is now a real possibility of a Senate bill, and that in itself represents a big change in the last two weeks.
On March 19, Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who heads the Finance Committee, dismissed the idea of a tax cut with these words: "The best thing we can do for the taxpayers of this country is just try to move toward deficit reduction. And if that gets their mortgage rates down a point or two, that is more important than anything else that we can do."
Only two weeks later, he and Mr. Dole, whose views Mr. Packwood is widely believed to reflect, are singing a different song. Over the weekend Mr. Packwood talked not about a choice between cutting the deficit and cutting taxes but about the prospect of finding "room for a tax cut" within a balanced budget. Never mind what he had said before; never mind what revenue experts have said.
The country as a whole remains deeply divided on taxes. In the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, for example, 41 percent of the respondents said that the country could afford a tax cut now and 55 percent said it could not.
What has changed, of course, is the political atmosphere on Capitol Hill, and the person who has changed it the most is Newt Gingrich. When some House Republicans balked at his plan, he stood fast and said that, in the end, they would not dare to kill a tax cut.
He was right; most of the rebels caved in, some telling each other that the Senate would block the Gingrich proposal.
Perhaps, but the Senate breathes the same political air as the House. And Bob Dole cannot help but recall what happened to him in New Hampshire in 1988 as he looks forward to the first primary of his new Presidential bid, in that same state.
Seven years ago, George Bush stunned Mr. Dole, then the front-runner for the Republican nomination, by running television commercials that positioned the Senator on the "wrong" side of the tax issue in a state whose leading newspaper has made a decades-long crusade for lower taxes. The advertisements said: "Bob Dole straddled, and he just won't promise not to raise taxes. You know what that means."
Mr. Dole, beaten, lashed out at Mr. Bush on television for "lying" about his record, and he never regained his momentum. Many times since then, he has vowed that he would never allow the same thing to happen to him again, and if he does not produce a tax-cut bill this year, his rivals for the nomination, notably Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, will surely pounce on him sooner or later.
On the other hand, Mr. Dole must take care that in seeking to insulate himself against attack from the right he does not lose the moderate voters whom he would need in November. It is the classic conundrum that faces those who seek the Presidency, made all the more difficult for Mr. Dole by his work as majority leader, which requires him to take public positions on everything.
Mr. Clinton is fighting the House plan, trying to portray it as untimely and irresponsible. Today, he told reporters in an impromptu news conference, "I do not think it is wise to have a tax cut of this magnitude." He said he hoped the Senate would produce something better.
Although Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and the budget director, Alice M. Rivlin, said on Tuesday that they would urge him to veto anything resembling the House measure, the President declared, "I do not want a pile of vetoes."
Nor does he want to get on the unprofitable side of the tax-cut debate. His own experience has shown him how painful that can be.
During the 1992 campaign, a rival for the Democratic nomination, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas, talked of the need for pain and sacrifice to bring the deficit under control, while Mr. Clinton promised a middle-class tax cut. Mr. Clinton prevailed. But then in 1993, as President, he chose instead to back a package that, while including modest tax increases, actually made a sizeable dent in the deficit. He got no political credit for that from the voters as the Republicans drubbed his party in 1994.
So, as 1995 approaches, Mr. Clinton, too, has every reason to sign on to a tax cut that he can describe as his own moderate, responsible alternative.
Whatever the economic merits of the situation, however much all this may look like a replay of Reaganomics, which wildly inflated the national debt, the political imperative is clear: tax-cutters win elections.
