HEADLINE: Stocks Close Mixed as Dow Retreats by 1.04, to 4,200.57

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday as gains in telecommunication shares and a rebound in technology issues balanced weakness in the dollar.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.04 points, at 4,200.57, after breaking 4,200 on Tuesday for the first time. Among broader market measures, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, which closed at an all-time high of 505.24 on Tuesday, eked out a gain of 0.33 point yesterday, to 505.57. The Nasdaq composite index, which includes many technology and telecommunications stocks, rose 2.60 points, to 816.32 
 On Tuesday, the Dow's advance meant the average had risen 9.6 percent so far this year. "People would have been pleased with this performance at the end of the year, much less in the first three months." said Peter DaPuzzo, senior trader at Cantor, Fitzgerald & Company. But as was evident yesterday, investors are concerned that their stocks are poised to fall after rising too far, too fast, he said.
One reason is the continuing weakness in the dollar. The currency slumped close to its postwar lows against the Japanese yen again yesterday even though the Bank of Japan, the Federal Reserve and other central banks stepped in to buy dollars. Later in the day, the dollar settled at 86.20 yen, unchanged from Tuesday. A weak dollar makes American stocks less attractive to foreign investors.
"The market is concerned with the dollar," said Alan Ackerman, a market strategist at Fahnestock & Company. "There is a sense that the dollar's weakness might postpone some foreign investors' commitments to equities."
Shares of telecommunications companies rose after Craig McCaw and his family said they would invest as much as $1.1 billion in Nextel Communications Inc. Technology stocks regained ground they lost on Tuesday, amid renewed confidence that company earnings will continue to grow.
"In the short term, everyone knows the techs' earnings look good," said Jim Benning, a trader at BT Brokerage. Still, "people tend to look out six months, and they're beginning to wonder how long the techs will sustain their growth -- especially if the economy starts to slow down."
Sybase Inc., which set off the Tuesday's slide in technology stocks, led the advance. The computer software company's shares plunged 41 percent on Tuesday after it announced it expected to earn 3 cents a share in the first quarter, a fraction of the 29 cents forecast by some analysts. The shares rose 1 3/8 yesterday, to 24 3/8..
Other technology stocks also recouped their losses. The Intel Corporation gained 1/16 , to 86 5/8, after dipping as low as 113/16 , and the Microsoft Corporation rose 3/4, to 70 5/8.
Adobe Systems Inc. jumped 2 1/2, to 50 3/4. Apple Computer Inc. was up 7/8, to 34 3/4.
"They've been knocking them down so much, at some point investors are going to find them reasonably priced again," Mr. Benning said.
Chemical stocks gained along with Du Pont, shares of which climbed 1 1/2, to 63 1/8, after adding 1 percent yesterday. The Seagram Company plans to announce by tomorrow an agreement to sell its 25 percent stake in Du Pont back to the company. Seagram gained 1/8, to 28 5/8.
Trading volume fell to 317.6 million, from 330.6 million on Tuesday. That is down from the average 332.2 million shares traded daily since the beginning of this year.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The Battle of the Studies: Is there competition at Nasdaq?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
IS Nasdaq a cartel, or does it just compete on some other basis than the narrowness of the spread at which stocks are quoted? Yesterday, Nasdaq and a group of market-makers released studies that they say prove that suspicions of collusion on pricing are unwarranted.
Until last year, the idea that Nasdaq was uncompetitive would have seemed absurd. There are about 400 market-makers -- brokers who stand ready to buy or sell Nasdaq stocks -- and it is common to see 10 or more of them listing prices on any given stock. 
 But then came a 1994 study by two economists, William Christie of Vanderbilt University and Paul Schultz of Ohio State University, which found that many Nasdaq stocks almost never were quoted in "odd-eighths," rather than in even-eighths like one-quarter or one-half dollar. Clearly, if some stocks are never quoted in odd-eighths, then the spread between what the dealer will pay for the stock, and what he will charge to sell it, must be at least 25 cents. The economists said they could find no other explanation for that other than to hypothesize collusion between market-makers.
That conclusion brought a Justice Department investigation and a private antitrust suit against 33 Nasdaq market-making firms. It also set Nasdaq to work sponsoring two studies, whose conclusions were released yesterday. A separate study was paid for by the market-makers. All the studies are slated to be discussed today at a conference at Vanderbilt.
"There is much less here than meets the eye," said Merton Miller, the Nobel Prize-winning economist from the University of Chicago, one of the people retained by Nasdaq for a study. "They stumbled onto a well-known phenomenon known as clustering," in which prices are more likely to be quoted at round numbers.
He said a study by him and four colleagues found similar clustering in several foreign markets. Mr. Miller conceded that there was somewhat less clustering on the New York Stock Exchange, but argued that was because specialists -- market-makers on the Big Board -- were given economic incentives to have orderly markets that moved only one-eighth of a dollar at a time.
The other study sponsored by Nasdaq was performed by Dean Furbush of Economics Inc., who argued that "the market structure makes any collusion inconceivable." He pointed to the large number of market-makers, and the ease of entry into the business, as proof. Mr. Furbush formerly worked for the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodities Future Trading Commission.
The study for the market-makers, by Allan Kleidon of the Stanford Law School and Robert D. Willig, a Princeton economist and former official of the Justice Department's antitrust division, concluded that competitive economic factors accounted for the evident discrepancies found by Mr. Christie and Mr. Schultz, and argued that when adjusted for such factors the Big Board was just as likely to avoid odd-eighths quotes. They added that "it would be prohibitively difficult to establish and maintain collusion on Nasdaq" in part because it is so easy for others to become market-makers in a certain stock and undermine a cartel.
All of this would be so much academic quibbling if the stakes were not so high in antitrust suits. Mr. Christie, in a telephone interview, said that the latest studies were clearly brought on by the lawsuits and that "there is a distinction here between what we said, and what the lawyers said" in bringing the suits.
He said that when he and Mr. Schultz used the term collusion, they referred to it in terms of "implicit collusion" contained in a branch of economics called game theory. "It is not in anyone's best interest to narrow the spread," he said.
It is possible that when all is said and done, that might be the conclusion reached by all. For a variety of reasons, the current structure of the Nasdaq market does not provide much, if any, additional business to a market-maker who improves his quote on a stock. All other market-makers simply match the quote. There does appear to be intense competition between market-makers, but it is focused in other areas, like service, a willingness to buy or sell large blocks of stock and, in some cases, payment to brokers for sending orders to a particular market-maker.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
South Korea Strives for a Market in Latin America

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: IQUITOS, Peru

 BODY:
To supply his new Daewoo dealership here, Moon Hyun Kim has drivers ferry South Korean cars over the Andes and then down jungle rivers to this bustling metropolis in the heart of the Amazon.
"In the last two years, Daewoo has opened 24 car distributors around Peru," said Mr. Kim in Lima, his command post for the South Korean conglomerate's export assault on this small market. One year after arriving from a Daewoo post in Carlstadt, N.J., the manager has peppered Peru's capital with 14 billboards, helping his company win 22 percent of the national car market. 
 Latin America is the only region of the world where the United States still ships more goods then it imports. But its status as the No. 1 exporter to the region is under heavy attack by aggressive Asian manufacturers. Asia's top five trading powers -- Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan and China -- recently supplanted Western Europe as Latin America's second-largest trading partner, after the United States.
Among the Asians, South Korea seems to be the most determined to carve out a chunk of a market that American manufacturers long took for granted as their own backyard. In addition to exporting cars, televisions, telephones and other consumer electronics, large South Korean companies are opening production plants in Latin America.
"In the 1950's and 1960's, Latin America was an American monopoly," Mr. Kim of Daewoo recounted in his American English learned in New Jersey. "In the 1980's, the Japanese started to take market share. Now, over the last four years, Korean manufacturers have been coming on very strong."
South Korea's drive into Latin America is partly a result of the growing reach of the Asian country's huge chaebols, or conglomerates. Flush with bumper profits, the chaebols doubled their overseas foreign investments last year, according to the Bank of Korea.
Much South Korean investment is aimed at using Mexico as a duty-free springboard into the United States market. Daewoo is preparing to assemble cars, refrigerators and washing machines in Mexico. Last year, Lucky Goldstar doubled its television production capacity at its Mexican plant.
But the South Koreans also aim to sell to Latin America, a region that in recent years has enjoyed the world's second-highest economic growth rates, after Southeast Asia.
"Normally, the Korean Government and the Korean companies have put a low priority on Latin America -- but that is changing fast," said Hyung Ho Lee, Peru director of Kotra, South Korea's official trade promotion agency.
Almost overnight -- actually, in the last 18 months -- South Korean cars have emerged as the best-selling imports in Peru, Brazil and Colombia.
"There is a great market for four-wheel drives down here, but American companies can't be bothered, so the Koreans flood the place," a United States Embassy economist complained in Lima.
In Brazil, which imports as many cars in one month as Peru imports in a year, Asia Motors and Kia Motors are the top importers. Rio de Janeiro's police department uses 50 new Kia vans. In addition, Hyundai is establishing a nationwide network of 25 dealerships. Alarmed by surging car imports, Brazil recently raised its tariff on such vehicles to 70 percent from 20 percent in February.
For Brazil, Latin America's largest market, Goldstar is planning to build a $50 million consumer electronics plant near Sao Paulo, and Samsung is planning a $32 million videocassette recorder plant in Manaus. Samsung is already producing fax machines and cellular phones in Brazil. Last month, Daewoo televisions went on sale here.
In Colombia, Daewoo started building buses last year. With thousands of South Korean cars clogging the streets of Bogota, Daewoo and Hyundai are studying the next step -- producing cars in Colombia.
In the last six months, Samsung, the largest chaebol, announced plans to build a $400 million television factory near Tijuana, Mexico; bought 15 percent of Entel, a Chilean telephone company, and started to negotiate huge purchases of gold and tin in Bolivia.
Expanding beyond cars and consumer electronics, South Korean companies are studying investments in Peru's oil, telecommunications and electricity generation sectors.
"There are very few American car companies here -- for Ford or G.M., Peru is not very important, they have a big market at home," said Mr. Kim of Daewoo. "Peru is a very small market. But for us, it is a very good market."
As ties with this Pacific Basin nation increase, South Korean money is flowing into company sponsorships and foreign aid projects -- areas that once were the domain of American companies and of the United States Government.
Goldstar, a major South Korean electronics supplier here, is the official sponsor of Alianza Lima, a club soccer team that often wins national championships. After Peru's President, Alberto K. Fujimori, visited Seoul in 1993, Peru granted South Korea a free port in return for an $18 million million grant to renovate the airport of Cuzco, Peru's major tourist destination. Not far behind the aid money, Daewoo recently opened a car dealership in Cuzco.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Daewoo, the South Korean auto maker, is making a big push in Peru, seeking to challenge long-established United States manufacturers. Salespeople chat on the floor of the Daewoo dealership in Lima, Peru. (Vera Lentz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Essay;
Bashing the Spooks

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The C.I.A. is defending the indefensible and failing to defend the defensible.
When the columnist Mary McGrory of The Washington Post criticized in passing "their most egregious and expensive blunder about the Soviet economy," the acting Director, Adm. William O. Studeman, huffed: "The most objectionable piece of fiction is the canard that the intelligence community's analysis of the Soviet economy was wrong. . . . The facts have been on the public record for any journalist who cares to do her homework." 
 The homework-skipper is the admiral. In 1988, when the C.I.A. made public its estimate that the Soviet G.N.P. was about half of ours, and that less than 16 percent of the Soviet economy was devoted to arms production, academics like Harry Rowan, Charles Wolf, Anders Aslund and Richard Ericson took sharp issue.
I went across the river to Director of Central Intelligence Bill Webster's office armed with their opposing view: that the Soviet G.N.P. figures were phony, that its economy was half its C.I.A.-estimated size, and that the portion going to arms was an unsustainable 30 percent, compared with 6 percent in the U.S. That would mean Moscow was on the brink of economic meltdown.
The assembled C.I.A. experts pooh-poohed this. When I suggested a "Team B" to challenge the C.I.A. evaluation, Director Webster looked toward his deputy, Robert Gates, who scornfully said, "It's the same different view." No independent assessment was permitted -- might hurt community morale, you know -- and the projections in Judy Sheldon's book "The Coming Soviet Crash" were brushed aside.
Result: The C.I.A. failed to alert the President and Congress about the inexorable Soviet collapse. The present D.C.I., in his starched white outfit wishing it all away, is in a curious state of institutional denial.
Now shift gears. After the fallout from the Ames affair and the resignation of Director Jim Woolsey, the agency faces months of headlines about its support of the Guatemalan Government -- especially its payments to an informant within the Government who has been "linked" by a Democratic Congressman to the deaths of an American citizen and an insurgent leader.
The New York Times promptly thundered editorial condemnation of the C.I.A.'s "disgraceful covert relationship with Guatemalan military thugs." President Clinton is displeased with the agency's apparent end run. Spook-bashers are salivating at the prospect of stories about abuses of secrecy, opening the way to whacks at the intelligence budget.
This has deep roots; two generations of liberals have been infuriated by our support of anti-Communist regimes in Central and South America. From the coup in 1954 that threw out Arbenz in Guatemala to the defeat of leftists in El Salvador and Nicaragua in the late 80's, C.I.A. agents carried out their assignment of helping stop the spread of Castro's Communism in our neighborhood.
Thanks partly to those C.I.A. covert operations, we won -- often messily, sometimes undemocratically, on occasion scandalously. But real war was being waged, and the alternative outcome -- Soviet-Cuban hegemony up to our Mexican border -- would have been far worse for democracy and human rights.
U.S. policy was the opposite of imperialism, and most C.I.A. operatives were not the villains or blunderers many in the media made them out to be.
Now, as the next wave of revulsion rolls in, we have to ask: Should we ever hire informers, none of whom would be played by Victor McLaglen? Do we hold ourselves responsible for all that these sleazy characters subsequently do?
Easy to say "stay clean." But if a C.I.A. operative claims he can recruit an informant inside the Hezbollah; or buy a line into the presidential palace in Pyongyang; or asks permission to guarantee safe haven to a military clique in Baghdad if a coup fails -- should the next D.C.I. insist that such inside sources not be describable as thugs?
Good ends do not justify evil means, but such dirty tricks that would save thousands of lives gain some moral coloration. Reform the C.I.A., but don't reform away its covert capacity.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Were the Government's mileage standards for cars a mistake?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
GOVERNMENT regulation is under harsh attack these days. So why has there been so little criticism of what was once among the most controversial interventions by Big Brother: corporate average fuel economy standards for new cars and trucks?
If only it were because the mileage standards worked so well that skeptics were converted to their virtues, everything would be fine. But I don't buy it. Indeed, Pietro Nivola and Robert Crandall, senior fellows at the Brookings Institution, argue in a new book, "The Extra Mile" (20th Century Fund), that the regulations have proved to be an exceptionally wasteful means of conservation. The story of how Americans learned to stop worrying and live with the mileage standards is a cautionary tale of our times. 
 The CAFE (Corporate Average Fuel Efficiency) standard was born in the midst of the first energy shock of the 1970's. Higher fuel taxes were considered, but Congress rejected any increases. Only later were gasoline taxes increased and then only by token amounts.
Much of the opposition to higher taxes was at least nominally linked to fairness. It wasn't right, said Republicans and Democrats alike, to conserve oil at the expense of poor people, long- distance commuters and rural areas.
Environmentalists, however, offered a rationale for opposing taxes that touched a responsive chord among efficiency-minded economists. Consumers and auto makers were myopic, the argument went. Hardly anyone would voluntarily pay for high mileage cars, even if the savings at the pump more than offset the cost.
The average fuel economy for each auto maker's new car fleet was set at 18 miles a gallon for 1978, ramping up to 27.5 for 1985. And while Detroit initially opposed the standards, CAFE has become a widely accepted part of the regulatory landscape. "The standards did what they were supposed to do," says David L. Greene, a researcher at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory.
By one measure, at least, they did: The fuel efficiency of new cars has nearly doubled since the early 1970's. But by other benchmarks, the consequences are less clear-cut. Total consumption of oil is up, largely because growth in the number of vehicle-miles traveled has more than offset the improved efficiency of the auto fleet.
The explanation is obvious. More efficient cars use less fuel per mile driven and since prices at the pump (adjusted for inflation) are roughly they same as in the early 1980's, the average cost of driving an extra mile has actually fallen.
That, however, doesn't necessarily mean fuel efficiency standards were a mistake. If auto makers had not been forced to improve mileage, Americans would undoubtedly be consuming even more gasoline today. A better test, then, is how much Americans have paid in higher sticker prices and diminished performance. And here estimates range from 30 to 60 cents a gallon of fuel saved.
Is a small margin of protection against blackmail by Mideast oil exporters (along with a modest reduction in air pollution and traffic congestion) worth this price? Hard to say. What Mr. Nivolla and Mr. Crandall have no hesitation saying, however, is that the same ends could have been achieved at one-third the cost by taxing gasoline more substantially.
Recent research suggests that Americans do respond to higher fuel prices, both by driving less and by driving more efficient vehicles. What's more, the equity arguments against taxing fuel now seem overblown. James Poterba, an economist at M.I.T., estimates that outlays for gasoline are roughly proportional to total family spending over a wide range of incomes.
If mileage standards are so problematic, why isn't anyone complaining? Christopher DeMuth, president of the American Enterprise Institute, argues that effective opposition to regulation is usually organized opposition. "Since the auto companies long ago accommodated themselves to CAFE standards," he says, nobody is carrying the banner of freedom from mileage rules, even in this deregulation-minded Congress.
And "accommodation" fails to capture the real advantage the auto companies derive from the rules. Complex regulations generally favor established corporations over newcomers, creating barriers to market entry and opportunities to make extra profits by charging uncompetitive prices. Mr. Crandall argues that the fuel standard limits the number of big, powerful cars sold each year, effectively organizing the large-car market as a cartel. It is no coincidence, then, that the industry has devoted so much attention in recent years to the luxury end of the car market.
There's a powerful lesson here. Don't just look at nominal costs and benefits when measuring the effects of regulations. For once they are on the books, there may be no way of getting rid of them even after they start doing more harm than good.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Let's Make A Deal Is First Order Of Business

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The Montreal Expos began dismantling the major leagues' best team in the strike-shortened 1994 season, trading their No. 1 starting pitcher, Ken Hill, and their No. 1 relief pitcher, John Wetteland yesterday. But their general manager said the moves were not reminiscent of the San Diego Padres' self-destruction a few years ago.
The Expos, faced with paying huge salaries through the injunction-restored salary arbitration procedure, traded Wetteland to the Yankees and Hill back to the St. Louis Cardinals. They received primarily minor league players in return. 
 In another trade related to economics and salary arbitration, the Kansas City Royals sent center fielder Brian McRae to the Chicago Cubs for two minor league pitchers. Both the Expos and the Royals, seeking to slash their payrolls, may make more moves to achieve their aim.
While the trades flowed from the eight-month battle between the owners and the players over the game's economic system, they were also a sign that baseball is back. The last previous trade was the 12-player swap Dec. 28 between the Padres and the Houston Astros.
Clubs also started fueling their signing pens. The Mets signed John Franco, their free-agent reliever, for two years and $5 million, and the Baltimore Orioles signed their catcher, Chris Hoiles, to a five-year, $17.25 million contract.
The Expos won't be signing any of their players to those types of contracts. They have let go Larry Walker, their right fielder, as a free agent -- he is expected to sign with the Colorado Rockies this weekend -- and they may also trade their center fielder, Marquis Grissom.
In 1992 and 1993, the Padres, having finally reached contender status, traded or let go Fred McGriff, Gary Sheffield, Benito Santiago, Tony Fernandez, Randy Myers and Craig Lefferts because their owners wanted to slash the payroll.
"I don't think there's any comparison," Kevin Malone, the Expos' general manager, said by telephone from West Palm Beach, Fla. "You can never compare the situations. We're known for having one of the best scouting and player development systems. We have as many prospects as anyone. We can afford to trade and replace them with prospects. We feel we have quantity and quality. It's not like San Diego. We can move those guys and still keep competitive."
Malone did not boast that the Expos could expect to be as strong as their 74-40 record last year, but he said: "We'll still be good. We're going be younger and less expensive. With younger players, it's hard to predict their production. You're asking a lot when you're banking on young players. But we've done it in the past."
The Expos could have waited to trade Hill, who last season had a career-best 16-5 record, and Wetteland, who has had 105 saves the past three seasons, but they acted under a self-imposed deadline -- tomorrow, the day clubs have to tender contracts to about 100 players who are eligible for salary arbitration.
"We had to do it before the tender date," Malone said. "We could've tendered them, then tried to trade them. But we didn't want to be caught holding the ball. We had to weigh the risk of keeping them and having to pay that money. We felt we had a deadline."
Hill's 1994 salary was $2.55 million, Wetteland's $2,225,000. Salary arbitration could put them in the range of $4 million. The Royals felt equally uncomfortable with the prospect of going to arbitration with McRae, who last season batted .273 and had 28 stolen bases with a $1.9 million salary.
"Each club's going to have to do what they feel is most appropriate in their situation," Herk Robinson, the Royals' general manager, said in a telephone interview. "Brian is not an easy guy to replace, but pitching is a valuable commodity. We've got some good athletes in our organization. It was a decision we made in our best interest."
The Cubs sent the Royals Derek Wallace, who reached Class AAA last season, and Geno Morones, who was a Class A pitcher.
In returning Hill to the Cardinals, where he began his career, the Expos received pitchers Bryan Eversgerd and Kirk Bullinger and outfielder Darond Stovall. Only Eversgerd played in the majors last season, compiling a 2-3 record and a 4.52 earned run average in 40 games. The other two played in Class A.
Mel Rojas, who has substituted for Wetteland as the Expos' closer, will assume that role. The Expos will use one of their young pitchers in Hill's place or sign a lower-priced free-agent pitcher.
"I think there are some bargains on the free-agent market," Malone said.

HEADLINE: Journal of Commerce Sale

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

DATELINE: MIAMI, April 5

 BODY:
Knight-Ridder Inc. said today that it had completed the sale of the Journal of Commerce Inc. to the Economist Group for $115 million. The Economist Group, based in London, publishes The Economist, a weekly current affairs and business magazine. The Journal of Commerce, a daily newspaper based in New York that began publication in 1827, focuses on trade, shipping, transportation, insurance and commodities. Knight-Ridder, based in Miami, has said the sale will increase its second-quarter earnings, but has not disclosed the amount.

HEADLINE: The Met: Power Meets Imagination

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
DO we build museums to honor the muse or to murder her? That question haunts the Met's new show, "The Architecture of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1870-1995." The Met's building gets bigger, its architectural style becomes grander and, as the gleaming walls of white limestone rise higher and higher, you begin to wonder whether the poor muse, that most mercurial of beings, has not been crushed beneath the massive weight of it all. But what a way to go.
Organized by Morrison H. Heckscher, the Met's curator of American decorative arts, the show traces the evolution of the museum's architecture, from the temporary quarters it once occupied on Fifth Avenue and 54th Street (Fortunoff's occupies the site today) to the sprawling labyrinth in Central Park. Presented to mark the 125th anniversary of the Met's founding, this is primarily a study in changing architectural taste. 
 Beyond that, the show depicts the dynamic interplay between power and the imagination, to use the terms the historian Lauro Martines applied to Renaissance Italy. The building of the Met paralleled New York's rise as a global economic force. Art was one of the symbols with which the city proclaimed that force and simultaneously masked it. The art museum declared the city's reverence for higher things than the money it took to build it. The show features designs by seven firms that have sought to express that dual function: to fuse power and imagination into architectural form.
More than a hundred architectural drawings, renderings and sketches depict their changing ideas about how to achieve this goal, and also their periodic efforts to give their often discordant ideas a semblance of unity. To today's eyes, however, it is the disunity of the parts that gives the building its contemporary appeal. The layering of period styles, the collision of parts that don't quite match, the occasional resurfacing of walls and floors buried beneath later additions: perhaps no other building in New York quite captures the contemporary taste for collage and fragmentation.
But the museum has always been a mirror of its time. Calvert Vaux and Jacob Wrey Mould, the designers of the museum's first Central Park building, completed in 1880, used a Victorian Gothic style. The effect was rustic rather than grand, but it was sympathetic to the bridges and other picturesque structures that Vaux designed for Central Park, and it reflected the Romantic view of art as an epiphany of nature.
Serious metropolitan grandeur arrived in 1894 with a design by Richard Morris Hunt, the first American architect trained at the Ecole des Beaux Arts in Paris. Victorian polychromy gave way to white limestone, Gothic windows to classical columns: at last, a Fifth Avenue dress to go with a Fifth Avenue address. With the arrival of McKim, Meade & White in 1904, the dress turned into a wardrobe. Under the supervision of Charles McKim, the museum acquired two new wings, in a subdued version of Hunt's Beaux Arts style. These extended the Fifth Avenue facade from 80th to 84th streets.
Severe black-and-white drawings present the master plan prepared in 1967 by Kevin Roche, the first architect since McKim to reconsider the museum as a whole. The drawings emphasize the low profiles of Mr. Roche's additions, designed to appease those who objected to the museum's continued expansion into the park. They also convey the master plan's admirable clarity. But they scarcely do justice to the feeling of radiance and openness that Mr. Roche brought to the Met.
The handsomest drawings in the show are those in which the muse seems to be guiding the draftsman's hand. Hunt's early sketches, in pencil on tracing paper, have the lightness of clouds; the building seems to be taking hazy shape in the architect's mind. Hugh Ferriss brings a touch of 1940's glamour to his rendering of designs by Robert O'Connor, a young architect who introduced the museum's first modernist designs, including the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in the early 50's. Technical drawings from the late 19th century remind us that the period's technology was often more inspired than its art.
The premise of this show, which runs through Sept. 3, is that the museum's architecture is now complete. This will please park advocates, although, as one section of the show gently points out, the plan to put the museum in its present location originated with Central Park and city officials, not with the museum itself. And it was always understood that the building was not going to be a little boathouse.
The show clears up another popular misconception, about the meaning of those big rough blocks of stone that crown the columns at the museum's entrance. Are they a sublime symbol of becoming, a metaphor for the masterpiece yet to be carved? Not at all. What they symbolize is that, even in the Gilded Age, New York's economic power had limits. The stones, part of Hunt's 1894 plan, were originally supposed to be carved into sculptures; alas, the money ran out. But the happy result of this budgetary miscalculation is that the meaning of the stones is left to the viewer's imagination. And what more eloquent piece of symbolism could an art museum place atop a column? It's pleasing to think that in the encounter between power and imagination, the latter sometimes comes out on top.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
U.S. and Allies Try to Prop Up the Dollar but Fail Again

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
Amid signs of increasing discord with its allies over the sharp fall of the dollar, the United States was joined today by Germany and Japan in largely symbolic moves to bolster the American currency. But once again, the Clinton Administration failed to reverse the dollar's decline.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin later took the unusual step of calling a small group of reporters in Washington to announce that the three countries had been acting in concert and to argue that "in effect what you have is a shared commitment to a strong dollar because it is in our interest and in the interests of the other economies of the world." 
 But the verbal commitment was considerably stronger than the financial one. Currency traders said that the repeated interventions today -- the second time in three days that central banks bought dollars in the market -- were relatively small in scale. The net result was unimpressive: The dollar was unchanged against the Japanese yen, ending the trading day in New York at 86.20 yen to the dollar, just about a half yen above its record lows set earlier this week. Against the German mark, the dollar was quoted in New York at 1.3742 marks, down from 1.3762 on Tuesday. [The dollar continued to show little change in Tokyo on Thursday.]
Choosing his words carefully, Mr. Rubin said that Washington's primary objective in trying to reverse the dollar's slide was to prevent the rising cost of imported goods -- from German machine tools to Japanese cars -- from causing higher inflation in the United States. At the same time, he insisted that the White House was not concerned that the weakness of the dollar would translate into a loss of influence for the United States, especially if other countries begin to conduct business around the world in other currencies.
At the same time, Mr. Rubin sought to put to rest a common belief among Wall Street traders that the United States did not mind a weak dollar because it helped put pressure on Japan to open its markets wider. "We have not and will not use the dollar as an instrument of trade policy," he said.
Mr. Rubin made the case that Germany and Japan were equally worried about the dollar's plight because their own goods were becoming more expensive and thus less competitive. A weaker dollar makes United States goods less costly for importers in nations whose currencies have gained in value.
But his insistence that the larger group of allies known as the Group of Seven shared the goals of the United States came in sharp contrast to statements today by several German officials, who made it clear that they saw the dollar as Washington's problem, not theirs. And the Germans argued that only Washington could overcome the dollar's weakness, chiefly by bringing the nation's budget and trade deficits under control.
"Stability begins at home," said Finance Minister Theo Waigel, Mr. Rubin's counterpart in Germany. In a particularly blunt assessment during a speech to a conference of German bankers in Bonn, Mr. Waigel said that "G-7 cooperation cannot be used to compensate for national deficiencies."
Speaking at the same conference, the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, said the German central bank he oversees was reluctant to meddle with the currency markets to rectify a problem it saw as made in the U.S.A. Germany slightly lowered its interest rates last week in a move that helped make the dollar more attractive. But after causing a brief flurry the change was ignored by the markets.
"Currency stabilization depends above all on countries with weak currencies," Mr. Tietmeyer said. "They must pursue policies that create confidence."
Mr. Rubin declined to specifically respond to the comments by the German officials. It is a particularly sensitive issue in Europe, where there is growing concern that the rise of the mark to record highs could break apart the delicate relationships among European currencies -- and with it the hopes for a true economic integration of Europe. A strong mark further heightens Germany's power in the European Community, and makes it all the more difficult for other nations on the continent to attract investment and generate enough growth to reduce unemployment from painfully high levels.
Signs of discord and mixed signals are nothing new for the major allies, and they have a long history. Only rarely have such conflicting signals truly shaken markets around the world, though the stock market crash in October 1987 was partly blamed on open disagreements between the United States and Germany over the dollar on the eve of the crash.
In the latter half of the 1980's, however, the Group of Seven cooperation initiated by James Baker 3d, the Secretary of Treasury at the time, was considered much more important in maintaining international economic stability than it is today. And after today's back and forth, it is clear that Mr. Rubin cannot count on much more than grudging and half-hearted help from Germany.
And Tokyo, while more active, is unlikely to prove any more helpful. Japan's industrial leaders appear to have taken the latest bout of "endaka," or a strong yen, far more in stride than past increases of far less magnitude. Several Japanese executives have said in recent weeks that they view the current Japanese Government as so weak that there is little it could do to solve the trade problems that are causing Japan's surpluses and contributing to the weakness of the dollar.
So, once again, they are racing forward with plans to move more plants overseas, in hopes that they can adjust to a yen hovering at 85 to the dollar the same way they adjusted to one at 150, then 120 and then 100.
Mr. Rubin gave no hint that he was ready to recommend a deeper cut in the Federal deficit or a rise in interest rates to support the dollar, and he said that America's improvements in competitiveness should be enough to keep the dollar higher. "Over time," he argued, "the dollar should reflect fundamentals."
But he and the markets appeared to be talking past each other. Some on Wall Street suggested that President Clinton, in warning today that Republican efforts to cut taxes sharply risk "exploding the deficit," only fueled the fears that the Government was trying to contain.
"That's hardly the words of a guy who's buying dollars," said David F. DeRosa, director of foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
"This is strike three," he said. "All the efforts have failed to sustain the dollar."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Gain Despite Weakness in Dollar

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities crept higher yesterday despite the continued weakness in the dollar.
Traders were taking on larger cash positions ahead of tomorrow's Government report on employment in March, traders and analysts said. 
The price of the 30-year bond rose 2/32 , to 1034/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.36 perent, from 7.37 percent on Tuesday. Shorter-maturity bill rates also performed well, down an average of 2 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Signs of a slowdown in consumer spending had only a muted impact on the market yesterday. The Commerce Department reported that its index of leading indicators, a key gauge of future economic activity, fell in February as higher interest rates put a leash to consumer spending. The index dropped two-tenths of 1 percent in February, its first decline since October and its largest since a drop of four-tenths of 1 percent in May 1993.
Analysts said weakening consumer demand was also evident in another Commerce Department report showing wholesale inventories rising a larger-than-expected 1.2 percent in February amid slower sales of big ticket items. Over all, wholesale sales were up a healthy 1 percent in February, with increases in auto and lumber inventories reflecting a drop in new home and auto sales.
While further evidence of a slowing economy usually bolsters bond prices, the market was focusing its attention on the weak dollar, which makes Treasury securities less attractive to foreign investors as well as being potentially inflationary. The market's uncertainty about the dollar is keeping a number of buyers on the sidelines.
"The market now appears to be tied to every whim of the dollar, in the short term," said Charles Roden, managing director and head of fixed-income investing for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. Still, he said, "I think right now that the long end of the market is the best of both worlds, and believe that the Fed's slowdown of the economy is achievable."
"Rates in the short end of the market would be somehwhat lower if not for the weakness in the dollar," he said.
In the municipal bond market, yields declined as investors were drawn by the higher yields offered in yesterday's $412 million bond sale by Washington State.
Many of this week's new offerings were sold at prices that produced yields below those of similar rated securities amid investor expectations that municipal bond sales will continue to fall behind last year's pace.
The Washington State 10-year bond was priced to yield 5.35 percent, or about 10 basis points more than a similar 10-year bond from Florida's $300 million offering on Tuesday. Both are rated double-A by the major rating agencies.
Traders said Washington bonds generally traded more cheaply relative to other state bonds in part because of the large amount of outstanding debt and memories of the 1980's default by the Washington Public Power Sytem on $2.25 billion of debt that was sold to construct a nuclear power system. Analysts say it remains the largest municipal bond default in history.
Good investor demand for the Washington State issue allowed the underwriters, led by Lehman Brothers, to reprice some maturities in the issue and lower yields. The maximum yield offered was 6.01 percent for bonds due in 2020, with a bond due in 2015 priced to yield 6 percent.
Serial bonds with shorter maturities were priced to yield from 4.45 percent in 1996 to 5.95 percent in 2013.
The Bond Buyer's index of 40 municipal bond issues saw the average yield to maturity decline to 6.36 percent, from 6.37 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Kidnappings Soar in Latin America, Threatening Region's Stability

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia

 BODY:
Every six hours, a kidnapping is reported in Colombia. Every four days a kidnapping is reported in Rio de Janeiro. But these two places, notorious though they may be, are just the tip of an iceberg of abductions looming over Latin America.
Huge income disparities, inefficient police forces, and near-total impunity for kidnappers are transforming Latin America into the world's top region for ransom kidnapping. The threat is inhibiting investment in the region and is forcing wealthy Latin Americans to use private guards, high walls and armored cars for protection. 
 A victims' group estimates that over the last three years $400 million has been paid in ransom in Colombia alone. But the toll goes far beyond ransom payments.
"Fear of kidnapping has cost the country many economic growth points, thousands of jobs, millions of dollars," Portafolio, a Colombian business newspaper, wrote in a recent editorial. "Who is going to invest and work to the maximum with such a high risk? It is absurd that one of the consequences of business success is to increase the probabilities of losing life, freedom, health and family peace. We cannot get out of underdevelopment with such a sword of Damocles."
Brian M. Jenkins, a deputy chairman of Kroll Associates, a New York-based company that specializes in executive security, estimates that last year Latin America had more than 6,000 kidnappings -- 4,000 in Colombia, 800 each in Mexico and Brazil, 200 each in Ecuador and Venezuela, and 100 each in Guatemala and Peru.
Latin American governments' official figures for the number of kidnappings are much lower, because of underreporting by victims' families and reluctance by governments to harm their images. "Governments seeking foreign investment and tourism have little incentive to publicize their kidnapping problems," Mr. Jenkins said.
In contrast, he said, the United States has fewer than a dozen kidnappings for ransom every year. There is concern, however, that Mexico's economic collapse could increase kidnappings there this year, and perhaps spill over into cross-border abductions.
Referring to an estimated $30 million ransom paid last June to free Alfredo Harp Helu, chairman of Mexico's largest bank, Banamex, Mr. Jenkins said that "in Mexico, the Banamex kidnapping was inspirational to criminals."
But the biggest problem remains Colombia, he said, adding, "Latin America is now the No. 1 region for kidnapping, and Colombia is the No. 1 country in the world." The list of hostages in Colombia includes nine Americans, the largest such group in the world.
Of the region's major kidnapping centers, Colombia is the only one in which political abductions play a major role. Pais Libre, a Colombian kidnapping victims' group, studied last year's kidnappings and concluded that guerrillas carried out at least half.
Peace talks with Colombian guerrillas are scheduled to resume this year after a three-year hiatus. Some Colombians speculate that the guerrillas are collecting American hostages to strengthen their hand at the negotiating table.
The guerrillas generally deny that they finance their operations through kidnappings.
"We have always been against kidnappings -- we have ordered a few political detentions," Jorge Briceno, the Revolutionary Armed Forces' spokesman for peace talks, told a Bogota newspaper, El Espectador, in February. "But we have nothing to do with economic kidnappings."
But a different voice was heard recently from the guerrillas when Pais Libre played a tape recording that it said was a radio conversation last August between a guerrilla commander and Wilma Garzon, the mother of a 31-year-old farm manager kidnapped on Oct. 30, 1993.
"The guy's already dead so we are going to charge you 10 million pesos to deliver his corpse," the man identified as the guerrilla commander said. "If you don't want it that way, we'll throw him in a hole somewhere."
Mrs. Garzon paid the money -- about $14,000 at the time -- but never received her son's body.
"The going price for an oil executive is $200,000," said Guy Squires, who has been working here for over a year to coordinate efforts to free five of the American hostages, missionaries for New Tribes Mission, a Florida-based Protestant evangelical group.
Guerrillas for the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, the nation's largest guerrilla group, have demanded $5 million for the release of three of the missionaries, who were seized in Panama in 1993 and later brought into Colombia.
"We are a mission and we cannot afford to pay ransoms," said Mr. Squires, who was last in contact with the guerrillas by radio a year ago.
Mr. Squires and friends of other Americans kidnapped in Colombia complain of the low level of interest by the United States.
"We were passed off to aides and not allowed to speak to Senators," Mr. Squires said of his trips to Washington with wives of several kidnapped missionaries.
His concern is echoed by Eugene Harter, a writer who is a friend of Thomas R. Hargrove, a journalist who is one of the nine hostages.
Last September, the Revolutionary Armed Forces kidnapped Mr. Hargrove, an editor of scientific publications at the International Center for Tropical Agriculture, an international development agency based in Cali, Colombia. The kidnappers demanded a ransom, reportedly $6 million, but center officials said they would not pay any ransom.
"His situation is just as big as the Beirut hostage situation," Mr. Harter said, contending that the plight of the American kidnapping victims in Colombia is largely unknown in the United States.
State Department officials have met with the family members and say only that they are following the cases closely. The State Department has issued a recommendation that Americans who visit the country remain in the major cities and avoid rural areas.
Security experts say most victims are seized from their cars. Some kidnappers use roadblocks, but others use their cars to block a victim's car and force it to come to a stop.
In the Barra neighborhood in Rio, the local authorities plan to construct gates to close access roads to this affluent neighborhood of 500,000 people. Barra has suffered 100 kidnappings since 1991. Critics liken the gates to medieval drawbridges.
Of the 14,000 Colombians estimated to have taken part in kidnappings last year, the police arrested or killed 350 -- fewer than 3 percent. Of 3,625 reported cases of kidnapping in Colombia in the last three years, the police rescued only 11 percent of hostages. For these crimes, only 70 people were arrested, tried and sentenced.
"It's become a wildfire industry -- so profitable that I don't see any end in sight," said Francisco Santos, a newspaper editor and former kidnapping victim who is president of Pais Libre.
To try to stop kidnappings, Ecuador created a separate anti-kidnapping police force in January, Rio de Janeiro doubled its force in February, and Colombia is adding 130 detectives to its anti-kidnapping unit.
Colombia's Defense Minister, Fernando Botero Zia, said in an interview that the Government was reorganizing anti-kidnapping squads and creating a national information bank to help catch kidnappers. He contended that the Government had a better success rate with solving urban kidnappings than the overall statistics would indicate.
"The Government is trying to make a great effort to control the problem," he said. "As we have more success against the guerrillas, we will have more success against kidnapping."
But in Colombia, Brazil and Mexico, some detectives have fallen victim to the temptation of stealing ransoms they were sent to pay in an effort to catch kidnappers. Others routinely kill kidnappers on the spot when they find them, often undercutting their own investigations.
"Police here like to fire their guns -- what they need is gray matter and investigative know-how," said Carlos Fragoso, a Rio de Janeiro criminal lawyer who has negotiated several hostage cases. "When the police kill the lowest level criminals at the hiding places, they never get to the leaders of the kidnap gangs."
Some business people are not waiting for the new police units to learn their jobs. "We are armoring an average of 10 cars a month," said Humberto Neiva, director of Riva, a Rio security company.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 3129 words

HEADLINE: Rethinking Welfare: Time Limits -- A special report.;
Iowa Plan Tries to Cut Off the Cash

DATELINE: DES MOINES

 BODY:
For all the tough talk around the country about cutting the Gordian knot of welfare dependency, Iowa is the only state that has cut off cash benefits to families because a parent refused to go to work or take other steps to get off welfare.
Even here, the state started removing parents and their children from the rolls only six months ago. Iowa has been unable to determine what became of most of the 881 families who have lost benefits so far. Some recipients say the new rules have prodded them to work, while others seem to have been pushed off a precipice. 
 Kathy Brundidge, 29, and a mother of three, was jolted from an 11-year reliance on welfare by the fear of losing her benefits. She now has a job checking people's eyes and fitting them for glasses. "If I didn't go to work, I was going to lose everything I was living off of," she explained.
But another woman, who got a job in a factory making boxes, was fired when she had to stay home with her sick 5-year-old. Then, when her benefits were reduced, she was evicted and fled to Ohio to avoid losing her children to foster care.
"Several churches went together to buy her bus fare," said Sharon Baker, director of Cross Ministries in Des Moines, who declined to name the mother to protect her privacy.
Republicans in Congress acknowledge that there is as yet no reliable evidence from Iowa or elsewhere about how drastic changes like time limits and cutoffs will affect the 4.5 million adults and 9.4 million children receiving cash payments nationally through Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main Federal welfare program. But they say the time has come to transform a system that many in both parties feel has sapped people of their will to work and trapped generations of children in poverty.
As a centerpiece of its sweeping overhaul of social welfare laws, the Republican-controlled House of Representatives last month passed a bill going well beyond what is being tried in Iowa.
Iowa now denies cash welfare benefits to families if parents refuse to sign or comply with agreements that specify what they will do to get off welfare and how long they have to do it. Some are given years to attend college, while others agree to find a job within months. The state sets no absolute limit on how long a family can receive welfare.
In contrast, the House bill decrees that, with few exceptions, families that received welfare for a lifetime total of five years would never again be eligible for Federal welfare payments.
Republican legislators predict that most recipients will become breadwinners if they have no alternative. "Welfare is always there as a crutch," said Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania. "Sometimes you knock the crutches out, and people will fall down. But they'll learn to walk."
But Democrats say an arbitrary time limit is too risky. "We don't know enough to say 'five years and you're out,' " said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York. "It's possible you'll do intense damage to children."
Advocates for the poor fear that millions of families could wind up homeless, while destitute children flood already overwhelmed foster-care programs. And in Iowa, where a single parent must participate in welfare-to-work programs once her youngest child is 6 months old, some recipients worry that their children will be worse off.
"I don't see where working at minimum wage or barely above is going to help us," said Brenda Aldrich, a former bartender and mother of Gabriel, 6, and Blake, 2. Ms. Aldrich lost all her cash benefits because she did not cooperate with the state. She thought it was more important to go to her older son's ball games and tend to her little one, who is afraid of strangers.
The House welfare bill will be taken up soon in the Senate, probably in May. Key Republican senators have said that they agree with the basic thrust of the bill, which is to give states near-total control of most welfare programs and relieve them of the obligation to match Federal welfare spending.
Ten states other than Iowa have begun their own experiments with time limits on welfare, but those limits have not yet run out. This year, Virginia and Massachusetts passed laws to limit able-bodied welfare recipients to two years of benefits in any five-year period. Both states will have to win Federal approval before carrying out their plans.
Under the current system, about half of all A.F.D.C. recipients at any given time have spent more than five years on welfare, according to studies by LaDonna A. Pavetti, a researcher at the Urban Institute in Washington. Seven in 10 recipients have spent more than two years on welfare.
A profile of long-term recipients suggests just how hard it will be for many to find and keep jobs, especially ones that pay enough to support a family. A large share of chronic welfare mothers, surveys show, bore children while they were in their teens, never graduated from high school, have never been married and have had little or no work experience.
Contrary to the stereotype of the welfare mother who goes on the dole for years, recent research shows that many women cycle between welfare and low-wage jobs they quickly quit or lose. The reasons include conflicts with bosses, loss of child care, layoffs, and boyfriends jealous of the women's new-found financial independence.
 
The Iowa Experiment
Trying to Adjust To a New System

As part of a broader effort to give states leeway to experiment with welfare, in 1993 the Clinton Administration gave Iowa permission to begin a statewide test of a new approach.
Those who do not find jobs, participate in education and training programs, or take other required steps toward working are given three months more of full benefits, three months of reduced benefits and then are cut off altogether.
The state softens the impact of the rules by allowing families who sign the agreements to get off welfare, but then try and fail, to negotiate for more time. It also permits families to re-apply for welfare six months after they are cut off.
"There are people who will forever need assistance," said Deb Bingaman, the state's welfare-experiment coordinator. "And they will continue to get benefits if they make an effort to become self-sufficient. It may be 10 hours a week of volunteer work is the best they can do."
The state has tried to track the families who have been cut off, but public-health nurses sent out on visits have been unable to contact more than half of them.
"We get letters back with no forwarding address," said Mary Ann Riensche, patient-care coordinator at the Visiting Nurse Association in Waterloo. "We go by the house, and it's vacant. They're just plain gone."
The threat of losing all cash benefits has given some parents an urgent shove into the job market. In January, about 30 percent of recipients participating in Iowa's new initiative were working, generally part time. In comparison, 17 percent of those in a control group receiving welfare the old way, without the threat of a cutoff, were working.
But while the program has put more people to work, it has also led to homelessness and family breakup for at least some.
Others have simply moved to states that have looser rules -- a phenomenon that could increase if Congress allows the states to develop 50 different sets of welfare rules. The Visiting Nurse Association in Dubuque found that 13 percent of the families they tried to contact had left the state.
Still other families have turned to charities and other public-aid programs for help. Jim and Debbie Baker and their three young children lost their benefits five months ago but wangled a temporary rent subsidy from the state's general relief program. Mr. Baker, a construction worker, has applied for unemployment insurance. The Bakers, who live in Cedar Rapids and are not related to Sharon Baker of the church group, recently got a disconnect notice from the electric company.
"I swear on the Bible I didn't receive the papers from Promise Jobs," Mrs. Baker said, referring to the cutoff notice from the state's jobs program for welfare recipients. "I would have done what they wanted me to if I got them."
All the families in Iowa's program are struggling to adapt to a bureaucratic culture that has suddenly changed from one that dispenses checks to one that puts recipients to work.
"Before, they'd let you sit there 'til your children were in school," said Ms. Aldrich, 33, the former bartender. Never married, she has been a "full-time mother and father" since her oldest son Gabriel was born 6 years ago.
At first Ms. Aldrich, of Sioux City, did not take the state seriously when she was notified that her benefits would stop on April 1. As the date approached, her attention was more focused. She knew that she could not count on Gabriel's father, who was convicted of selling drugs and just got out of prison. Two-year-old Blake's father pays $220 a month in child support.
"I suppose I'll get a job," she mused recently, the newspaper classified advertisements at her elbow. "Maybe I'll call my worker and see if I can go back and fix it." She paused for second thoughts, then added, "We'll definitely have to look harder than I thought for this job."
Ms. Brundidge is among those who quickly adapted to the new rules. She first became pregnant when she was a high school senior and had her three children by a man who has worked off and on at fast-food restaurants. She never married him, and he never supported them financially.
"I had gotten myself in a mode where my daughter was 4 and I didn't want to work 'til she was 6 or 7," said Ms. Brundidge, of Cedar Rapids. "The new program didn't give me that option."
She started with a $5-an-hour factory job, but quit when the man she is now engaged to marry fell off a roof and her employer refused to give her permission to go home. "For $5 an hour, your family comes first," she said.
Her caseworker then put Ms. Brundidge to work as a volunteer in a job-placement office. There, Ms. Brundidge spotted a listing for an optician's position. She landed the full-time $6.50-an-hour job, which also offered training. She expects a raise to $7 soon, an amount "that would put me ahead."
But some mothers wonder how long their low-wage jobs will last.
Cherrie Sharkey, 26, has been on and off welfare for six years. Her caseworker told her that she had to report for a job-search and resume-writing program, but the hassle of arranging child care for Benjamin, 6, Cheena, 5, and Alexandria, 3, seemed to Ms. Sharkey more trouble than it was worth to do something that paid nothing.
"I got a job on my own," she said. "I didn't have time to do what they wanted me to."
She now works for $5.50 an hour flipping burgers and making pizzas at Mario's in Dubuque. Her take-home pay is less than $300 a week. And she has no confidence that her employer will long tolerate her lateness or absences when her children are sick.
"I was two hours late one snowy day because the kids had a two-hour delay for school," she said. "I got yelled at, but what can I do? I'm a single mother, and I don't have anyone to depend on."
 
The National Challenge
Untried Changes, Big Uncertainties
 President Clinton has crusaded for a two-year time limit on welfare benefits, but proposed a bill that would have dropped families from the rolls only if the parents did not try to find jobs. His bill also provided billions of dollars in new training, work and child-care programs.
The House bill gives states no extra money for job preparation or to support child care for working mothers. Instead, the states would get a block grant to divide as they wish. The grant would not automatically grow in hard times.
Some House Republican leaders are hedging about how they would cope with the casualties of their approach. A few months ago, Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia was touting orphanages as a solution for the children of welfare recipients kicked off the rolls.
But Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr. of Florida, chairman of the subcommittee that produced the House welfare bill, recently downplayed the orphanage option, saying in an interview that the Speaker had just been making "an offhand remark." Mr. Shaw said Congress would reconsider the legislation if it had tragic consequences.
"We're not going to put up with thousands of children going into foster care or with people starving," he said.
Mr. Shaw's tentativeness says much about the enormous uncertainties facing the nation if it goes forward with untried, systemic changes in welfare.
Several of the state experiments with time limits are exceedingly modest. For example, in Wisconsin, Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, a Republican, boasts of drawing a line in the sand for welfare mothers: two years, and you're off the rolls for good. But Wisconsin is only trying the approach in two small counties that have very low unemployment rates and a total welfare caseload of about 900, covering only 1 percent of the state's welfare recipients.
Mr. Thompson has warned that welfare overhaul will not save money in the short run, and may cost more: The state has increased its spending for counseling, job training, child care and transportation, and it may subsidize private employers who hire welfare mothers.
So far, Iowa's program has cost more than the old system, officials say. While the state is spending slightly less on grants to families, and the caseload has begun to decline somewhat, it is spending more on education, training, transportation and child care.
And Iowa, which has the third lowest unemployment rate in the nation and none of its largest cities, does not face the densely concentrated urban poverty of Chicago, Detroit, Los Angeles or New York City. For example, there are only about 37,000 families on welfare in Iowa, compared with more than 300,000 in New York City.
Still, state officials believe that Iowa will eventually save money. They also point proudly to the rising proportion of recipients who are working.
"We're attempting to change a culture, not only of those who have received welfare, but of the people working with people on welfare," said Charles Palmer, director of the state's Department of Human Services.
In hope of helping parents qualify for better jobs, Iowa is trying to upgrade the skills of many welfare recipients, though studies have found limited results. The state has placed 4,000 people in education programs. Another 4,000 are wait-listed indefinitely.
Iowa has also provided somewhat more liberal allowances for child care. Still, state officials acknowledge that some women are finding it difficult to get off welfare because of a shortage of affordable child care in some areas. And the subsidy itself is limited.
For example, a single mother of two who works full time at $5 an hour still qualifies for a small welfare check, but will get only an extra $22 a week per child to pay for day care -- which costs $40 to $120 a week.
 
The Families
Staying Together, Breaking Apart
 A garden-variety problem with day care set off a disastrous chain of events that led to one Iowa family's undoing. Mrs. Baker, who heads a philanthropic alliance of Presbyterian churches, tried unsuccessfully to help the family and told their story.
The mother had signed an agreement with the state to go to college, which she believed offered her the best route to a job that paid enough to support her three children. She was put on a waiting list.
Her caseworker told her she would have to get a job in the meantime. A few weeks after she began working for $5.50 an hour, her 5-year-old got sick. The boy was running a fever and could not go to the day-care center.
The worker then told the mother that the only acceptable excuse for missing work was a doctor's note saying she herself was ill. So she left her son with a neighbor. When she came home, she found him alone and untended.
She stayed home with him and was fired from her job. Her welfare benefits were then reduced because she had not done what her worker required. Unable to pay the rent, the family was evicted, Mrs. Baker said, and slept in a friend's car.
Because of the family's homelessness, one of the children's teachers reported them to child-protection services. The child-protection worker told the mother that her children would be placed in foster care if she could not provide for them.
Mrs. Baker said she tried to persuade the woman to fight the system, but could not overcome a mother's fear of losing her children. All the woman could think of was escape to Ohio where she had a sister. This family became one of those that simply disappeared off the state's radar screen.
Sharon Brooks's son is another such case.
He had first gone on welfare four years ago, after he seriously injured his back at a construction site where he was working. By then, his wife had left the family. The son, who is 33, has a learning disability and cannot read beyond a fourth-grade level. Unable to hold down a manual labor job or to compete for more skilled work, he remained unemployed.
He and his three daughters were living with Mrs. Brooks in Des Moines when he began getting letters from the state about the new welfare rules. Mrs. Brooks, who has worked for 26 years at an anti-poverty agency, pleaded with her son to open the letters, but he told her to stay out of his business.
"It was a way of not facing the issue," she said. He became increasingly depressed, sometimes going on long crying jags. On Oct. 1, he and his children were among the first families to lose all cash benefits.
"For him, that loss was the straw that broke the camel's back," Mrs. Brooks said. "He didn't know how to deal with it. He saw no way out. Emotionally, he was not able to deal with the system he was in."
When he refused to seek counseling for his anger and depression, his mother told him he could no longer live in her home. He is homeless now, sleeping in his car or in shelters.
His three girls still live with their grandmother. The oldest, who is 11, told Mrs. Brooks that she hated her life and wished she were dead. "I'm kind of sad 'cause we don't have no parents around," the girl said recently to a visiting reporter.
The youngest daughter is having the hardest time. One recent chilly evening, the 8-year-old dressed defiantly for church in pink shorts and a skimpy T-shirt. Her grandmother told her she could not go unless she changed into something warmer. The girl stomped to her bedroom and slammed the door.
"I don't care," she screamed. "I hate you. I hate you. Liar. Liar. Liar."
When her older sisters boarded the church van, the youngest stayed behind, raging against forces she could not understand.

 THE GOAL -- To fight welfare dependency and force all recipients to seek work.
 THE PROPOSAL -- In a bill that passed the House and is now before the Senate, families could receive cash payments for no more than five years.
 CURRENT LAW -- No Federal time limits.
 STATE EXPERIENCE -- Eleven states have begun experiments with time limits, and Iowa has recently cut off people who refuse to take job training and prepare to get off welfare, but no state has yet implimented an absolute time limit and the consequences are uncertain.

HEADLINE: Christian Pineau, French Hero And Foreign Minister, Dies at 90

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Christian Pineau, a leader of the French Resistance who became one of postwar France's most active Foreign Ministers, died on Wednesday in Paris. He was 90 and had homes in Paris and Vence, a resort in the French Alps.
A gentlemanly politician and Socialist, he served as Foreign Minister from 1956 to 1958. During his tenure he signed the Treaty of Rome, one of the foundations on which the European Union is built, and spoke for France to a skeptical world in the Suez War in 1956. 
 He also sought solutions to France's colonial problems and worked to mitigate the cold war by shifting the focus from military confrontation to closer economic links.
Christian Paul Francis Pineau was born in Chaumont-en-Bassigny, Haute-Marne, the son of an Army colonel. His father died when he was young and his mother married Jean Giraudoux, the playwright.
He earned degrees in political science and law, and went to work for the Bank of France.
With the German occupation, he helped to found an underground newspaper, Liberation, and went on secret missions as a liaison between occupied France and Gen. Charles de Gaulle's Free French headquarters in London. He was captured twice by the Nazis in 1943. Tortured by the Gestapo and sentenced to death, he escaped the firing squad with forged identification papers and he was sent to the Buchenwald concentration camp. He was liberated by American soldiers in 1945.
In the postwar Fourth Republic, he turned to politics and was elected to the National Assembly. His first Government position, his appointment as Food Supply Minister, came barely three weeks after his release from Buchenwald. He held a variety of cabinet posts in a succession of short-lived Governments. Just before he took charge of the Foreign Ministry he was designated Prime Minister but failed to cobble together a cabinet.
A courteous, well-dressed and modest man of distinguished bearing, Mr. Pineau once said the motto of his foreign policy was "negotiate, negotiate again, negotiate always."
He wrote children's books as well as memoirs of the Resistance, the Suez crisis, the Treaty of Rome and Nikita S. Khrushchev. His first children's book was titled "Tales From I Don't Know When" and dedicated to Giraudoux, his stepfather.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
An American REIT Will Invest in Mexico

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 6

 BODY:
The Mexican Government has approved a plan to allow an American real estate trust to invest in Mexican properties for the first time.
The trust, based in San Diego, hopes to profit from depressed Mexican real estate prices and demand for industrial space along the border. It plans to invest about $250 million from American corporate and public pension funds in Mexico over the next three years. 
 Such real estate investments are typically held for 15 years or more, real estate experts here and in the United States say. The money would provide the kind of long-term direct investment that the Mexican Government hopes will prevent a recurrence of the current economic crisis that developed when short-term investments were withdrawn in panic late last year.
Real estate projects in Mexico tend to be riskier than similar projects in the United States, but they can generate greater returns.
"We believe that Mexico is going to be very successful, and that whatever risk is involved will be offset by much higher yields," said Michael J. Dunigan, a San Diego real estate investor who is one of the principals in the newly former trust, which is called the Mexus Real Estate Investment Trust.
Until recently in Mexico, complicated rules restricted foreign ownership of land and property, making it difficult for Americans to enter the real estate market. But a ruling by the Mexican Finance Ministry last Friday cleared the way for real estate trusts to own property.
Alejandro Beuchot, executive vice president of the Mexican Investment Board, which worked with the Mexus group over the last two years to get the Government's approval, said that many American manufacturing plants situated in Mexico along the border had increased their export production this year and were looking to expand.
"But they can't because of the lack of capital caused by the crisis," Mr. Beuchot said. "The trust provides a great opportunity to raise money for the expansions."
Real estate investment trusts, or REIT's, have existed in the United States since 1960, but until now there has not been one totally dedicated to investments in a single foreign country.
The trusts essentially function as mutual funds for the real estate market, permitting a manager to pull together money from many different sources and invest it in various projects.
The records of such trusts have been spotty. Many failed to provide their promised returns and were hurt by the real estate collapse of the late 1980's.
Mr. Dunigan has worked in real estate investment and finance for 25 years. One of his two partners is Malin Burnham, an owner of the San Diego Padres who is chairman of the First National Bank of San Diego and head of Burnham Pacific Properties, a real estate investment trust. The other partner is George Codling, a San Diego developer.
Mr. Dunigan said two corporate pension funds and one trust fund of a public institution had already expressed interest in Mexican property investments. He said he was focusing on properties in Mexico City and along the border.
