HEADLINE: Tax-Cutters and the '96 Election

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
With the approval on Wednesday night of a $189 billion tax cut by the House of Representatives, Speaker Newt Gingrich has all but completed his self-decreed 100 days in the center ring of American politics.
He calls the tax bill the crowning jewel of his Contract With America. But for all his considerable achievements in the last three months, he lacks the power to assure that Americans will keep more of their paychecks. In a nice piece of political congruence, that power lies mostly with the two men considered most likely to compete for the White House next fall: President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader. 
Both will inevitably hear the echoes of recent Presidential campaigns, when a permissive line on taxes has often proved fatal, as they weigh their strategies and ponder their impact on the campaign ahead. One thing is clear to them and to most other leading politicians here: Like Ronald Reagan a decade ago, Mr. Gingrich and his young followers in the House have succeeded by their boldness in drastically altering the context of American politics.
Now more than ever, it is perilous for politicians to oppose lower taxes.
"The days of tax and spend are over," said Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, in Wednesday's long House debate. "The days of smaller government and less taxes are at hand."
Fewer and fewer people here are disposed to argue with him.
Yes, the mood of the Senate remains less fiery than that in the House. If the Senate passes a tax-cut bill, it will almost surely be less sweeping and less tilted toward rich taxpayers. But there is now a real possibility of a Senate bill, and that in itself represents a big change in the last two weeks.
On March 19, Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who heads the Finance Committee, dismissed the idea of a tax cut with these words: "The best thing we can do for the taxpayers of this country is just try to move toward deficit reduction. And if that gets their mortgage rates down a point or two, that is more important than anything else that we can do."
Only two weeks later, he and Mr. Dole, whose views Mr. Packwood usually reflects, are singing a different song. Over the weekend Mr. Packwood talked not about a choice between cutting the deficit and cutting taxes, but about the prospect of finding "room for a tax cut" within a balanced budget. Never mind what he had said before; never mind what revenue experts have said.
The country as a whole remains deeply divided on taxes. In the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, for example, 41 percent of the respondents said that the country could afford a tax cut now and 55 percent said it could not.
What has changed, of course, is the political atmosphere on Capitol Hill, and the person who has changed it the most is Newt Gingrich. When some House Republicans balked at his tax plan, he stood fast and said that, in the end, they would not dare to kill a tax cut.
He was right; most of the rebels caved in, some telling one another that the Senate would eventually block the Gingrich proposal.
Perhaps, but the Senate breathes the same political air as the House. And Bob Dole cannot help but recall what happened to him in New Hampshire in 1988 as he looks forward to the first primary of his new Presidential bid, in that same state.
Seven years ago, George Bush stunned Mr. Dole, then the front-runner for the Republican nomination, by running television commercials that positioned the Senator on the "wrong" side of the tax issue in a state whose leading newspaper has made a decades-long crusade for lower taxes. The advertisements said: "Bob Dole straddled, and he just won't promise not to raise taxes. You know what that means."
Mr. Dole, beaten, lashed out at Mr. Bush on television for "lying" about his record, and he never regained his momentum. Many times since then, he has vowed that he would never allow the same thing to happen to him again, and if he does not produce a tax-cut bill this year, his rivals for the nomination, notably Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, will surely pounce on him sooner or later.
On the other hand, Mr. Dole must take care that in seeking to insulate himself against attack from the right he does not lose the moderate voters whom he would need in November. It is the classic conundrum that faces those who seek the Presidency, made all the more difficult for Mr. Dole by his work as majority leader, which requires him to take public positions on everything.
Mr. Clinton is fighting the House plan, trying to portray it as untimely and irresponsible. This week he told reporters in an impromptu news conference, "I do not think it is wise to have a tax cut of this magnitude." He said he hoped the Senate would produce something better.
Although Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and the budget director, Alice M. Rivlin, said on Tuesday that they would urge him to veto anything resembling the House measure, the President declared, "I do not want a pile of vetoes."
Nor does he want to get on the unprofitable side of the tax-cut debate. His own experience has shown him how painful that can be.
During the 1992 campaign, a rival for the Democratic nomination, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas, talked of the need for pain and sacrifice to bring the deficit under control, while Mr. Clinton promised a middle-class tax cut. Mr. Clinton prevailed. But then in 1993, as President, he chose instead to back a package that, while including modest tax increases, actually made a sizeable dent in the deficit. He got no political credit for that from the voters as the Republicans drubbed his party in 1994.
So, as 1996 approaches, Mr. Clinton, too, has every reason to sign on to a tax cut that he can present as his own moderate, responsible alternative to Republican "wild men.".
Whatever the economic merits of the situation, however much all this may look like a replay of Reaganomics, which wildly inflated the national debt, the political imperative is clear: tax-cutters win elections.

HEADLINE: Major Retailers' Sales in March Were Weaker Than Expected

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
In a sign that higher interest rates may be pinching consumers, the big retailers reported March sales figures yesterday that were weaker than expected.
Analysts and merchandisers alike had been prepared for a poor year-over-year comparison, if only because Easter fell much earlier in 1994 than it does this year. As a consequence, some sales that occurred last year in late March may be pushed into early April this year. 
 Easter-related buying trends is much more important for apparel makers than for so-called hard goods merchandisers, analysts said. Sales at major retail clothing chains were poor last month, continuing a trend that has been in place for months.
"Expenditures for home-oriented goods, like furnishings and consumer electronics, have been posting healthy gains," said Kurt Barnard, publisher of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report, a monthly newsletter. But "there is a very distinct slowdown for spending in clothing."
But analysts said a possible shift in holiday buying did little to account for the steep drop in the sales figures reported yesterday.
"Even adjusting for the lateness of Easter, the numbers are crummy," said Robert Buchanan, a senior vice president at NatWest Securities.
"The Federal Reserve Board has been raising interest rates for a year, and wants to slow the consumer sector. There is no question in my mind that we are in the midst of a consumer slowdown."
A measure of overall sales performance at major retailers, the Goldman Sachs Retail Composite Index, rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month, compared with a 12.6 percent increase in March 1994. In February, the index, a weighted average of the same-store sales of 50 retailers, rose 3.5 percent.
Among the retailers, same-store sales fell 5.5 percent at J. C. Penney, 2.5 percent at Federated Department Stores and nine-tenths of 1 percent at Ann Taylor, according to Goldman, Sachs. Still, Kmart rose 5.5 percent, while Wal-Mart gained 2.8 percent.
Stock market investors reacted poorly to the sales figures, and pushed down prices of many retailers in heavy trading.
Among the biggest movers were the Dayton Hudson Corporation, whose stock fell $2.25, to $68.75. Ann Taylor fell $3.75, to $33. And Circuit City shares dropped $1.75, to $25.25.
Richard N. Baum, a retailing analyst at Goldman, Sachs, said the market's reaction was "a little bit schizophrenic."
"As negative as the market was to the March numbers, we think there will be a sales rebound in April due to Easter, and the stocks will have an upward move," he said.
Despite a possible rebound in April, Mr. Baum said "1995 will be a difficult year for retailers."
Mr. Baum and others are pessimistic about a possible surge in spending because for the last several months real average hourly wages have been flat to up slightly; installment credit continues to rise at a very rapid rate, and housing turnover, an important element for sales of so-called hard goods like furnishings, has fallen sharply as interest rates have risen.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Increase in Price On New Signs of Slowdown

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended higher yesterday on growing confidence that the economy was slowing.
Reports by retailers of weak sales in March and and an increase in new claims for unemployment insurance for the week supported the market's view of a slowdown. But ahead of today's employment report few investors were willing yesterday to make large bets before the number was released, and trading was a lackluster. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 9/32 , to 10313/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.34 percent, from 7.36 percent on Wednesday. Short- maturity bills also improved, as unsubstantiated rumors of foreign central banks buying short-term securities circulated throughout the day.
Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said he was encouraged that the market finished near the top of its trading range yesterday going into the employment report. Wall Street, he said, is looking at the bond market more favorably "after focusing so much on the negatives like the dollar and higher commodity prices and inflation."
The bond market has been helped recently, he added, by interest from retail investors, rather than institutional investors. "When you have retail interest the Street stops trying to sell the market," Mr. Burtnick said. "Today there was enough retail interest to keep the shorts honest."
Other data released yesterday included housing completions as reported by the Commerce Department. The number of housing units completed fell 9.5 percent in February, the biggest monthly decline in more than three years.
Completions, which lag behind starts of new construction by six months, fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.29 million, the lowest level since July 1994.
Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch, a market analysis firm, said today's employment report should confirm a slowdown. He said he expected a slowdown in the growth of real gross domestic product to about 2.5 percent in the second quarter of 1995 after an estimated 3.5 rate this quarter.
Mr. Palash said he saw the March employment report coming in on the moderate side, with a 175,000 gain in nonfarm payrolls and a rise of one-tenth of 1 percent in the national unemployment rate, to 5.5 percent.
In the municipal bond market, bond prices rose as investors focused on bonds sold earlier in the week. Investors have recently been balking at the prices of new issues, saying that the nearly 50 percent drop in issuance during the first quarter has helped drive up prices to expensive levels.
As as a result, traders said, some investors have moved from new issue sales to the secondary market.
The Bond Buyer's index of 40 municipal issues showed the average yield to maturity down two basis points, to 6.30 percent. A basis point is one hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gasoline Prices Surge on Worry About Tighter Summer Supplies

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Gasoline prices surged yesterday after problems at two refineries suggested that supplies could tighten ahead of the summer driving season.
On other commodity markets, platinum prices fell sharply on profit taking and cotton continued to climb. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 0.19 point, to 236.51. 
 The partial shutdown of a Koch Refining Company plant in Texas and continuing problems at a Sun Oil Company refinery in Philadelphia followed reports earlier this week that gasoline inventories fell sharply last week.
"That makes any news about closures more significant," said Monica Kelly, director of energy research at Pegasus Econometric Group in New York.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, gasoline for May delivery jumped 1.2 cents, to 61.68 cents a gallon, the highest daily settlement for near-term deliveries since May 1993. It was the third consecutive strong advance in gasoline.
The rally pushed prices of crude oil and heating oil higher. May crude oil rose 21 cents, to $19.77 a barrel, and May heating oil rose 1.2 cents, to 49.21 cents a gallon.
Gasoline production typically declines in the spring as refiners close some units for seasonal maintenance. As a result, unscheduled closings like those at Koch and Sun can have a more substantial effect on prices.
Koch said it shut down a fluid catalytic cracker on Tuesday in Corpus Christi, Tex., that normally produces 50,000 barrels of gasoline a day, 40 percent of the refinery's total production. The unit will be restarted over the weekend, the company said.
Sun closed its 40,000-barrel-a-day catalytic cracker in Philadelphia last week. The company said the operation would not be restarted this week.
Platinum futures fell sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders took profits after a powerful five-day rally.
On Wednesday, platinum rose to its highest price since Sept. 7, 1990, after the Engelhard Corporation said it had developed a new pollution-control catalyst that uses the metal. The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it would work with Engelhard to develop applications for cars.
April platinum fell $9.10 yesterday, to $452.50 a troy ounce.
Cotton rose the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound for the third consecutive day on the New York Cotton Exchange on signs of strengthening export demand for tight supplies of American cotton.
The May contract, which peaked at $1.10 a pound on March 13, settled at $102.22 yesterday.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Royals Shed Cone; Braves Get Grissom

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
David Cone, the American League Cy Young Award winner who only last week said he thought he would be traded because of his union activity, was traded yesterday, but the Kansas City Royals said they sent the pitcher to the Toronto Blue Jays for economic, not punitive, reasons.
The Montreal Expos, acting from the same payroll-tightening motivation, completed a frenzied two-day effort later in the day by trading their outstanding center fielder and leadoff batter, Marquis Grissom, to the Atlanta Braves for three players, including two major league outfielders, Roberto Kelly and Tony Tarasco. 
 Grissom thus joined pitchers John Wetteland, who went to the Yankees, and Ken Hill, traded to the Cardinals, as high-priced players eligible for salary arbitration who have been dispatched by the Expos.
The trading of Cone, one day after the Royals dealt outfielder Brian McRae to the Chicago Cubs for two minor leaguers, also followed a pattern in which high-salaried players have been acquired by clubs wealthier than the clubs that traded them.
The Royals acquired three minor leaguers for Cone, their No. 1 pitcher last season with a 16-5 record and a 2.94 earned run average. This marks the second time the Royals have traded Cone, who reached the majors with Kansas City in 1986, and the second time he has been traded to the Blue Jays.
By re-acquiring Cone, whom they originally obtained from the Mets for the last five weeks of the 1992 season, the Blue Jays displayed a determined effort to keep up with the Yankees, who have bolstered their pitching staff with the addition of the starter Jack McDowell and the reliever Wetteland.
During the recently concluded 234-day work stoppage, Cone became one of the most visible and articulate spokesmen for the union. He was often sought for television interviews, so his face and views were widely seen and heard.
Steve Fehr, the agent for Cone as well as McRae, is the brother of Donald Fehr, the baseball union's leader. When Steve Fehr was asked yesterday if he thought the trade was union related, he said, "I certainly hope that's not true."
Herk Robinson, the Royals' general manager, said flatly it was not true.
"It had absolutely nothing to do with his union activities," Robinson said by telephone from Haines City, Fla. "I talked to David two or three times over the winter. I told him I thought he was doing a good job. Somebody has to do that job. Nobody was offended by that. The reason we did it was we have to reduce our payroll. And we did not feel we could sign David for 1996 and beyond."
"I can't say it was as much a shock this time," Cone, a Kansas City native, was quoted as saying by The Associated Press. "This morning, my general manager and my manager didn't have much to say to me. After a while in baseball, you get a sort of sixth sense for these things."
Robinson didn't say, but other people in baseball believe the Royals will also trade another of their starting pitchers, Kevin Appier, in their payroll-slashing strategy.
Cone, 32 years old and a three-time National League strikeout leader, can be a free agent after this season, the third of a three-year, $18 million contract he signed with the Royals as a free agent Dec. 8, 1992. Half of his contract was paid in the form of a $9 million signing bonus that came not from the Royals' treasury but from the personal fortune of Ewing Kauffman, the owner, who died eight months later.
Robinson referred to the signing bonus in discussing Cone's labor status.
"I'm not sure many of the things he did on his behalf were not beneficial to helping the situation," the general manager said. "He had played in a small-market town, he was born and raised in one. He knew Mr. Kauffman personally paid much of his salary, the up-front money. He did not want to burden the ball club."
The Blue Jays gave the Royals two infielders, Chris Stynes and Tony Medrano, and a relief pitcher, David Sinnes.
In the deal for Grissom, besides Kelly and Tarasco, the Expos received a 20-year-old minor league pitcher, Esteban Yan, who was 11-12 with a 3.27 earned run average for Class A Macon last season.
Kelly, a former Yankee, is expected to be Montreal's starting center fielder. He hit .293 for Atlanta and Cincinnati in 1994 with 9 home runs, 43 r.b.i. and 19 stolen bases. Atlanta will pay much of Kelly's 1994 salary of $3.4 million.
Tarasco, 24, played in 87 games for Atlanta last season and hit .273 with five homers and 19 r.b.i. He started only 18 games and led the Braves in pinch-hits.
In Grissom, though, Atlanta is getting a center fielder who hit .288 in 1994 with 11 homers, 45 r.b.i. and 36 stolen bases. The Braves beat out the Florida Marlins and Boston Red Sox in acquiring the highly skilled defensive outfielder, who is from Atlanta and whom the Braves intend to offer a long-term contrct.
The trades yesterday were only a small part of the furious activity general managers are faced with. Today, the first day of mandatory spring training for the returning strikers, clubs have to tender contracts to players who are eligible for salary arbitration or let them go as free agents, and they have to offer arbitration to their players who became free agents last October or lose their negotiation and compensation rights.
Also on the schedule today is the opening of the union's camp for free agents in Homestead, Fla. Mark Belanger, the union official coordinating the camp, said he already has lined up an exhibition game for a camp team. The free agents are scheduled to play the Chicago White Sox in Sarasota on April 22.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Resume Their Climb

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
The number of newly laid-off workers applying for jobless benefits climbed last week for the fourth time in five weeks, fresh evidence the economy has cooled from its strong pace at the end of the year.
New claims for unemployment insurance rose by 3,000,to a seasonally adjusted 341,000, the Labor Department said today. Claims fell by 10,000, to 338,000, in the week that ended on March 25, ending the first three-week string of advances in nearly a year. 
 The four-week moving average of new weekly jobless claims edged up to 342,500 last week, from 341,750 in the period that ended on March 25. It was the highest level since 347,750 in the period ended last July 30.
Many analysts prefer to track the less volatile four-week average because it smooths out the spikes in the weekly reports.

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Ruth Reichl 

 BODY:
One night four gorgeous women walked into Zut! wearing huge fluffy pink hats that looked exactly like cotton candy. Every head in the restaurant turned to watch as they were seated at a front table. Those pink clouds were so mesmerizing that everyone in the long, dark room waited to see if the women would remove them. We waited all evening and when they finally got up and left, hats still firmly anchored to their heads, a collective sigh zipped around the room.
This display was particularly impressive, given the difficulty of making an entrance at Zut! The fabulously silly room captures most of the attention. The eye is first caught by the animals cavorting over the circular bar and then bounces to the chandeliers made of giant straw hats. By the time it discovers the musical giraffes, dancing rabbits and bridge-playing penguins on the wallpaper, it is hooked. There is so much to discover: sombrero mirrors, copper monkey panels, gold animals twinkling on the ceiling like urban constellations. This is one of the most playful spaces in New York City. 
 Comfortable, too. The banquettes, dressed up in the dark striped silk that was once reserved for dressing gowns, are plush and cozy. If you are lucky enough to be seated in one of the curved booths in the back, you can sink into the silk and watch the TriBeCa parade. People look good and enjoy themselves in this wonderful room, and three months into its run, it is already packed.
Beautiful waitresses scurry about, opening bottles from the impressive wine list; there is something attractive to drink at just about any price. The menu is another appealing document. It describes the upscale bistro fare with humor and presents a great many choices at a variety of prices. Those feeling expansive can order caviar for $35, while the more economy-minded can choose an entire three-course dinner for $28. Everything sounds delicious.
But from the moment the cottony bread appears on the table, it is clear that food is not Zut!'s strong suit. It is certainly possible to have a fine meal here, but it is equally possible to have a pretty grim one.
If you want to be happy when you eat at Zut!, I suggest beginning with the roasted beet salad. It glistens like garnets beneath a slick of fragrant truffle oil. The coq au vin, a smoky, meaty stew of chicken and red wine balanced on chickpea spatzle, makes a satisfying main course. This is fine bistro cooking, the sort of straightforward, unpretentious food that is France at its best. Warm chocolate bread pudding offers two kinds of comfort mixed into a single dish, a perfect dessert. And then, to cap the meal, why not a shot of Calvados in your coffee? It's the best of Paris and New York at a single dinner.
There are other likable dishes at Zut! I am fond of the chewy, garlicky, escargots in their little copper pot. I appreciate the quality of the veal chop, and I love the creamy flageolets topped with buttery bread crumbs that come with the rack of lamb. And while I find the tabbouleh salad distressingly dull, the pretty pyramid of grains drizzled with yogurt-lime dressing and served with a few little crayfish is perfectly acceptable. Unfortunately, there is not much else at Zut! that I would happily order again.
The salad has a dreary dressing. Oysters on two occasions were flat and completely lacking in liquid. The saucisson lyonnaise is dense and delicious, but the warm potato salad on the side is little more than a few cubed potatoes. And so it goes.
Salt can be a serious problem. Foie gras, a special one night, was overcooked and salty, although the caramelized apples on the side helped a little. The bouillabaisse, an impressive all-shellfish concoction featuring clams, mussels, scallops and shrimp with a lobster tail smack dab in the middle, was marred by a very salty broth. And the sauce on a special steak one night was salty enough to make my mouth tingle.
The steak frites is a better choice. The meat is slightly tough but tasty. The frites, a haystack of skinny fried potatoes, is so attractive it is hard not to reach out and grab a fistful as they go sailing past the table. Unfortunately, it turns out that they have sacrificed taste to appearance; they are all crunch and stone cold.
Both the skate and the black bass strike me as dull. And the choucroute, which should be rich with the mingled juices of the smoked pork chop, blood sausage and white sausage with which it is garnished, is thin and acid-tasting; the dominating flavor is cabbage and white wine.
Desserts have improved a bit since the restaurant opened, but they are still works in progress. Warm pear tarte Tatin comes in a soggy shell, and the lemon-lime mousse is bouncy enough to recall the consistency of Jell-O. A special chiffon cake filled with mascarpone and blackberries is as sweet and bland as a Twinkie.
Even so, I'd go back to Zut! It's fun. It's lively. The food might get better. But even if it doesn't, I now know what to eat, where to sit and when to wear my most outrageous clothes.
 
Zut!
 *
 139 Duane Street, TriBeCa, (212) 513-0505.
Atmosphere: Z is for zany and for zoo, a wacky menagerie of animals that cavort on the wallpaper and over the bar, making this merry bistro one of the most appealing rooms in Manhattan.
Service: The waitresses are so beautiful they look like aspriring actresses, but they know their business and care about their customers.
Recommended dishes: Roasted beet salad, escargots, coq au vin rouge with chickpea spatzle, veal loin chop, rack of lamb with flageolets, chocolate bread pudding.
Wine list: Large, fairly priced and nicely chosen.
Hours: Dinner only, 6 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. Mondays through Wednesdays, until 2:30 A.M. Thursdays through Saturdays. Closed Sundays.
Price range: Appetizers $6 to $14, entrees $16 to $24, desserts $7.
Credit cards: American Express, Mastercard, Visa.
Wheelchair accessibility: There are ramps and the bathrooms are completely accessible.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Tumbles Below 84 Yen And Traders See New Weakness

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar continued to plunge to new lows against the Japanese yen in Asia today after tumbling yesterday.
At mid-afternoon today in Tokyo, the dollar dropped below 84 yen for the first time. 
 Still, many currency dealers wondered whether the Federal Reserve and other central banks would ultimately step in and buy dollars in an effort to prop up its value. Dealers said they were concerned about being caught short of dollars. On Wednesday, the Fed was joined by the Bank of Japan and the Bundesbank in buying dollars on foreign-exchange markets for the second time in three days.
Data on United States employment in March, which are scheduled to be released today, also created a sense of wariness in the markets.
Dealers said they expected the dollar to tumble again should the payroll numbers come out weak, as expected, which would create a sense the Fed might hesitate to raise interest rates.
Yesterday, however, the dollar managed to hold onto some ground against the German mark and other currencies.
 "It's the calm before the next storm," Richard Vullo of the Bayerische Hypotheken Bank said about yesterday's trading. "The bad news is out there. We're just waiting to see what the number looks like."
The dollar touched a post-World-War-II low of 85.14 yen in European trading yesterday. In late New York trading, the dollar settled at 85.27 yen, down from 86.20 yen on Wednesday.
But by mid-afternoon in Tokyo today, the dollar had fallen to 83.82 yen.
The dollar also fell yesterday to a postwar low against the Swiss franc, sliding to 1.113 Swiss francs. It recovered to 1.1270 francs in New York, up from 1.1235 francs on Wednesday. The dollar slipped to 1.3735 German marks from 1.3742 marks and to $1.6070 British pounds from $1.6085. These currencies showed moderate change this afternoon in Tokyo.
Analysts warned that further weakness might be in store for the dollar, saying that they saw scant signs that Washington was ready to bite the bullet on the dollar.
"The world is running out of options to deal with the dollar," said Michael Aho, senior international economist with Prudential Securities in New York.
In the five trading sessions ending yesterday, the dollar fell 5.27 percent against the yen and 2.62 percent against the mark.
The International Monetary Fund has suggested that the United States may need to raise interest rates further if the dollar remains under pressure.

HEADLINE: Janet Fitchen, 58, Rural Sociologist And Anthropologist

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Janet Mathews Fitchen, a cultural anthropologist who studied rural poverty in the United States, died on Saturday at her home in Ithaca, N.Y. She was 58.
The cause was a brain tumor, her family said. 
 Dr. Fitchen brought the eye of an anthropologist and her profession's ethnographic methodology to the field of rural sociology. A professor of anthropology, she was the chairwoman of the department of anthropology at Ithaca College.
She wrote "Poverty in Rural America: A Case Study" (Westview, 1981), which surveyed pockets of poverty in the vast stretches of forests and fields of upstate New York. "I call it northern Appalachia," she told a reporter in 1984. "It is poverty that has been entrenched."
Her latest book was "Endangered Spaces, Enduring Places: Change, Identity and Survival in Rural America" (Westview, 1991). It chronicled the demographic, social, cultural, economic and agricultural changes transforming the Northeast. Both books are in print.
More recently, she researched poverty in other regions as an associate of the Western Rural Development Center in Corvallis, Ore. She had accepted a faculty appointment in the department of rural sociology at Cornell University and had planned to leave Ithaca College, where she had been a faculty member since 1977, at the end of the semester.
Dr. Fitchen was born in Manhattan but grew up on her family's dairy farm in Brewster, attending a one-room school. She graduated from Vassar College and received a master's degree in anthropology from the University of Illinois.
She did field work with Oscar Lewis in a Mexican village and received her Ph.D. in anthropology from Cornell.
Dr. Fitchen is survived by her husband, Douglas B. Fitchen, a Cornell professor; a son, John H., of La Jolla, Calif.; and two daughters, Katherine F. Nisbet of Bozeman, Mont., and Sylvia Fitchen of Tucson, Ariz.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Janet Mathews Fitchen (Diana Papineau)

SECTION: Section A; Page 34; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 558 words

HEADLINE: Alms for the Affluent

 BODY:
House Republicans approved the last major element of their Contract With America this week by proposing to hand voters a $189 billion tax cut over five years. At the same time, in a second, less splashy part of the bill, they proposed a $315 billion cut in discretionary spending (after accounting for inflation) over five years.
The tax cuts are tilted toward the wealthy; the spending cuts are tilted against the poor. The double whammy makes the contract an outrageously unfair transfer of income from the needy to the rich. 
 The tax bill, according to the Treasury, would cut taxes by perhaps $99 billion a year when phased in. About half the total (including corporate) cuts would go to the wealthiest 10 percent of households. A fifth of the cut would go to the wealthiest 1 percent of families. To help pay for the measure, the bill would cut more than $60 billion out of welfare programs and 17 percent out of discretionary programs by the year 2000.
The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal think tank, estimates that 70 percent of the House's spending cuts would come from the 20 percent of the budget that goes to low-income families. Food stamps, school lunches, housing assistance, day-care allowances and every other need-based program will shrink after taking account of inflation. By the center's estimates, low-income families would absorb two-thirds of the spending cuts, but reap only about 5 percent of the tax cuts.
The plan did not have to be this skewed. The Republicans could have chopped Government down to whatever size they wanted without tilting it severely against the needy. Indeed, to put its sorry budget policy together, the G.O.P. had to betray many of its own values.
The G.O.P. recognizes savings as the key to faster growth, yet House Republicans passed a contract that would encourage consumption with a tax cut of $500 per child. The G.O.P. says it wants to stimulate future investment, but then proposes to cut taxes on the sale of old investments.
The Republicans would write into the tax code new protections against inflation for investors, while wiping out some inflation protection for recipients of food stamps. The G.O.P. preaches the virtues of letting markets guide investors. Yet the contract jimmies the tax code so that investors in certain assets will pay negative tax rates -- in effect receiving a government check on top of their private earnings.
The audacious move to rewrite the Federal budget goes well beyond anything President Reagan attempted, let alone acccomplished. Roughly speaking, Congress did not cut taxes under Mr. Reagan. It substituted higher payroll taxes for lower income taxes, thereby putting little downward pressure on government spending. This time around, G.O.P. conservatives intend to make sure taxes drop lower, forcing government spending down as well.
Stepping beyond the contract, the G.O.P. pledges to balance the budget. Counting the tax cuts under the contract, the pledge would require Congress to knock about a third out of cuttable Government programs by 2002. Americans can judge for themselves whether they want a third of nearly everything the Government pays for -- from student loans to border patrols -- to vanish. But they should be shamed if Congress follows the House's lead and victimizes the most vulnerable.

HEADLINE: U.S. Scrambles to Block Oil Rigs From Reaching Serbia

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: ATHENS, April 7

 BODY:
In a secret transaction involving four countries, several companies and altered documents, two oil rigs have been shipped from Iran en route to Serbia in violation of the United Nations sanctions against Belgrade, Western officials say.
The shipment was discovered by the Central Intelligence Agency after it left Iran, officials said, and now the United States is trying to prevent the contraband from reaching its destination. 
 Apparently in an attempt to disguise the identity of the intended recipient in Serbia, which would use the equipment for its war machine, the original documents for the transaction described the contents in the ship's hold as oil-drilling equipment destined for Bulgaria, then Russia. The oil rigs had belonged to a Canadian company owned by a Serbian immigrant.
The documents were later altered to say the rigs were hydrological research equipment, destined for Macedonia, according to officials from several countries, who have seen the documents and are tracking the equipment. Western officials said similar shipments were planned if this one was successful.
"It is a particularly egregious example of a broader problem," said a Western diplomat who follows sanctions closely.
The broader problem, officials said, is that the sanctions have developed a huge leak in the southern Balkans, and traders and the Serbs are using so many false fronts that governments are finding it hard to stem the flow. Not since engines for fighter planes were smuggled into Serbia a few years ago has a single shipment in violation of the United Nations embargo so alarmed Washington, officials say. And now the high-stakes espionage drama continues.
Investigators are trying to keep track of the equipment, which is more than 100 trucks' worth and already in at least three countries -- and block it from reaching the Serbs, who have oilfields in the north and in a Serbian-controlled area of eastern Croatia.
"This is big stuff," a Western diplomat said. "The most important thing you can deny to Yugoslavia is oil."
With the United States having declined to send troops into the war zones of Bosnia and Croatia, sanctions against Yugoslavia are the centerpiece of Washington's Balkan policy. They are the means by which the United States hopes to persuade President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, the most powerful politician in Yugoslavia, to negotiate, end his support for the Bosnian Serbs and recognize the independence and boundaries of Croatia, Bosnia and Macedonia, all of which broke away from the old Yugoslavia.
The case of the oil-drilling equipment is highly delicate, and officials who answered questions did so only on the condition that they, and in some cases even their countries, not be identified.
The issue is delicate in part because about 700 tons of the equipment has already slipped through Greece and Bulgaria, and neither American nor European diplomats want to embarrass those countries' governments. In addition, Western intelligence agencies do not want the Iranians and the Serbs to learn how they found out about the shipment.
Slobodan Popovich, who works in the foreign press section of the Yugoslav Information Ministry, said he knew nothing about the shipment. "I doubt if anyone would," he said. He said that it would be a violation of the United Nations sanctions for anyone to sell such equipment to Yugoslavia, but that he did not think it would violate any law for Yugoslavia to try to buy it.
The Iranian Embassy here declined to comment, saying it knew nothing about the matter, and the Foreign Ministry's press office in Teheran declined to answer questions.
One of the most perplexing questions for investigators is why Iran would sell something of such military and strategic value as oil-drilling equipment to Yugoslavia, since Iran openly supports the Muslim-led Bosnian Government in its war with the Serbs.
One Western official speculated that Iran did it simply for the money. But some Western officials have not ruled out the possibility that even Iran did not know the ultimate destination of the equipment and that it might have been diverted after leaving that country, though they said this seemed unlikely given the control the Iranian Government exercises.
The shipping documents list the shipper of the equipment as Canadian Triton International, which is based in Calgary, Alberta. It is owned by Vladimir Katic, who Western officials said is a Serb who immigrated to Canada from Yugoslavia in 1966.
Canadian Triton is a small oil-drilling company whose only operations are in Iran, George Duchesne, a company official, said in a telephone interview from Calgary. Mr. Duchesne, who declined to give his position in the company, confirmed that Mr. Katic was the owner and said he did not know about his background.
Mr. Duchesne said he did not know why Canadian Triton's name was on the shipping documents. He said the company had leased the two rigs from a Yugoslav company in 1992 and had used them in Iran for one year. At the end of that time, Mr. Duchesne said, they belonged to Yugoslavia again.
"It's theirs," Mr. Duchesne said. "Is there a problem with their bringing their own stuff home?"
Based on interviews with American, Western European and Balkan officials in seven countries, it is possible to piece together this outline of events:
An Iranian ship, the Ershad, left Iran about Feb. 1, loaded with two rigs. It landed at the Greek port of Salonika about Feb. 20. The equipment, valued at $4.9 million, was consigned to a Bulgarian company.
When the United States, through its intelligence sources, determined that the equipment was headed for Yugoslavia, it approached all governments in the region.
One of the Security Council's sanctions resolutions -- No. 820, which was passed in April 1993 -- requires countries to detain all vessels and cargoes "suspected" of having been involved in violating sanctions.
When the American intelligence was first relayed to the Greeks, they were slow to react, European and American officials said.
A Greek Foreign ministry official who insisted on anonymity said Greece had not initially interfered with the shipment because under Greek law the Government has no right to stop a shipment in transit to a legitimate country, in this case Bulgaria, according to the shipping documents.
Later, under constant pressure from the United States and the European Union's sanctions monitoring office in Brussels, Greece put a hold on the rest of the equipment.
Before Greece acted, Western officials said, about 1,200 tons had already been hauled by trucks to Bulgaria. They crossed the border at Kulata, consigned to a company called Baypass, several officials said, including one who read from the shipping documents. Officials said they had not been able to locate the company.
It was after the shipment reached Bulgaria that the documents were altered, declaring that the cargo was hydrological research equipment, Western officials said.
American officials asked the Bulgarian Government not to allow the cargo to continue. But the Bulgarians said they could not interfere with the shipment since it was intended for Macedonia, a country against which there is no embargo.
The Bulgarian Foreign Ministry said no one was available to answer questions about the case. The President's office said he was on a trip to North Korea and Mongolia with his spokesman and foreign affairs adviser.
Bulgaria notified the United Nations sanctions committee this week that 60 truckloads of the equipment passed through Bulgaria into Macedonia.
Some of it was loaded onto rail cars and was about to go to Serbia when American officials stepped in. The fully loaded rail cars sit on the tracks.
If the United States succeeds in persuading Greece and Macedonia not to release the equipment now in their custody -- and Western officials say it is by no means certain Washington will -- the deal will have fallen through for the Serbs, because the parts that have been held up are needed for the rigs to work.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From President's Speech

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 7

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's address today to the American Society of Newspaper Editors, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:
Ladies and gentlemen, we are at an historic moment in our country's history, on the verge of a new century, living in a very different kind of economy with a bewildering array of challenges and opportunities. In 1992 and in 1994, the voters spoke out and demanded bold changes in the way we govern and the policies we pursue. They know better than anyone else that they are living in a time with new challenges that demand new answers. In the last two years, my Administration has begun to meet those challenges. . . . 
 But it is not enough. Too many Americans don't yet feel any of those benefits. Too many still feel uncertain about their own future, and too many people are overwhelmingly concerned about the social and the underlying moral problems of our society.
And so in 1994 they voted to give the Republicans a chance to run the Congress. In the last 100 days, the House of Representatives has passed a series of bold initiatives. We will soon begin the second 100 days of this Congress.
In the first 100 days, the mission of the House Republicans was to suggest ways in which we should change our Government and our society. In the second 100 days and beyond, our mission together must be to decide which of these House proposals should be adopted, which should be modified and which should be stopped.
In the first 100 days, it fell to the House of Representatives to propose. In the next 100 days and beyond, the President has to lead the quiet, reasoned forces of both parties in both houses to sift through the rhetoric and decide what is really best for America. In making these decisions, it is absolutely vital that we keep alive the spirit and the momentum of change, but the momentum must not carry us so far that we betray our legacy of compassion, decency and common sense. . . .
We stand at a crossroads. In one direction lies confrontation and gridlock; in the other lies achievement and progress. I was not elected President to pile up a stack of vetoes. I was elected President to change the direction of America. That's what I have spent the next two, last two, years doing, and that's what I want to spend the next 100 days and beyond doing.
Whether we can do that depends upon what all of us in Washington do from here on out.
So I appeal today to Republicans and to Democrats alike to get together, to keep the momentum for change going, not to allow the energy and longing for change now to be dissipated amid a partisan clutter of accusations. After all, we share much common ground. . . .
In that spirit I come here today to outline where I stand on the remaining items in the Republican contract and the unfinished business of my New Covenant.
Let's begin with taxes. In 1993, I made a down payment on the middle-class tax cut I advocated when I ran for President. We cut taxes for 15 million working families. What that means on average is that this year a family of four with an income of $25,000 a year or less will have about $1,000 in lower tax bills. We did this to insure that nobody who works full time and has children should live in poverty. If you want to reform the welfare system, you must reward work and parenting.
So I want a tax cut to expand, to include more members of the middle class. . . . But this $200 billion tax cut, which is really more than three times that, if you look at it over a 10-year period, is a fantasy. It's too much. It's not going to happen. We can't afford it.
A realistic cut would be somewhere around a third of that. That's something we can afford. . . . Let's target a tax cut to the right people and for the right purpose. We have to choose. Do you want a tax cut for the wealthy or for the middle class? . . .
Let's take welfare reform. As I said, both of us -- both the Republican contract and my New Covenant -- have focused heavily on welfare reform. What do we agree on? That there ought to be a limit to welfare, that there ought to be flexibility for the states, that we ought to have the toughest possible child support enforcement and that people have to take more responsibility for their own lives and for children they bring into this world.
But the current House bill focuses primarily on cutting costs. It's weak on work and tough on kids. It punishes young people for past mistakes. . . . The House bill also punishes young children for the sins of their parents. I think that's wrong. . . .
But look what we agree on. We are near historic change, we can do this. We can make a difference, we can break the culture of welfare. And we can do something good for our country to support the values we all believe in. And we can give these children a better future. But to do it we're going to have to talk through our differences and get beyond the rhetoric to how these real lives work, and not stand on the sidelines posturing for political gain.
Let's take cutting the deficit. The balanced-budget amendment is dead, but now we have to get specific. How are we going to cut the deficit and move this budget toward balance? If we can focus on cuts, not making partisan points, that's the first step. There are cuts I can't live with, there are cuts the Republicans can't live with. Let's avoid them and make cuts we can all live with. . . .
Regulatory reform -- another big item in the Republican contract. There are lots of horror stories. Every one of you probably knows a story that shows where a bureaucrat overreached or there were too many regulations or there was too little common sense. I am committed to changing the culture of regulation that has dominated our country for a long time. . . .
We are working on these things to move forward, but we must do more. And yet, surely the answer is not to stop the Government from regulating what it needs to regulate. If the Republicans send me a bill that would let unsafe planes fly or contaminated meat be sold or contaminated water continue to find itself into city water systems, I will veto it. I will veto it. . . .
Crime. Crime was a big part of the New Covenant, a big part of why I ran for President. The personal security of the American people should be our first concern. And we delivered. After six years, we broke gridlock and I signed a crime bill that was endorsed by all the major law-enforcement agencies in the country. . . .
Now, if the Republicans wish to continue to try to repeal the commitment to 100,000 police, or to repeal the assault weapons ban, they have a perfect right to do it. But if they send me those provisions, I will veto them. On the other hand, while the rest of their crime bill needs some work, and I disagree with some provisions of it, it has some good points. If we can build on the '94 crime bill instead of tear it down, we can continue our efforts to make the American people more secure. So let's do that. Let's pass a crime bill we can be proud of, that builds the country up and makes our citizens safer. . . .
I haven't forgotten the need to reform health care. Everybody knows we still have problems. It costs too much. There are a lot of people who have inadequate coverage. There are a lot of people who have no coverage at all. And there are millions of Americans who could lose their coverage at any time.
So I call on Republicans to join me in taking this one step at a time, beginning with things the majority of them have long endorsed: first, making benefits portable, so you don't lose your health care when you change jobs; second, requiring coverage for families with a pre-existing condition, so a whole family doesn't lose health care just because there's been one sick child. . . .
Cutting education in the face of global competition -- as I have said repeatedly -- would be just like cutting the defense budget at the height of the cold war. It undermines our security as a people, and we shouldn't do it. . . .
I do not want a pile of vetoes. I want a pile of bills that will move this country into the future. I don't want to see a big fight between the Republicans and the Democrats. I want us to surprise everybody in America by rolling up our sleeves and joining hands and working together.

HEADLINE: Iraq Dismisses Limited Plan to Ease Sanctions

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 7

 BODY:
Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister seemed today to dismiss as unacceptable a new Security Council plan that would allow his country to sell a limited amount of oil to raise money for medicine, food and other essential supplies.
The Baghdad Government says that the sanctions imposed by the United Nations in 1990 and modified after the Persian Gulf war prohibiting most exports and imports by Iraq are causing severe hardships for ordinary people. 
 The Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, told reporters after he met with Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali today that he had "strong reservations" about the Security Council resolution proposed by Argentina, the United States and Britain, though he indicated that he would be willing to look at a modified version.
The new resolution, which could be voted on as early as next week, would allow Iraq to sell $1 billion worth of oil every 90 days. The resolution would be in effect for six months but could be renewed. Under a previous Security Council resolution that has lapsed, Iraq would have been permitted to make only a onetime sale worth $1.6 billion to pay for the basic needs of people suffering from the trade sanctions.
The new measure stipulates that 70 percent of oil income would go to human needs in Iraq, including Kurdish-held areas of the north. Thirty percent would be earmarked for a compensation fund for victims of Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
But Iraq, with some support from France and Russia, has been holding out for the broader lifting of limits on Iraqi oil sales under the terms of a resolution adopted by the Security Council in 1991. That resolution would allow President Saddam Hussein to resume sales under less stringent conditions when Iraq fully complies with the demands of a special commission monitoring the destruction of Baghdad's weapons of mass destruction.
The head of the commission, Rolf Ekeus, is expected to present a report to the Security Council next week saying he is confident that cooperation has been sufficient in eliminating missiles and chemical weapons and that an effective monitoring system is now in place.
But on biological weapons, Mr. Ekeus is expected to express concern about a large quantity of imported growth cultures missing from Iraq's accounting that could be used to produce either vaccines or biological weapons.
Diplomats say that the Ekeus commission lists 17 tons of biological cultures, far more than a country would need for pharamceutical purposes, that have not been accounted for. Another 13 tons have been traced, but Mr. Ekeus says that until he can account for all the materials he cannot judge Iraq's capability.
The United States, which on those grounds alone can argue that Iraq has not satisfied all the demands of the resolution -- or proven it can live up to other agreements -- will try to head off a French and Russian move to lift sanctions.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

Clinton Warns G.O.P. He Will Veto Bills
After three months of ceding the initiative to Congressional Republicans, President Clinton defined the limits of his willingness to compromise, saying he would veto bills dealing with legal and regulatory reform, crime, the use of United States troops in United Nations operations and compensation for property owners whose land loses value as a result of Federal regulations.
 While he did not specifically say he would veto the $189 billion tax cut bill enacted by the House as the climax of the Republicans' first 100 days, Mr. Clinton called it a "fantasy." "We can't afford it," he said. Page 1.
 
Inquiries Into Seagram Deals
Canadian securities regulators and the Toronto Stock Exchange plan to investigate Seagram disclosures of its plans to sell a stake in Du Pont and buy control of MCA. 40.
 
From the start, Matsushita and MCA were an odd couple. Matsushita is conservative in nearly every way, from the dull blue employee uniforms to the frugal beliefs that pulled the purse strings on MCA's desires. By contrast, Hollywood is instinctively ostentatious and extravagant. "Matsushita basically gave up," one analyst said. 40.
 
McCaw Offers $3.3 Billion for LIN
AT&T's wireless unit, McCaw Cellular Communications, will offer $3.3 billion for the part of LIN Broadcasting it does not already own. McCaw will acquire approximately 26 million LIN shares for $127.50 each in cash. The price was recommended by Wasserstein Perrella & Company on March 7 after advisers to AT&T and LIN placed widely different values on the company. 41.
 
Dow Retreats on Profit Taking
The Dow retreated 12.79 points, to 4,192.62, as traders took profits from the week's record-setting rally. Stocks were weighed down by the March unemployment report that showed that manufacturers' payrolls shrank as the unemployment rate rose one-tenth of 1 percent. In the currency market, the dollar fell to another low against the yen, settling in New York at 83.82 yen. 43.
 
Inflationary pressures pushed the price of the 30-year Treasury bond lower. 51.
Mexico Backs Off on Bonds
The Mexican Government now concedes that this year it is unlikely to bring to market a new kind of treasury bond to replace those tied to the dollar -- called tesobonos. Nor is the Government expected to issue new versions of the tesobono this year. Instead, officials say they will raise funds by offering commercial paper sometime after May that would be backed by loan guarantees from the United States. The tesobonos had been identified as a principal cause of Mexico's economic troubles, and investors were not sorry to see them disappear. "Good riddance to them, absolutely," said one analyst in the United States. 42.
 
Netscape Sells Stake to Investors
Netscape Communications, which makes the most popular software program for browsing the World Wide Web, has sold a 11 percent stake to a group of investors consisting of Adobe Systems, Hearst, Knight-Ridder, Tele-Communications and Times Mirror. 41.
 
Judges Get More Power on Patents
A ruling by the nation's highest patent court --essentially saying that judges should determine what a patent means -- is likely to stem the number of infringement cases heard by juries. 41.
 
Paine Webber Alters Compensation
Paine Webber introduced a new compensation plan in an effort to increase sales by 10 percent this year and to encourage brokers to stay with the securities firm. 43.
 
B.C.C.I. Suit Is Thrown Out
A Federal court dismissed a lawsuit filed by depositors against the people they contended were responsible for the collapse of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. 43.
 
Breaking Up the Yankees, for Profit
A New York lawyer is trying to buy a 3.1 percent stake in the New York Yankees so that he can divide it into 20,000 shares and sell them for $500 apiece. 25.

HEADLINE: Into the Woods in Asia;
Myanmar? North Korea? No Sweat for Hong Kong Firm

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, April 7

 BODY:
Francis Pike liked what he saw in North Korea on a reconnaissance trip for Peregrine Investment Holdings Ltd., the Hong Kong investment bank, in the fall of 1993.
 It was a place of pervasive tyranny and cultish obeisance to a "great leader." The Communist Government was an international pariah, accused by the United States and other Western countries of feverishly building nuclear weapons, shipping missiles to the Middle East, fomenting terrorism, kidnapping its critics abroad and crushing domestic dissent. And the country was overwhelmed by poverty. 
 "Clearly, their economy was a catastrophe," Mr. Pike recalled. "There really was no economic life there."
 It was, in short, the sort of place that Peregrine found appealing. For North Korea had one huge asset: opportunity. "They clearly gave the indication that things were going to change," he said. "I think they're expecting us to be able to bring in capital, companies and clients."
 Since that trip, Peregrine has formed a joint banking venture with the Daeson Group, which is controlled by the North Korean Government. And while Peregrine remains the only outside investment firm active in the country, it is also doing business with other countries where many investment banks may tread warily, or not at all.
 It was the first investment bank to move into Myanmar, formerly Burma, ruled by a military dictatorship. It was one of the first to go to Communist-ruled Vietnam. And, when other companies and banks stepped back after the Tiananmen Square massacre in Beijing in June 1989, the newly created Peregrine only accelerated its activities in China.
 Such willingness to take gambles, combined with a talent for making friends in high places, has helped Peregrine grow from a start-up with $38 million to spend into a regional powerhouse in a little more than six years. But its willingness to strike alliances with some of Asia's more unsavory regimes, and accusations of unethical behavior ranging from market manipulation to plagiarism, have created a serious image problem for the bank.
 Its ties with the Myanmar Government, which crushed civil unrest in the late 1980's and continues to imprison the leader of the country's democratic opposition, have soured some of its investors, for example. The Quantum Fund N.V., run by the American financier George Soros, recently divested itself of 10,000 shares of Peregrine stock.
 While other Western companies have footholds in China and Vietnam, some human-rights advocates dislike what they regard as Peregrine's unapologetic embrace of dictatorial regimes. "We're strongly opposed to any business going into a country like North Korea or Burma or even China unless it is willing to press for human rights and a greater respect for the rule of law," said Sidney Jones, executive director of Human Rights Watch/Asia in New York.
 The Economist magazine noted recently that while other banks did business in China, "the difference is that Peregrine does not even affect to hold its nose."
 None of this fazes Philip L. Tose, Peregrine's chairman and co-founder, who contends that a dismal political or human-rights record of a regime is no reason to avoid a lucrative market. "Yes, there had been a very unfortunate incident which had a lot of coverage, shocked a lot of people," Mr. Tose said of the Tiananmen Square killings. "But underneath all that, nothing really had changed in terms of the fundamentals that had made people originally want to invest in those areas.
 "Our view," Mr. Tose said, "and it's a very controversial view, is that countries develop through economic dialogue. Simply introducing political democracy is not necessarily the first step that should be taken. It is better to increase the standard of living of the people, which in turn will lead over time to social change, political change, etc."
 Francis Leung Pak To, Peregrine's managing director and Mr. Tose's partner, said the bank had come to the conclusion "that these events were just a hiccup."
 "We decided we wanted to take advantage of depressed market conditions at the time," he said. Peregrine rapidly bought control of two companies which it used to expand its asset base and to raise capital.
 Mr. Tose also brushes aside ethical lapses by his bank. In 1993, the Securities and Futures Commission of Hong Kong reprimanded Peregrine for engaging in "trading activity which was, or was likely to be, prejudicial to the interests of the investing public" by buying back shares that it had previously sold in an effort to disguise the real market for those shares.
 "It happened at a time we were growing very fast and frankly we didn't have the right systems in place of checks and balances," Mr. Tose said. "We have now. I think a recurrence of something like that would be difficult."
 But tripping over the line of the permissible did not end there. Earlier this year, Peregrine published a long research report on the economic prospects of Myanmar. The report was intended to promote the group's own access to the military regime and the country's business community; the problem, however, was that the contents of the report were plagiarized from a report on Myanmar written by a smaller Hong Kong securities firm, Kerry Securities.
 Mr. Leung blamed the Myanmar office for the plagiarism, and said the office was not closely supervised. "That was an example of growing pains," he said.
 Whatever its public image, Peregrine has enjoyed a meteoric rise in Asian banking. It was founded in late 1988 by Mr. Tose, who had previously headed a Citicorp venture in Hong Kong, and by Mr. Leung, one of his rising stars there. The two men cobbled together $38 million (United States) from some of Hong Kong's wealthiest business leaders. Though the founders wanted to call their new firm Falcon, they could not obtain rights to the name, Mr. Tose said, so they chose Peregrine, a breed of the same bird of prey. "We like it because it's an aggressive bird," Mr. Tose said. "It typifies what we are."
 Since then, the capital base of Peregrine has soared to $550 million, which would put it at the lower end of the top 20 investment banks in the United States. It had revenue of $3.74 billion last year, up from $233 million in 1989. And while profit fell last year, to $82.5 million from $112 million in 1993, Mr. Tose said the results were not "nearly as bad as many of the international investment banking houses." Peregrine also managed to tighten its grip on the market for initial public offerings in China and Hong Kong, increasing its share to 75 percent from 60 percent in 1993.
 Analysts attribute much of the success of Peregrine to the founders' brilliant choice of investors. They include Li Ka-shing, one of the world's richest men, who made much of his fortune in Hong Kong's property market; Gordon Wu, a property developer, and Larry Yung, head of the Hong Kong branch of the China International Trust and Investment Corporation, the mainland's principal investment bank.
 Peregrine has also built an impressive list of high-level contacts across Asia, where it has opened 25 offices in 14 countries, both its admirers and competitors say.
 Mr. Li, whose vast business empire includes ports in Hong Kong and China, hotels, telecommunications ventures, satellite services and electric power projects, made no bones about the importance of knowing the right people. And in Asia, he said, that usually means having influence with the right families.
 "If you were working in Europe or America at the turn of the century, your connections were vital," Mr. Li said. "Without them, you were dead. Asia is to a degree at that stage of development today. It's not quite, because everyone has moved on a little bit. But business, industry, government to a degree, are controlled by families just the way they were in the West at the turn of the century."
 Mr. Tose said he would like to reduce Peregrine's reliance on China and Hong Kong to half its business from the current 80 percent. As a result, the bank keeps pushing into other parts of Asia.
 Today, for example, it has 250 employees in the three major cities of South Korea and is the only foreign company with a seat on the Seoul stock exchange. In Myanmar, it has opened Peregrine Capital Myanmar Ltd., which among other things has invested in a shrimp-processing plant.
 For some people, sniping at Peregrine for its supposed cozying up to dictatorships smacks of sour grapes. "The success of Peregrine is a measure of the failure of competitors to take advantage of market conditions," said a Hong Kong banker who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "The market here needed a local investment bank more in tune with their needs, particularly smaller companies that want to come to the market."
 A European banker here, who has watched Peregrine's march through Asia with some admiration, said he had one major concern -- that the expansion had gone too fast. "The jury is well and truly out," the banker said. "Management there is very thin. For a company that size it is surprising that decisions are made by three or four people. Clearly there is a lot of skepticism about whether they can manage a business of that size."

HEADLINE: Bad Jobs News for New York, But New Jersey Registers Gain

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
New York's unemployment rate rose last month, raising renewed concern that the economic lag that has plagued the state would continue to kill any chance of a significant recovery any time soon, Labor Department officials said yesterday.
 They said the possibility of additional layoffs of New York City workers, particularly in the health care sector, raised the prospect of even more unemployment. 
 Moreover, they said the slowdown in manufacturing reflected in yesterday's national unemployment figures could also worsen New York's inability to generate an economic recovery.
 "The possibility of additional job losses in the health care and hospital sector could become a major social issue in New York City," said Anthony J. Ferrara, acting regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
 But in sharp contrast, employment conditions in New Jersey continued to improve, reflecting the state's break from the economic doldrums that have blanketed much of the Northeast.
 "In real terms, New Jersey continues to be the best economic performer in the Northeast, way ahead of Connecticut, New York and Pennsylvania," Mr. Ferrara said.
 While the national unemployment rate rose slightly last month to 5.5 percent, up one-tenth of 1 percent from February, the unemployment rate in New York State rose to 6.6 percent, up from 6.1 percent in February, but down from the 7.9 percent rate a year earlier.
 The number of unemployed was 558,000, compared with 523,000 a month ago and 681,000 a year earlier.
 At the same time, New York City's jobless rate was 8.5 percent, down from 9 percent in February and 10.3 percent in March 1994. But Mr. Ferrara said last month's decrease in the city was not significant because it was based on figures that were not seasonally adjusted.
 In New Jersey, meanwhile, the unemployment rate last month fell to 5.8 percent from 6.1 percent in February and nearly two full points below the 7.7 percent rate a year earlier.
 Connecticut is not one of the 11 states for which the Labor Department provides separate figures when it releases national employment data.
 With the exception of New Jersey, Mr. Ferrara said prospects of an economic recovery in the Northeast region were apparently still stalled.
 "What we see is a very flat economy that is barely able to tread water," he said."
 And what might make conditions appear worse, officials said, was that the economic fall from the boom years of the mid-1980's to the late 1980's was so steep and unforgiving, particularly in the city's major economic areas of construction, insurance, finance and real estate.
 For example, Mr. Ferrara said New York State generated only 52,000 new jobs in the last year, giving it a ranking of third to last among the 50 states in new jobs.

HEADLINE: Rich Nations Criticize U.S. On Foreign Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
An organization of wealthy industrial nations issued a stinging report today criticizing the United States for moving to cut foreign aid when it already gives a smaller share of its economic output to such assistance than any other industrial nation.
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a Paris-based group of 25 nations, said the United States, once far and away the world's leading donor, was setting a poor example by cutting its aid budget and warned that the move might prompt other countries to follow suit. 
 Using unusually blunt language, the report said that "this seeming withdrawal from traditional leadership is so grave that it poses a risk of undermining political support for development cooperation" by other donor countries.
The report said the United States had slipped to No. 2, well behind Japan, in the amount of foreign aid provided excluding military assistance. The United States provided $9.72 billion in 1993, compared with $11.3 billion for Japan.
It said the United States contributed 15-hundredths of one percent of its gross domestic product for economic aid, putting it last among the 25 industrial nations. The average among these nations was 30-hundredths of one percent, while Sweden, Denmark and Norway all give 1 percent of their overall output to foreign aid.
J. Brian Atwood, Administrator of the Agency for International Development, the Government's principal aid arm, welcomed the report, making clear that he intends to use it as ammunition in the Clinton Administration's fight to persuade Congress not to cut foreign aid. At a news briefing today, Mr. Atwood criticized Congressional committees for proposing to cut $3 billion from the $21 billion international affairs budget, which includes State Department spending as well as foreign aid.
The report was written by the O.E.C.D. Secretariat and was overseen by James H. Michel, the chairman of its development assistance committee. Mr. Michel was an assistant administrator of A.I.D. in the Bush Administration.
