HEADLINE: Critics Claim Javits Chief Is Not Up to the Challenge

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: CORTLANDT, N.Y.

 BODY:
At a small hospital tucked among the sloping woods of this Westchester County community, Robert Boyle is considered a savior.
 As the volunteer chairman of the Hudson Valley Hospital Center, he brought in a new management team that helped rescue it from the brink of financial failure, turning it into a thriving competitor among the region's nonprofit hospitals. To admiring staff members, one administrator said, "he walks on water." 
 Mr. Boyle, the new chief executive of the troubled Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, is now facing a far more arduous challenge.
 He is charged with eliminating mismanagement, labor problems and mob corruption at the state-run center, which has been steadily losing money and business. His job will demand that he lower costs, modernize the center and promote it as an attractive convention destination, while overseeing 100 full-time employees and hundreds of other workers in the six labor unions operating there.
 "The problems are entrenched," says Stephen J. Morello, president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. "There's no shortage of challenge."
 Mr. Boyle, whose selection as head of the Javits Center was confirmed this week by the center's governing board, is a former owner of a concrete company in Tarrytown, a business that he says has given him insight into organized crime.
 But since Mr. Pataki nominated Mr. Boyle as head of the center, a number of questions have been raised about his experience and about the track record of the companies he has led. Because his experience is limited to running small- and medium-size companies, as well as serving on civic boards like the hospital's, some skeptics have questioned whether he is prepared to take on the huge task of operating the Javits Center.
 "The Javits Center is a major business enterprise with complicated issues," said Michael Cherkasky, who conducted a 1992 investigation of the convention center for the New York District Attorney's office and currently works as a managing director at Kroll Associates, an investigative firm. "This will not be a doable job if the person doesn't have experience with big business and in dealing with extensive labor problems."
 Other critics have wondered whether Mr. Boyle's personal relationship with Mr. Pataki -- who chose Mr. Boyle as his campaign treasurer last year and has yet to repay a $10,000 personal loan from him -- is evidence of an ongoing pattern of patronage and indifference at the convention center. "It certainly calls into question whether he has the requisite independence to take on this position," said Neil V. Getnick, managing partner in a New York law firm that specializes in commercial fraud and crime and is familiar with the Javits Center from his days as an Assistant District Attorney in Manhattan.
 Mr. Boyle, who defended his qualifications in a recent interview, said he was not daunted by the skeptics or by the job ahead. "The challenge now is to sweep the place clean," he said. "I have a very difficult task, but I know how to do this. We'll do this a hell of a lot faster than anybody thinks it will get done."
 When Mr. Pataki nominated Mr. Boyle for the $125,000-a-year job, he cited Mr. Boyle's "extensive experience in finance, administration, labor relations, construction, budget control and crisis management."
 For most of his career, Mr. Boyle, 58, has been an entrepreneur with interests in concrete, construction and real estate. While few could dispute his success as volunteer chairman of the Westchester hospital, not all of his business dealings have fared as well.
 Federal Court records show that one of Mr. Boyle's partners in a concrete business was among a group of trustees who were removed from a pension board by the Federal Government, which said they had allowed a union official with ties to organized crime to misuse money.
 In addition, Mr. Boyle and his partners sold their concrete business to a company that Federal investigators have said is linked to the mob. That company is now in bankruptcy and still owes Mr. Boyle about $250,000 for the 1988 transaction. Also, a condominium project that Mr. Boyle tried to develop in Vermont went into bankruptcy midway through construction and is still faced with unsettled claims.
 "Given the history of the convention center, the Governor shouldn't want anyone other than someone with a perfect record of having no association with organized crime and a track record of running a convention center in a major city," said William J. Stern, a private investor who formerly headed the state's Economic Development Corporation. "The center has never been run by anyone with the appropriate experience. Now the beat goes on."
 Mr. Boyle acknowledged the pervasive existence of organized crime in the concrete and construction business, but he said he had successfully fought for more than two decades to keep it out of his own companies. He said he was not aware until long after the fact of any mob associations involving his partner or the purchaser of their company. And like other entrepreneurs, Mr. Boyle said, he lost money on some of his ventures.
 Mr. Boyle said that he planned to surround himself with managers who have convention center expertise, but that he did not want to disclose his specific plans for removing the mob element because doing so would "build up too much animosity" before his arrival. "I can't wait to prove the skeptics wrong," he said.
 After graduating from LaSalle University, Mr. Boyle began working for a New York City concrete company, where he advanced in administration and operations. By 1967, Mr. Boyle was a part owner of Westchester Concrete, a company in Tarrytown, N.Y., that he said eventually grew to generate $25 million in annual revenue, with 150 full-time employees.
 In more than two decades at Westchester Concrete, Mr. Boyle said, he gained "a lot of experience keeping corruption and organized crime out" of the company. He said he had negotiated more than 25 labor contracts, with unions including the United Steel Workers and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
 In 1984, Westchester Concrete merged with N & W Concrete of White Plains and in 1988, the merged companies were sold for $4.5 million. For his 25 percent stake in the company, Mr. Boyle was to receive $1.1 million. But he and his partners did not receive all of the proceeds from the transaction, nor did they emerge from the concrete business unblemished.
 One of the partners, Louis Nappi, who held a 50 percent stake in Westchester Concrete, was one of a number of trustees removed in 1983 from the pension board of a teamsters local in New York. A Federal judge accused the trustees of allowing pension money to be misused by a union official who had ties to organized crime.
 The company that bought Westchester Concrete was Valente Industries of the Bronx, which later went into bankruptcy and still owes Mr. Boyle and his partners about $1.3 million. Federal inquiries have alleged that Valente, one of the area's largest suppliers of concrete, has links to organized crime. Valente officials have denied the allegations. Telephone calls seeking further comment from Valente officials were referred to John Hasluck, a New York lawyer at the firm of Crocco & DeMaio. Mr. Hasluck did not return calls.
 Mr. Boyle said he was never aware of Mr. Nappi's problems with the teamster pension board. He said, however, that he had warned Mr. Nappi "to stay out of those union trusteeships."
 Also, Mr. Boyle said that Mr. Nappi recommended that they sell Westchester Concrete to Valente. "I had never met the people from Valente until the night before we closed," Mr. Boyle said.
Mr. Nappi confirmed in an interview that the sale was largely at his instigation and he termed the transaction "a mistake."
 Another company owned by Mr. Boyle, Rogene Industries, has also taken its lumps. Set up as a shell company to manage some of the extraneous assets acquired when Mr. Boyle first bought Westchester Concrete, Rogene eventually ventured into real estate development, but with only marginal success. In its 28 years, Rogene has built a branch building for a Westchester County bank, rehabilitated an automobile showroom to serve as offices for Westchester Concrete and tried to develop a condominium community in Vermont during the 1980's.
 The Vermont project stalled shortly after getting off the ground, Mr. Boyle said. "Several lots were never developed," he said, and as a result, the condominium project has lost about $1.5 million and is still trying to settle claims.
 Since 1992, Mr. Boyle has worked primarily as a consultant, earning fees to manage A. Barletta and Sons, a family-owned construction company in Hazleton, Pa. Documents issued by Mr. Pataki's office cite Mr. Boyle's "expertise in corporate turnaround," and say that he "returned the company to seven-figure profitability" and "continues as board chairman and consultant to the company."
 What Mr. Boyle has actually done, however, is liquidate the assets of A. Barletta, which employed 80 workers and was operating under bankruptcy protection when he took it over.
 At the Hudson Valley Hospital, Mr. Boyle is chairman of the 30-member board of trustees, and is credited by hospital officials with providing important leadership and guidance to administrators. In 1988, when he assumed the leadership, the 120-bed hospital had an operating loss of $800,000, on revenues of $21 million, and the possibility of a shutdown loomed large.
 Under his guidance, the hospital reversed its course. By 1991, it had an operating surplus of $1 million, and the hospital expects another surplus this year. "He's the first board member who looked at the hospital as a business," said Jane Morabito, the hospital's vice president of patient services.
 About one mile from the hospital is the Pataki Farm, where the Governor grew up. When Mr. Pataki was a State Assemblyman in the late 1980's, he joined the hospital's board at Mr. Boyle's invitation. Mr. Boyle said that some time after that, he lent Mr. Pataki $10,000 to help subdivide the farm for development. "I told him I could help him," Mr. Boyle said. "I wanted some consideration when it was time to consider a builder."
 The property is still undeveloped, and Mr. Boyle said the loan had not been repaid. A $10,000 payment that he acknowledges receiving last year from Mr. Pataki's campaign committee was a bonus for volunteer work he had done on the campaign, not a repayment for the loan, said Mr. Boyle. "I probably had five or six hundred hours in," he said. "Bonuses were given to paid staffers and to volunteers. I felt I deserved it. I didn't want to be left out."

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Stocks Retreat, With Dow Falling 12.79

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks retreated yesterday as traders took profits from the week's record-setting rally.
 After recording its 16th high since Feb. 15 on Thursday, the Dow Jones industrial average declined 12.79 points yesterday, to 4,192.62. For the week, the Dow was up 34.93 points. But the broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks edged up 0.34 point, to 506.42, a new high. And the Nasdaq index rose 0.89 point, to 814.69, helped by a rebound in technology stocks. 
 Declining stocks led advancing issues, 1,141 to 980, on active trading of more than 314 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
 Stocks were weighed down in part by concerns that a slowing economy would hurt corporate profits. Further evidence of a slowdown came after the Labor Department reported that manufacturers' payrolls shrank in March as the nation's unemployment rate inched up one-tenth of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent.
 Analysts said stocks were starting to look tired after their recent record-setting run.
 "The market has just kind of run out of gas," said Jay Meagrow, institutional trader at McDonald & Company.
 The market shrugged off another sharp drop in the dollar against the Japanese yen. The dollar settled in New York yesterday at a record low of 83.82 yen, down from 85.27 yen on Thursday.
 Wall Street has not been particularly worried about the dollar's slide, partly because it expects that the weak currency will help United States exports.
 But some analysts said further weakness in the dollar could make stocks vulnerable to the possibility that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates to attract foreign investors to the currency.
 Ron Hill, investment strategist at Brown Brothers Harriman, said the weaker-than-expected jobs data might also have given rise to worries that the economy could be slowing more abruptly than investors had expected.
 "There's a little question the slowdown may be a little less gentle than people expect and that would certainly be negative for profits," he said.
 Among technology stocks rebounding from recent profit taking, Micron Technology rose 1 3/8, to 76 1/4, and Intel was up 1 5/8, to 87 1/8.
 Du Pont fell 2 3/8, to 62 3/8, on concern over a planned reissue of a portion of shares that it repurchased from Seagram, the Canadian distiller.
 Seagram fell 1 3/8, to 26 1/2, in heavy trading on concern about its expected acquisition of 80 percent of MCA, the entertainment unit of Matsushita Electric Industrial.
 The New York Stock Exchange Composite index of all listed common stocks fell 0.05 point, to 273.73. The average share was down 1 cent. The American Stock Exchange index was up 0.48 point, to 469.35. The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of Big Board, American and Nasdaq issues -- was at a new high of 4,957.79, up 2.03, or four-hundredths of 1 percent.
 In Tokyo, stocks ended only slightly lower despite the sharp rise in the yen against the dollar. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 96.37 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, at 15,719.50.
 "Sellers are becoming cautious, taking into account the possibility that the dollar may rebound if Japan unveils comprehensive measures to boost the economy and stem the yen's rising trend," said Kenzo Doi, an analyst at Kokusai Securities.

HEADLINE: Messinger Ventures West of 12th Avenue

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, April 7

 BODY:
Like New Yorkers, residents of China's largest city have a reputation for aggressiveness, savvy and style. But when it comes to comparisons, there is no Shanghai equivalent to Manhattan. With 14 districts instead of 5 boroughs, Shanghai has no single cultural, financial and political center.
 Nor is there an equivalent to Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, who visited Shanghai this week with a dozen New York businessmen and three members of her staff. 
 One Chinese official wondered aloud what a local official was doing in China talking about international business, since government work of the districts here typically concerns only matters like housing and municipal infrastructure.
 Ms. Messinger described her tour -- Shanghai is the fourth of six Asian cities she is visiting -- as a way "to deepen economic, cultural and governmental ties between New York City and Asia."
 Yet the trip also seems to be a chance for her to act mayoral and to engage in the nebulous field that businessmen and politicians like to call "building relationships," relationships that may, or may not, lead to some meaningful investment or cultural exchange.
 Rudolph W. Giuliani has never traveled abroad as Mayor, but Ms. Messinger joins a long list of borough presidents who have journeyed far from home turf. Claire Shulman has visited Portugal, which has close historical ties to Queens, and herself went to China to promote Queens in 1988. Fernando Ferrer has pushed the Bronx in Israel. Howard Golden last year visited Brooklyn's sister city, Anzio, Italy.
 On Thursday, Ms. Messinger worked on her relationship with Han Zheng, head of Lu Wan district, who asserted that his district was actually the Manhattan of Shanghai. Lu Wan, something like the Upper East Side in size and temperament, is competing with two rival areas for Ms. Messinger's affection, which may lead to designation as an official sister district of Manhattan.
 Lu Wan's strongest draw is Huai Hai (pronounced HWAI-high) Road, the city's premier shopping street, even if nearly half of it is under construction. Mr. Han, looking clean-cut in a navy blue suit, showed off the street to his visitor on Thursday and was eager to impress her.
 "The first McDonald's in Shanghai is on Huai Hai Road," he boasted.
 Mr. Han spilled a long list of plans and statistics about construction and office space. Ms. Messinger studiously scribbled notes, nodding steadily.
 Over an eight-course lunch, Mr. Han got down to business.
 "How is the Chinese food in New York?" he asked.
 Ms. Messinger, grappling with a slice of sauteed squid that kept slipping between her chopsticks, replied diplomatically. "We have many different kinds," she said, "but none are as good or as beautifully served as this."
 Mr. Han, one of his aides noted, is widely expected to rise to a citywide post one day. What is Ms. Messinger's future, the aide asked.
 "She's going to run for mayor in two years," said one businessman on the trip, James Jao, chairman of the Long On Group, a conglomerate of trading and consulting companies based in New York.
 For those accompanying Ms. Messinger, the trip is a way to get formal introductions to officials in Asian cities where they want to do business.
 While other New York borough presidents say they usually pay for their own trips, the businesses represented in the delegation are paying for Ms. Messinger and her staff, although local Chinese officials are picking up most hotel and meal expenses. Ms. Messinger's husband, Andrew Lachman, a public school administrator, paid his own way on the trip, she said.
 Ms. Messinger, who said she had not officially decided whether to run against Mayor Giuliani in 1997, described the trip as an outgrowth of the work she already does as Borough President to encourage Asian investment in New York. The delegation, which has so far also visited Beijing, Changzhou, Seoul and Hong Kong and plans to visit Taipei.
 "People do business with their friends," she said. "We've been able on this trip to expand friendships and build on the relationships we already had."
 Andrew Breslau, her director of communications, put it another way: "Economic integration is proceeding. You have to surf it."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A New Mexican Bond Fails to Materialize

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 7

 BODY:
When Mexico's economic crisis was taking a turn for the worse in early January, Government officials promised that in two weeks they would introduce a new kind of treasury bond to replace those that were pegged to dollars and which had been identified as a principal cause of Mexico's economic troubles.
Three months later, the Government not only has failed to create a new bond, but officials now also concede that they are unlikely to bring to the market any version of the dollar-based bonds -- known as tesobonos -- this year. Instead, they say they will raise funds by offering commericial paper sometime after May that would be backed by loan guarantees from the United States, if the market accepts it. 
 "It is difficult to see any tesobono auction before the end of the year," said Alejandro Valenzuela, director of international affairs for the Mexican Finance Ministry and the Government's chief spokesman on Mexico's economic recovery plan. "The instrument today simply has no credibility."
Few investors will be sorry to see the bonds disappear. "Good riddance to them, absolutely," said Jeffry H. Taylor, an analyst at NatWest Washington Analysis. The success of the Government's new financing plans will lie in whether the recovery measures continue to progress, he said, and the market continues the slow improvement it has shown over the last two weeks.
"It may not be the best time to offer anything but I think it's a realistic scenario," Mr. Taylor said.
Mr. Valenzuela said: "We have to regain Mexico's reputation, but that takes time. Right now, there is no market for us. Not even short term."
He expects that situation to continue until at least May. Then the Government will test the market, probably with an issue of commercial paper handled by American commerical banks and brokerage houses.
"The candy on the post for the offering will be the U.S. guarantees," Mr. Valenzuela said. The guarantees, as arranged under the agreement signed by the two countries, allow Mexico to issue instruments backed by the United States Government for up to 10 years. He said the first offering could be pegged to the United States Treasury bill rate, plus 250 basis points.
"We have to sit down with the market makers and see what is the appetite for this kind of issue," he said. "We want it to be big enough to achieve a critical mass and reduce costs. But it is very important that the deal comes out as a good deal for investors and successful for us because it will be our first exit to the market after the crisis."
Thomas J. Trebat, head of emerging markets research at Chemical Bank in New York, thought that the Mexican officials might be overly optimistic in their target interest rate for the new offering. "It sounds tight," he said, "but possible."
Mr. Valenzuela said that if the proposed offering was successful, Mexico would try to move toward medium-term notes and then eventually long-term bonds.
As for the tesobonos, the Government has already all but put a stake through their heart. No auction of the bonds has been held since Feb. 15, and that auction was limited to $210 million. During 1994 the weekly tesobono auctions sometimes exceeded $1 billion.
Mexico's debt just in tesobonos grew to almost $30 billion by the end of 1994.
Mexico has since reduced the amount of outstanding tesobonos to approximately $15.5 billion. It has done so by using $7.5 billion from the International Monetary Fund and $5.2 billion from an aid package offered by the United States in January. Mexican officials anticipate that by the end of 1995, only about $5 billion in tesobonos will remain in circulation.

HEADLINE: Bold Plan Seeks to Wrest Control of Federal Lands

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER 

DATELINE: ALAMOGORDO, N.M.

 BODY:
When it comes to outsiders, especially those wearing military uniforms and suits, the ranching and logging families of Otero County have always been a little suspicious.
But one newcomer, a Los Angeles lawyer whose monogrammed white shirts and splashy ties contrast with his clients' dusty boots and jeans, has become something of a hero. 
 He is John Howard, 46, president of the Individual Rights Foundation, a conservative public interest law firm in Los Angeles. The foundation has joined with the county's ranchers, loggers and public officials in a sophisticated legal and political campaign to fight the Federal Government's efforts to curb environmental damage by restricting grazing and logging on public lands.
The centerpiece of the effort is a lawsuit that Mr. Howard filed in January in Federal District Court in Washington on behalf of the county and three of its wealthiest ranchers. In it, he argued that the Government had no authority to own and manage the public domain in New Mexico, and that control of the land should pass to the state and, ultimately, to Otero County (pronounced oh-TAIR-oh).
If the suit is successful -- and Mr. Howard says his foundation intends to take the case to the Supreme Court, if necessary -- it would completely change 150 years of ownership and management practices for more than 500 million acres of Federal land in the West.
"Because of how these lands have been managed, there has been a fundamental breaking of trust across the West," Mr. Howard said. "People at the local level are eager to claim more authority to determine what's best for them. For the last 10 years, the Federal Government has been giving these people the back of its hand."
The Justice Department and New Mexico's Attorney General, Tom Udall, a Democrat, say the constitutional theory underlying the suit has no basis in law and predict it will fail. In March, the Justice Department filed suit against Nye County, Nev., arguing that the steps the county's commissioners had taken under an identical legal theory to gain control of public land and intimidate Federal land managers were unconstitutional. Mr. Howard also represents Nye County in that case.
Conservationists say that the legal tactics used by Western ranchers, timber companies and mining conglomerates represent the well-financed efforts of a minority eager to cash in on lucrative Federal subsidies that support their way of life.
"What this is all about is money," said Faye Lee, a retired English teacher and publisher of "A Hoot and a Holler," a local environmental newsletter here. "The community has been all stirred up by a few people who see an opportunity to make a lot of money if the laws change. It's not going to work. Those lands are the public's lands. They aren't the domain of a few people who think it's theirs."
Mr. Howard's lawsuit is based on the Constitution's "equal footing" clause, which gives new states entering the union the same powers and authorities as the original 13 states. Mr. Howard believes that when Western states were admitted to the union, they were denied equal footing because the Federal Government retained vast amounts of land.
Mr. Howard argues that a 1987 Supreme Court decision, written by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, lends credence to his interpretation. In that case, the Court voted, 5 to 4, to uphold Utah's authority to bar the Government from leasing lands underlying Utah Lake for oil and gas development. The Government contended that it had the right to issue leases because it owned the land beneath the huge reservoir. Utah said that under the equal footing doctrine, title to the lake bed passed to the state when it entered the union because the original states retained lands under navigable waters.
"The way I read that decision," Mr. Howard said, "Justice O'Connor is leaving the door open for our case. The message inherent in the Utah lands case is you get the votes if you ask the question."
But Lois Schiffer, the Assistant Attorney General for environment and natural resources, said the courts had consistently upheld the Government's authority to own and manage the public domain in the West.
The Government contends that when New Mexico became a state, in 1912, its constitutional convention voted to "forever disclaim all right and title to the unappropriated public lands lying within" its borders.
The Government also argues that the United States Constitution's property clause vests Congress with "power to dispose of and make all needful rules and regulations" with respect to Federal land.
Ms. Schiffer said: "What they are plainly trying to accomplish is a court decision on the question of whether counties or states have ownership of what we would regard as Federal land. We think the theory does not have merit."
It is almost logical that Otero County, which borders Texas on the south and is larger than Connecticut, is the scene of a legal shoot-out with historic ramifications. This tortured landscape of desert, steep mountains and thick alpine forests still has fewer than 50,000 residents and was once used by Billy the Kid to hide from his pursuers. Nearly 50 years ago, when the Army tested the first atomic bomb in the desert 60 miles northwest of Alamogordo, the county seat, Federal officials told local ranchers blown out of their beds that the giant blast was caused by an accidental explosion of an ammunition depot. It was the start, many residents say, of the distrust between citizens and the Government.
Slightly less than 90 percent of the land in Otero County is owned by the military, the Federal Bureau of Land Management and the United States Forest Service. For most of this century, the patterns of ownership and management of these grazing and timber lands suited local ranchers and loggers just fine. The Government charged cattlemen a minimal fee to graze their animals on Federal land. The Forest Service paid for the roads that helped loggers clear-cut Ponderosa pine and fir from the Sacramento Mountains.
In the late 1980's, though, the Government began to restrict logging and grazing under pressure from environmentalists and Congress. Because of rules to protect endangered animals, the region's streams and other natural assets, the number of cows grazing in Otero County declined to 25,000 last year, from 35,000 in the 1970's. Similar rules led the Forest Service to restrict to 2.1 million board feet the amount of timber taken out of the Lincoln National Forest last year, as against 20.5 million board feet in 1988.
Many residents found other jobs in the county's increasingly diverse economy. Otero County is becoming a mecca for retired people and a center of small manufacturing and service industries, and its economy supports a civilian labor force numbering 20,000 jobs, swamping the timber, ranching and mining economy in size and importance.
But prodded by angry loggers and ranchers, who turned up by the hundreds at public meetings, Otero County unanimously approved ordinances in 1992 and 1993 that were intended to loosen the restrictions by giving the county more authority to participate in decisions on managing Federal land.
Then Charlie T. Lee, a prominent rancher, introduced leaders here to Mr. Howard, whose foundation agreed to represent the county in its lawsuit for $5 a month. The foundation is the legal arm of the Center for the Study of Popular Culture, a conservative research group.
The ranchers in Otero County say the issue of access to Federal resources is a historical right.
"This is about power," Mr. Lee said. "It's a struggle to re-establish the rights of people to live their lives and conduct their business with much less interference from environmentalists and the Government."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Howard, right, a Los Angeles lawyer, is a hero to ranchers and loggers in Otero County, N.M., because of his legal battle to overturn Federal environmental curbs that restrict grazing and logging on public lands. HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Rose to 5.5% During March

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
The slackened pace of economic growth showed up clearly in the job market last month as factories failed to add workers for the first time since September and the unemployment rate inched up one-tenth of a point, to 5.5 percent, Labor Department figures showed today.
 The March results, a bit weaker than expected, were further confirmation that the economy, as policy makers desire, is decelerating rapidly to about half its breakneck 5.1 percent growth pace of late 1994. 
 With the economy still digesting the impact of a doubling of short-term interest rates over the last 14 months, analysts said the Federal Reserve was quite unlikely to raise rates again soon, even though doing so would provide some support to the badly battered dollar.
 "What you see suggests the soft-landing scenario is right on track," said John R. Williams, a senior economist at Bankers Trust. "It's probably exactly what the Fed would like."
 The financial markets showed little reaction after the employment report was released this morning, although stocks and bonds slipped later in the day.
 Payrolls expanded by a moderate 203,000 last month, 41 percent less than in February, with the telltale temporary help category losing 35,000 jobs. Manufacturers' payrolls, which had swelled by an average of nearly 40,000 from October through February, contracted by 4,000 last month while the factory workweek and factory overtime each fell by 12 minutes.
 As a result, the output and operating rate of American industry may have fallen in March, a development that would "obviously attenuate inflationary concerns," said Elliott Platt, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
 Moreover, Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, said average hourly earnings advanced a modest three-tenths of 1 percent last month and only 2.8 percent over the last year.
 "There's no sign of inflation at all from wages," which account for more than two-thirds of business costs, Mr. Reich said in an interview.
 Separately, the Federal Reserve reported today that consumers took on $8.2 billion more in installment debt than they repaid in February, the third straight month in which credit-card, automobile and other nonmortgage loans expanded by less than $10 billion. By contrast, outstanding loans rose by more than $10 billion -- and in August by more than $15 billion -- in eight of the nine preceding months.
 Much of the payroll growth in today's job survey reflected jumps of 58,000 in construction and 42,000 in amusement and recreation services, both of which owed much to unseasonably mild weather. There was also a 36,000 gain in health services, its biggest in a year. Employment in the finance, insurance and real estate category climbed 17,000, recovering most of the losses it had suffered since August.
 But retail and wholesale trade was flat and the bulk of the overall payroll increase was the 159,000 jobs that the Government assumed were created by new businesses not yet picked up by its statistics.
 The Labor Department's survey of households, meanwhile, showed a 149,000-job increase that combined with 203,000 more people in the labor force to produce an unemployment rate of 5.46 percent, scarcely above February's 5.43 percent but one-tenth of a point higher after rounding. Before seasonal adjustment, this survey showed a gain of 600,000 jobs.
 The ranks of those jobless for more than six months rebounded last month by 140,000, to 1.3 million. This group now accounts for 19 percent of the unemployed, twice the proportion that prevailed before the 1990-91 recession, observed Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics.
 By region, the biggest change last month was an increase, to 4.6 percent from 4.3 percent, for unemployment in the Midwest, where manufacturing is an economic mainstay. The jobless rate also edged up in the South, to 5 percent from 4.8, and in the Northeast, to 6 percent from 5.9. The West, however, improved for the second straight month, with unemployment easing to 6.2 percent from 6.4, despite the fact that the rate for California edged higher. Illinois and Massachusetts both saw unemployment skid to about 4.5 percent, but the rate for New York rose five-tenths of a point, not a statistically significant amount, to 6.6 percent.
 The Labor Department's monthly tally also found that 7,610,000 employed people, or 6.1 percent, held two or more jobs last month, up 434,000 from the March 1994 level. Over the same period, however, the number of so-called discouraged workers -- people who have given up looking for jobs because they think it futile -- fell by 79,000, to 454,000.
 Last month, 55.6 percent of industries were adding to payrolls compared with 58.6 percent in February, the Labor Department also found. Among manufacturers the proportion was 46.4 percent, down from 50.7 percent.

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Turn Lower on Report Suggesting Inflation Threat

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
After four days of gains, prices of Treasury securities turned lower yesterday when a report suggested that inflationary pressures were still a threat.
 The report, the Columbia University inflation index, quickly pared early gains from a Government report that said the economy had added fewer jobs than expected last month, pointing to a slowdown. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 18/32 , to 10227/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.39 percent, from 7.34 percent on Thursday and back to levels a week ago.
 Traders said the selloff was caused by a rise in the Columbia University inflation index for March, which came in at 112.3, higher than the preliminary 111.9 in February, but lower than the revised February number of 113. The market had expected the index to fall to 110. Traders note that since the market has already priced in a slowing economy, any news suggesting otherwise will cause some investors to cash in and wait for more conclusive news.
 Earlier, bond prices briefly rose about a half-point after the Labor Department said the economy added 203,000 jobs, fewer than the 230,000 expected. In the same report, the nation's unemployment rate rose to 5.5 percent from 5.4 percent.
 Anthony Chan, chief economist for Banc One Investment Advisers in Columbus, Ohio, said the decline in the factory workweek to 41.9 hours versus 42.1 "confirms the pause in activity that was seen in the recent orders components of the National Association of Purchasing index, the Chicago Purchasing index and the Philadelphia Fed regional survey."
 The gain in average hourly earnings, Mr. Chan said, suggested that although the economy's inflationary pressures might be dormant, they could reappear in the not-to-distant future. "Consequently, it is safe to say that the end to short-term interest rate increases is still not behind us," he said. "This view was reinforced by this morning's sharp upward revision in the Columbia University's inflation index for the month of February."
 Rosanne M. Cahn, chief economist, equity research department at CS First Boston, said she did not believe that the employment report would persuade the Fed to quit its current holding pattern. But if demand for labor firms, the Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for loans could well be pushed up another 50 basis points, to 6.50 percent, when the Fed next meets, on May 23. "As this expectation is not currently embodied in the fixed-income market," she said, yields could fall lower over the next two months.
 In the municipal bond market, where investors have voiced concern that the shortage of new issues so far this year has made securities too expensive, prices were little changed yesterday, as increased demand from mutual fund managers offset concern about prices.
 The average yield to maturity for the Bond Buyer's index of 40 municipal issues was down one basis point, to 6.29 percent, from the previous day. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber Moves Up on a Report Of Louisiana-Pacific Cutbacks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Lumber prices recovered some ground yesterday after the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation said it was suspending some mill operations, reducing supplies to lumberyards and home builders.
 Rising prices for lumber, cotton and other commodities pushed the Commodity Research Bureau index to its highest since last June 17, rising 0.78 point, to 237.29. 
 Lumber prices rose after Louisiana-Pacific said it had stopped production at its mill in Walla Walla, Wash., and was considering similar action at two of its mills in Montana because of recent low prices.
 The closing at the Walla Wall mill could last up to three weeks, a company executive said, reducing supplies by an estimated eight million board feet a month.
 Lumber prices have been weak as higher interest rates slow the housing industry, reducing demand. About 70 percent of the lumber produced in North America is used in construction.
 May lumber rose $3 to settle at $264.20 for every 1,000 board feet on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
 The May and July cotton contracts rose their daily trading limit for the fourth consecutive day amid speculation that an export sale to China would drain already tight United States stockpiles.
 Traders said a large sale of cotton was made to China in the last few days, possibly as much as 300,000 bales, for shipment both before and after this year's crop was harvested.
 Cotton for May delivery on the New York Cotton Exchange rose the 2-cent daily limit, to $1.0422 a pound, while July cotton also gained 2 cents, to 99.10 cents a pound.
 Soybean prices rose after Brazil moved on Thursday to raise the minimum guaranteed price paid to farmers, which could put more soybeans into Government reserves and keep them off the export market. Brazil is the world's second-largest soybean producer and exporter after the United States.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Plunges to a Record Low Of 83.71 Yen, Off 16% on Year

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled again to a post-World-War-II low against the yen yesterday as Japanese institutional investors sold dollars to limit their potential foreign exchange losses on United States assets.
 Japanese insurance companies and banks have been selling dollars in expectation that the dollar could fall further against the yen, currency dealers said. 
 "The dollar is still looking for the bottom," said Hidetoshi Yanagihara, vice president and currency trader at the Industrial Bank of Japan in New York. "Japanese insurance companies and banks are hedging their U.S. investments."
 The dollar fell to 83.71 yen, its lowest since the end of World War II. In New York, it also set a record low, ending at 83.82 yen, down from 85.27 yen on Thursday.
 At yesterday's rate, the dollar is down 16 percent against the yen since the beginning of the year.
 The dollar has suffered because Japan has a $66 billion annual trade surplus with the United States, meaning its exporters have a steady supply of dollars to sell for yen when they send revenue back to Japan.
 Those sales intensified in March as exporters brought money home before the end of the fiscal year on March 31. Now, there is new pressure on the dollar as Japanese insurance companies and banks try to hedge their investments for the year.
 "It's a crazy market," Mr. Yanagihara said. Few Japanese investors or companies expected the yen to rise so far, so fast, he said.
 The dollar also suffered from expectations that the Bank of Japan would not cut a key interest rate. Many dealers expected a cut in the discount rate after Japanese officials hinted that one might be in the offing.
 Lower rates often hurt a country's currency by making deposits there less attractive. Many traders said they were skeptical about whether a rate cut would slow the yen's ascent because the Bank of Japan's discount rate on overnight loans to the country's banks is already at a record low 1.75 percent, compared with the United States discount rate of 5.25 percent.
 But the dollar was steady against other leading currencies yesterday. The dollar edged up to 1.3779 German marks, from 1.3735 marks on Thursday. After touching a postwar low of 1.113 Swiss francs on Thursday, the dollar ended yesterday at 1.1288 francs, up from 1.1270 francs in New York late Thursday.
 "The dollar is starting to form a base against the mark," said Paul Farrell, manager of strategic currency trading at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "People still want to sell it for yen, though."

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Finding Friends Among Competitors

BYLINE: By David Gonzalez 

 BODY:
NO money down.
 Down, more like broke and depressed, is how Jesus Rodriguez felt after an accidental fire incinerated his Bronx hardware store one July morning in 1992. Within hours, flames destroyed his business and five others that shared a bustling stretch of Tremont Avenue. They nearly destroyed any chance of rebuilding. 
 "What collateral did we have?" Mr. Rodriguez said. "Only our word and our track record."
 Those intangible assets were not enough for city officials, who had descended on the smoldering scene with promises of grants, advice and low-interest loans. No interest and red tape is what Mr. Rodriguez ultimately got from the city, while he's still trying to settle with his insurer.
 But if his word wasn't good enough for bankers or bureaucrats, it was enough to trigger the compassion of his landlord, other merchants and even his competitors, who came through with Sheetrock, tools and financing. Like a salesman who fervently believes in his product, Mr. Rodriguez did it himself, laying out the store design, painting walls and building displays.
 After nearly a three-year absence, he wondered if he and his father would sit in an empty store once they opened their doors. Never mind, the customers flocked to General Hardware before the doors were installed.
 "My first order came when they were taking a load of paint off the truck," Mr. Rodriguez said. "A guy was parked in a car and asked how much for the paint. We made our first sale -- $34.99 for five gallons."

MONTHS after the flames had died down, so too had Mr. Rodriguez's hopes of rebuilding. In his mind, the only image that he could conjure was the burned-out store where he had perfected his trade after dropping out of college.
 Although he was a partner in another hardware store, business there was slow, and creditors were bearing down on him. His wife dropped out of college and went to work, while his mother chipped in with baby-sitting duty when she wasn't working as a manicurist.
 City officials originally told him he could get a $250,000 low-interest loan. But the official who made that promise never returned his phone calls, Mr. Rodriguez said, while higher-ups later denied making any such offer. Months passed. Little happened.
 "They promised a lot but nothing came through," Mr. Rodriguez said. "We could have been in business two years earlier if they had kept their promises."
 But one of his biggest boosters was his father, Pedro, a former grocery store owner who was now his partner in hardware. In trying to rebuild the store, he got a glimpse into what his father went through when he immigrated from Cuba with nothing more than hope.
 "When we lost this business I felt sorrier for him than anyone else," he said. "He worked 20 years to build it and everything was lost in four hours. But he was able to keep himself together and he always had the feeling, if we did it once we can do it again."
 Mr. Rodriguez's landlord eventually financed his return to the block, although he lost time in rebuilding because of a bureaucratic glitch. A phantom street that was mapped but never built on the property delayed the issuance of a building permit. Construction finally began last year.
 Then he learned there was honor among hardware sellers.

THE Morales brothers from Uptown Lumber in the Bronx gave him Formica and Masonite for counters, telling him to pay when he could. A contractor donated metal beams left over from a job in Manhattan. Joey from the New Palace Paint Store a few blocks away lent him a paint sprayer for a week. Free.
 "I sell paint and sundries like he does," Mr. Rodriguez marveled.
 For a guy who grew up selling behind a counter, this was one lesson he had yet to learn. Tears come to his eyes when he talks about it.
 "It made me see things differently," he said. "You shouldn't take things for granted. You should always be grateful for what you got and be honest with yourself, because when you're down in the gutter, that's when you find out who your real friends are."
 A few days ago, the store was cold, but business was warming up.
 "Diga, primo," Mr. Rodriguez said to his customers. "Talk to me, cousin."
 Around him, the shelves and walls were crammed with everything from night lights to pipes and pans to kitchen sinks, as workers hauled in bags of cement. If he doesn't have it in stock, he tells customers where they can find it down the street.
 While he always prided himself on price and service, he said the struggle to reopen made him even appreciate how hard his customers have to work for their money.
 "We've brought down the markup a good percentage," he said. "It's good that people see you're not here to make a killing and you try to provide the best service you can. Don't turn anybody away, because we didn't have anybody turn us away."
 At least nobody in the hardware business.
 Talk to me, cousin.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
On the Face of It, Yankees' McDowell Is Excited

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 7

 BODY:
Jack McDowell shaved off part of his beard but left a Fu Manchu mustache and enough facial hair to possibly create trouble. Danny Tartabull strutted into camp and declared himself on time and ready. Buck Showalter began the opening of Spring Training II with an obsessive look that did not exist around the replacement Yankees.
 The Yankees attracted roughly 250 fans to their training complex today, three times as many as the replacement team drew for its first session. McDowell, John Wetteland and Tony Fernandez have been added to a team that had the elite record in the American League last year. 
 Did someone whisper pressure?
 "We got a chance to win it all, a real good chance," said McDowell. "All eyes are on us as the team to beat. That's a good place to be."
 The best place to be for the Yankees was simply in a uniform and on the sun-drenched field. Most players admitted that being back before fans was exhilarating. Like every spring, everyone felt a pennant was possible on the first day. Fans and players alike.
 "We kind of have a sour taste in our mouth after what happened to us last year," said Tartabull. "It looked like we would be there in the post-season. Then the unthinkable happened. It's unfinished business for us. We have work to do once we step on the field."
 Before McDowell tossed a pitch, the former White Sox right-hander was the target of one fan's hostility. Standing about 20 feet away from a bench on which McDowell sat with the pitching coach, Billy Connors, the man shouted at the unsigned pitcher about the players' strike and its effects.
 "How many jobs were lost because $5 million wasn't enough, Jack?" the fan asked. "How much was lost in the South Florida economy? One-hundred million dollars?"
 McDowell never turned around, never flinched and the fan eventually left when the workout began. Proving to be as cool and as he is shrewd, the 29-year-old former Cy Young Award winner has also declined to discuss his negotiations because he figures no one wants to hear about $20 million contracts now. But McDowell stressed his preference for a long-term deal.
 "I'm looking to stay put and know I'm going to stay put for a number of years," said McDowell, who spent his first seven seasons with Chicago before leaving after last season. His agent is due here this weekend to negotiate with the Yankees.
 The owner George Steinbrenner's policy allows mustaches that do not grow below the upper lip. McDowell might have violated that regulation with facial hair that resembles that of Goose Gossage of Yankee years past. McDowell's beard has been trimmed, but his mustache drooped to his chin with a patch of hair beneath his lower lip.
 "It's something that's important to him," said Showalter, who took McDowell for a ride in his golf cart. "If it's important to him, then it's important to me. Jack is getting off to a clean start and trying to make a good impression."
 McDowell said he missed his beard. "I've been wearing it so long," he said. "Hopefully, I'm fitting in and we can win a championship."
 He later added: "It doesn't really have to be a story, does it? Baseball is back. Can we discuss baseball?"
 There were six hours of baseball, a morning workout for established players and an afternoon session for everyone else. Typically, Don Mattingly received the loudest and longest ovation. Typically, Tartabull, Paul O'Neill and Jim Leyritz hit the loudest and longest homers. Tartabull was also ribbed incessantly by teammates for not returning phone calls in the off season.
 "If I were a fan, I would be psyched that the real players are back," Tartabull said. "Major leaguers are major leaguers. You saw that today."

 
 
INSIDE PITCH
 The Yankees tendered contract offers to JACK McDOWELL ($5.3 million), JOHN WETTELAND ($2.225 million), JIM LEYRITZ ($742,500), PAT KELLY ($810,000) and SCOTT KAMIENIECKI ($235,000) -- all at the salaries they made last season. They can file for arbitration between next Wednesday and Friday.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Baseball's Unemployed Work Out and Wait

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla., April 7

 BODY:
They put their uniform pants on, like players in baseball's 28 other training camps, one leg at a time. They ran laps and sprints, did calisthenics, threw, took batting practice. The only difference in this 29th camp was that the players who began the belated version of spring training did so without jobs.
"We're going to call ourselves the Homestead Homies, the team of the misfits," Randy Velarde, formerly of the Yankees, said at the end of the 1-hour-50-minute workout. 
 On the first official day of spring training for regular major leaguers, 29 jobless players showed up today for the start of this camp organized by the union. They are baseball's free agents, unsigned players of varying talents who do not belong to any team and so have nowhere to work out. They are all hungry for work, but the nearly eight-month strike set back the clubs' timetables and reduced their budgets for signing players.
Many of these players will still be jobless when the season opener is played April 25, which has made anxiety an uninvited visitor in the camp.
"I'm going to be here for however long it takes to land a job," said Mike Felder, an outfielder who has played with four teams in his career.
More players are expected in the next few days. More scouts are expected, too, than the one who arrived at camp today.
Some of the the game's best free agents remained at home while their agents intensified negotiations with prospective employers. The players in camp generally ranked below that top category of players, and if they get jobs at all will command salaries far below the multimillion-dollar level popularly associated with coveted free agents of the past.
"There's no disgrace being here," said Dave Stewart, a pitcher with 14 years of major league experience. "There's no reason to be ashamed about being here. If there wasn't a strike, we wouldn't be here."
But Chris Sabo, formerly with the Cincinnati Reds and Baltimore Orioles, reflected the anxiety of the players here when he said: "You would think the teams, if they want you, would want you before games start. There are only 10 or 11 games. You'd think they'd want you to get used to your teammates. I'm not going to sit down here forever."
The camp, which might be called Camp Fehr after the union leader Donald Fehr, is being operated by the Players Association in an effort to help the more than 150 free agents be in shape to play when, and if, they are offered contracts.
"We want to make sure we get them into as good a shape as we can without getting them hurt, and get them out of here as quickly as possible," said Jackie Moore, a former major league manager and coach, who is running the camp. ("I'm a free agent like everybody else here," he noted.)
Located about 30 miles south of Miami, the complex is the newest in Florida. Completed in 1991 at a cost of $22 million, it was devastated by Hurricane Andrew in 1992, six months before the Cleveland Indians were scheduled to move in. An $8 million repair has made the facility seemingly as good and attractive as any, starting with the pink facade of the stadium, which is the centerpiece of the five-and-a-half-field complex.
Working out in the stadium today were some players who could offer strong competition for many major league teams. "I'd take this club now and go to Phoenix with it," said Moore, referring to one of the two new expansion sites.
The group on hand for the first workout lacked only a closing relief pitcher. It could field Dave Magadan at first base, Mariano Duncan or Scott Fletcher at second, Velarde at short, Sabo at third, Mickey Tettleton as the catcher and Howard Johnson, Mike Devereaux and Felder, Candy Maldonado or Lloyd McClendon in the outfield.
Stewart, Bobby Witt, Todd Stottlemyre, Scott Sanderson and Erik Hanson would form the starting rotation.
Velarde is here because the Yankees, he said, offered him a $200,000 salary, less than a fifth of his 1994 salary of $1,125,000. "I expected a cut," he said, "but that's chopping you off, leaving nothing but toes."
Asked how long he would stay in camp, he said: "It's hard to put a timetable on it. I'd hoped to be just a couple days. I'm saying that optimistically, but who knows. I don't plan on being here the whole camp. I would like to think just a week and if nothing happens in a week, I'd probably just go home."
But the plans are mixed. When Devereaux was asked how long he would stay in camp without a job, he said: "Did I bring enough clothes? Well, I'm not going to go home in a week if I'm not signed."
And Tettleton said: "I haven't even thought about it. I'm just glad to be back in a baseball atmosphere."
Tettleton and his fellow campers found one new touch to their environment -- women leading their calisthenics. Ann Marie Miller and Peggy Rose were among the exercise leaders, assigned by Reebok, the shoe manufacturer that had planned to be one of the sponsors of an all-star tour of major league players if the strike had continued.
"It looks like they're in pretty good shape," Miller, a New York exercise physiologist, said of the players.
Some of the players liked the plan Moore has adopted for their workouts. Figuring veterans know what they have to do to get into shape, he will let them proceed at their own pace.
Derek Lilliquist liked the absence of P.F.P. -- pitchers' fielding practice, which is a hated staple of all other camps. "The only thing we didn't do that we'd normally do in camp is cover first a hundred times," he said. "I know where first is."
But he and the other pitchers will soon become reacquainted with it just in case. "What they don't know," Moore said, "is tomorrow they will be introduced to it again."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From House Speaker's Address on the First 100 Days

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the speech to the nation tonight by Speaker Newt Gingrich, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:
Thank you for joining me tonight and for this chance to give you, the American people, a report on the new Congress: what we've been doing, what we hope to do, and how we're working to keep faith with what you sent us here to do. . . . 
 Last September, the House Republicans signed a Contract With America. We signed this contract and made some promises to you and to ourselves. You elected us, and for the last 93 days we have been keeping our word. With your help, we're bringing about real change. We made Congress subject to the same laws as everyone else. We cut Congressional committee staffs and budgets by 30 percent. And we voted on every item in the contract. And I can tell you tonight we're going to sell one Congressional building and privatize at least one Congressional parking lot.
While we've done a lot, this contract has never been about curing all the ills of the nation. One hundred days can't overturn the neglect of decades.
The contract's purpose has been to show that change is possible, that even in Washington you can do what you say you're going to do.
In short, we wanted to prove to you, and I think to us, that democracy still has the vitality and the will to do something about the problems facing our nation. And it seems to me that whether you're a conservative or a liberal, that is a very positive thing. . . .
What I want to talk with you about tonight is not just what a new political majority on Capitol Hill has accomplished in 100 days, but how all of us together, Republicans and Democrats alike, must totally remake the Federal Government, to change the very way it thinks, the way it does business, the way it treats its citizens. After all, the purpose of changing Government is to improve the lives of our citizens, to strengthen the future of our children, to make our neighborhoods safe and to build a better country. Government is not the end. It is the means.
We Americans wake up every morning, go to work, take our kids to school, fix dinner, do all the things we expect of ourselves, and yet something isn't quite right. There's no confidence that Government understands the values and realities of our lives. The Government is out of touch and out of control. It is in need of deep and deliberate change.
Now, when that change is accomplished, then perhaps Americans will be able to sleep a little better at night and wake up feeling less anxious about their futures. . . .
We sincerely believe we can reduce spending and at the same time make Government better. You know, virtually every institution in America except Government has re-engineered itself to become more efficient over the last decade. They cut spending, provided better products, better education and better service for less.
But I believe we must remake Government for reasons much larger than saving money or improving services. The fact is, no civilization can survive with 12-year-olds having babies, with 15-year-olds killing each other, with 17-year-olds dying of AIDS, with 18-year-olds getting diplomas they can't even read.
We must start by recognizing the moral and economic failure of the current methods of government. In these last 100 days, we have begun to change those failed methods. We outlined 10 major proposals in the contract that begin to break the logjam of the past. The House passed 9 out of 10.
We passed the balanced-budget amendment in the House with bipartisan support. It has been temporarily defeated in the Senate by one vote. . . . Don't be discouraged. Senator Dole has said he will call it up for another vote. The momentum is with us. And with your help and your voice, I believe it is possible this amendment will pass later in this Congress.
As promised, we introduced a constitutional amendment on term limits, but we failed, even though 85 percent of House Republicans voted for it. . . . I pledge to you that term limits will be the first vote of the next Congress. So keep the pressure on. Keep your hopes up.
In both the House and the Senate, we passed the line-item veto, just as you asked. It's remarkable that a Republican House and a Republican Senate are giving such a strong tool to the President of the other party. I believe it shows our good-faith determination to cut spending.
Other contract proposals have passed the House and are being worked on in the Senate. . . .
The purpose of all this change is not simply a better government. It is a better America. A truly compassionate government would replace the welfare state with opportunity, because the welfare system's greatest cost is the human cost to the poor. . . .
We need to promote economic growth by reducing regulation, reducing taxation and reducing frivolous lawsuits. And everywhere I go, Americans complain about an overly complicated tax code and an arrogant, unpredictable and unfair Internal Revenue Service. This summer we will begin hearings on bold, decisive reform of the income tax system. We're looking at a simplified flat tax and other ways to bring some sense to the disorder and inequity of our tax system. . . .
I want to reassure all of you who are on Social Security or who will soon retire that your Social Security is fine. No one will touch your Social Security, period. But we must make sure that the baby boomers' retirements, which are coming up in the next century, are as secure as their parents'. Unfortunately, the money the Government supposedly has been putting aside for the baby boomers' Social Security is not there. The Government has been borrowing that money to pay for the budget deficit. So when the baby boomers get set to retire, where's the money to pay them going to come from?
"Well," you might ask, "can't the Government just borrow more money?"
The honest answer is "no". No system, no country is wealthy enough to have unlimited borrowing.
The answer is clear. The key to protecting the baby boomers' Social Security is to balance the budget. That way, by the time the baby boomers retire, the Government will be financially sound. It'll have the money to pay them.
The problem is not Social Security, after all. Social Security would be fine if the Federal Government would stop borrowing the money. The Government can stop borrowing the money when we balance the budget. It is just that simple. . . .
Next month we will propose a budget that is balanced over seven years. The budget can be balanced even with the problems of the Federal Government. It can be balanced without touching a penny of Social Security and without raising taxes. In fact, spending over all can go up every year. We simply have to limit annual spending increases to about 3 percent between now and 2002. The key is the willingness to change, to set priorities, to redesign the Government, to recognize that this is not the 60's or the 70's. This is the 1990's, and we need a government to match the times.
As I said, Social Security is off the table. But, you know, that leaves a lot on the table -- corporate welfare, subsidies of every special interest. Defense is on the table. I'm a hawk, but I'm a cheap hawk.
As the budget battle rages over the coming months, you'll hear screams from the special-interest groups. I'm sure you've already heard the dire cries that we're going to take food out of the mouths of school children, that we're going to feed them ketchup.
The fact of the matter is, all we did was vote to increase school lunch 4.5 percent every year for five years and give the money to the states to spend because we thought they would do a better job than the Federal Government of managing the children's meals and the school lunch program. . . .
Whatever the arguments, this remains a country of unparalleled possibilities. I was talking the other day to a fellow who does business in Europe. He said what impresses people overseas is that Americans can change faster than anybody. That's why we're competitive once again in the world. We as a people have the natural ability to respond to change. That is what we do best when the Government is not in the way. Our potential is as great and prosperous as it's ever been in our history. From now on, all roads lead forward.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

The only man arrested in connection with a melee between the police and worshipers at a Harlem mosque in January 1994 has been sentenced to five years' probation for assaulting a police officer. Officers were responding to a 911 call, which turned out to be a hoax. Page 26.

LENGTH: 403 words

HEADLINE: Renewed Repression in Kenya

 BODY:
Kenya's President, Daniel arap Moi, has an easy answer for critics who charge that his Government is corrupt and dictatorial. They are, he says, all in league with Uganda-based Communist guerrillas out to overthrow his Government.
The latest to be smeared by him are Kenya's conservative Roman Catholic bishops. In a pastoral letter Sunday, the bishops lamented that "too many of our people are living in fear," and complained that "it would seem there is no law, no justice, no protection, except for the powerful." Similar concerns have been expressed by international human rights organizations and the State Department. 
 The bishops join a long list of critics threatened with or subjected to retaliation by the thin-skinned Moi regime. The brunt of repression has fallen on parliamentary opponents, two of whom were briefly detained this week, and independent human rights advocates. An emblematic case is Koigi Wamwere, now on trial for his life on what Amnesty International considers trumped-up charges. A determined opponent of tribalism, brutality and corruption, Mr. Wamwere has been a political prisoner for most of the past two decades.
The Moi Government has also threatened to expel the Nairobi correspondents of Time, Newsweek and The Washington Post. Earlier this year, it briefly detained United States Ambassador Aurelia Brazeal, even though this Clinton appointee had made a point of muting the vociferous human rights advocacy of her Republican predecessor.
Mr. Moi seems worried that accurate reporting could threaten Kenya's privileged position among foreign investors and aid donors. Kenya has successfully marketed itself as East Africa's most stable and one of its economically most promising countries. This reputation has drawn multinational corporations to Nairobi, brought millions of dollars in tourist revenues and attracted substantial foreign aid. International donors recently pledged $800 million in new aid to Kenya, and the United States alone plans to give nearly $20 million for 1995.
Ordinary Kenyans have not benefited much from the aid and tourist spending. Annual per capita income is a mere $340. But those close to the regime have done a lot better. That is why the Moi Government has always been attentive to international opinion. That opinion must now be heard, before the last remnants of independent politics, and Kenya's stability itself, are lost.

HEADLINE: In America;
The New Slavery

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The transaction took place right beside me, in the chill of early morning, on a slatted bench at the edge of Central Park. The dealer counted the money, folded it, and nodded. The buyer slid the packet, probably containing heroin, into his jacket pocket.
"Thank you, my brother," said the buyer. The dealer smiled. The two young men stood and clasped hands, then walked off in different directions. 
 Thank you, my brother. Thank you for the opportunity to shoot up, to get high, to wallow in the degradation of addiction, to contract disease, hepatitis perhaps, or maybe AIDS. Thank you so much, my brother.
Whenever I see black people involved in any way in the drug trade I think of the prototypical Uncle Toms, the black Africans who sold their brethren into slavery. Thank you, my brother. Excuse me while I clamber aboard this ship. Thank you.
Something similar is happening with drugs. Much of the heroin and cocaine that comes into the United States is shipped through Nigeria, which has become one of the world's great drug-smuggling and money-laundering centers. Enormous amounts of drugs produced in Asia and Latin America are delivered to Europe and the United States by networks headquartered in Nigeria. It is estimated that a third to nearly a half of all heroin that reaches the U.S. passes through Nigeria. Couriers from Nigeria are in prisons around the world. The U.S. State Department has classified Nigeria as an international drug trafficker -- in effect, an outlaw nation -- and has imposed sanctions. But the trafficking and the money-laundering continue.
The effect of this flourishing of evil in a country that once was the pride of its continent has been deeply tragic. Drug abuse in Nigeria and neighboring countries has surged. And Randall Robinson, executive director of TransAfrica, the Washington-based lobbying group, said, "The dramatic increase in drug consumption in South Africa is directly attributable to Nigeria."
Thank you, my brother.
Narcotics trafficking is not the only evil flourishing in Nigeria. A report issued last fall on the country's human rights abuses was titled, "The Dawn of a New Dark Age." Succinctly put, Nigeria is in shambles. Gen. Sani Abacha's military dictatorship has crushed all opposition. There is not even the pretense of a democracy. The economy has collapsed, despite extensive oil resources. There is 100 percent inflation and extreme unemployment. The per capita income, which was $1,000 in 1980, has plunged to $250.
Nigeria has become a nation of sorrow, its crumbling infrastructure mirroring its economic, social and educational decline.
Mr. Robinson has organized a national campaign, supported by a large group of prominent American blacks, to push for the restoration of democracy and the rule of law in Nigeria. Except for the color of the oppressors, Mr. Robinson noted, there is very little difference between the abuses in Nigeria today and the abuses that prevailed for so long in South Africa.
"Nigeria should be completely isolated," Mr. Robinson said. "Politically, economically and socially."
It is highly unusual, probably unprecedented, for American blacks to speak out so loudly about the abuses of a black African regime. It is a major step, a triumph of outrage over a deeply imbedded (and profoundly destructive) sense of collective mortification. We have closed our eyes and kidded ourselves for too long. It is only in the never-never land of denial that barbarism by blacks is less evil than barbarism by whites. When someone denies you your freedom, or puts a bullet in your mother's heart, or a needle in your baby's vein, the correct response is not thank you, my brother.
Randall Robinson would like the United States to boycott Nigerian oil. Until changes are made, he would like the international community to treat Nigeria as a pariah. He is on to something. Barbaric behavior, by anyone, cannot be tolerated.
I would like to see a similar high-profile effort launched by African-Americans against some of the evils occurring here at home. Randall Robinson knows there is great power in ostracism. It is a lesson that more of us need to learn.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 383 words

HEADLINE: Fish Don't Observe the 200-Mile Limit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your coverage of the fisheries dispute between Canada and Spain helps inform the public of a problem global in scope: too many people chasing too few fish. Such a situation cannot continue indefinitely. The Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations has recently warned that some 70 percent of the world's fish stocks are either fully utilized, overfished or rebuilding from previous overfishing. 
 Nonetheless, at the same time catch effort continues to grow. The dispute between Canada and Spain is but one manifestation of the pressures in a number of world locations created by the reality of a finite resource and economic pressures for continued exploitation.
Your March 28 and March 31 news articles on the dispute contain an inaccuracy about the relevant law of the sea. In the March 31 article you say, "Canadian initiatives, for example, led to the extension of territorial seas from 3 miles to 200 miles." Canada has not extended its territorial seas to 200 miles; the 200-mile limit of Canada refers to the limit of the Canadian exclusive fishery zone, a zone that has a basis in the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and in customary international law.
There is a substantial difference between the two zones. In the territorial sea the coastal state has total sovereignty with the exception of the necessity to recognize the right of innocent passage by ships of other states. In the exclusive fishery zone the coastal state has sovereign rights over fishery resources and other designated functional rights and jurisdictional capacities.
The dispute between Canada and Spain is occasioned by the fact that the fish do not respect the 200-mile limit and swim beyond it into the high seas, where they become subject to capture by fishing vessels of other states.
The problem of such "straddling" stocks is being addressed by an ongoing fishery conference at the United Nations. It will be in the interest of effective fishery management worldwide that a multilateral agreement be achieved so that unilateral actions of the type seen in the northwest Atlantic do not have to be repeated.
 
LAWRENCE JUDA
Professor and Chairman
Department of Marine Affairs
University of Rhode Island
Kingston, R.I., March 31, 1995

HEADLINE: International Briefs;
McDonnell Douglas Gets Order for Dutch Copters

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation beat a French-German venture yesterday for a Dutch military helicopter order valued at $845 million. The Government chose an upgraded version of the Apache attack helicopter, flown by the United States Army during the Persian Gulf war, over the prototype Tiger, produced by Eurocopter, which is 60 percent owned by Aerospatiale of France and 40 percent by Daimler-Benz Aerospace of Germany. 
 The award was good news for McDonnell Douglas, which has seen its aerospace business decline because of military cuts and the recession in the worldwide air travel industry. The Dutch Parliament will negotiate the final contract, which is expected to call for 30 helicopters.
