HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
The Daily Digital

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL 

 BODY:
SOME PEOPLE THINK THEY SEE THE handwriting on the computer screen saying, "NEWSPAPERS ARE EXTINCT." Some of these anxious folks work for newspapers and are fairly described as prematurely gray. Some are politicians frankly impatient for the day. Some are professional historians, expert in the burial of the horse and ocean liner. Some are professional futurists who, when television first appeared, airily predicted the burial of film and radio.
That newspapers live on borrowed time is not a new idea. I have always thought them a precarious business, no matter how great the journalism. Just think about the technology of The New York Times: it trucks processed trees from the forests of Canada down into the center of New York, stamps the pulp with inked impressions, cuts, folds and bundles the product into individual papers and trucks these back toward the readers, two-thirds of them scattered along the East Coast from Richmond to Portland, Me. Every day. 
 And every day, this method of distributing news grows more, well, charming. That is why both the adventurous and fainthearted among us are anxiously turning news dispatches into electronic packets and launching them into the still-primitive Internet, hoping that our journalistic seed will flourish in electronic form. But much of this energy is misdirected. The technology of the newspapers of 2020 is already in sight. It's the content that warrants fretting.
NEWSPAPERS DO CONFRONT A SHORT-TERM problem. Big advertisers, who used to pay 90 percent of a big daily's cost, continue to shift their allegiance to other media, thus forcing on readers an increasing share of newspaper costs. And now computers are poised to strip newspapers of those highly profitable small-print ads that list Help Wanted and Houses for Rent and Sale. Computers are good at keeping lists and searching them for precisely your size Tudor in the town you want at a price you can handle. The time is near, therefore, when computers at home or at a shopping mall kiosk will take over the classified business and, for a fee, print out the list of homes you want to inspect or the jobs you want to seek.
Computers are also good at digging up last week's reviews of the movies in your neighborhood and ordering your tickets. They can dredge up last month's travel article about Mexico along with the airline schedule and hotel roster. And they can quote stock prices any time of day together with a thorough briefing on the company's profits and competition. If newspapers don't learn to transform their listings and archives into a computer business, someone else will.
Even now, computer screens and desktop printers are good enough to convey that kind of raw data and archival research -- by and large information that you already know exists and specifically want. Although such information has been appearing in newspapers, it is not journalism.
And fortunately journalism -- that melange of engagingly written and illustrated reportage, analysis and opinion about the most important, surprising and interesting events of the day -- does not sit well on computer screens. Real reading on the best of screens is cumbersome and disorienting. Random scanning is even harder. The convenience of getting a package of selected, ordered, palpable and portable news on paper will keep good newspapers in business for at least another generation -- until these same conveniences can be rendered electronically. But sooner or later, they surely will be.
Of all the speculative designs for the electronic newspaper of that hardly distant day, I favor two models that are likely to coexist through much of the 21st century. Call them The Tabloid Tablet and The Ephemeral Express.
The tablet will be a portable screen the size and thickness of this magazine. It will project articles and information downloaded from a home computer or, eventually, a satellite transmitter. The "cover" of the tablet can be a familiar front page, with posterlike illustrations and summaries of articles that reflect the values and judgments of a particular journalistic team. Touch any headline or image and the screen will display a longer article or chart and related indexes to still other material on related subjects.
The tablet's cover images can be as rudimentary as a book's table of contents or as vibrant as the front of USA Today. On every page, the touch of an image will bring forward both what you asked for and some unexpected material, thus replicating the fun of leafing through a newspaper. Every page on the portable screen could also carry an advertisement, which at your touch would bring up more information about a product or service. In time, the tablet will also learn to respond to spoken commands and, when you're driving, to read its contents out loud.
Still more readable and scannable will be The Ephemeral Express, a journal printed every night by your home computer on endlessly re-usable paper in inks that disappear after 24 hours. As thick as you choose, this sheaf will contain extensive coverage of the subjects you've requested and also articles and advertisements that the editors you have chosen judge suitable for someone with your professional and personal profile.
You will be able to read this journal anywhere, like a newspaper, but you'll return all its pages to the computer for re-use in future editions. On command, the computer could retain and file any article or image you designate, and print it out on ordinary paper at any time. Obviously you could subscribe with this machine to any number of newspapers and magazines.
These are not pipe dreams. The Knight-Ridder Information Design Laboratory, headed by Roger Fidler, has been experimenting with designs for a hand-held flat-panel computer screen that he calls a "personal information appliance." And Jerome Rubin, the chairman of the News in the Future program of M.I.T.'s Media Lab, has shown a strong interest in printing on paper with "reversible ink."
So it is not technology that will kill off newspapers. On the contrary, technology will give them new functions and features and a global reach. The newspapers that prosper in the next century will be the ones that offer the best journalism, that master the subjects about which they write and acquire the talent and expertise to appraise and explain an infinite variety of events.
Oddly, that simple, self-evident proposition will be resisted in some newspaper companies because it turns the habits of decades upside down. All too many papers have prospered by investing heavily in manufacturing and marketing while shortchanging the newsroom. That is because new technologies have been cutting factory costs -- virtually eliminating printers, for example -- while traditional news gathering has become steadily more expensive.
The ultimate economies of distributing information are at hand. Volumes of news, customized for each subscriber, can be sent around the world and into the home at trivial cost. But gathering that news, assessing its significance and explaining it to readers with varying needs and interests will become ever more labor-intensive. Newspapers can trust the fermenting computer industry to perfect the technologies that will gradually replace their presses and delivery trucks. It's talent that they will need to survive in the digital age -- gifted editors, reporters and image artists who can find meaning in the approaching information glut

HEADLINE: If They Built a Memorial to the War In the Streets

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
The war memorial may be our most distinguished form of "victim art." For generations, American cities have carved out special places to honor those who have sacrificed their lives for a cause. From Augustus Saint-Gaudens's Memorial to Robert Gould Shaw to Maya Lin's Vietnam Veterans Memorial, artists have sought to wrest dignity and meaning from conflict and death.
The projects presented on these pages, many realized on site via computer graphics, commemorate people killed in a war that may never be officially declared. They are casualties of urban violence. School children, subway riders, shop clerks: people who found themselves on the losing side of a battle for the right to dwell in cities without risking their lives. 
 These seven projects were inspired, in part, by those impromptu offerings -- flowers, photographs, handwritten testimonials of love and remembrance -- that have blossomed on New York City streets in recent years like some exotic new perennial. These ephemeral offerings mourn individuals. But they also lament a set of collective losses: loss of community, of control, of respect for the dignity of life. When The Times Magazine asked Ellen F. Salpeter, executive director of Threadwaxing Space, a not-for-profit Manhattan exhibition space, and Anne R. Pasternak, executive director of Creative Time Inc., a national public arts organization based in New York, to commission the proposals, the hope was that the memorials would suggest ways to give the civic dimension of random street crime an enduring, public form.
An enduring form on a more intimate level is practiced by a Manhattan outfit called the Victim Services Agency, a kind of Red Cross for the urban wounded. The agency is misnamed, really, for the task of its social workers is to convince crime victims that they are actually heroes. It is to help them regain power over their lives.
The artists who created these projects have faced a similar challenge. Though occasioned by social calamity, their projects are offered in the optimistic belief that a city can shape its fate.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Neil Estern -- AM I MY BROTHER'S KEEPER?
"Urban violence and murder within the community take such a variety of forms that I am inclined to look for a universal symbol," says Estern, a veteran public monument sculptor whose most recent commission is a life-size sculpture of Fiorello LaGuardia. His proposal for a bronze figurative sculpture located in Central Park links contemporary tragedy to the story of Cain and Abel -- the first murder, according to biblical tradition.
Cain holds the rock; Abel tries to deflect the blow. But the two figures are intertwined, irrationally inseparable. In the 19th century, Realist painters sought to depict the heroism of everyday life. Estern's sculpture evokes the daily inhumanity of life in the urban jungle. (DIGITAL IMAGE MANIPULATION BY MARC BRYAN-BROWN)
 
Laurie Anderson -- THE BLOOD FOUNTAIN: MONUMENT TO MURDER
Red liquid gushes from a groove at the top and an opening on one side of Anderson's 50-foot-high monument. As the liquid flows down the sides into a circular pool at the base, it stains the white marble scarlet. The pool is ringed with red lights that illuminate the fountain at night. Anderson, a world-renowned performance artist and musician, adheres to the City Beautiful ideal of adorning major civic spaces with heroic sculpture. A fountain of blood is probably not what City Beautiful architects had in mind, but then they did not envision a city where children pass through metal detectors on entering school. (DIGITAL IMAGE MANIPULATION BY JAMES PORTO)
 
Glenn Ligon -- MEMORIALS
"For after all life is but a procession of shadows, and God knows why it is that we embrace them so eagerly, and see them depart with such anguish, being shadows," wrote Virginia Woolf in "Jacob's Room," her fictional elegy for a young man killed in World War I. Ligon's project makes a painful stab at pinning down fleeting lives: a series of plaques commemorating murder victims, each mounted on a wall near the site where the murder occured. A photograph, dates of birth and death and brief quotes by friends or relatives recalls the victim with yearbook poignancy.
The city is full of plaques marking the lives and homes of great achievers. Ligon's placques would mourn the death of potential. "Murder is the end of possibility," writes Ligon, a 34-year-old conceptional artist whose works have been exhibited at the Whitney. "We say: 'He was turning his life around' or 'She was just about to start her first real job.' " (PHOTOGRAPH BY FRED R. CONRAD/THE NEW YORK TIMES)
 
Gary Simmons -- JUST TO GET A REP
 
Killed for a pair of designer sneakers: that was early shorthand for the moral disintegration of inner-city youth and for the predicament of a society that is very good at creating a desire for status symbols, less resourceful when it comes to inspiring people with the hope.
Simmons's memorial, a set of gilded metal footprints modeled after sneaker soles, commemorates those who had not yet reached the age of 25 when they lost their lives. And the site -- a subway station -- reinforces the theme of transitory life. Simmons, whose work is frequently about the influence of black youth culture on the overall American society, says: "The memorial is both a cautionary reminder and perhaps a comfort to those who look down at their feet when they are afraid to make eye contact with another passenger while riding the train." (FRED R. CONRAD/THE NEW YORK TIMES)
 
Pepon Osorio -- FAMILIAS
 
We make the dead work hard. It's not enough that, in life, they had to drive a cab, punch a keyboard, wait on tables. After they're gone, we call on their memory to restore a sense of wholeness to the communities that failed them.
To memorialize taxi drivers slain on duty, Osorio, a Bronx-based artist known for his community art, proposes a series of "portraits" -- videotapes, personal memorabilia -- installed inside working cabs. The portraits would focus also on the survivors, to show how their families were affected by the loss. Osorio says that "this is not an installation about mourning; rather, it serves as a vehicle to enhance awareness and instigate meaningful change." (FRED R. CONRAD/THE NEW YORK TIMES)
 
Mel Chin -- GOUGE
Caryatids are cruel. Classical columns sculpted into human form, they stare out impassively from the facades of buildings, unmoved as they survey the cityscape of human ups and downs. Mel Chin, celebrated for work that deals with environmental and social issues, has created a caryatid in negative, a fallen architectural angel. Gouged with deliberate brutality out of two marble columns, thereby jeopardizing the stability of the building they support, Chin's ghostly figure wants to rock the scale of values that ranks real estate higher than life.
"Gouge" also protests what Chin calls the "janitorial approach to tragedy," those "evasive and sanitizing strategies that the modern world invents to keep our minds free from contemplation and reaction." Sweep it up, scrub it down, turn it into tabloid fodder. (DIGITAL IMAGE MANIPULATION BY TAM MILLER AND DALLAS MOORE)
 
Carrie Mae Weems and Jeffrey Hoone -- ODDS ARE AGAINST YOU
All it takes is a dollar and a death wish. Or, as they used to say, your money or your life. Weems and Hoone's memorial is a pop art take on fate, a look at the city as a diabolical pinball arcade. Designed for a public site in Harlem, the project would be modeled after the machine used to select each week's winning Lotto numbers. A new ball pops up every 21 minutes, corresponding to the national murder rate. The balls are color-coded to represent the ethnicity of the victims; the numerals represent their ages.
"Odds are against you" suggests how precipitously the stakes have risen in the city of economic extremes. As the middle ground drops away, the options narrow: it's instant riches or sudden death. But, hey, you never know. (DIGITAL IMAGE MANIPULATION BY TAM MILLER AND DALLAS MOORE)

HEADLINE: [APPEARANCES];
FEEL THE BURN

BYLINE: By Mary Tannen; Mary Tannen regularly contributes to the Magazine. Her new novel, "Loving Edith," will be published next month.

 BODY:
TEN MINUTES AFTER MEETING CAROLE Maggio for the very first time, I was lying supine on the bed in her hotel room while she sat in a chair by my head chanting "pump, pump, pump." She's from Los Angeles and doesn't stand on ceremony. Besides, she has a mission. She wants to persuade people to use exercise instead of surgery to help their aging faces look younger, and she has written a book to show them how -- "Facercise," due out this month from Berkley Publishing.
When I walked in the door, Maggio destroyed any resistance I might have had by taking two Polaroids, front and profile. I was not allowed to smile, duck my head or arrange my hands across my chin -- usual ploys when confronted by a camera. As a result, it was all out there: the incipient dewlaps, the crooked mouth, the crevasses some call smile lines. I was appalled. Most people are, Maggio said. (She's had women return the photos, believing they'd been given the wrong one, and Maggio has had to point out that the "stranger" in the picture was wearing the exact same blouse.) Your own aging face is a terrible thing to confront. If Maggio said she had exercises that would give me wider eyes, higher cheeks, a plumper mouth and a firmer chin, I was willing to suspend disbelief. 
 Maggio's own face is testimony to her method. All right, she wears plenty of makeup, maybe even false eyelashes, but at 49 she has skin that's virtually wrinkle-free. Her cheekbones are high and broad. When she invited me to feel, I discovered they were muscle, not bone. She created those cheeks and she can flex them at will. In conversation, Maggio uses her face the way a dancer uses her body, with economy -- distinct muscles expressing particular emotions. For 11 years she's been pumping the muscles of her own face, though she claims she can make a visible difference in others in a matter of days.
Her method is to work individually with a client for three intensive, consecutive sessions. She has done faces in London, Tokyo, Jordan and Brunei, and they love her in Hollywood. She showed me before and after photos of a 42-year-old woman who traveled that week from Tennessee and booked a room in the same hotel so that Maggio could help her overcome the effects of Bell's Palsy, which had left her face paralyzed on one side. The first picture was of an attractive blonde with one side of her mouth pulled down. In the second photo, her mouth was straight. When the woman left after three days, Maggio said, "I can't even pull away from her, she's hugging so hard."
Maggio put me through 10 exercises lying down and 3 sitting up. I used my fingertips for resistance and also to prevent effort lines. She taught me to isolate each muscle. (I tended to use all at once.) As in weight training, she had me "go for the burn," picking my head up from the bed to increase the tension. She encouraged visualization -- "imagine the sides of your face lifting."
I promised to exercise faithfully, morning and night, 11 minutes a session. Maggio wanted me to exercise in taxicabs, while driving, while talking on the phone. Sleep on your back, she said, with the pillow under your knees; put tape on your forehead so you don't frown in your sleep. I could promise only to be faithful, not fanatical.
My friends and I used to think facial exercises were a big joke. But we were younger then. Now that our faces are lengthening into something out of Grant Wood's painting "American Gothic" (the one with the pitchfork), some of us are casting about for wholesome alternatives to surgery. Exercise has worked on our bodies to keep them lifted and firm, why not our faces?
LAST FALL I RECEIVED VIDEO AND AUDIO tapes, plus a booklet of face exercises, from Laura Hart of Newton, Mass. (Face Life, 800-905-2211). I handed the packet off to G., who ever since she hit 40 has been threatening to go under the knife to restore the chin of her youth. I completely forgot about having given G. the tapes until a couple of months later when I found myself looking across the table at her during a dinner party, wondering what she was using on her face. It looked plumper, less lined. Then I remembered -- the exercises.
The difference between the methods of Maggio and Hart is the difference between Los Angeles and Boston. Maggio gives clients three days to master the 13 exercises; Hart advises building up to her 40 exercises over the course of three weeks. Hart, who is 55, demonstrates each exercise on the video, mentioning such refinements as "almond-shaped nostrils" and "rainbow-arched brows." Instead of going for the burn, she flexes, then stretches, individual muscles or muscle groups.
Adepts who've mastered the routine can dispense with the tapes and do the exercises once a day for 10 to 20 minutes. (Hart says she can do them in 7.) At the beginning of Hart's video, there are some striking befores and afters. In three months, one dieter lost her double chin, yet filled out her cheeks.
Maggio and Hart don't claim that exercise will do much for skin. They maintain that working muscles makes them thicker and shorter. Plumped-up muscles lift droopy skin and fill in for decreasing subcutaneous fat.
I began pumping away, using Maggio's exercises, hoping for miracles. In a matter of weeks, I seemed to be getting more compliments from women, more flirtatious interest from men. No longer the helpless victim of aging, I was bending time's arrow the other way.
When I called some plastic surgeons in New York to ask about facial exercises, however, they were less than encouraging. Dr. Helen Colen cautioned that exercise doesn't do much for the skin and could even deepen lines. Working the masticator muscle could give someone a square jaw. From Laura Hart's before-and-after pictures of herself, I could see that she had definitely acquired a square jaw. But it was firm. Dr. Mark Erlich said that aging was a problem of sagging skin and disappearing subcutaneous fat and he didn't see how exercising muscles could help. He did say that in surgery now, muscles are being tightened by elevating them with sutures, sort of like a pleat, to create a more natural-looking result. Exercise might bring some benefit -- a fuller, firmer face -- but he didn't see it as a great source of promise.
Now six weeks into the exercises, after careful and considered scrutiny of my face next to those Polaroids, I can't say I'm seeing miracles. But the cheeks are higher and fuller, the mouth plumper and more symmetrical, the chin more resolute. The biggest changes are inside my head. This souped-up face feels stronger and sexier. And as my friend T. once said when we spotted a certain hot Hollywood actress who was reveling in the notice she was attracting on the street, knowing she was the most beautiful woman on the block if not in the universe, even though we could plainly see a sag below her chin: "It's conviction. It's all conviction."

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Hyundai Accent;
Immigrant With an Education

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON 

 BODY:
ONE of my pet peeves, one that I have muttered about in my beard until I am gray in the face, is the taste that car makers have for alphabet soup. The auto executives even admit privately that their nomenclature -- offering J30's, MX-6's, C280's, etc. -- creates confusion within their own offices.
But regular names have their problems as well. My wife has insisted for years that we will never buy a Mitsubishi because it is too hard to say. And you hear some strange pronunciations of Toyota's Paseo. But the name that seems to confuse more Americans than any other is Hyundai. 
 Consensus notwithstanding, the cars are not "Huh-Yundaze." Nor are they "Hi, Undies." No, unmangled, Hyundai should rhyme with Sunday. But it is certainly fitting that the Korean company's new offering is called the Accent.
For 1995, the latest little kid on the block can be had as a three-door hatchback or a four-door sedan, and the cars replace the Excel, which has gone to sit on its laurels as Hyundai's biggest seller, albeit not one that distinguished itself for quality.
As one of America's least expensive automobiles, the Excel posed warranty and image problems for the manufacturer even as the car helped to establish the Koreans as a real force in the market. Now, though, Hyundai says that it has addressed quality-control issues and that it expects big things of its new small model.
The Accent, five years in the making, is indeed quite different from its predecessor. It is a bubble of a car, slick and short, with little overhang at the rear. Bumpers flow smoothly into the body for aerodynamic advantage, and they can be thumped at 5 miles an hour without damage. Side-impact protection has also been improved, and the sides of the body are made from single pieces of steel to cut vibration while reducing weight.
That saves fuel, of course, and plastic is used extensively in the battle against heft and cost. In fighting trim, including plastic hubcaps, the Accent sedan weighs a paltry 2,100 pounds or so, making it lighter than a two-seat Mazda Miata. Fuel economy is rated at 29 miles a gallon in town and 38 on the highway with the manual transmission.
The test car was of the four-door variety, done up in today's hot color and perfect for Easter. In short, it was an egg in the purplest purple I've seen. Hyundai calls it "indigo pearl," but then the marketing guys also call some of the seven other colors things like cashmere and noble white.
A week's worth of driving evoked more interest from other drivers and their passengers than I expected. But whether the stares and finger-pointing -- mostly from women -- were a result of the all-new profile or the eye-popping color is hard to say.
The least expensive Accent is the plain-jane "L" hatchback at $8,484. A fancier version has a sticker of $8,984, and the sedan costs $9,484. (All figures include a $405 delivery charge.) The test car was tagged at $11,404, with $1,920 worth of accessories in the form of a four-speaker stereo system, air-conditioning, power steering and a manual, tilting sunroof.
The car did not have anti-lock brakes, a $650 option, or the $730 electronic four-speed automatic transmission. The standard transmission is a five-speed stick.
The car rolls on all-season tires mounted on 13-inch wheels that look stingy even on a subcompact. What is surprisingly generous, though, is the car's trunk. It is easy to load, with liftover at bumper height, and the cargo capacity is a roomy 10.7 cubic feet.
For a tiny car, the surprise extends to the back seat, where legroom is adequate and headroom is quite good. The lower cushions are a bit short, but four adults can manage nicely -- if they don't have to manage for too far. The cushions are extremely hard.
Also, like so many cars today, the Accent has rear windows that go down only partway. And the knobs for all of the windows are guaranteed to make you cranky. The knobs are plastic, shallow and hard to grip, and they make heavy work of opening and closing the glass.
Up front, buckets flank a wee console from which the shifter sprouts. And like the rest of the car, the front compartment is an odd mix of Spartan and serendipity.
There are no power side-view mirrors, for example. No power locks or windows. There is no tachometer. But there are adjustable seat belt mounts, a feature usually associated with luxury cars. And the Accent has grab handles, front and rear. There are remote latches for the trunk and fuel-filler lids. It even has a dead pedal for the driver's left foot.
Dual air bags are also standard, and the designers have managed to tuck a good-sized glove box under the passenger bag.
With the hood, you have to fend for yourself, lifting and propping, but the lid is light. The engine should pose no difficulties, Hyundai says, since it is what the company calls "self-adjusting." That means there are self-adjusting valves -- three for each of the four cylinders -- and an electronic ignition to minimize maintenance. The 1.5-liter engine, mounted sideways and sending 92 horsepower to the front wheels, has the distinction of being the first ever developed "in house" by a Korean manufacturer.
The designers in Seoul also opted for four-wheel independent suspension, and they gave the car a wheelbase an inch longer than that of last year's Excel, while whacking more than 7 inches off the car's length.
All of that translates into a reasonably pleasant experience. The engine moves the car with sufficient zip, and the usual thrash and whine of such small beasties has been kept to a minimum. Given its low price and high utility, one might even rate the car as A-O.K. If one were into alphabet soup.

INSIDE TRACK: Short on price, short on length. Probably not for the long haul.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Replacing the problem-plagued Excel, Hyundai's Accent comes as a three-door hatchback, left, or sedan. (Hyundai Motor America)

LENGTH: 1214 words

HEADLINE: No Sprawl, Please. This Is Connecticut.

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
UNLESS a lot of thinking in Connecticut changes for the better, Laura Weir Clarke warns, in two decades the state could look like -- horror of horrors! -- northern New Jersey.
That means, she said, a place of sprawling malls and superstores with huge parking lots, gridlock traffic congestion, more air pollution, more noise and less open space, fewer barns, fewer trees, fewer fields, fewer traditional New England vistas. "We could see the utter degradation of the Connecticut landscape in 20 years," she said. 
 Ms. Clarke is executive director of the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation, an organization that notes its 20th anniversary this year. It has headquarters in Hamden in a building that fits its name and purpose, a 19th-century building that once was a boardinghouse for single workers at Eli Whitney's nearby gun factory.
The trust is a small organization -- some seven full- and part-time workers -- and for most of its existence has concentrated on preserving historic buildings. More recently, however, it has become involved in opposing "commercial sprawl," what it considers the overdevelopment of the state's suburbs with huge shopping malls and megastores that have contributed to the economic decline of the cities and are now, the trust feels, equally imperiling the suburbs by gobbling up farms and other open spaces and worsening the quality of life for people who live there.
The quality of life in the suburbs, Ms. Clarke said, has not been so wonderful in recent times anyway. "For most people over the past 10 or 15 years, the American dream has been a total myth," she said. "The life style they wanted isn't working."
The problem, she said, originated with the cookie-cutter makeup of suburban towns, which originated at the end of World War II when people started moving out of the cities. The towns developed into grids of neat lots and neat homes but with no real sense of neighborhood that the new suburbanites had once enjoyed in the cities: shopping in neighborhood stores, walking to church and schools, knowing people who lived nearby. Instead, they got isolation on progressively bigger and bigger lots and the need to have a car handy to get to the shopping center, sometimes miles away, or anywhere else.
"The neighborhood, the fabric that held society together, was gone," Ms. Clarke said. So also was the original supposition that living in suburbia would be inexpensive. New schools had to be built and most youngsters had to be bused to them because of the distances involved. The bigger schools cost lots of money but since land had been set aside in large chunks for commercial and industrial development, the new tax dollars that would come pouring in would solve the new economic problems. At least, that was the theory.
The gurus of the new suburbia, Ms. Clarke said, were the professional town planners and some of the more enlightened of them now admit they were wrong in many of their past actions. "Today, there are a lot of neo-traditionalist planners who once thought that mixed use would ruin the towns," she said. Now, she added, they feel the towns should have a blend of homes, business, industry and open spaces, and all in scale. The giant mall or giant single business, once regarded as desirable, is no longer held in such esteem.
In fact, some towns in the state are now reacting with what borders on paranoia to what might be described as the invasion of Wal-Mart.
The Connecticut Trust reports that at least half a dozen Connecticut towns have been targeted over the past several months by Wal-Mart, the nation's biggest retailer, with headquarters in Bentonville, Ark., which has a reputation of underselling small local merchants until they go out of business.
The local reaction to proposed new Wal-Marts has been swift, exemplified in New Milford when some 150 residents turned out to denounce a plan for a 163,000-square-foot shopping center on Route 7, a road already considered very dangerous for motorists. In Old Saybrook, even before it was known whether Wal-Mart or some other big retailer planned to build a 124,000-square-foot retail store on Route 1, local merchants were huddling together to discuss a concerted effort to oppose the store, which, it was estimated, would attract some 6,000 shoppers daily and close to 8,000 on Saturdays to a community of about 10,000 residents.
The major fact about such proposals in most towns, however, is that they are perfectly legal under local zoning laws, approved by local planning and zoning commissions and the professional planners they hired. Ms. Clarke said now that there is a general realization that megastores are not the panacea they once were believed to be, and that residents should pay more attention to what kind of zoning is currently in place.
The problem of towns losing their identities to suburban sprawl has prompted the Connecticut Trust to sponsor two conferences to be held this month.
The first, on Thursday at Guilford Community Center, will be about the character of small towns deteriorating because of pressures from developers. The second, on April 28, at Mattatuck Museum in Waterbury, will be concerned with superstores and how they are advancing the problems of traffic congestion, air pollution, destruction of older buildings and loss of small businesses.
Both conferences, scheduled from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M., are expected to attract people active in historical preservation and some worried town officials. (The fee for each session will be $35; for more information or to register, call 562-6312.)
Ultimately, however, Ms. Clarke said, the decision on what will happen to Connecticut's towns will be made by the people who live there.
"People should study the planning and zoning regulations that have fostered commercial sprawls in their towns and then not let up on planning and zoning commissions," she said. "These old formulas can be broken. I think that in addition to town plans of development, there should also be a retail plan that supports small businesses instead of one that supports commercial sprawl. Big commercial centers should not be allowed to stretch out along major roads and highways.
"And regional planning is needed. People should protest the bureaucracies in towns and their small town mentalities. And they should challenge the Federal standards on roads. We don't need more highways. We need more roads on a smaller and more scenic scale."
A major advantage to keeping suburban towns in scale, she added, is that the cities, devastated by the loss of business, would benefit by the return of huge stores that are no longer welcomed in suburbia.
Ms. Clarke is a native Texan and if anyone wants to see a state that has been successful in maintaining its character, she said, Texas is not the place to go. It is replete with commercial sprawl. "Texas has been up for sale to the highest bidder for years," she said.
The successful state, she said, is Vermont. Since 1970, by state law, Vermont has prohibited big commercial developments that do not meet strict requirements on water and air cleanliness, impact on the transportation system, and -- most importantly -- on scenic beauty. She thinks Connecticut might learn a major lesson from Vermont.

HEADLINE: GREAT OUTDOORS;
After Years of Disease, There's a Wary Joy In Bivalve as the Oyster Season Begins

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: BIVALVE

 BODY:
DR. HAROLD HASKIN, father of modern oyster studies, co-discoverer of the MSX oyster parasite and the name behind the Haskin Shellfish Research Laboratory, reached into a freshly dredged sample of Delaware Bay bluepoints and selected a fat specimen four inches across. He pulled an old iron oyster knife from his pocket, jammed the flat end into the shell's hinge and twisted to reveal a mass of healthy, yellowy-pink flesh that nearly overflowed its generous container.
"Very nice," said Dr. Haskin, a retired Rutgers zoology professor, aboard an oyster boat making a test run out of the oysterishly named port of Bivalve. One at a time, he lifted the four layers of delicately frilled gills, and slicing a membrane to show a pair of full, meaty lips. "They really are beautiful animals." 
 A healthy oyster is an especially beautiful and welcome sight around these parts nowadays. Tomorrow, for the first time since 1991 and only the third time in a decade, oyster boats are expected to depart from Bivalve and head down the Maurice River to the seed beds of the Upper Delaware Bay. As has been done for two centuries, the oystermen will transplant their catch a few miles down to a saltier part of the bay to grow fat and flavorful.
And as they have done for the last 30 years, they will pray that their stocks will not be wiped out by the parasites with the comic-book-villain names that have nearly destroyed New Jersey's oyster industry.
In its heyday during the first half of the century, New Jersey oystering was the stuff of legend. About 500 tall-masted oyster schooners brought up to 2.4 million bushels a year into Bivalve, then a bustling town with a seasonal population of 5,000 and a railway line that ran from the loading docks straight to Chicago.
But in 1957, disaster struck. A miscroscopic parasite dubbed MSX (for Multinucleated Sphere Unknown) killed 90 percent of the population within three years. MSX ran its course by 1979, but in 1985 the unrelated Dermo parasite wiped out 90 percent of the population again.
Steve Fleetwood, general manager of the Bivalve Packing Company, the town's only remaining business, remembers crying as he watched a dredge haul up load after load of dead oysters after Dermo hit.
"It was just shells and meats coming up on the belt," Mr. Fleetwood said. "They just opened up and the meat fell right out. You might as well go home."
Oystermen called off the season for the next three years, then caught a modest 700,000 pounds of oyster meat between 1990 and 1991 -- about $3 million worth -- only to see Dermo return with a vengeance. There has been no oystering since. Dermo has also devastated the once-mighty oyster beds of the Chesapeake Bay, and Virginia and Maryland authorities are reporting no substantial improvement there.
Last fall, though, the Haskin Lab, an arm of Rutgers University quartered next door to Bivalve Packing, found an increase in both the number and size of the oysters on the 14,000 acres of state seed beds. Explanations include the above-average rains in recent years, which have lowered the salinity in the bay, making it less hospitable to Dermo, as well as the possibility that the oysters that have survived the plague may be genetically resistant to Dermo. Those oysters have now had three growing years without a harvest.
"There is enough of an indication that you may be able to harvest some oysters and get an economic return on them," said Joseph Dobarro, principal fisheries biologist of the bureau of shellfisheries in the Department of Environmental Protection's division of fish, game and wildlife, who works out of the Haskin Lab.
In order to thwart Dermo, which flourishes in warm water as well as salt, the lab recommended a two-week transplanting season starting in April instead of May, a move that required new legislation.
"We want to give the oysters a chance to acclimate before seeing the plague," Mr. Dobarro said. Scientists are also asking the oystermen to begin harvesting on the planting grounds, which they lease from the state for 50 cents an acre, within a month or two, before Dermo has a chance to set in.
In a normal five-month growing season, an oyster can add up to an inch after being transplanted. Mr. Dobarro said he did not know how much growth to expect in a short season.
In the meantime, though, Dermo -- which does not physically affect humans -- has taken its toll on the oystermen as well. Dozens of them have had to sell their aging boats because they could not keep them up.
"A lot of them have been crabbing or fishing, doing whatever they can to get by," said Larry Hickman, captain of the J. Roberts Bateman, a converted schooner that Bivalve Packing purchased from a strapped oysterman.
Bivalve Packing itself has survived by boxing and shucking oysters caught in Long Island Sound by its Connecticut-based parent company, Tallmadge Brothers. Bivalve Packing has also opened two large marinas for recreational fishing boats on the Maurice, a broad, flat ribbon of dark blue that winds through the golden marshes of southern Cumberland County.
Only 25 oyster boats are going out this year, down from 59 in 1991. Mr. Fleetwood, the 42-year-old great-grandson of a Port Norris oysterman and one of five year-round residents of Bivalve, will be captaining one of them. He has spent the last week scurrying back and forth between his cramped corner office and a converted 63-foot schooner, the Peter M. Paynter, making sure the 97-year-old craft is bayworthy.
Mr. Fleetwood noted that even if the industry's gamble pays off and the transplanted oysters survive, oystermen face more problems in the marketplace. One is cheap competition, mostly from the Gulf of Mexico, which is blessed with natural oyster beds and produced 18 million pounds of oyster meat in 1993, about 52 percent of the nation's catch.
The other is a decline in demand, due partly to the wave of negative publicity that followed several fatal cases of shellfish-related hepatitis in the last decade.
"That 'death on the half shell' stuff just about killed us," Mr. Fleetwood said.
Mr. Dobarro said shellfish's bad rap is undeserved, especially in the Delaware Bay, whose marshy banks are nearly unpopulated and whose water, though murky with phytoplankton, is unpolluted enough to drink.
"Eating shellfish is safer than eating red meat," Mr. Dobarro said.
The nationwide drop in oyster consumption, from 75 million pounds in 1956 to 33 million in 1993, may also have to do with changing American tastes. The days when no Thanksgiving turkey was complete without oyster stuffing are long gone.
Fortunately for New Jersey, the Delaware Bay oyster still has a good name among shellfish partisans. Its superior shelf life and fine flavor and texture allow it to command up to three times the price of a Gulf oyster. Indeed, if the oyster Dr. Haskin opened -- zesty, firm and succulent with a delicate, sweet broth -- is any indication, 1995 could be a very good year.
But even if disaster strikes again, Mr. Fleetwood said he had no choice but to be optimistic.
"I look forward to it coming back every year," he said. "You might as well quit if you don't."

HEADLINE: WHAT, US WORRY?

 BODY:
Leave it to Cuomo to point the finger of blame for his defeat at such things as changing social attitudes, the international economy, Japanese manufacturing skills, etc. -- everywhere but where he should. He was a mediocre governor who gave us higher taxes, loss of jobs, lower bond ratings, budget failures and government inefficiency. 
 Of course, he was skilled at covering his shortcomings with intricate oratorical arguments, but the bottom line is simply this: We, the voters of New York, find him to be a far better tortilla-chip salesman than Governor.
 
JOHN P. NOONAN

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1616 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Funds Roar Back After Dismal '94

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
NOW that's more like it!
Mutual fund investors, battered by bad markets in 1994, are now breathing a sigh of relief, even of pleasure, after the funds' strong showing in the first quarter of 1995.
Bond funds rebounded, stock funds soared -- indeed, practically every kind of fund, except those that invest overseas, turned in its best performance in several years. The funds that Americans own the most -- those that hold home-grown equities -- jumped 7.4 percent, according to Morningstar Inc. Last year, those funds were modestly in the red, losses that have now been wiped out by the first quarter's spectacular gains. 
 Whether the surge is simply a snap back from last year's losses or something more sustainable remains, of course, unknown. "I keep coming back to our measures of the length of this bull market, and it makes me nervous," said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services. Last year was more of a lull than a correction, he said, adding that stock funds have been rising for almost four and a half years. Historically, fund rallies have lasted about three years.
"But if you take that away, and you buy that there will be a flat to declining dollar, there's a case to be made for another 4 to 5 percent increase" in fund returns, Mr. Lipper said. "Add that on to what has already occurred, and you would have a very good year."
As far as fixed-income funds go, some bond market seers are forecasting a quiet year, in which investors will receive interest payments but are unlikely to see any appreciation in bond prices. But some money managers fear the future may be more volatile than some investors expect -- even if interest rates fall. For example, if long-term rates decline just a little bit, homeowners will start paying off their mortgages again. This means people who invested in mortgages will get their principal back "at exactly the worst time to have to reinvest in lower rates," said Daniel Dektar, a portfolio manager for Smith Breeden Associates. That would come as another blow to fund investors, who have only recently returned to bond funds after pulling out billions of dollars last year.
The recent stock fund rally seems to have confirmed investors' confidence that, over the long haul, equities are the best place to put their money. Americans have been rewarded for their willingness last year to pour billions of dollars into stock funds while the market was dropping; in the last 12 months, diversified stock funds have returned 9.6 percent, only a tad less than their average historical return of 10 percent a year.
Of course, some investors may be disappointed because they would have fared even better if they had put their money in a fund that tracks a market index, rather than relying on a portfolio manager. For example, Vanguard's fund that mimics the S.& P. 500 index zoomed 9.7 percent in the first quarter, more than two percentage points more than the average managed stock fund.
BUT such lagging performance has been common for at least the last decade. One reason is that analyzing, buying and selling stocks costs more money than just tracking an index, and costs eat away at returns. Some mutual funds also carry a lot of cash, which helps them when the market plunges and allows them to pay off departing shareholders, but drags down performance when stocks shoot up.
Perhaps the most important factor last quarter, however, is that mutual funds tend to own a lot of smaller companies' stocks, and those stocks did not gain as much as those of giant corporations. In fact, funds that stick to smaller issues rose just 5.8 percent last quarter, while those that specialize in bigger stocks that pay dividends (the category known as growth and income) climbed 8.1 percent.
While small stocks generally outperform their larger brethren over long periods, years can go by, as they did throughout most of the 1980's, when investors prefer big companies' stocks. Some analysts suggest that the current resurgence in the shares of giant corporations indicates investors are uncertain about the economy and looking for the safety that a big, diversified company can provide.
It certainly paid to keep money at home. Funds that invest all their money in foreign stocks fell an average of 5.1 percent, dragged down by the meltdown in Latin American markets that caused even the best fund investing there to lose more than 20 percent.
Such funds, along with those that explore emerging markets, dominate the losers' list for both the last quarter and the last 12 months.
Usually, a declining dollar helps American funds that invest overseas, because a stock that is valued in yen or marks or francs is suddenly worth more dollars. But the Japanese stock market fell almost 20 percent, more than wiping out the benefit American investors got from the falling greenback.
The other big loser: gold funds, which dropped 1.5 percent.
Otherwise, an unusually wide variety of funds prospered last quarter. Funds that often move in opposite directions tended to rise in tandem.
For instance, funds that look for cheap stocks and are known as value investors rose sharply; so did those that look for companies with accelerating earnings and are known as growth investors.
In fact, they scored almost identical gains (the Vanguard fund that mirrors the growth stocks in the S. & P. index rose 9.7 percent, while the value index fund rose 9.6 percent).
But those similar gains mask some underlying turmoil, money managers say. In a continuation of last year's pattern, groups of stocks moved quickly into and out of favor, and then back again, a phenomenon known as sector rotation.
That pattern has been particularly pronounced in the area of high-technology stocks. Last year, funds that specialize in high-tech stocks were the only group to post double-digit gains.
But they paid for their success in the last two weeks of January, when they declined sharply. Then they took off again, and plunged again. They ended the quarter up 6.2 percent, but it was a wild ride.
"Yeah, we've been through about six rotations, and now people are dumping tech and buying cyclical stocks," said Garrett van Wagoner, who manages the $130 million Govett Smaller Companies, the top diversified fund of the last 12 months and one of the quarter's winners.
Nevertheless, technology stocks should continue to climb, Mr. van Wagoner contends. He points to a lot of big trends driving technology issues, including the popularity of Intel's Pentium computer chip and of CD-ROM players, the promised introduction of Microsoft's Windows 95 program, and the exploding volume of computer communications over the Internet. A stock like Intel, which zoomed by about one third last quarter, "probably needs to rest," Mr. van Wagoner conceded. "But I wouldn't want to short it or not to own it."
A similar passion for technology stocks, especially those related to semiconductors and personal computers, rules many of the first quarter's winning fund managers, including Ron Elijah, who manages the $330 million Robertson Stephens Value and Growth.
He also has a stake in an even hotter sector: health care stocks, which have benefited from a boom in takeovers. He particularly likes the shares of health maintenance organizations like United Healthcare Corporation, Healthsource Inc., Humana Inc. and Coventry Corporation ("That's my takeover candidate," he said.) The aging population and Government cost-cutting efforts make him optimistic about the future for these kinds of medical stocks, but Mr. Elijah steers clear of most biotechnology offerings. "I like companies selling a product that people are already using."
A third sizzling sector in the quarter was financial services. Funds that focus on financial stocks rocketed 10.2 percent in the quarter, with a few bank specialists, including SIFE Trust, gaining more than 13 percent.
TO some extent, bank stocks are just bouncing back from the pounding they took last year, after the Federal Reserve began raising interest rates, said Sam Marchese, president of SIFE (which, when the fund was founded in the 1960's, stood for Selected Insurance and Financial Equities).
"Banks will benefit from a stable interest rate environment, and will do better to the extent that environment includes lower rates," Mr. Marchese said. He is hopeful that rates will fall as the economy slows, but remains concerned about the effects of the falling dollar, which might eventually force the Fed to raise interest rates again.
Making sector bets was not the only road to success in the first quarter, or even the best one the top fund in the period was Venture Advisers' $50 million Retirement Growth fund, which is widely diversified. Graham Tanaka, president of Tanaka Capital and manager of the fund, said he deliberately buys both big stocks and small ones, both growth stocks and value stocks, all to reduce risk.
What ties together the fund's roughly 30 core holdings is that all the companies have something going on that will cause them to surprise Wall Street with the strength of their earnings, he said. So while his fund owned familiar stocks like Intel, it also scored big with Score Board Inc., which makes baseball cards, and Thomas Group, a small management consultant.
While he usually focuses on individual companies and their prospects, Mr. Tanaka said he does look at the stock market, though on a very long-term, once-a-generation basis. But looking at the demographics give him hope. Americans saving for retirement should start saving and investing more by the end of this decade. And that, he said, "should be a very favorable environment for stocks."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 9, 1995

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1153 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

TAXES
Numbers Don't (Always) Lie
Would it be humanly possible to come up with tax cuts universally considered fair? Of course not. Seventeen experts will get out calculators and show, with mathematical certainty, 17 different evaluations -- which just might be linked to those experts' politics. And so it was when the House passed its tax cuts last week -- triumphantly waving the Contract With America. Republicans pointed proudly to cuts that bulged to 4.4 percent for the middle class and trickled down to 2.9 percent for the wealthy, while Democrats complained that the wealthy would get an outsized share of the cuts. Yes, both were probably right. But more to the point: the Senate is likely to have different ideas, and a Clinton veto looms if it doesn't. In any case, can the nation really afford a tax cut now? In a poll, 55 percent of Americans said no.
 
ENTERTAINMENT
Mr. Bronfman Goes Hollywood
The lure of Hollywood is powerful, and laden with risk. Sony found that out, losing billions on Columbia Pictures. And Matsushita found it out in its stormy ownership of MCA. But Edgar Bronfman Jr. of Seagram wants to try his hand anyway, agreeing last week to buy 80 percent of MCA from Matsushita. The deal involves some big reshuffling of corporate money -- Seagram's getting the cash by selling most of its Du Pont stake for $8.8 billion -- as well as marking a big shift by Seagram, from drinks to entertainment. And it will undoubtedly involve some big reshuffling in Hollywood, for MCA is likely to lose Lew Wasserman, its 82-year-old chairman, and it's unlikely that Steven Spielberg would keep providing the studio with his golden touch.
 
ADVERTISING
Where There's Smoke . . .
Cigarette ads on television are illegal, of course -- have been for two decades. It couldn't be clearer. Or could it? If a sports arena advertises cigarettes to fans, and the camera lingers on those ads, does that constitute television advertising? The Justice Department says it does -- though arenas and stadiums are loaded with such ads -- and last week it settled its first lawsuit to close that loophole, as Madison Square Garden agreed to keep the offending ads out of camera range. The Garden called the deal a "formality," since it had removed tobacco signs in November. But the agreement sends a clear signal to other sports sites. Just days later came word that the Marlboro sign at Shea Stadium would be moved to be less visible to cameras.
 
TRANSPORTATION
Taxing Interstate Tickets
Taxes. Everywhere you go, taxes. And now, if where you go is across state lines by public transportation -- yes, another tax. It used to be that states didn't tax interstate tickets -- the Supreme Court apparently barred that in 1948. But last week the Court said no, that was different -- New York wanted then to tax a bus company's gross receipts. Now it says the ticket price itself is fair game as long as the trip originates in the state -- that way there's no danger of taxing a company twice for the same ticket. But the question is whether states, no matter how starved for cash, would want to take the political heat for levying what would undoubtedly be an unpopular tax. For passengers, not transportation companies, would be hit hardest.
 
COMMUNICATIONS
Whatever You Say, Mr. McCaw
Craig McCaw had a lot of money burning a hole in his pocket after selling his company to AT&T, and he knows a lot about wireless communications. Nextel, once a high flier in that very field, was badly in need of an investor. So last week, in a marriage that both surely hope was made in technology heaven, Mr. McCaw said he and his family would invest $300 million now -- and perhaps $1.1 billion over six years -- in the struggling company. The deal: Nextel would scrap its effort to build a nationwide cellular network -- "been there," said Mr. McCaw, "done that" -- and focus on private dispatch networks, like those for truck or taxi fleets. Nextel's stock sold for a quarter of what it did in the fall before jumping on this news; for $1 billion, it would probably have gone into the diaper business.
 
BANKING
Adding Up Chase's Parts
In banking, bigger is better, right? Consumer banking, corporate business, global lending -- adding up to a strong, diverse business. That's what giants like Chase Manhattan believe, and Chase is doing fine at it -- its profits growing steadily. But some investors like things simple and easy to size up. If something looks muddled, they want to break it into bite-size pieces -- parts, they bet, worth more than the whole. That's clearly what's happening at Chase. Last week a money manager named Michael Price -- known for pushing to wring all the value he can out of companies -- said he'd bought 6.1 percent of Chase, and the stock shot up 10 percent.
 
THE ECONOMY
Too Hard a Landing?
What gives? The markets like signs that the economy's slowing to a nice even pace, and most of the week the Dow industrials bumped to new highs for that very reason. But when word came Friday that the unemployment rate had reversed course and risen to 5.5 percent -- a sure sign of slowing -- stocks retreated, with the Dow ending up off 12 after being off 36 earlier. Could things be slowing too much? Manufacturing lost a lot of jobs, and total payroll jobs rose just 203,000. "We can kiss the soft landing goodbye," said one economist. But the Administration was more upbeat -- it needs that soft landing badly -- as Labor Secretary Reich saw the economy in a steady "glide pattern."
 
AIR POLLUTION
Smog? Cars Have It for Dinner
Forget "zero emission" vehicles, the lab-coat name for electric cars. The latest answer to foul air is a "negative emission" car. No, there's no Mobius strip of a tailpipe, twisted in on itself and spewing exhaust into some Star Trek-style parallel universe. Well, not exactly. Last week Engelhard, which developed catalytic converters in the 70's, came up with a way for cars to, essentially, devour any smog in their path. A new catalyst would break down existing smog, or ozone, into breathable oxygen -- but would do nothing for the car's own exhaust. Sound far-fetched? The stock market didn't think so, as Engelhard stock jumped 30 percent in a day, and futures prices for platinum -- a key part of the process -- hit a four-year high. An unanswered question: after it eats all Los Angeles smog, will it eat Los Angeles too?
 
GEOGRAPHY
Take a Left at the Berlin Wall
Be realistic. With national boundaries sometimes seeming to shift by the day, with countries born and countries dying, no one could possibly keep up. You could easily forget that a faraway place called the Soviet Union had, well, gone through some changes. So Dow Jones should certainly not be faulted for featuring, on its just-released '94 annual report, a globe with these words: Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Peso or Dollar Wages? In Mexico, It Matters

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
JORGE ORTEGA and Kimberly Rustad have a lot in common. They are both young Americans. They both live here. And they both love their jobs. But one is paid in dollars and one in pesos, and because of the Mexican currency crisis, that has made a world of difference.
Mr. Ortega is paid in dollars, and for him life is coming up roses -- much like the roses that now cost the equivalent of just 75 cents a dozen on Reforma, the elegant boulevard that runs through the heart of Mexico City. With the peso falling by half against the American currency since the devaluation last year -- to about six to the dollar from three -- the flowers would have cost nearly twice that four months ago. 
 "It's like somebody's given you two to three months of bonuses at the beginning of the year," said Mr. Ortega, the 31-year-old director general of the Burson-Marsteller public relations office here.
But Miss Rustad, a 25-year-old mathematics teacher at the American School here, gets paid in pesos. She now earns the equivalent of what a hamburger flipper gets, in dollars, at a McDonald's in the United States. And when her students asked her to use her salary in a currency conversion problem, she refused. It is too depressing to see the truth spelled out on a blackboard, she said.
Dealing with a flip-flopping local currency is an issue not just for the 520,000 American expatriates in Mexico. More than 2.58 million Americans live and work outside the United States, often at a cost of three to four times that of domestic employees.
Giles C. Archibald, managing director of William M. Mercer, an international consulting firm, said companies usually pay their expatriate employees in dollars when a foreign operation started, and then switch to the local currency after the business was under way. Typically, senior executives continue to be paid in dollars.
Generally, employers try to assure that their expatriates enjoy the same standard of living abroad as they would at home, and use devices like housing subsidies, education allowances and cost-of-living adjustments to narrow whatever gaps may exist. But whatever the currency of the paychecks, a shift in exchange rates can alter everyone's plans and expectations. The peso crisis is the most telling recent example.
For their part, Mr. Ortega and his wife, Tracy, have taken modest advantage of the devaluation. A few weeks ago, when the exchange rate was about five pesos to the dollar, they bought a compact-disk player for about $80. In December the equipment would have cost about $140. And while they usually shop for their two-year-old daughter, Anna, on trips to Miami, where they used to live, Mrs. Ortega recently bought her some leather Keds sneakers at a Mexico City mall for $19, instead of the pre-devaluation price of $40.
For Mr. Ortega, the arithmetic of the exchange rate can be irresistible. "If I take a client to a restaurant and the bill comes to 240 pesos, I have a tendency to divide by 6 and say, '$40. Not bad,' " he said. "But I can't do that. I have to remember that I have a peso-based company. I bill my customers in pesos. At the end of the year I'll have to convert to dollars. But for now it's in pesos, and 240 pesos is 240 pesos."
And Mr. Ortega's boss at the home office in Miami should not assume that his subordinate is living high on the hog. Many big-ticket items like flights back to the United States are still priced in dollars, as is rent, often the single biggest monthly expense. Many Mexican landlords have lived through and learned from several devaluations.
Moreover, inflation is expected to top 50 percent for the year. On April 1 Mexican sales taxes were raised to 15 percent from 10 percent.
And because many American expatriates intend to return to the United States, many of their loans and investments are based in dollars. For example, Mr. Ortega and his wife are paying off dollar-based student loans.
But Miss Rustad is worse off. She has watched the buying power of her peso-based salary shrink so much that she had to ask her family to make the payments on the 1991 Chevrolet Cavalier she bought when she graduated from Marquette University that year.
"I think of spending my pesos as soon as I get them, because they're not worth anything now and they could be worth even less tomorrow," she said. "It's not even worth changing them to dollars anymore."
Miss Rustad has already told the school that June 15 will be her last day there and that she plans to pack the belongings she has not sold into her Cavalier and drive home to Minnesota.
"I love what I'm doing here, I love the students and I love the school," she said. "But it gets to the point where I say that I need to make money, too."
She is not alone in her plans to leave; six of her fellow teachers and three of her four roommates are heading back to their homes in the United States as well.
For the first time in several years, more Americans are leaving Mexico than arriving. The classified advertising columns in the local English-language newspaper, The News, are filled with ads for household furnishings that departing Americans are desperate to unload.
It's not just the Americans paid in pesos who are leaving. Many with dollar-based paychecks are being called back home, because their employers think it will be cheaper to hire local workers who can be paid in pesos, according to Deborah L. Riner, chief economist for the American Chamber of Commerce in Mexico.
Mr. Ortega, who says he is careful with money, said he had resisted the temptation to look at the extended buying power of the dollar as anything but temporary. "I say to myself, 'Don't get caught up in this,' " he said. "Besides, I'm surrounded by people who get paid in pesos. Hearing their stories rubs off and I end up being more cautious."
For Miss Rustad, the time for caution has passed. When she took her job teaching eighth-grade math at the American School in September 1993, she knew she would not make a lot of money. But at about $2,000 a month, the salary wasn't bad. That sum included extra money she earned by tutoring students at home and coaching a soccer team at the school.
Her life in Mexico has changed since she read during her Christmas vacation in Minnesota that something had gone wrong in Mexico. "I thought it was one of those things that was just going to pass," she said. "But it got worse."
BY the time she returned from Christmas vacation, she knew she had already lost much of her purchasing power.
And the peso, instead of improving, has continued to deteriorate. Suddenly, her monthly income of 6,000 pesos was worth only $1,000, and dropping. She had to cancel a ski trip to Utah in February because she could not afford the flight. She held off seeing a doctor for her sinus condition because it cost too much.
Her spirits dropped as low as the peso. The final straw came when the school said it would increase salaries by 6 percent, which seemed absurd to Miss Rustad after a devaluation of almost 50 percent, not to mention raging inflation that has sent up some costs, like electricity, by 20 percent in the last month.
Miss Rustad said she hoped to get a graduate degree in mathematics after she returns to Minnesota. But the one thing she knows is that some change is necessary.
"I make less than I would at McDonald's -- I figured it out," she said. "My mother is paying my debts and I'm 25 years old. I think it's time I pay my own debts. My mom says, 'Don't worry,' but even in these times that can only go so far."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Cutting Taxes and Causing Heartburn

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS if more than a year of rising interest rates hasn't made investing enough of a challenge, the tax bill passed by the House last week would add a brand new dimension to financial decision-making.
A little-noted facet of the tax-cutting bill, which Republicans have called the crown jewel of their Contract With America, indexes capital assets for inflation so you no longer pay taxes on phantom profits, those that just maintained -- and did not enhance -- your buying power. 
 Assuming the measure survives the Senate, where it has drawn considerable skepticism, investors could fairly easily obtain the benefits of an adjustment for future inflation. But the tactical question of if and when to do so looks almost fiendishly complex.
For stocks and other assets acquired after 1994 and held for a minimum of three years, there is no problem -- you would simply raise your cost, or tax basis, by the amount of inflation that occurred since 1995. The higher the cost, the less your taxable profit on the sale. The gauge to be used is the price deflator issued by the Government in its quarterly calculation of gross domestic product.
Take, for example, someone who bought $10,000 of stocks early in 1995 and sold them three years later for $14,000. Under present law, the investor would probably have to pay taxes at the 28 percent capital gains rate on the $4,000 profit -- a tax bite of $1,120.
But under the Republican plan, the gain -- and the tax -- would be less if prices rose. If inflation averaged 4 percent over the three-year period, the original $10,000 purchase price would be adjusted upward for tax purposes by 4 percent a year, to $11,249. So the profit would be $2,751 instead of $4,000, and the tax bill would be $770 instead of $1,120.
Further, excluding from taxes 50 percent of the capital gain, which the bill also does, would push the $770 liability down to $545.
For people with such mid-length investments, indexing seems a fairly unambiguous blessing. But for those with stocks, bonds or other long-held assets, the choice is harder.
The measure says assets bought before 1995 can be indexed in the future, but only if the investor immediately pays taxes as if the assets were sold on Jan. 1, 1995. For people with successful long-term investments, this could amount to a huge tax bite now in exchange for reduced taxes later.
Since you can always sell stock and immediately buy it back -- so long as you have a profit rather than a loss -- the law would provide the same effect automatically and without paying commissions or other transaction costs.
The home you live in also qualifies for indexing, though you wouldn't need to pay any tax until you really sold it. Even under current law, however, relatively few homes generate capital gains liability.
"Very few people would get any benefit from indexing their houses," said Mark S. Mullet, a tax aide to Senator William V. Roth Jr., a Republican from Delaware.
Collectibles can be indexed, too, but only if the taxpayer picks this option instead of paying a tax rate of less than 28 percent; you can't have both.
Tax specialists and others who have begun to fathom the effect on individual investors -- assets of the typical small business would also be covered -- say that indexing is likely to be at least mildly attractive to most investors with pre-1995 assets, though certainly not all.
"If they can afford to pay the tax and get on an indexing system, that would usually be a good thing to do," said C. Clinton Stretch, director of tax legislative affairs for Deloitte & Touche, referring to investors already owning assets with paper profits. "But it's not free," he added. "You have to come up with the cash" to pay Uncle Sam.
But he and others noted that there are many factors to be considered and that individual situations are quite different. Prominent among the considerations are these:
*Age Indexing would typically be of little benefit to an elderly person who intended to leave, say, a stock portfolio to his children. The cost basis of their inheritance would step up to the market value at the time of death, wiping out any capital gains tax liability.
*Activity People who trade stocks or other assets often would have a relatively current basis. So indexing would tend to have limited appeal, unless inflation were to be very high in a given three-year period.
*Profits Since the benefit increases with the part of a gain that is attributed to inflation, the greatest benefit is to those who expect to hold an asset for a long time and who also expect high inflation.
In other words, you need to evaluate a combination of factors, including how long you expect to hold an asset, how much inflation you anticipate in coming years and what return you could make on the money you might decide to send to Washington now.
Indeed, their interaction suggests that you would need to analyze your assets on a stock-by-stock and property-by-property basis.
THE availability of indexing is also likely to help govern the composition of portfolios, said Dennis E. Ross, a tax partner at the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell and a former senior Treasury Department tax official. "You might want to pick stocks that are positively impacted by inflation," such as natural-resource companies, he said. In an inflationary period, you would probably at least stay even since your nominal, or inflation-related, profit would not be taxed.
And corporate managers, according to Bruce Beardslee, a managing director of Smith Barney Inc., might be induced by indexing to put more emphasis on raising stock prices rather than rewarding shareholders with higher, unindexed dividends.
While indexing capital gains has broad conceptual appeal, it has significant opposition on economic and practical grounds as well as political vulnerability to charges that it mainly helps the well-to-do.
Theoreticians contend that assets like real estate should not be indexed without also adjusting the tax-deductible mortgages that finance them. This produces what Mr. Ross called "a kind of imbalance" in the economic system. The American Bar Association has been a particularly strong opponent of one-sided indexing, which it believes will lead to revived tax-sheltering shenanigans.
But the biggest threat to adoption seems to be administrative complexity, which would require intense record-keeping and probably "an accounting system that does not exist," Mr. Stretch of Deloitte & Touche said.
Imagine, for example, trying to calculate inflation adjustments for dividends reinvested over a 20-year period or for monthly purchases of mutual-fund shares. The argument is said to have made a strong impression on Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who heads the Senate Finance Committee.
Still, Britain is said to have largely remedied the problems experienced by its indexing system created under Margaret Thatcher. And the Investment Company Institute, the mutual fund industry's chief trade association, expresses less concern than it had previously.
Most funds now provide holders with data on their average per-share cost, an institute spokesman said, adding, "I assume the computer wizards can work it out."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COLLEGE POINT;
Megastore Wares Include Worries As Well as Jobs

BYLINE: By THOMAS H. MATTHEWS 

 BODY:
Megastores are coming to the College Point Corporate Park in Queens, the Economic Development Corporation announced last week. Unsurprisingly, residents are worried about noise and traffic and, above all, the possibility that small merchants may not survive.
But development corporation officials say that if the site is fully developed, it will bring 1,000 new jobs and take in $200 million worth of business a year that would otherwise be lost to suburban stores. 
 Both Toys 'R' Us and Kids 'R' Us are scheduled to open in fall 1997 and will be next to a planned 12-theater movie house operated by National Amusement Company on land owned by the city but to be sold to Triangle Equities, a New York City private developer. The Triangle project, on a 9.4-acre piece of land at the Whitestone Expressway service road, Ulmer Street and Linden Place, will cost $26.5 million, the corporation said.
In all, 550,000 square feet are to be developed at the park. Besides the city-owned land, there are two privately owned parcels: 25 acres owned by the Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company of New York and 7 acres belonging to Triangle. Pepsi has earmarked its land, bought in 1985 as a site for a bottling plant, for 330,000 square feet of retail space in a single-story building, said Clay Lifflander, president of the development agency. Triangle is looking for retailers for its 100,000-square-foot space. In January, PriceCostco, a retail food warehouse, appeared before Community Board 7 to discuss tentative plans put a Costco store in the park. Company officials did not respond to requests for information.
Community leaders fear superstores will irreparably harm College Point, a community of 25,000 people on the East River. So ingrained is the tradition of patronizing small stores that residents, many of whom are employed in local factories, began mobilizing last summer as soon as the agency revealed plans to bring megastores to the park.
Built in the early 60's, the corporate park has since included light industries and warehouses. But for several years, it has been used for corporate office space.
"When we first developed that area, it was as an industrial park, but now it's become attractive to retailers and so they're bringing them in," said Eugene Kelty, chairman of Community Board 7. "We don't want to hurt the little town."
But officials say College Point will reap benefits. "This will create 1,000 permanent jobs and competition, and we view competition as good," Mr. Lifflander said.
New York City loses $3 billion every year because shoppers seek out lower prices at suburban stores, Mr. Lifflander said. "The majority of people want this."
But Mr. Kelty attacked the agency's figures as vastly inflated. .
"One thousand jobs, that's a bogus statement," he said. "Where are those jobs coming from?" He speculated that the new stores might transfer workers from other branches.
The College Point Board of Trade, an organization that represents 175 local businesses, supports the plans for a Toys 'R' Us, Kids 'R' Us and a multiplex, saying they will fulfill genuine needs in the area. But a giant discount store like Costco is different, Fred Mazzarello, board of trade president, said.
"A price club has 14 or 15 departments, each equivalent to a store," Mr. Mazzarello said. "They have hundreds of free parking spaces and on top of all that, they're selling at a huge discount."
"A store like that would wipe out the stores in our area." THOMAS H. MATTHEWS
