HEADLINE: Financial Fear And Retirement

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Another Day Older And Running Out Of Time" (March 26) accurately assesses today's retirement savings problem. 
 While I certainly concur with the article's assessment, one of the most important causes of this situation was not clearly stated. Congress has routinely tinkered with pension rules to limit tax expenditures and to raise revenue.
Since enacting the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (Erisa) of 1974, Congress has passed an average of one new law each year that has significantly affected pension plans. Each measure was primarily concerned with limiting Federal revenue losses instead of improving pension policy.
As a result, the percentage of American workers covered by employer-sponsored pension plans has remained virtually constant since 1982.
Qualified pension plans are integral to the economy of the United States. They provide an efficient way for employers and workers to save; they pay retirement benefits to tens of millions of Americans; they provide an important source of capital for investment in our economy and they equitably insure that middle-income people receive the same incentives as corporate executives receive.
To encourage the creation of a greater number of these plans and an expanded coverage of American workers, we must reduce excessive Government regulations, simplify existing rules and preserve the current tax incentives.
 
RAY S. CRABTREE
Des Moines, March 30
 
The writer is the senior vice president for the pension department at the Principal Financial Group.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Seeking the High-Profit Staples of Tomorrow

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
RON BARON began the Baron Asset Fund in the summer of 1987, not long before the crash in October. In a way, that timing proved fortuitous. Most of the fund's cash had not been invested before prices plunged, leaving him with plenty of cash to search for bargains. He generally looks for stocks with niches or demographic factors that will cause them to soar, and has compiled a record far better than most small company stock funds -- up more than 10 percent in the first quarter of this year and a compound annual return of 14 percent over the last five years.
In the 12 months ended March 31, the fund was up 21 percent, a performance all the more impressive because the fund largely stays out of technology stocks, the stars of the last year. That performance has started to bring in the cash. The fund grew from $87 million at the end of 1994 to $161 million at the end of the quarter.
 FLOYD NORRIS
Q. What's cheap these days? 
 A. Heilig-Meyers, for example. It's come down from $37 a year-and-a-half ago to $21. And that is without any interruption in the company's growth process.
Q. Why did it come down?
A. It came down because people are anticipating that a recession will have an impact on their growth. The reason we're excited about it is because they sell furniture in small towns. They're not selling $10,000 couches in New York, they're selling $400 couches in the South, the Southeast and the Midwest.
People need to buy furniture. It's not a luxury; it's a necessity. They're very good at managing credit. The margins on stores that are four years old are 15 percent and on one-year-old stores are 7 percent.
We're able to make longer-term investments at very attractive prices because we don't have to have every stock performing all the time. And when stocks come down, and we like their businesses, we're able to buy them.
Q. Technology was the big star last year and most funds that did reasonably well were loaded up on it. You weren't.
A. We've never invested in technology because it changes so fast. We've elected not to invest in companies whose businesses can be here today and gone tomorrow, but we do have a technology component in our portfolio in that we invest in DeVry, which provides technology-based education. You know that the Government says 80 percent of the jobs by the year 2000 will require an education beyond high school. DeVry is the beneficiary there.
We also invest in Robert Half International, which provides programmers to companies that are changing the way they configure their office. It's a provider of temporary accountants and temporary lawyers and temporary programmers and highly skilled office assistants and administrators who know how to use computers. All the regulations that come from the Government, for family leave and Americans with Disabilities Act and health care coverage and wrongful-termination litigation, makes permanent workers expensive and therefore companies want to use temporaries whenever they can. Robert Half has the most profitable temporary business of the publicly traded companies.
Q. You also bought a lot of Charles Schwab this year.
A. We're trying to find talented managements which operate fast-growing businesses, highly profitable businesses in sunrise industries, as opposed to sunset industries. We're investing in communications and financial services and media and entertainment, gaming and temporary help and health care and where people are going to create the jobs of the future.
When we talk about Schwab, it gets to our schematic investing, and one of the things that we're trying to do is take advantage of the changes that we see. We're not predicting the stock market; we're not predicting the economy. What we are focusing on is what's happening within the economy. And what is evident is that the demographics are changing tremendously. One factor is the aging population and another is a tremendous surge of baby boomers. Charles Schwab is going to benefit from the huge population of baby boomers who haven't saved enough to retire.
Q. There are a lot of brokers out there. Why Schwab?
A. People have discovered that the only way they can have enough money to retire is by investing in equities, and they do that through mutual funds. Charles Schwab is a tremendous innovator in the distribution of mutual funds.
We think that the customers' assets at Schwab, now about $130 billion, will reach $500 billion by the year 2000.
Q. How much of your fund's sales come through Schwab?
A. A good portion of it right now, which is one of the reasons why we've been able to buy Schwab stock and feel comfortable. When some people look at Schwab, they say, "Gee, why should Charles Schwab sell at twenty times earnings when everyone else in the brokerage business sells at ten times earnings?"
Q. They do indeed say that. What's your answer?
A. They're not a broker. It's a different firm. Charles Schwab doesn't have any brokers. They have telephone operators. They're spending $80 million to $100 million on this technology enabling them to answer all these telephones and provide all these services.
Q. What are you paying Schwab?
A. We pay 35 hundredths of a percentage point, based on the assets of our fund held in Schwab accounts.
Q. That's coming out of a 12B-1 marketing fee?
A. Yes, that and part of it from my management fee.
But they have made me and people like Mario Gabelli and Dick Strong competitive. They've made everyone who's a little guy competitive with big guys. Financial planners can deal with Schwab just like they can deal with Fidelity or Vanguard.
Peter Lynch said that anyone who worked in a mall in the 1960's and saw what Gap was doing and didn't buy it deserved not to make money. Here I am in a mutual fund business and I see that my mutual fund wasn't growing in sales before it got into Schwab and now it's growing tremendously. So here we are with an inside view. How can I not buy the stock?
Q.Let's move on. You seem to like nursing homes.
A. We're very excited about that business. There have been some tremendous changes in the industry. Six or seven years ago there was a nursing shortage; now nurses are getting fired so there isn't a nurse shortage, and the cost of nurses represents about 50 percent of revenues.
Second, you're taking care of sicker patients in nursing homes than you have previously. Therefore you're getting more revenues per bed and therefore more profits per bed.
Q. Which nursing homes do you like the best?
A. Our largest holding is Manor Care, which we regard as the Cadillac in that industry. We think that its business values are somewhere around $50 a share and the stock's trading around $31.
If we get lucky in Manor Care and they separate the hotel business from the nursing home, then the stock will be $40 this year. Now the other big nursing home is Summit Care, which has really talented management.
Q. Medicare is obviously a big business for nursing homes, but Medicare cutbacks have been talked about in Washington and every state house in the land. That doesn't sound like good news to me.
A. This is one of the great stories. You used to have to care for patients at a hospital at $1,000 a day. Now nursing homes can take a $50,000 bed and spend $15,000 on that bed -- putting in oxygen, rehab facilities -- and care for that patient for $300 a day.
When the Medicare cutbacks come, these guys are going to be the beneficiaries because they are going to take care of them in a nursing home. Let the cutbacks come.
Another beneficiary will be Olsten Corporation, which provides care at home. So as Medicare comes around, the nursing homes are going to benefit and the home health care company is going to benefit.
Q. The stock has slipped.
A. The stock came down pretty sharply from $40 to $31, so we have doubled our position at Olsten as well. And I guess in the past couple of weeks the stock has popped from $31 to $36 again.
What's happening at Olsten is that they have two businesses. One of them is home care, and the other is staffing. The staffing business is doing great. They're running ahead well into double digits, and they're signing a lot of contracts with big corporations to provide temporary help.
Temporary help is a very exciting industry, a $23 billion industry growing 13 percent a year. Olsten is one of the leading providers of general staffing personnel. In addition to that, half their business is home care.
